DOC.HEAD: Researchers Clone Monkey AIDS Virus
DOC.TEXT: Researchers have taken a step they think could help them better understand AIDS, using a cloned virus to infect monkeys with an AIDS-like disease. This is the first time a laboratory-developed virus has been used to cause an AIDS-type infection, the researchers reported in a paper published today in the journal Science. ``The importance of this is that we can now ... make very precise changes (in the virus) and try and predict what will happen,'' explained Harry Kestler of Harvard University's New England Regional Primate Research Center. Because all copies of a cloned virus are identical, scientists can compare the results of an infection with the original virus with infections from a virus in which they have made specific changes. And, since the virus used in this experiment is a close relative of the one that causes AIDS in people, the affect on the monkeys may help doctors better understand the human disease, the researchers say. Teams at Harvard and the University of California at Davis used a cloned simian immunodeficiency virus, the closest known relative of the human AIDS virus, to infect the monkeys. While the mixture of viruses found in infected animals has been used to induce the disease in the past, this is the first time it has been done with a cloned version, Kestler explained. In cloning a virus scientists make an exact copy of it. This allows them to understand the exact characteristics of the virus they are working with and to make specific changes in the virus for experiments, Kestler said. Many of the monkeys infected with the cloned virus developed a fast-acting form of AIDS, according to the report. The fast-acting disease occurs in monkeys that fail to develop an antibody response to the infection, and these die in about six months, Kestler explained. Other monkeys do develop an antibody response and seem to live longer, he said. The researchers assume that those animals will eventually develop a more lingering form of AIDS, Kestler said, but they must wait to see what happens. ``This is sort of a progress report on an ongoing study that is going to take a couple of years to complete,'' he observed. The monkeys that become ill develop ``all the hallmarks'' of AIDS, said Kestler, such as weight loss and a variety of opportunistic infections when their immune system weakens. AIDS, or acquired immune deficiency syndrome, is a contagious disease that attacks the body's immune system, rendering it incapable of resisting other diseases and infections. The incurable condition is believed to be caused by an unusual virus, now called human immunodeficiency virus or HIV, which is spread through contact with blood or semen from infected people. The chief victims of AIDS have been homosexual men and intravenous drug abusers. Some people have become infected through blood transfusions, although blood supplies are more closely screened now. Health officials estimate that heterosexual contact is responsible for 4 percent of cases and that between 1 million and 1.5 million Americans have been exposed to the virus. As of April 30, 1990, AIDS had been diagnosed in 132,510 Americans, of whom 61 percent, or 80,799, have died since June 1, 1981, according to the federal Centers for Disease Control. No one is known to have recovered from AIDS. The World Health Organization said that as of April 30, 1990, there have been 254,078 cases reported from 151 countries. The Global Programme on AIDS, an agency of the World Health Organization, estimates that the actual number of AIDS cases in the world is more than 500,000 and that there will be at least 1 million new cases worldwide by 1993.

DOC.HEAD: Comments from Summit Participants
With PM-Summit Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are quotations from the summit meeting between President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev.
DOC.HEAD: Bush:
DOC.TEXT: ``I'd just say at the end of a very interesting day that the talks have gone reasonably well.'' ``Over the next four days, we're not going to solve all the world's problems. ... But we can and will take significant steps toward a new relationship.'' ``The agreements we've reached cannot cause us to lose sight of some of the differences that remain. Lithuania is one such issue.'' ``... the success of this summit depends not on the agreements we will sign but on our efforts to lay the groundwork for overcoming decades of division and discord, to build a world of peace in freedom.'' ``... whatever deep differences divided us in the past, the United States and the American people approach every issue with a sincere belief that our two nations can find common ground. Indeed, because of our unique positions in the world _ we must find common ground.''

Gorbachev: ``It is not here that the German question will be resolved.'' ``I cannot say yet how we are going to conclude this meeting, what the results will be. That would be premature.'' But based on the talks Thursday, he said it was ``possible to expect major results from this meeting.'' ``The walls, which for years separated the peoples, are collapsing.'' ``The trenches of the Cold War are disappearing. The fog of prejudice, mistrust and animosity is vanishing. ... This generation of people on Earth may witness the advent of an irreversible period of peace in the history of civilization.'' ``Americans know pretty well what a market is and about the whole intricacies of a market, but we are innocent, so to say. ... As far as a market is concerned, we have to start from scratch.''

White House Spokesman Marlin Fitzwater: ``The meeting was friendly, with both presidents being upbeat and at times animated in their discussion of their countries' futures.'' (On Germany:) ``I don't expect a conclusion to that issue at this summit.''
Soviet spokesman Arkady Maslennikov: ``A very good beginning.''
DOC.HEAD: National Security Adviser Brent Scowcroft:
DOC.TEXT: ``NATO was an organization that for the Russians was designed to attack the Soviet Union. That's wrong, but that's their image of us.''
Anna Perez, spokeswoman for Barbara Bush: ``She (Mrs. Bush) said that Mrs. Gorbachev and Millie bonded. ... Millie sat on Mrs. Gorbachev's foot and she followed her ... all over the house.''

DOC.HEAD: Nikkei Average Closes Lower
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 32,891.12, down 239.68 or 0.72 percent, on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Grandson of Theodore Roosevelt Dies
DOC.TEXT: Archibald Roosevelt Jr., a grandson of President Theodore Roosevelt and a retired CIA officer, died Thursday of congestive heart failure at his home. He was 72. Roosevelt served as CIA station chief in Istanbul, Madrid and London before retiring from the agency in 1974. He then became vice president of the Chase Manhattan Bank, based in Washington. He was active in diplomatic circles during the Reagan administration, when his wife, Selwa Showker Roosevelt, was chief of protocol at the State Department. Roosevelt was born to high social position in Boston, graduating from Harvard College in 1940 in the same class as President Kennedy. He won a Rhodes Scholarship to Oxford University but he was unable to take it because of World War II. An Army intelligence officer in the war, he joined the Central Intelligence Group, the immediate predecessor of the CIA, in 1947 and served for 27 years, always under diplomatic cover. Some have written that he had a hand in various coups of the early 1950s, notably the overthrows of King Farouk in Egypt and nationalist Iranian Prime Minister Mohammed Mossadegh. But Roosevelt was the soul of discretion in his 1988 memoirs, ``For Lust of Knowing: Memoirs of an Intelligence Officer.'' In it, he did not even list his duty stations _ but he did tip off an interviewer to check his Who's Who entry to figure them out. Roosevelt confessed a fascination with the Middle East and languages, learning about 20, including Uzbek. The intelligence officer ``must not only know whose side he is on, but have a deep conviction that he is on the right side. He should not imitate the cynical protagonists of John LeCarre's novels, essentially craftsmen who find their side no less amoral than the other,'' Roosevelt once wrote. Besides his wife, he is survived by a son by a first marriage that ended in divorce, and two grandchildren.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Court Issues Last-Minute Stay in Nevada Execution
DOC.TEXT: A federal appeals court issued a stay late Thursday just 90 minutes before the scheduled execution of a condemned killer who had wanted no further appeals. Thomas Baal, 26, had been scheduled to be put to death by lethal injection at 12:05 a.m. PDT Friday for stabbing a bus driver to death in Las Vegas. The 9th Circuit Court of Appeals panel ruled 2-1 that the execution should be stayed until noon Saturday to get more information from U.S. District Judge Howard McKibben, who earlier ruled against a stay. Justice Alex Kozinski dissented. Baal's parents had petitioned McKibben for the stay, citing their son's long-term mental problems and possible brain damage. As his parents listened, Baal told the court, ``I just want to go die and be free. That's all.'' Justice Harry Pregerson questioned whether Baal's competency hearing had properly focused on whether he could make a rational decision to give up his appeal rights if he was suffering from a brain disorder, disease or defect. ``We're doing everything here on the run,'' said Pregerson. Baal had told McKibben he didn't want anybody to appeal on his behalf, including his parents. Edwin and Doris Baal traveled from Mesa, Colo., to see their son before his execution. Asked if he had any other requests, Baal said, ``Bring me a hooker.'' The judge said he couldn't grant that, and asked if he had any others. Baal replied, ``Just my last meal and get the ball rolling, man.'' McKibben ruled that on the basis of Baal's comments it's clear ``he does not want to stop the execution. The court finds that he is competent to make that decision.'' The hearing was held to review an 11th-hour petition filed by Assistant U.S. Defender Pat Flanagan on behalf of Baal's parents. Flanagan sought to intervene on what's known as a ``next friend'' basis, a tactic often rejected by courts. But the U.S. Supreme Court, in an April 24 decision rejecting an Arkansas death row inmate's ``next friend'' status for another condemned convict in that state, spelled out conditions that could allow such petitions. They include mental incapacity or other disability that prevents a condemned person from pursuing an appeal. Baal, a former mental patient, smashed a television set in his cell Tuesday. He was described as quiet Thursday. Prison spokesman Glen Wharton said Baal was spending much of his time making phone calls. Baal was sentenced to die for stabbing bus driver Frances Maves to death in 1988 as she resisted his robbery attempt. His execution would be Nevada's fifth and the 129th nationally since the 1976 U.S. Supreme Court ruling allowing states to resume use of the death penalty. Nevada's last executions were in June 1989. In the same week, confessed murderers Sean Flanagan and William ``Bud'' Thompson were given lethal injections after both said they wanted no further appeals.

DOC.HEAD: Liberia at a Glance
With PM-Liberia, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are some facts and figures on Liberia:

THE LAND: Lying between Ivory Coast, Guinea and Sierra Leone, the West African nation of Liberia covers 37,743 square miles. The coastal plain gives way to rocky cliffs, and strong tides make access to the Atlantic Ocean difficult. The highest elevations are in the northern highlands, which rise up to 4,500 feet. The capital is Monrovia.

THE PEOPLE: The population is estimated at more than 2.5 million, including 16 principal tribal groups and about 50,000 descendants of freed American slaves who founded the country. English is the official language. The vast majority of the country practices traditional African religions.

THE ECONOMY: Even before a 5-month-old guerrilla war began, the economy was near collapse, though the country possesses some of the richest iron ore in the world. Liberia has been unable to pay its foreign debt, and it has been suspended by the International Monetary Fund. Though the currency is tied to the U.S. dollar, little money is in circulation, driving up prices and increasing the value of the few dollars available. Though mining earns more than 64 percent of Liberia's foreign exchange, agricultural remains the main employer.

THE HISTORY: In 1822, freed American slaves visited Liberia and began settlements. They declared Liberia an independent republic in 1847. Descendants of the freed slaves, called Americo-Liberians, dominated the country until then-Master Sgt. Samuel Doe led a military coup on April 12, 1979. He was popular with the majority of Liberians, who resented the dominance of the Americo-Liberians. Doe headed a military government until October 1985, when elections were held. He claimed a victory, but opposition parties and independent observers said the vote was rigged. On Dec. 24, 1989, former Doe aide Charles Taylor invaded with a small band of men from Ivory Coast. Taylor said he intended to topple Doe's government.

DOC.HEAD: Hurricane Center Director Warns of New Era of Destructive Storms
LaserPhoto MH1
DOC.TEXT: The 1990 Atlantic hurricane season begins today amid dire warnings that killer storms on the East and Gulf coasts in the last two years may have been harbingers of a new era of destructive storms. The hurricane season runs until Nov. 30 and was ushered in by a tropical depression last week in the Caribbean that brought heavy rain to Cuba and south Florida but did not intensify into a hurricane. Many coastal communities, with swelling populations, are ill-prepared to handle a hurricane emergency, said Robert Sheets, director of the National Hurricane Center. A recent National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration report predicts the number of people in seaside counties from Maine to Texas will grow 60 percent, counting from 1960 until 2010. Some states such as Florida and Texas will experience near 200 percent growth during the period, the report said. ``What we're looking at is the possibility of greater destruction and greater loss of life,'' Sheets said Thursday. ``We can't stop the hurricanes. The only thing we can do is work on better preparedness and emergency planning.'' The aftermath from Hurricane Gilbert in 1988 and Hugo last year taught officials what improvements are needed to better evacuate and protect the estimated 45 million coastal residents from Maine to Texas, Sheets said. ``If the long-term trends are any indication of what's to come, we are in for more frequent and stronger hurricanes,'' said Sheets. Gilbert killed more than 300 people and caused heavy damage from the Lesser Antilles to Mexico. Hugo killed 28 people in the eastern Caribbean and 29 more in South Carolina and caused a record $10 billion in damage. Sheets said the predictions of increased hurricane activity are based on studies of past decades, atmospheric low-pressure waves and increased rainfall trends in West Africa, near the breeding waters for most hurricanes. Hurricane activity started dropping after drought conditions began in the early 1960s in Africa's Sahel region, he said. Between 1940 and 1969, the United States was hit by 22 hurricanes with minimum winds of 110 mph. From 1970 to 1989, there were only eight such storms, including Hugo, Sheets said. ``I hope we don't catch up this year with the decade of the '40s,'' he said. There are five categories of hurricanes, ranging from Category 1, which has top sustained winds of 74 mph to 95 mph, to Category 5, with top winds greater then 155 mph. Both Gilbert and Hugo reached category 5, according to meteorologist Barry Fatchwell of the National Hurricane Center. Sheets praised most South Carolina officials' response to Hugo, but said some leaders ``didn't have their proverbial act together'' and lives may have been saved. Also, he said Hugo showed inadequacies in the Emergency Broadcast System and some communities used emergency shelters ill-suited to withstand a powerful hurricane. In the Caribbean, officials have worked to improve communications systems after links were cut by Gilbert.

DOC.HEAD: US Warships Stationed Off Liberian Coast
DOC.TEXT: The United States has a flotilla of warships off the coast of Liberia in case it needs to use military force to evacuate thousands of Americans who might become trapped by an armed rebellion there. The six warships carrying more than 2,000 Marines were ordered to remain on station in international waters off the Liberian coast, the Pentagon said Thursday. The number of Americans in Liberia has been declining. Several weeks ago, the State Department said 10,000 people, including American citizens and others holding claim to U.S. protection, were in the country. That figure later was pared back to around 6,000, and the department now estimates, because some have left already, that 1,100 people could be eligible for evacuation. More than 1,000 people have been killed in a rebellion against the rule of Liberian President Samuel Doe during the last five months. The State Department on Thursday advised all U.S. citizens to leave the African country immediately. The U.S. flotilla includes a destroyer, an amphibious assault ship, a tank landing ship and other support vessels carrying ammunition and combat supplies, said Cmdr. David Thomas, a spokesman for the Defense Department. Also aboard are 179 Marine officers and 2,102 enlisted men, Thomas said. Rebel troops moved to within 25 miles of the Liberian capital, Monrovia, on Thursday and there was concern that fighting in the city could raise the death toll dramatically. The State Department, in a travel advisory, warned that conditions in the country were deteriorating. All non-essential U.S. personnel and all dependents were ordered to depart. Americans in the country needing assistance were advised to contact the U.S. Embassy in Monrovia. The U.S. ships are under orders to ``be prepared to evacuate American citizens in the event that they would no longer be able to leave the country by commercial means,'' Thomas said. The probability of using military force to evacuate Americans is low and the ships are being stationed off the Liberian coast as a precaution, Thomas said. The ships in the U.S. force are the USS Sipan, an amphibious assault ship; the USS Ponce, an amphibious transport dock ship; the USS Sumter, a tank landing ship; the USS Concord, a combat stores ship; the USS Suribachi, an ammunition ship; and the USS Peterson, a destroyer.

DOC.HEAD: Elvis Book Claims Living Reporter Committed Suicide
DOC.TEXT: Reports of his death have been greatly exaggerated. Not Elvis, but close; the King's friend James Kingsley, a longtime reporter for The Commercial Appeal. In ``E Is For Elvis,'' the new guide to the king of rock and roll, there is a premature announcement of Kingsley's death _ by suicide. ``I was shocked,'' said Kingsley. ``I didn't know what to think.'' According to the book, ``James Kingsley, a friend of Elvis Presley who had grown up in the same North Memphis neighborhood as the star, was a reporter for the Memphis Commercial Appeal. ``Kingsley wrote about Elvis frequently and broke many news stories concerning his activities. On Feb. 22, 1989, Kingsley died of a self-inflicted gunshot wound.'' The person who actually died of a gunshot wound on that date was another James Kingsley, 51, who was a friend of Elvis' and movie stuntman. The reporter Kingsley said he did not grow up in Memphis, but his family and the Presleys knew each other in Tupelo, Miss. The two Kingsleys were not related. Kevin Mulroy, an editor for the publisher New American Library, said Wednesday he was trying to contact one of the authors to find out what went wrong.

DOC.HEAD: NAACP Settles Fee Case With Former Attorneys
DOC.TEXT: The NAACP has agreed to drop a lawsuit against former staff attorneys who it alleged illegally kept more than $2 million in fees. A statement issued by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People on Thursday said an agreement was reached with former NAACP general counsel Nathaniel Jones, who is now a judge on the Sixth U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals. The statement gave no details on the disposition of the fees. NAACP President Benjamin Hooks said the dispute was ``an honest difference of opinion as to how these fees should be distributed.'' A lawsuit pending in Cleveland was being dismissed as part of the agreement, the statement said. Others besides Jones were parties to the case, but the statement did not mention them and the NAACP office did not answer a telephone call seeking clarification. The legal fees resulted from five discrimination cases dating to 1970.
DOC.HEAD: NYNEX Indicted for Business Practices of Tennessee Unit
DOC.TEXT: Regional telephone giant NYNEX Corp. has been indicted for allegedly violating the 1982 court order that broke up the old Bell system. The New York City-based telephone giant was indicted Thursday on one count of criminal contempt of court for allegedly providing information services to customers in violation of the 1982 consent decree. NYNEX denied any wrongdoing. The indictment is likely to provide ammunition to those opposing efforts in Congress to lift some of the restrictions the 1982 decree imposed on the regional Bell companies. The landmark 1982 ruling by U.S. District Judge Harold H. Greene prohibited the seven regional Bell holding companies from engaging in certain types of business, including processing computerized data. The indictment, obtained by the Justice Department's antitrust division, accused NYNEX through its Nashville, Tenn., subsidiary, Telco Research Corp., of providing data processing and information retrieval services over telephone lines from April 1986 to February 1987. The indictment did not cite possible penalties. Telco provided a computer and software to the long-distance company, MCI Communications Corp., to help make MCI's network more efficient, NYNEX spokesman Bob O'Brien said. He said Justice alleged that NYNEX did not provide enough of the computer to MCI. Justice said NYNEX violated terms of the 1982 consent decree, known as the Modification of Final Judgment, that prohibit NYNEX and the other regional Bell companies from providing information services. The consent decree was set up to divide different types of communication services between American Telephone & Telegraph Co. and the spinoff companies. ``Our position is that there was no violation of the MFJ,'' O'Brien said.
DOC.HEAD: Minority Employment Up Slightly in Newsrooms
DOC.TEXT: A study says the number of minorities and women working for daily newspapers grew slightly over the past two years but both groups are still under-represented in the industry. A survey by the American Newspaper Publishers Association, released Thursday, said minorities now account for 18 percent of the newspaper industry's work force, while representing 22 percent of the nation's total civilian work force. Women comprise 39 percent of newspaper staffs and 48 percent of the total work force, the study said. Both categories, according to a survey taken this year, improved their representation on newspaper staffs by 2 percentage points since 1988. The survey said minorities are still dramatically under-represented in newsrooms. Minorities make up 10 percent of news-editorial department staffs, the same percentage as 1988, the study showed.

DOC.HEAD: State Panel Says Analysis Would Have Shown Highway, Bridge Quake Danger
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of California highways and bridges probably wouldn't withstand a major earthquake because of outdated engineering standards, according to a long-awaited state report. The report Thursday by the governor-appointed Board of Inquiry, also concluded that officials should have known portions of the San Francisco-Oakland Bay Bridge and Interstate 880 would collapse in the Oct. 17 Loma Prieta earthquake. They didn't because the state couldn't pay for an updated engineering study due to budget constraints, the panel said. ``More aggressive efforts are needed if the disastrous potential of future earthquakes is to be minimized and the public safety adequately protected,'' said board Chairman George Housner, a professor of engineering emeritus for the California Institute of Technology. Engineering standards used to build I-880 and the Bay Bridge in the 1930s and 1950s and other structures were adequate for engineering knowledge at that time but seismic standards ``were very low compared to those in use today,'' the report said. The Oct. 17 earthquake measured 7.1 on the Richter scale, caused an estimated $7 billion in damages and killed 67 people, including 42 in the freeway collapse. Crews took one month to repair a 50-foot stretch of the upper deck of the Bay Bridge that crashed to the lower deck. The Cypress viaduct remains closed. The panel said the double-deck Cypress structure collapsed because it was built on soft soil and its upright support columns and connecting joints weren't strong enough to hold up the upper deck. The shaking literally pulled the structure apart, the report said. Gov. George Deukmejian, who attended the Oakland meeting where the 272-page report was released, said the report will help because it tells state officials ``what we should do and how to go about it.'' Deukmejian said he hoped voters Tuesday would approve Proposition 111, which would increase the gasoline tax by 9 cents. Some of the extra funds should be used to retrofit the state's highways and bridges in line with report recommendations, he said. ``The Loma Prieta earthquake should be considered a clear and powerful warning to the people of California,'' Housner said. ``We have made progress during the last two decades in reducing earthquake risks, but much more could have been done and awaits doing.''

DOC.HEAD: Fashion for Fido: The Fall Collection is Going to the Dogs
LaserPhoto NY9
DOC.TEXT: And now, for the pooch who has everything: designer togs for dogs. From New York's ritzy Park Avenue to Hollywood's walk of stars, fashion mavens with leashes are swaddling their pets in Spandex doggy swimsuits, denim jean jackets, Burberry raincoats, and fur coats _ though the fur is fake; even such extravagance has limits. ``Everything from tuxedoes to sequined gowns can be had or custom-made,'' said Mark Drendel, a pet pamperer at Canine Styles by Ursual Lehnhardt, a New York salon. ``If a lady goes out to buy an expensive Chanel suit, I don't think she would mind spending a little extra on her dog. In fact, most of our clientele are very wealthy and they don't think twice about it.'' Karen Thompson, a New York fashion designer, is working on a fall collection of wool dog sweaters mirroring the latest human fashions gracing magazine covers. ``People are into eating right, looking good and staying healthy. So naturally, it's not such a big thing anymore to want the same things for their pets,'' she said. A dog wardrobe at Thompson's two New York shops begins at $150: $60 for a hand-knit wool sweater and $90 for a ``Chanel-style'' lead and collar made of hand-braided leather and gold. But Thompson said the price is worth the stunning fashion statement of a well-dressed owner and matching pet. ``I really care about the pets that come in to my store,'' said Thompson. ``I can dress them up and make them very pretty. It's fun to take care of them and make them look good.'' Even big retailers are getting into the act. The main Macy's department store in Manhattan is reporting brisk sales at its year-old Petigree Shop, where a Burberry raincoat from London is going fast at $120, Spandex doggy swimsuits for $12. It also offers fake furs, handpainted T-shirts, vinyl raincoats in hot electric colors and tailored wool coats. Demand is big among the wealthy. Mary Jane Weiskopf of New York City said she has spent oodles to make sure her outfits are canine-coordinated, but the effort has earned her little Alice many fine compliments. ``I wear a lot Chanel suits and I put a lot of matching collars to them. Tomorrow I'm wearing a red plaid Valentino jacket and Alice will be wearing her red raincoat,'' Mrs. Weiskopf said. ``Alice is the most pampered dog in the world. She has wonderful clothes,'' Mrs. Weiskopf said. ``She's gone from her Southwestern mood to her Leopard mood to her Chanel mood _ and now she has close to 20 sweaters.'' Asked if Alice would ever go out without dressing, she chided the reporter, ``If you're a proper lady, you don't go out without looking your best.'' In the dog-eat-dog world of Washington, D.C., Bone Jour Boutique claims to cater to some truly top dogs. Among the very important pooches: the first dog, Millie, and Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole's pet. ``Senator Dole's dog is a regular grooming client and Millie Bush was in here for a photo session a year ago,'' said Bone Jour manager Brian Bean, referring to the bouncy springer spaniel owned by President Bush. Bean confided that Millie has received a pearl necklace from Bone Jour, to match the trademark pearls worn by first lady Barbara Bush. But any mutt, not just a presidential pooch, can look like a million. ``It's a whole new world; now you even have to decide what color toenail polish your dog is going to wear,'' Bean said. ``We even have little tuxedoes and little satin gowns for dogs,'' he added. That would make a splash at Embassy Row parties. Pet Limo, based in Beverly Hills, will pick up a pooch in a white stretch limousine, take it to its salon for grooming, dress-up in a tuxedo or sequined dress and return it home in time for a big bash. ``New Year's Eve is one of our biggest nights,'' said Steve L. May, the driving force behind Pet Limo. ``We've also done some black tie events and we once brought in 52 white doves, flowers and dressed the dogs up in little ouftfits for a wedding shower.'' Limo rental averages between $45 and $55, grooming $20-$45 and a tuxedo another $20. May said some big-name Hollywood stars are among his clients. ``I'd love to tell you their names but I can't,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Insurance Company Retiree: Thanks But No Thanks for Lunch
DOC.TEXT: When Genevieve McLaughlin told her boss at Independence Blue Cross she wanted to skip the traditional retirement lunch so the money could be spent on charity, she got a typical corporate response. The company set up a committee. Blue Cross usually throws a retirement lunch at a fancy hotel for employees of a decade or more, complete with flowers, photographs and a $100 gift certificate. The guest of honor can invite up to 35 co-workers, and a handful of managers attend. The non-profit health insurance company, with about 2 million subscribers in the Philadelphia area, picks up the $1,200 tab up to 20 times a year, but Mrs. McLaughlin, 64, wasn't interested in sitting through a bunch of speeches by executives she hardly knows. ``You ride the elevator with these people and they don't have the faintest idea who you are,'' she said. Mrs. McLaughlin suggested to her boss that instead of spending the money on a lunch she didn't want, the company split it between her favorite charities _ St. John's Hospice and her grandson's Little League team. ``They gave me a memo saying they'd set up a committee to consider whether or not the rules could be changed,'' she said. Mrs. McLaughlin's retirement as a Medicaid claims adjuster officially starts today after nearly 19 years with the company. She doesn't know when the committee decision will be announced. Meanwhile, Blue Cross gave her a choice _ have the lunch or wait for the committee decision. ``They said it might be five years from now. And who knows if I'm even going to be around tomorrow?'' Mrs. McLaughlin said. ``But I don't care, I want that money to go to that hospice and that Little League team. ``After all, it's not like I'm saying, `Just give me the money so I can go down to the shore.''' Blue Cross spokesman Dick Mendenhall said the decision has been put on hold. He didn't know of any other employees who made similar requests. Mrs. McLaughlin said she sympathizes with the company in one respect. ``I understand part of their problem. They're worried that some day, some one retiring will want to donate the money to the Ku Klux Klan or a group like that,'' she said. ``Well, why don't they just specify that you can't donate the money to something destructive?'' Bob Cantlin, a company vice president, bristled at the suggestion Blue Cross could be a little quicker about making a decision. ``I think, quite frankly, some companies would just say, `This is the policy and we won't consider changing,''' he said. Mrs. McLaughlin said she feels bad about the controversy, but she isn't backing down. ``If a big outfit like Blue Cross would change their policy like this, maybe other companies would follow suit and there'd be a little less hunger in the world,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Interior Considers Captive Breeding of Owls
DOC.TEXT: The Interior Department may advocate the captive breeding of spotted owls to save the threatened species while allowing the cutting of old-growth forests where the owls live, an official said. ``President Bush has told the Interior secretary that we've got to save the owl and we've got to save jobs,'' said Jim Hughes, deputy assistant Interior secretary for lands and minerals. ``Our mission is to make them compatible.'' Hughes, who accompanied Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan on a visit to Idaho that ended Thursday, said the department was not committed to the captive-breeding idea. ``It's something we're looking at,'' he said. Bill Burnham, director of The Peregrine Fund and the World Center for Birds of Prey, which Lujan visited Wednesday, said he would be glad to cooperate in an experiment to see if spotted owls will breed in captivity. ``Typically, owls are easier to breed than falcons,'' Burnham said. But he was careful to note that the issue of logging uncut forests is likely to remain even if captive breeding could save owls. ``The Peregrine Fund is interested in the conservation of the owl as a way to preserve the species,'' he said. ``Whether to cut or not cut the old-growth forests is another issue.'' The U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service is expected to decide in late June whether to list the spotted owl as an endangered species. If it is listed, the timber industry says hundreds of loggers, millworkers and others could lose their jobs because timber cuts would be sharply curtailed. An estimated 3,000 to 5,000 spotted owls remain in the old-growth forests of the Pacific Northwest. Burnham said he expects both environmentalists and timber workers to be skeptical of captive breeding. ``The problem with the owl is not the owl,'' he said. ``The main issue is overcutting of old-growth forests. The environmental community is probably not interested in the captive breeding of owls because then they lose their argument for saving the forests. ``And the timber industry won't be interested either, because then that would mean they're admitting that logging has hurt the owls.'' Joe Hinson, executive director of the Coeur d'Alene-based Intermountain Forest Industries Association, agreed with Burnham's assessment. ``The environmental groups have made it clear the owl is just a surrogate to the eliminating of harvest of old-growth stands of timber in the Pacific Northwest,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Roh To Invite Gorbachev To South Korea, North Angry Over Meeting
DOC.TEXT: President Roh Tae-woo will invite Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to visit South Korea when the two meet next week, newspapers said today. A North Korean official denounced the planned meeting. Several Seoul newspapers quoted high-ranking government sources as saying Gorbachev will be invited to visit Korea after his trip to Japan, planned for next April. The Roh-Gorbachev meeting Monday will be the first between leaders of the two countries, which have no diplomatic ties. The Soviet Union is a close ally of Seoul's rival, communist North Korea, to which it provides arms. North Korea's official news agency today quoted a Foreign Ministry official as denouncing the planned meeting between Roh and Gorbachev. ``If President Gorbachev has a meeting with Roh Tae-woo, which we do not think will take place, it will be a serious political issue,'' the official was quoted as saying. The report by the Korean Central News Agency was monitored in Tokyo. ``We consider that the president of the Soviet Union, an ally of ours, is quite able to analyze and judge what a serious political consequence will be entailed by his meeting with Roh Tae-woo, who is seeking only the split of Korea,'' the report said. The Korean Peninsula was divided into the communist North and capitalist South at the end of World War II in 1945. The two sides fought the Korean War in 1950-53. A South Korean official said today that the agenda for the Roh-Gorbachev talks will include the normalization of relations between Seoul and Moscow, economic cooperation and peace measures on the divided Korean peninsula. Kim Kim Chong-hwi, presidential assistant for foreign affairs, expressed optimism about the chances for formal relations. ``The meeting itself shows that the Soviet Union recognizes the Republic of (South) Korea,'' he was quoted as telling the Dong-A Ilbo newspaper. Dong-A Ilbo said Roh and Gorbachev are expected to agree on an early establishment of diplomatic ties, possibly before September. Seoul officials hope the Roh-Gorbachev meeting will help ease tension on the peninsula. They believe improved ties with the Soviet Union will result in better relations between the two Koreas.

DOC.HEAD: Man Sets Himself On Fire In Front Of U.S Consulate
DOC.TEXT: A man set himself on fire in front of the U.S. Consulate in Shanghai this morning, the U.S. Embassy said. Shanghai officials said the man, who suffered serious burns, was a mentally ill Chinese worker. Embassy press officer Sheridan Bell said Chinese bystanders reported that the man, who appeared to be in his 30s, doused himself with gasoline and lit a match. Chinese guards put out the blaze with fire extinguishers and the man, who appeared badly burned but still alive, was quickly taken away in a police car. Bell said the man said nothing and carried no sign or letter to explain his act. No embassy personnel witnessed the incident. An official in the Shanghai Foreign Affairs Office said the man suffered from mental illness. He said the man, now hospitalized, was a worker but that his name, age and employer were not known. Most of the 50 to 100 Chinese outside the consulate at the time of the incident were waiting to file visa applications, but it was not known if the man was also seeking a U.S. Visa. Thousands of young Chinese, seeking to escape political repression or poor job opportunities at home, are trying to gain entry to the United States and other Western countries. Many who lack proper qualifications are rejected. In the past year there have been protests outside the Australian and Japanese consulates in Shanghai by people unhappy over strict new regulations on student visas.

DOC.HEAD: 47-Pound Tumor Removed From Miner's Abdomen
DOC.TEXT: A 47-pound tumor was removed from a Pennsylvania coal miner's abdomen following unsuccessful attempts to reduce the cancerous growth through chemotherapy, hospital officials said. The tumor was removed from Richard Moody, 47, in a five-hour operation Wednesday at Johns Hopkins Hospital. ``He's still in shock that it's gone,'' Moody's wife, Lilly, said Thursday. ``He's suffered so much in the last few months, and he's still in a daze knowing that it's out of there.'' The tumor had filled Moody's abdominal cavity and crowded his digestive tract, making it impossible for him to eat normally and leaving him bed-ridden for the last several weeks, she said. The tumor was described as a schwannoma sarcoma, a slow-spreading growth that originated in nerves near Moody's right kidney. Surgeons had to remove one kidney along with the tumor, hospital officials said. Moody was in stable condition, hospital spokeswoman Carol Pearson said. Lab results should indicate in a few days whether cancer had spread to other parts of his body. Moody's weight dropped to 130 pounds following surgery, she said. Without surgery, the tumor would have killed him within a few weeks because of the progressive crowding of his organs, Pearson said. A spokeswoman for Dr. John Niederhuber said it was the largest tumor he had seen in 20 years of surgery. Moody, of Uniontown, Pa., first had sought to have the growth removed in March 1989, but a West Virginia surgeon said it was too large to be removed.

DOC.HEAD: Police Storm Insurance Company Headquarters To End Strike
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of riot police stormed the headquarters of an insurance company today to break up a sit-in strike by workers demanding wage hikes. No injuries were reported. Shortly after midnight, about 800 riot police moved into the downtown Seoul headquarters of the Daehan Education Insurance Co., where about 1,000 union members were in the ninth day of their strike. Police took away 212 union activists who had led the sit-in protests, but no clashes were reported. Police said all but three of the detained protesters would be released. The strike began last Wednesday when the company rejected workers' demands for a 15 percent increase in their basic monthly salaries. Workers have staged sit-down protests in the lobby and third-floor offices. South Korea has been rocked by labor unrest in recent months, and the government has vowed to deal firmly with the strikers, saying the fate of the country's slumping economy is at stake.

DOC.HEAD: Letter From `Lord's Avenger' Throws Curve in Bombing Investigation
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Earth First! cq
DOC.TEXT: An anonymous letter from a person claiming to be ``the Lord's avenger'' has complicated the investigation of two pipe bomb explosions that damaged a lumber mill and injured two environmentalists. The letter writer claimed to have set both pipe bombs. ``It could be serious; it could be a prank,'' FBI special agent Barry Mawn told a news conference Thursday. Anybody could have sent the letter, Mawn said, but the writer ``had a very good knowledge of explosives.'' The new evidence has unsettled Earth First!, the anti-logging group that says members Darryl Cherney and Judi Bari were the targets of one of the bombs. Police allege they were carrying the device in their car when it blew up on them May 24 in Oakland. ``Sure, maybe there's a religious wacko out there who's interested in killing environmental activists,'' Earth First! co-founder Mike Rosells said Thursday. ``But it's also possible this is a smoke screen for an organized conspiracy to murder environmental activists.'' The FBI was concentrating on trying to find out if the explosion that injured Bari and Cherney was linked to a blast that caused minor damage at the Louisiana-Pacific mill in Cloverdale on May 9. The Oakland Police Department said it would continue to concentrate its investigation on trying to prove Cherney, 33, of Piercy, and Bari, 40, of Redwood, were transporting the pipe bomb when it went off inside Bari's car. ``They're still the two prime suspects,'' Oakland police Sgt. Robert Chenault said Thursday. Alameda County prosecutors, however, on Tuesday postponed filing charges against the pair, saying they want to review the evidence. The two have strongly denied they were carrying the bomb, saying they were the victims of an attack, possibly by someone who had been sending the Earth First! activists death threats before planned summer-long anti-logging demonstrations called ``Redwood Summer.'' Cherney was released this week on $100,000 bail after Oakland police arrested him for investigation of transporting explosives and carrying a boobytrap. Bari remains hospitalized under police guard, recovering from a broken pelvis and other injuries. She also is being held on $100,000 bail. The letter writer warned he should be taken seriously. ``Doubt me not for I will tell you the design and materials such as only I will Know,'' he wrote in an excerpt released Thursday by The Press Democrat of Santa Rosa, which received the letter. The author claims to have been driven by religious zeal and anger at Bari's opposition to anti-abortion protesters and to timber cutting. The letter included specific details about the construction and placement of the bomb that injured Cherney and Bari and had accurate and never-disclosed information about the Cloverdale bomb, according to Larry Sheets, a bomb expert with the Sonoma County Sheriff's Department. Mawn said remnants of both pipe bombs would be sent to the FBI laboratory in Washington D.C. by Friday for detailed analysis. The analysis could take weeks or months. The FBI doesn't anticipate making arrests in the case until after the analysis is completed, Mawn said.

DOC.HEAD: Cigarette-Selling to Children Rarely Cited
With PM-Smoking-Minors, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Laws in 44 states prohibit sales of cigarettes to children, but they bought about 1 billion packs last year and federal health inspectors know of citations against only 32 vendors. ``Very few states have laws that are effective in preventing access to tobacco by minors,'' Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan said Thursday. ``Effective enforcement is the key to successful efforts.'' A week ago, Sullivan called for bans on cigarette machines, licensing of tobacco retailers and a minimum age of 19 for tobacco purchases. An estimated 1 billion packs of cigarettes are sold to children in this country each year, said a report in the Journal of the American Medical Association earlier this year. The national Centers for Disease Control noted in its weekly report Thursday that 44 states and the District of Columbia have laws restricting minors' access to tobacco. Thirty-six states require cigarette buyers to be 18, three states set the age at 19, four set it at 17 and one state and the District of Columbia set it at 16. Kentucky, Louisiana, Missouri, Montana, New Mexico and Wyoming have no minimum age for sale of cigarettes. Kentucky will restrict sales to minors under 16 beginning July 13. Only five states _ Alaska, Connecticut, Florida, New York and Vermont _ could provide Sullivan's inspector general with data on citations for tobacco sales to minors, said the CDC's Office on Smoking and Health. And only three states reported any sales violations at all in 1989 _ Florida with 16, Alaska with eight and New York with eight. ``It's clear these laws are not enforced,'' said Dr. Tom Novotny of the Office on Smoking and Health. Studies have indicated that 3 percent to 16 percent of underage smokers get their cigarettes out of machines, Novotny said, while the majority of sales to kids occur over the counter. Just six states _ Alaska, Idaho, Indiana, Maine, Minnesota and Utah _ prohibit cigarette machines in areas accessible to children or ban such machines altogether, the CDC said. Novotny said dual strategies are needed to keep cigarettes out of children's hands _ awareness by vendors and others in the community and commitment from law enforcement officials to enforce cigarette laws. Sullivan has proposed model legislation for states to control tobacco sales to minors. Such laws would be ``a potentially effective public health strategy to prevent tobacco use by teen-agers,'' said the Atlanta-based CDC, an agency of HHS. But Sullivan's proposal has been criticized as too weak by the Coalition on Smoking or Health and by U.S. Sen. Edward Kennedy, D-Mass., sponsor of a $110 million-a-year anti-smoking measure pending in the Senate.

DOC.HEAD: Minister: Talks With Tamil Rebels Progressing
DOC.TEXT: A senior minister says talks between the government and Tamil rebels have been progressing and there have been few incidents of violence in areas where rebel attacks were once common. ``The halt in killings in the north and east is a major breakthrough,'' Deputy Defense Minister Ranjan Wijeratne said Thursday. He said some fighters with the Tamil Tigers, also known as the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam, have carried out several raids, but rebel leaders appeared to support talks with the government. The Tiger rebels have been fighting the Sri Lankan government and also fought an Indian peacekeeping force. The rebels have accused the island's Sinhalese majority, which controls the government and the military, of discrimination, but accepted negotiations in June 1989. India withdrew its troops in March, 1990. Tamils, who are mostly Hindu, make up 18 percent of the island's 16 million people. Talks have been held regularly in Colombo, the island's capital, and in Jaffna, the northern stronghold of the Tigers, since last June. Government communiques and independent reports have claimed that since the truce began Tiger rebels have abducted and assaulted policemen and soldiers, shot wild elephants and illegally felled timber. ``The government's view, despite these provocative acts, is that the talks are moving satisfactorily,'' Wijeratne said. ``We do not want another war in which we will kill our own people.'' He said the Tiger hierarchy has repeatedly expressed confidence in President Ranasinghe Premadasa. Since the Tigers took up arms in 1983, more than 16,000 people have died in the fighting.

DOC.HEAD: Death Toll At Least 137 In Peruvian Quake
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with death toll rising to at least 137, report on damage to buildings. Pickup 4th graf pvs, `The government ...
DOC.TEXT: Strong aftershocks rocked jungle villages in northern Peru, sending terrified residents into streets and town squares two days after a killer earthquake rocked the region. The death toll rose to at least 137. Hundreds of people whose homes were damaged slept on towels and mats Thursday in the streets of Rioja and Moyobamba, the two largest towns in the affected area about 400 miles north of Lima. The quake destroyed between 30 and 40 percent of the buildings in the area, the civil defense office in Lima said. Civil defense officials in the earthquake zone said at least 137 people died in Tuesday's earthquake, which measured 6.3 on the Richter scale. The government daily La Cronica, however, said more than 200 were killed. The differing figures could not immediately be reconciled. Peru's Geophysical Institute in Lima said at least 70 aftershocks had struck since Tuesday night, including one Thursday morning that registered 4.6 on the Richter scale. All the tremors were centered around Moyobamba, a farming community of 50,000 that produces corn, rice, coffee and sugar cane. The air above nearby Rioja, a town of 20,000, was thick with smoke from outdoor cooking fires as residents crowded the central square. Many held crying infants as they waited for aftershocks to subside. ``All of us slept in the streets, but we were afraid to take out our beds because we might be trapped by another tremor,'' said Flor de Maria Masaboya of Rioja, pointing out a 3-inch-wide crack in her adobe home. Several small villages around Moyobamba were the hardest hit. At least 23 people died in Soritor, a village six miles south of Moyobamba, including 15 people in one family whose two-story house collapsed on them. La Cronica reported Thursday that officials feared some remote villages may have been buried by mudslides that resulted from the quake, but civil defense officials could not confirm that. About 40 people were reported missing, and hundreds were injured. Authorities in Lima said the affected area was still without electricity, water or telephone service. At least three military transport planes carrying doctors, medical and food supplies had arrived at the Rioja airport by Thursday afternoon, according to the government. Neighboring Chile offered to send tents for those left homeless. Thursday marked the 20th anniversary of a devastating earthquake that shook Peru's northern Andes Mountains, killing 70,000 people. The 1970 quake registered 7.7 on the Richter scale. The Richter scale is a gauge of the energy released by an earthquake, as measured by the ground motion recorded on a seismograph.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mixed, Gold Lower
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was mixed in light European trading this morning. Gold was moderately lower in extremely thin trading. Currency traders said the market was waiting for the announcement of U.S. unemployment figures in Washington later in the day. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 152.17 yen, up 0.42 yen from Thursday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 152.22 yen. ``Trading was very quiet, and the dollar-yen rate was fluctuating rather narrowly as investors made position adjustments,'' said Minori Takeuchi, a dealer with Chemical Bank in Tokyo. Spot trading volume totaled $10.5 billion, down from Thursday's $12 billion. DOC.HEAD: Thunderstorms in Plains; Dry Skies in East
DOC.TEXT: Thunderstorms rumbled across the central Plains early today ahead of a cold front. Dry weather and mild temperatures were forecast in the East. Rain fell in the central Rockies, and snow advisories were posted for the central mountains of Montana. Showers and thunderstorms were likely in the Tennessee Valley, the vanguard of inclemental weather expected across the Plains. A cold front stretching from west Texas to the western Dakotas pushed thunderstorms over Oklahoma early today. in Texas, three tornadoes touched down Thursday south of Perryton and one each in Waka and Farnsworth. Twisters also touched down west of New Orleans and New Iberia, La. The high Thursday in the Lower 48 states was 104 degrees at Presidio, Texas. DOC.HEAD: Rush Hour Drive Scratched in Latest Gorbachev Tour Change
DOC.TEXT: The threat of rush hour traffic over the Golden Gate Bridge apparently proved too much for organizers of Mikhail Gorbachev's San Francisco tour. Tentative plans were scrapped Thursday for a Gorbachev motorcade over the landmark span to Marin County. The Soviet leader and his wife, Raisa, will instead view the bridge from a parking lot on the San Francisco side. Robert Stockwell, president of the Golden Gate Bridge District, is to give the Gorbachevs a tour Monday of gardens near the bridge's toll plaza. ``We want to show them the most beautiful part of the bridge and show them the view that millions of visitors have admired,'' he said. Stockwell also is to present the Gorbachevs with several bridge mementos, including a section of the original suspension cable, a copy of Chief Engineer Joseph Strauss's original report on how and why the bridge was built and a pair of sweat shirts. Civic leaders hope the trip will boost San Francisco's economic spirits, devastated by the Oct. 17 earthquake. ``San Francisco has been feeling some of the downturn in business ever since the earthquake,'' Chamber of Commerce spokeswoman Carol Piasente said. ``Having Gorbachev visit is a great boost to the local economy.'' At Stanford, the post office plans to issue a special envelope Monday commemorating the Gorbachev visit with a special cancellation design featuring Gorbachev's face above the word ``Stanford,'' written in Cyrillic alphabet. At City Hall in San Francisco, the Soviet flag will be flying. Mayor Art Agnos, joined by Soviet Consul General Valentin Kamenev and the city's chief of protocol, Charlotte Mailliard Swig, planned to raise the flag today off the balcony of the mayor's office. ``There's a great deal of excitement about the visit,'' said Ms. Piasente said. ``We're fielding hundreds of phone calls.'' While Gorbachev meets with San Francisco business leaders, Mrs. Gorbachev will take a separate tour of the city Monday afternoon, traveling by motorcade to Golden Gate Park, the War Memorial Opera House, Davies Symphony Hall, the Bank of America building and Fisherman's Wharf. Earlier plans to include the Civic Center, where dozens of homeless people have been living for months, were dropped. The Gorbachevs' whirlwind tour _ arriving in San Francisco Sunday night and leaving Monday afternoon _ will include a bit of socializing. Four members of a group called ``Friends of Raisa Gorbachev'' were scheduled to meet with Mrs. Gorbachev at the Soviet consul general's residence for a ``nonpolitical, people-to-people'' conversation.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Issues Final Order in School Desegregation Case
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge permanently banned racial discrimination in the city's public schools in his final order in a 16-year-old desegregation case. The order Thursday from U.S. District Judge W. Arthur Garrity Jr. barred ``creating, promoting or maintaining racial segregation in any school or other facility in the Boston school system.'' In a 1974 ruling on a lawsuit brought by black parents, Garrity found the city's public schools were segregated. He ordered them desegregated, and the resultant busing of students touched off years of turmoil. Garrity monitored the city's compliance with his order until 1987, when a federal appeals court ruled that the schools were desegregated and gave control over student assignment back to the School Committee. Garrity continued to monitor school administration and operations, however. He said Thursday's order would be his last. Perhaps the most controversial part of the four-page ruling was a decree that teacher layoffs must follow court-ordered racial guidelines rather than be based on seniority alone. That order, which means teachers and administrators must include 25 percent blacks and 10 percent other minorities, is to remain until ``seniority would be a racially neutral standard,'' he said. Achieving a fully desegregated faculty and staff ``will be an important milestone on the long road to affording equal educational opportunity to all students in Boston's public schools,'' Garrity wrote. More than 200 teachers are expected to be laid off _ nearly 800 have received layoff warnings _ before the next school year because of budget limitations. The Boston Teachers Union's contract calls for layoffs strictly on the basis of seniority. Union President Edward Doherty has said the union would appeal any ruling that continued minority quotas, which he said would mean many white teachers with 20 or more years of experience would lose their jobs. But lawyers on both sides of the desegregation case praised Garrity's final judgment. ``The order is consistent with affirmative action policies the School Committee has in place and clarifies some issues that need clarification concerning layoffs,'' said Henry Dinger, a lawyer for the School Committee. Robert Pressman, a lawyer for black plaintiffs, said the ruling shows that Garrity ``studied the papers carefully and manifests his continuing steadfastness in protecting the rights of the plaintiff class.''

DOC.HEAD: Deputy Arrests 3-Year-Old For Uprooting Flamingo Ornaments
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to CORRECT spelling of judgment in lead, add that order was for house arrest. Picks up 4th graf pves, `Nugent said...'.
DOC.TEXT: A deputy who arrested a 3-year-old for uprooting a neighbor's flamingo lawn ornaments exercised ``poor judgment,'' his commander says. Tony Salgado, a wide-eyed boy with curly blond hair, wandered onto his neighbor's lawn two weeks ago, pulled out two ornamental pink plastic flamingos and dropped them in the driveway. The neighbor called police. Deputy J. Burnett of the Hernando County Sheriff's Office arrived at the scene and filed an affidavit charging Tony with criminal mischief, said Sheriff's Capt. Rich Nugent. Burnett ordered the boy held under house arrest, and also referred the case to state social workers. Nugent said he immediately stopped charges after learning about the incident late last week. ``It was poor judgment,'' Nugent said. ``Obviously, we don't condone this.'' Burnett and Sgt. Lanny Corlew, who reviewed Burnett's affidavit, may face disciplinary action, Nugent said, although Corlew said he did not notice the boy's age. Tony, meanwhile, has promised not to uproot any more flamingos. ``That's a no-no,'' he said Wednesday as he rolled in a pile of laundry on his living room floor.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf of 2nd item to recast, deleting reference to `his invention.' Longer version moved on sports wires.
DOC.TEXT: Abram Shorin, co-founder with three brothers of the Topps baseball card company, died Monday in Miami at the age of 91. At the suggestion of a nephew, Shorin put bubble gum together with baseball cards in 1951, and Topps Co. Inc. became the world's largest manufacturer of the two products. The company was founded in 1938. In 1953, Topps gave consumers the comic character Bazooka Joe to accompany the bubble gum, which is sold in 55 countries. Before the comic strip, the gum was manufactured in a funnel shape, like a humorous musical instrument, called a bazooka. The bazooka also gave its name to the armor-piercing gun.

DOC.HEAD: Bush, Gorbachev Ready to Sign Nuclear, Chemical Arms Accords
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Top 9 grafs new with TV interviews; trims and edits throughout to tighten; Gorbachev meets members of Congress at 9:30 a.m. EDT, talks with Bush at 11 a.m.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev headed today toward a new round of summit talks shadowed by disputes over Germany and Lithuania but assured of yielding agreement on long-sought curbs on strategic nuclear weapons and poison gas. Before he met with Bush at the White House, Gorbachev summoned leading members of Congress to the Soviet Embassy for an exchange that was expected to focus on trade, arms control and Gorbachev's economic squeeze on the breakaway Baltic republic of Lithuania. Bush and Gorbachev were upbeat after their initial talks Wednesday, even though they concluded they would be unable to resolve the issue of German unification before Gorbachev leaves Sunday. They left the German question for their foreign affairs experts to tackle later. However, both U.S. and Soviet officials today saw encouraging signs in the summit exchanges over a united Germany and its future military role. ``Now we are moving closer to each other,'' said Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman Gennady Gerasimov, interviewed on ABC-TV's ``Good Morning America.'' Although the German issue won't be settled at the summit, Gerasimov said, ``we understand better the arguments'' and that is ``a very good sign for the summit.'' Both Gerasimov and chief U.S. arms negotiator Richard Burt, interviewed on the same program, said European security arrangements must be overhauled as a result of dramatic changes in East-West relations. Burt said the United States is ``taking a new look at security and institutions in Europe, including a concept of remodeling NATO for a new era.'' He said it was important for the Soviets to understand that U.S. moves are ``not designed to undermine Soviet security.'' Gorbachev displayed his trademark spontaneity Wednesday when he halted his limousine one block east of the White House, during a brief evening ride to the Soviet Embassy. Wading into a crowd of pedestrians on the sidewalk, he exulted, ``I feel really at home here.'' Bush offered a light moment at the end of the day. Toasting Gorbachev at a glittering White House state dinner _ Maine lobster was on the menu _ he said expectations were at a fever pitch for the events of Day Two. ``When Barbara and Raisa go to Wellesley College,'' he deadpanned. The first ladies were traveling there for commencement ceremonies. The White House said the two men would sign a treaty late today ending production of chemical weapons and sharply trimming poison gas stockpiles. An agreement also was ready for their signatures outlining agreement on major points of a treaty to scale back long-range nuclear weapons. Accompanying it was a pledge to pursue deeper reductions after the first treaty is completed. The treaty, nearly a decade in negotiations, will eventually reduce stockpiles of long range nuclear missiles, bombers and submarines, by 30 to 35 percent. From the U.S. viewpoint, the key provision will halve the number of Soviet SS-18 missiles capable of reaching the United States. The pact on chemical weapons would halt production of poison gas and reduce each country's stockpiles to 5,000 tons. The United States currently has about 25,000 tons and the Soviet Union twice that amount. Bush called the pacts ``proof that differences can be resolved _ even while others remain.'' One of the major differences centered on Lithuania, where Gorbachev has applied economic pressure to quell an independence drive. Bush prodded Gorbachev on the subject in his welcoming remarks outside the White House, and said Lithuania and the related topic of expanded trade relations might come up in summit talks. At the State Department, other agreements were ready for signing by Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze covering air travel, oceanography and maritime issues. And despite the continuing impasse over Germany, the two sides were reportedly making some progress in arms control talks continuing at the State Department, and laying plans for future negotiations. Gorbachev told reporters that while the issue of German unification would not be resolved at the summit, Baker and Shevardnadze would discuss the issue next week at an international conference in Copenhagen, and again in late June in Berlin. As hopes for a German accord faded, so did chances for agreement on a reduction in troops and conventional arms in Europe. Even so, Soviet spokesman Arkady Maslennikov said he looked for two more Gorbachev-Bush meetings this year, one to ratify agreements on a new Europe and the second late in 1990 to sign the nuclear arms control treaty. Bush and Gorbachev said their wide-ranging discussions on Wednesday included detailed discussions of Germany. Gorbachev and White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said new ideas had been exchanged, but another U.S. official said that wasn't the case. ``The bottom line is both presidents restated their well-known positions,'' the official said. The partial economic blockade the Soviets have imposed on Lithuania has deterred Bush from approving a new trade agreement with Moscow, details of which were completed last week. Bush also has ruled out a trade pact until the Soviets enact liberal emigration legislation.

DOC.HEAD: Government Declares State of Emergency in Two Cities
DOC.TEXT: The government has declared a 30-day state of emergency in the capital and nearby port of Callao in advance of the June 10 presidential runoff election. The runoff pits novelist Mario Vargas Llosa against Alberto Fujimori, an agricultural engineer whose parents emigrated from Japan. A similar state of emergency, which gives the military broad powers to fight leftist guerrillas, was in effect during the first round balloting on April 8. The decree announced Thursday places the two cities under military control and allows authorities to restrict freedom of movement, detain people without filing charges and search residences without warrants. In Lima, the capita and home to a third of Peru's 22 million people, the state of emergency will be administered by the national police. A state of emergency remains in effect for eight departments and one province, where government troops are battling Maoist Shining Path guerrillas. The areas are located in Peru's central and southern highlands and northern jungle region. In the southern highlands, police said on Thursday that Shining Path guerrillas killed eight people in three towns near the city of Huancavelica, 145 miles southeast of Lima. A column of 15 rebels entered the town of Pueblo Libre on Wednesday night and abducted three former village officials from their homes, police said. The officials were later shot to death in a field near the town. At the same time, another guerrilla band shot to death the town manager and two other officials in the village of Tansire, police said. In another Wednesday night raid, the rebels fatally stabbed two peasants near the town of Condorsurco and stole 20 head of cattle, police said. The government says that more than 18,500 people have died in violence since the Shining Path guerrillas launched their insurgency in 1980. The government first imposed a state of emergency in December 1982 in Ayacucho, birthplace of the rebel movement. Since then the measure has been steadily extended to other areas as the rebel violence has expanded.

DOC.HEAD: Experts Hopeful About New AIDS Drug
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, `New York-based...', to CORRECT spelling of Myers. INSERTS one graf after 11th graf, `If little...' to add background on controversy over release of untested drugs. Other minor editing.
DOC.TEXT: AIDS experts were hopeful that a new experimental drug will slow the progress of the deadly disease and prove less toxic and cheaper than the anti-viral drugs AZT and DDI. The U.S. Food and Drug Administration has made Hoffman-La Roche's drug DDC available to AIDS patients in a ``compassionate use program'' designed to test the safety of the drug, the pharmaceutical company and the FDA announced Thursday. ``The most exciting thing about DDC is that it is looking more and more to be the drug that DDI was supposed to be,'' said Dr. Jay Lalezari, co-director to the HIV Clinical Research Center at Mount Zion Hospital in San Francisco. ``We don't know the efficacy, but it looks like it is well-tolerated,'' he said. New York-based Bristol Myers has been distributing the experimental drug DDI free in a similar compassionate use program to about 8,000 patients who are not responding to AZT treatment or cannot tolerate AZT. The side effects of DDI include nausea, diarrhea and depression, but DDC, which stands for dideoxycytidine, has shown few side effects, Lalezari said. AZT is the only AIDS drug approved by the FDA. DDC, because it is still classified as experimental, is available only in clinical trials. The compassionate use program announced Thursday expands those trials. Though it does not cure AIDS, AZT prolongs the lives of some people infected by the virus. Others have stopped taking the drug because of side effects such as anemia and depletion of bone marrow. There are two ongoing clinical trials in which researchers are comparing the effectiveness of DDC and AZT. Patients do not know which of the two drugs they are receiving. Hoffman-La Roche will begin a study June 25 with 50 patients who cannot tolerate DDI or AZT. The study will assess the toxicity and effectiveness of DDC. If little toxicity is found, the program will be expanded to 200 patients after four weeks and opened to unlimited enrollment after four months. This approach is a compromise in a bitter controversy between some people with AIDS and researchers who fear participants in clinical trials will drop out if the drugs are available elsewhere. AIDS activists have staged street protests to demand that all promising drugs be made available to any desperately ill patients willing to risk untested remedies. Jim Eigo, a member of the AIDS Research Advisory Council, said the combination of DDC and AZT seems to be more effective than either drug alone. ``In addition, the combination is less harmful because their toxicities do not overlap,'' Eigo said. DDC's low manufacturing cost could make the drug much less expensive than AZT, which can cost up to $8,000 for a year's treatment, said John James of the AIDS Treatment Newsletter. James said it costs about five cents to make a day's dose of DDC. The final price of the drug, if approved, would be much higher, however, because it would include the costs of clinical trials, research and development, marketing and a profit. ``It's simply too early to know what the price would be,'' said Hoffman-La Roche spokeswoman Karen Kmetik.
Editors: Physicians, patients and others wanting information about DDC or other experimental drugs can call 1-800-TRIALS-A.

DOC.HEAD: Eritrean Rebels Claim They Killed 7,000 Gov't Soldiers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to ADD report on sentences for officers in coup attempt.
DOC.TEXT: Eritrean rebels claim they killed 7,000 government troops in the latest battle in their offensive to capture Asmara, the besieged capital of Ethiopia's northernmost province. Also today, the official Ethiopian News Agency reported that a military court had sentenced 18 army officers stationed in Eritrea to prison terms ranging from two to seven years for their involvement in a failed May 1989 coup attempt aimed at overthrowing President Mengistu Haile Mariam. The news agency said the military court ordered the release of three other officers linked to the coup attempt because they had served sufficient terms in pre-trial custody. The Eritrean People's Liberation Front said in a clandestine broadcast Thursday that its fighters had also wounded about 4,000 government troops and captured 1,100 in winning their second victory in a week of heavy fighting southeast of Asmara. The broadcast, monitored in Nairobi, said the fighting was on the Segeneyti Front, 30 miles from Asmara. ``The offensive is continuing to push forward with vigor,'' the rebel broadcast said. On Tuesday, the Eritreans said they had ``completely routed'' government troops during another battle on the same front. It was not possible to verify independently the rebel claims, but a broadcast on state-controlled radio in the Ethiopian capital, Addis Ababa, implied there were heavy casualties on the government side. ``The joint offensive by the EPLF and the Weyane (Tigreans) on the Segeneyti Front is being repulsed by our revolutionary army with great martyrdom,'' the government broadcast said Thursday. The Tigre People's Liberation Front, another smaller rebel group, is fighting a 15-year-old insurgency to oust the nation's president and establish a hard-line Marxist government. The Tigreans control their home province of Tigre, Eritrea's southern neighbor. The Eritreans and Tigreans often coordinate their offensives. The Ethiopian News Agency said the officers sentenced to prison for the coup attempt ranged in rank from lieutenant to colonel. Although troops loyal to President Mengistu quickly crushed the rebellion in Addis Ababa May 16, 1989, the mutineers in Eritrea held out for three days. The officers' sentences were considered light compared to the death penalties imposed on 12 generals, including the commander of all ground forces and the air force chief of staff, who were convicted of treason for their role in the coup attempt. The executions, announced May 21, have led to nearly two weeks of sporadic student demonstrations at the University of Addis Ababa. The trial of another 35 senior officers is continuing, while an additional 130 officers are yet to be tried. The Eritreans are fighting a 29-year-old war for the independence of Eritrea, a former Italian colony annexed by Ethiopia in 1962. They launched their current offensive Feb. 8 and captured the Red Sea port of Massawa three days later, cutting off all but air access to Asmara.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS SPRINGFIELD, Mass.-dated last item in rdp to DELETE incorrect reference to hopes of baseball career; INSERTS 1 graf after 5th graf, `Doctors rebuilt...', to give detail.
DOC.TEXT: More than 30 years ago, a college prank cut short Fay Vincent's hopes of an athletic career. Saturday night, the baseball commissioner returns to the college campus where his dreams were shattered. But the baseball commissioner said his trip to Williams College as a commencement speaker won't resurrect bad memories of the fall that left him permanently injured. ``It's a very nice honor and I'll be happy to be up there,'' Vincent said in a recent interview. ``It was a wonderful college. I got a fine education.'' A 1960 graduate of the school in the picturesque Berkshire community of Williamstown, Vincent was the strapping captain of the freshman football team when he was locked in his room by a friend. Climbing out the window onto an icy ledge, Vincent slipped and fell four stories, crushing two vertebrae. Doctors rebuilt the vertebrae, but Vincent must still sometimes use a cane to walk. Though he had played some baseball as a teen-ager, Vincent's career hopes had been pinned on football. But his love for baseball grew during his long convalescence as he turned to game broadcasts to pass the time. He was selected baseball commissioner last fall after commissioner A. Bartlett Giamatti died. Vincent will be the baccalaureate speaker Saturday night and will receive an honorary doctor of laws degree Sunday.

DOC.HEAD: Son Succeeds Assassinated Cleric in Kashmir
DOC.TEXT: A teen-age boy was installed today as Kashmir's top Moslem clergyman to succeed his assassinated father, and Kashmiris used the occasion to renew a call for independence. Amid recitals of Koranic verses, 16-year-old Umar Farooq took his place as the mirwaiz maulvi, or chief preacher, of Kashmir during a special service in the Jama Masjid, Kashmir's largest mosque. About 100,000 Moslems thronged the mosque and an equal number crowded the streets around the building to mark the installation that coincided with the Moslem sabbath. Ghulam Pandey, head priest of a local mosque, wrapped a turban around Farooq's head, formalizing his appointment as the mirwaiz. Other priests showered the new preacher with rose petals. The boy, wearing a loose shirt and trousers and a brocaded silk gown, then climbed a black marble dais and read from the Koran, the Islamic holy book, for 30 minutes as the congregation listened in rapt attention. After Farooq's sermon, the Moslems shouted in Urdu: ``Join hand to hand, give the mujahedeen a sturdy stand,'' and ``What do we want? We want independence.'' The militants are commonly called mujahedeen, or Islamic holy warriors. Outside the mosque, militants burned Indian flags and copies of the autobiography of former Indian Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru, a Kashmiri Hindu. Several Moslems, inside and outside the mosque, began weeping as Farooq read the Koran. ``We used to listen to his father read the Koran every Friday. Today he is no more,'' said an old man who refused to identify himself. Umar's father, Mirwaiz Maulvi Farooq was killed by three unidentified gunmen in his Srinagar home on May 21. A few hours later security forces opened fire on a crowd carrying Farooq's body in defiance of a curfew, killing 58 people and wounding 300. The toll was the highest in one day in security force action since they launched a crackdown on Kashmiri separatists Jan. 20. At least 486 people have been killed since then. Most were militants or supporters of the campaign for the independence of Jammu-Kashmir, India's only Moslem-majority state, from the predominantly Hindu India. Kashmir, a former princely state, was divided along a still-disputed forntier between India and Pakistan after British colonial India became independent in 1947 and was partitioned along religious lines. The border dispute has also led to a harsh war of words between India and Pakistan and has raised fears of a fourth war between the two countries. Two of the previous wars were over Kashmir and both were won by India. Pakistan also lost the third war, when India helped Bangladesh become independent from Pakistan. About 64 percent of the 6 million people in Indian-governed Jammu-Kashmir state are Moslems. Nationwide, Moslems account for 12 percent of India's 880 million people while Hindus comprise 82 percent.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Vetoes Council Fact-Finding Mission to Israel, Angers Arabs
