DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with Palestinians announcing boycott on U.S. contacts, ADDS background on uprising. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The United States vetoed a Security Council resolution calling for a fact-finding mission on abuses against Palestinians in Israeli-occupied lands, drawing sharp criticism from Arab states. In Jerusalem, Palestinian leaders in the Israeli-occupied lands said today they were cutting off contacts with U.S. officials because of the veto. Arab nations said the 14-1 vote Thursday in favor of the resolution demonstrated that the United States and Israel are isolated on Middle East issues. The observer of the Palestine Liberation Organization, Zuhdi Labib Terzi, called it ``a sad day'' in the Security Council ``when one member blocks the council from responding to its responsibility to report on an alarming situation.'' After the council meeting, Clovis Maksoud, observer of the 22-nation Arab League, vowed to raise the issue again in the council, despite the risk of another U.S. veto. U.S. Ambassador Thomas R. Pickering said the resolution was ``more likely to add to the problems, rather than help resolve the peace process in the region.'' ``This resolution does not focus on the real need to move the peace process forward,'' Pickering said. ``Rather, it could too easily become a vehicle which could be misused to generate more needless controversy,'' he told the 15-member council. The United States favors an envoy dispatched by the U.N. secretary-general to investigate violence in the territories. Israel, however, opposes any fact-finding mission, and Israeli officials said they will not permit U.N. officials or Security Council members to enter its territory. The United States frequently has voted in favor of its Israeli ally and has used its Security Council veto power to shield Israel from harsh criticism in the council. During the council meeting, Israeli Ambassador Johanan Bein said the PLO had fanned violence in the territories and was murdering its own dissidents. More than 700 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli gunfire during the 30-month Palestinian uprising against Israeli rule in the territories. In addition, more than 210 Palestinians have been killed by fellow Arabs, most on suspicion of collaborating with Israel. Forty-five Israelis have also been killed. Thursday's council session was a continuation of the meeting that began May 25 in Geneva, Switzerland. At that meeting, PLO chief Yasser Arafat called for a U.N. military observer force to protect Palestinians. The meeting was prompted by the May 20 killing of seven Palestinian laborers by an Israeli gunman the government described as deranged. Palestinians rioted in protest, and at least 15 were killed in clashes with Israeli forces. The Palestinian leaders in the territories today called on the Arab world to take ``serious and decisive positions'' against America, including withdrawing funds from U.S. institutions, boycotting U.S. products, and cutting off its supply of oil. The U.S. veto was ``a new indication it (the Bush administration) is unfit to have any responsibility at all in the peace process in the Middle East,'' said a statement read at a news conference. ``We declare our boycott, our refusal, to conduct any official contacts with the American Consulate, with any American representative or emissary.'' It was endorsed by 43 Palestinian leaders from the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip who gathered at a hotel in east Jerusalem to end a 13-day hunger strike. The protest was called to demand better protection for Palestinians after the May 20 killings. Don B. Cofman, the U.S. Embassy spokesman in Israel, had no comment. Foreign Minister Moshe Arens of Israel said today that his government was ``glad'' about the U.S. veto. The resolution that was vetoed would have established a three-man commission from the council to immediately ``examine the situation relating to the policies and practices of Israel, the occupying power, in the Palestinian territory, including Jerusalem, occupied since 1967.'' The council includes five permanent members with veto power and 10 members serving 2-year terms.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Plane Sports a New Look
DOC.NOTE: Eds: In 3rd item on artist, CORRECTS name throughout to Kumankov sted Kumakov
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev arrived in Washington aboard a jet bearing a new look reminiscent of the President Bush's Air Force One. Gorbachev in the past has traveled aboard an Ilyushin 62M four-engine jet that bore the standard blue markings of Aeroflot, the Soviet airline. But the plane that brought him to the United States had the words Sovyetski Soyuz, which is Russian for Soviet Union, painted on the fuselage just above the windows. Air Force One and a fleet of similar planes the Air Force maintains for top government officials carry the words ``United States of America'' emblazoned in the same place.
DOC.HEAD: Soviet Press Center Loses Track of Mrs. Gorbachev's Agenda
DOC.TEXT: Vladimir Ustimenko, a Soviet official manning the Soviet office at the press center, was just as frustrated as the reporters he was trying to help. Ustimenko had heard _ but couldn't confirm _ that Raisa Gorbachev would be accepting a painting as a gift sometime Thursday. But he didn't know where the event was to take place and he couldn't get through to the Soviet Embassy. ``Busy,'' he told a reporter who muttered that the press operation was ``useless.'' Ustimenko kept his humor, though. The problem, he said, was that he was used to using a cellular telephone. For the record, Mrs. Gorbachev never paid a noontime visit to accept paintings, but she did attend a Library of Congress reception where she was given framed items.
DOC.HEAD: Moscow Artist Meets Mrs. Gorbachev at Washington Museum
DOC.TEXT: Anton Kumankov lives in Moscow, but he had to come to the Capital Children's Museum here to meet Raisa Gorbachev. Children's portraits by Kumankov, a book illustrator, are on display until June 17 at the hands-on museum housed in a former school building near Capitol Hill. He was visiting the United States when he got the call from a museum official that Mrs. Gorbachev would be stopping by. While awaiting her arrival Thursday, Kumankov milled about his exhibit _ two rooms of portraits of solemn, big-eyed children, most drawn in pencil on paper. His favorite portrait is called ``Natasha and her dog Pif.'' ``This is a very nice-looking girl, but she thinks she is not beautiful and she suffers very much. This dog very much resembles its owner,'' Kumankov said. Since he drew Natasha, he said, ``her parents never called again.'' Why? Because the picture was published all over the Soviet Union and ``some journalists wrote a letter saying `Dear Natasha, don't worry, one day you'll be beautiful and you will not resemble your dog anymore.''' Kumankov looks the part of the artist, with longish red hair, glasses and big bow ties he says he likes because 19th century painters wore them. Almost totally deaf, he also wears two hearing aids. He is not expecting his life to change because of his unexpected encounter with Raisa Gorbachev. ``I'm interested in doing more art,'' he said, ``and that's exactly what I have been doing for the past 10 years.''
DOC.HEAD: Summit Press Center Far From Plush
DOC.TEXT: The United States Information Agency office is in a racquetball court. The food service is in a weight room. And the briefing room is in a basketball arena, complete with cement, bleachers and ceiling pipes. The international press center for this year's contingent of summit journalists is a little different than the pampering and plush service of 1987. The J.W. Marriott went all out that year. The press had its own marble ballroom with crystal chandeliers. The hotel provided free coffee and sodas, plus press releases on how much coffee and sodas journalists had consumed. ``It was beautiful,'' reminisced Victor Karasin, an aide in the Soviet press office. ``We even had the Glasnost Cafe on the ground floor.'' The Smith Center at George Washington University does have the Summit Minimart for those needing aspirin or souvenirs, but it's not the same. The food service, a carryout in a cinder-block workout room, serves exotic dishes such as styrofoam plates of egg salad and cardboard boxes of cereal. Reporters can be seen tripping on the floor of the briefing center, which has been covered with large, taped-together pieces of carpet in varying shades of gray, punctuated by inexplicable subterranean bumps and slightly raised wooden platforms. The many TV cameras in the room, however, are focused on an attractive wooden podium backed by large U.S. and Soviet flags. On television, it all looks fine.

DOC.HEAD: Segregation of All Public Amenities to End by October
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with further details on the legislation, background on earlier reforms. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The government introduced legislation today that would repeal the Separate Amenities Act, a pillar of apartheid that has allowed racial segregation of all public amenities for nearly 40 years. The legislation, which would take effect Oct. 15, will be submitted to Parliament on Monday, where it is expected pass by mid-June, the South African Press Associated reported. Since 1953, the Separate Amenities Act has authorized provincial governments, municipalities and privately owned entertainment establishments to reserve facilities for whites. If the law is repealed, public bathrooms, libraries and transporation _ as well as privately owned restaurants and nightclubs _ could no longer be segregated. Many public amenities already have been integrated in Johannesburg, but dated laws remain on the books. The effort to repeal the Separate Amenities Act was the latest move by President F.W. de Klerk to end apartheid. He has said he intends to give South Africa's black majority the vote by 1994, but he has stopped short of endorsing black majority rule. The largest white opposition party, the Conservative Party, is the only parliamentary group expected to oppose repealing the Separate Amenities Act. But the party does not have enough votes to block it. Hernus Kriel, minister of provincial affairs and planning, said the legislation would not take effect until October to give those affected time to prepare for the changes. Kriel said that if the act is repealed, no South African individual or institution would enjoy legal protection for discrimination on the basis of race in any facility generally open to the public. Apartheid, the system of racial separation and white minority domination, was encoded into law by the National Party when it came to power in 1948. Other pillars of the system that remain are laws that reserve most of the country's land for white ownership and put power in the hands of the white minority by denying a national vote to blacks. Since taking office in September, de Klerk has legalized dozens of outlawed black political organizations, freed scores of political prisoners, legalized a few, small multiracial neighborhoods, suspended the death penalty, ended segregation of beaches and ordered the end of segregated hospitals. Still, de Klerk opposes one-person, one-vote majority rule and suggests a system where cultural, social and ethnic groups could be sure to have representation in the government. The Conservative Party and white extremist organizations have denounced de Klerk's actions as treason to the white Afrikaners who control the government. Some have said they are willing to defend their rights under apartheid with force, if necessary. Opening government and entertainment facilities to whites would partly depend on government employees, many of whom support the Conservative Party or generally oppose the rapid changes taking place. Two weeks ago, Health Minister Rina Venter announced that segregation of all hospitals had ended. However, this week, the administrator of the country's 44 white hospitals gave his interpretation of that order. He said hospitals designated for whites would continue to give preference in admission to white patients because they are residents of the area where the hospitals are located. Although segregation at government-run resorts and recreation areas officially ended months ago, blacks, Indians and people of mixed race continue to be turned away. Some local administrators of the resorts say they have not yet received the official government orders telling them to admit people who are not white.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Asks Japan to Help Fund $8 Billion Supercollider
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 2 grafs to CORRECT secretary's surname to Moore, sted Morre. Pickup 3rd pvs, ``We have...''
DOC.TEXT: U.S. officials are asking Japan to help pick up the tab for an $8 billion superconducting supercollider that could answer basic questions about th nature of matter and the origin of the universe. Deputy Secretary of Energy Henson Moore, who is heading a visiting U.S. delegation, told reporters he would present a letter from President Bush to Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu, inviting Japan to become a partner in the supercollider project to be built in Texas. ``We have asked Japan to be the first country to participate ... because of their technical expertise ... and also because they have the capability of being a partner,'' Moore said. ``The size and the expense of building this project is such that no one country can do it alone,'' he added. ``And we believe that for it to be a scientific success, it must be an international project.'' Moore did not specify the amount the U.S. government wants Japan to contribute. The Kyodo News Service reported that the United States wants Japan to allocate $1 billion for the project. Backers say the racetrack-shaped supercollider, which would encircle Waxahachie, Texas with a 54-mile tunnel, would be the world's most powerful particle accelerator and its largest scientific instrument. The Department of Energy says the supercollider's 12,000 superconducting magnets will produce a magnetic field 150,000 times as strong as Earth's and send streams of protons smashing against each other at nearly the speed of light to break them into subatomic particles. Scientists then would study the tiny pieces of matter produced in hopes of finding previously unobservable particlesthat would provide clues to how the universe began. Scientists say such intensely powerful collisions will approximate the ``big bang'' explosion that some believe created the universe. The cost of the project has grown from an initial $4.4 billion to about $8 billion. Earlier this month, the U.S. House of Representatives authorized $5 billion in spending over several years on the supercollider, and Texas agreed to provide about $1 billion to get the project. The government hopes that the remaining $2 billion will come largely from foreign sources, Department of Energy officials said. Some U.S. congressmen have demanded Japan bear a large portion of the cost because of its trade imbalance with the United States, but others have warned that foreign involvement would result in a giving away U.S. technology. Moore said the United States wanted Japan as a partner because of its ability to contribute both scientifically and financially to the project. Moore said Japan also has shown ``an understanding of the need to spend more on basic research.'' Japan spends less of its gross national product than the United States on basic scientific research, but more on applied research. It frequently has taken the discoveries of basic research conducted elsewhere and developed them into new consumer products. Participation in research projects at the superconducting supercollider would be open to any nation, regardless of whether it helps fund it, as is true with most such particle accelerators, Moore said. Department of Energy officials said up to half the accelerator's magnets could be provided by Japan, which already has developed a prototype of a magnetically levitated train that uses superconducting magnets. Each cylindrical magnet will be 45-feet-long and weigh 13.2 tons, the department says. After a week in Japan, the U.S. delegation is to visit South Korea to seek its participation in the project. The only country that has already officially agreed to participate is India, which pledged $50 million. The world's most powerful collider is a 17-mile ring near Geneva that was completed last year. The U.S. delegation here made the funding request at meetings with Education Minister Kosuke Hori; Tomoji Oshima, director general of the Science and Technology Agency; and Ichiji Ishii, deputy foreign minister.

DOC.HEAD: Rembrandt Painting Fails To Sell; Price Below Seller's Expectation
DOC.TEXT: A Rembrandt painting of a remorseful St. Peter failed to sell because the highest bid at auction was lower than the minimum price set by the seller, Christie's auction house said. The bidding on ``St. Peter Repentant'' stopped Thursday at $9.5 million, said Dana Micucci, a spokeswoman for Christie's. The 1631 painting had been estimated to be worth at least $10 million. Micucci said sellers usually set a reserve price ``a little bit below the low estimate.'' ``St. Peter Repentant'' was the first Rembrandt painting put on the auction block since the artist's ``Portrait of a Girl Wearing a Gold-trimmed Cloak'' fetched $10.38 million in 1986. The St. Peter painting, a 23-by-18-inch oil on oak panel, was put up for auction by an anonymous private American collector. ``I was quite surprised it didn't sell,'' said Ian Kennedy, director of Old Master collections at Christie's. ``I didn't think it would be that easy, but I thought we would manage to do it.'' Kennedy said the picture's present owner bought it about two years ago from a Belgian family. Doris Athineos, a Christie's spokeswoman, said the auction house did not know how much the present owner had paid for it. Old Master paintings typically do not fetch the premium prices paid at auction for Impressionist and modern paintings, Kennedy said. ``The Old Masters are rather dark. People like bright-colored pictures,'' Kennedy explained. ``It's also the subject matter. Old Masters are more religious and serious. People prefer subject matter that is less demanding.'' The record price for an Old Master painting is $35.2 million, paid by the Getty Museum in Malibu, Calif., last year for a portrait of Duke Cosimo I de' Medici by Pontormo. Contemporary, Impressionist and modern sales in May posted record prices for works of masterpiece quality. Van Gogh's ``Portrait of Dr. Gachet'' sold for $82.5 million, the highest price ever paid for a painting at auction. Two days later, Renoir's depiction of an open-air dance hall fetched $78.1 million. Both paintings were bought by a Japanese businessman.

DOC.HEAD: Coke Ends `MagiCan' Promotion Because of Mechanical Problems
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Adds 5 grafs at end with comment from Beverage Digest publisher and more comment from Donaldson. Version moved on financial wires.
DOC.TEXT: The Coca-Cola Co. has scrapped its ``MagiCan'' promotion because of complaints of prizes that failed to pop out of cans and leaks of foul-tasting chlorinated water. The Atlanta-based soft drink company had planned to distribute 750,000 of the special cans throughout the summer, but spokesman Randy Donaldson confirmed Thuursday the shipments had been halted after about 200,000 were shipped. The randomly distributed cans looked like regular cans of Coca-Cola Classic but contained a mechanism that ejected either cash or prize certificates. The bottom end of the can was filled with chlorinated water to make it feel like the real thing. But some consumers reported that the prize mechanism jammed, keeping it from ejecting. And in some cases the chlorinated water, which tastes bad but is harmless, leaked. Though Coke received only about 70 complaints about defective cans, Donaldson said, ``There is the impression we don't like among our consumers that there is a problem with the promotion.'' ``We are winding it down early,'' Donaldson said. The cancellation came one week after Coca-Cola ran full-page advertisements in newspapers across the nation acknowledging the problems and explaining how the prize cans work. Donaldson said television ads are telling consumers that only a few prize cans are left on the market and that they will be ``going, going, gone by mid-June.'' Jesse Meyers, publisher of the soft drink industry trade publication Beverage Digest, said Coca-Cola had little choice but to end the promotion in view of the publicity. ``Once again, perception is greater than reality,'' Meyers said. ``I think it is the right move, because the soft drink industry has a golden bond with the consumer,'' he said. ``And whatever the reality may be, the perception has to be that the quality has to be better than the norm of any other food product.'' Other aspects of the ``Magic Summer'' promotion, which began May 7, are to continue, Donaldson said.

DOC.HEAD: Flash Flood Inundates Nearly 200 Homes in Vicksburg, Miss.
LaserPhoto JX3
DOC.TEXT: Fire trucks pumped high-pressure streams into homes today to wash away mud and debris left by flash flooding that sent several feet of water into subdivisions in this Mississippi River town. ``I've been back to my home and everything is turned over and destroyed,'' said Hope Williams, who spent Thursday night with her six children at an emergency shelter. ``That was my first year in the subdivision and I hope it was my last year _ I mean, water was six feet deep in that house.'' Williams, whose children range in age from 2 to 17, said ``the only thing we can do now is put together what we've got left and try to move from down there.'' About 200 people were evacuated from low-lying homes during Thursday's flooding. Vicksburg-Warren County Civil Defense chief Luther Warnock Jr. said today that 187 homes and two businesses were flooded before water receded late Thursday. The National Weather Service said the area was hit with about 7 inches of rain. No injuries were reported, said Warren County Sheriff Paul Barrett. ``We were lucky,'' he said. ``We packed some people out on our backs and some out in boats, but we didn't lose anybody.'' Barrett said some residents could probably return to their houses today, but others may have to wait through the weekend. Warnock said he had been in Vicksburg for 30 years and ``while a lot of the areas flooded Thursday had flooded before, this was the worst flooding we've had in a flash flood. People I've talked to say they've never seen anything like this before.'' City and county officials met today to issue formal disaster declarations, the first step in seeking state and federal disaster funds. Warnock said officials were still estimating damage, ``and we expect quite a lot.'' He said the water also damaged bridges and roadways in the county of 50,000 people. Gov. Ray Mabus declared a state of emergency in Warren County late Thursday. The Mississippi National Guard was placed on standby but Warnock said the guardsmen were not needed.

DOC.HEAD: Yeltsin Promises Ties With Lithuania, Moldavia Gives Recognition
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 2nd pvs, `Yeltsin's offer...' with 3 grafs to CLARIFY that Yeltsin has not explicitly promised to provide goods to Lithuania. Pickup 3rd graf, `Yeltsin, who...'
DOC.TEXT: Boris N. Yeltsin, the president of the Russian Federation, promised his Lithuanian counterpart today he will foster close ties between his huge republic and the secessionist Baltic region, Lithuanian sources said. Yeltsin's offer represents a slap in the face for Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, who ordered an economic blockade against Lithuania in an effort to force it to back off its March independence declaration. If Russia were to resume supplying Lithuania with gas, oil and other raw materials, it would mean the virtual end of the Kremlin's sanctions _ without Gorbachev's consent. But Yeltsin has not explicitly said he intends to provide such goods to Lithuania. Morever, it is not clear whether his republic could gain practical authority to do so, even if it adopts an autonomy plan championed by Yeltsin. Yeltsin, who was elected president of the Russian republic Tuesday, met with Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis for ``a very friendly talk with full mutual understanding,'' said Natasha Boganova, secretary of the Lithuanian representation in Moscow, where the two met. ``Yeltsin is prepared, as soon as Russia gets its sovereignty, to cooperate fully with the Baltic republics, and Lithuania first of all,'' she said. Lithuania, struggling to circumvent the blockade, has been seeking direct ties with newly elected radical leaders in various parts of the country. On Thursday, the legislature of the republic of Moldavia recognized Lithuania's independence, the official Tass news agency reported, making it the first Soviet republic outside the Baltics to do so. The move represented another challenge to Gorbachev's efforts to isolate Lithuania from the rest of the Soviet Union. Gorbachev has demanded Lithuania suspend its declaration of independence before the blockade can be lifted and talks begun. Lithuanian lawmakers have offered compromise measures, but they refuse to suspend the declaration. Landsbergis plans to meet with delegates from Moscow and Leningrad, where radicals have taken over the city administrations, and delegates from other parts of Russia, the Lithuanian parliament's information service said. Yeltsin has said he expects the Russian parliament to declare the Russian Federation's sovereignty within the first 100 days of his term. The Russian Federation is the Soviet Union's largest republic, with two-thirds of its territory and just over half its population. Sovereignty would mean republic authorities would have the final say over which Soviet laws are valid on Russian territory, and greater independence in general from the national government. But even if a Russian-Baltic accord is worked out, it might not be soon enough for the Lithuanians, who are racing to establish alternate sources of supply before their fuel runs out altogether. About 46,000 people have been laid off and eight factories closed because of the blockade, Lithuanian radio has reported. Many residents of Vilnius, the Lithuanian capital, have been without hot water for weeks. Lithuanian radio reported that Poland will begin supplying the republic with cooking oil and sugar _ at steeper prices than Soviet suppliers commanded. In neighboring Latvia, which declared May 4 it had begun its move toward independence, rationing of several food staples began today, Tass said. The Kremlin has not extended its economic sanctions to Latvia, but residents fearing a blockade began panic-buying after the May 4 declaration. Yeltsin said repeatedly during his election campaign that he would seek direct ties with Lithuania, Latvia, and Estonia, which is also seeking independence. Today's meeting was his first reported concrete move to begin establishing those ties. Tass said Thursday that deputies of the Moldavian Supreme Soviet, meeting in the capital, Kishinev, favored the establishment of direct diplomatic, economic, political and cultural relations with Lithuania. The legislature also proposed to exchange ``permanent missions'' with the Lithuanian parliament, or Supreme Council, Tass said. The report did not give vote totals on the measure. So far, only Latvia and Estonia have formally acted to cooperate on such levels with Lithuania. On May 12, the three Baltic republics revived a 1934 political alliance pledging mutual cooperation.

DOC.HEAD: NASA Still Searching for Fuel Leak; Launch Put Back Another Week
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Rewrites throughout to UPDATE with launch until week after next, details on leak search. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The space shuttle Columbia's astronomy mission is off until at least the week after next while NASA continues to search for a hydrogen leak in the shuttle's rear engine compartment. ``It doesn't look like we're going to launch next week,'' NASA spokesman Bruce Buckingham said today. ``It's reasonable to assume, with the work we have yet to do and the fact that we haven't isolated the exact location of the leak yet.'' If workers cannot find the leak, or it cannot be repaired on the launch pad, Columbia will have to be rolled back to a hangar for a complete inspection. That would mean a delay of about a month for the first shuttle mission in five years devoted entirely to scientific research. ``I hope we don't have to roll back, but I can tell you we will roll back if we have to, if the problem is that serious,'' NASA administrator Richard Truly said Thursday. Workers found a tiny leak in the rear engine compartment Thursday, but judged it too small to have been the source of the hydrogen leak that delayed Wednesday morning's launch, Buckingham said. After the launch was scrubbed, officials had said it would take at least a week _ that is, until next Wednesday _ to find and repair the leak and prepare for another launch. Now with continuing problems finding the leak, the launch is off at least until the week after that, Bukingham said. The search continued until late Thursday afternoon, then was halted so Columbia's on-board fuel tanks could be drained. Officials today further increased pressure on the shuttle's external tank, which was drained of fuel and filled with nonflammable helium, to find the main leak. Engineers are now fairly certain the leak is in or near a 17-inch valve in a pipe that carries fuel from the shuttle's external tank to its main engines, Buckingham said. Traces of helium were found early today in a tight cavity between two metal plates that connect the shuttle and its external tank, he said. If the leak is in that cavity, ``It would be an extremely difficult area to repair at the pad,'' Buckingham said. ``But nothing at this point has been ruled out.'' If the leak is not pinpointed today, helium may be circulated through the shuttle's entire fuel system Saturday, Buckingham said. The next step would be to use super-cold liquid hydrogen in an attempt to duplicate the conditions under which the leak was detected six hours before launch while liquid hydrogen and oxygen were being loaded. Preparations were under way for the liquid hydrogen test, which is scheduled for the middle of next week, Buckingham said. Columbia's astronomy mission, with a $150 million observatory called Astro, already had been delayed two weeks for repairs to the shuttle's cooling system.

DOC.HEAD: Embattled Liberian Leader Says He Will Not Stand for Re-election
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with Doe saying he won't stand for re-elections, details of news conference. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: President Samuel Doe, hemmed in by an advancing rebel army, announced today he will not run for re-election, and he asked the United States and other nations to help end his nation's civil war. U.S. military officials said 2,100 Marines aboard four ships of the U.S. Navy's 6th Fleet stood off the Liberian coast to protect property and lives of Americans and other foreign nationals and, if necessary, to evacuate people. The rebels, from the National Patriotic Front of Liberia, are seeking Doe's ouster. They accuse his administration of corruption, economic mismanagement and human rights abuses. More than 1,000 people have been killed in six months of fighting, most of them civilians slain by government troops. Rebel leader Charles Taylor said in an interview with the British Broadcasting Corp. on Thursday that his fighters would not stop until they had taken Monrovia, the capital, and formed their own government. Rebel troops already control the country's main port of Buchanan, 95 miles east of the capital, and were advancing on two fronts within 35 miles of Monrovia. Thousands of people have fled the city. At a news conference today, Doe said: ``I wish to announce here today my firm decision not to stand for the 1991 general elections.'' ``Accordingly, I hereby appeal to our traditional friends, the United States government and other friendly counties, to bring to an end this 6-month-old, Libyan-backed incursion in order to pave the way for a peaceful, free and fair election in 1991,'' he said. The news conference also was attended by legislators who for months have tried to persuade Doe to not seek another term. ``It's too little, too late,'' said one diplomat, who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``Six months ago, this might have helped.'' U.S. Embassy officials said about 2,000 U.S. citizens, including scores of missionaries and many people of Liberian origin, remain in the country. Thousands of expatriates fled last month. Late Thursday, the U.S. State Department issued a travel advisory warning that conditions in Liberia were deteriorating and ordering all non-essential U.S. personnel to leave immediately. Cmdr. David Thomas, a spokesman for the Defense Department, said a U.S. flotilla was off the Liberian coast under orders to ``be prepared to evacuate American citizens in the event that they would no longer be able to leave the country by commercial means.'' Rebel ambushes this week on the road between Buchanan and the main international airport, 35 miles from Monrovia, have prompted many airlines to cancel flights. Thomas said the flotilla includes a destroyer, an amphibious assault ship, a tank landing ship and other support vessels carrying ammunition and combat supplies. Aboard the ships were 179 Marine officers and 2,102 enlisted men, Thomas said. Doe told reporters the U.S. 6th Fleet set sail ``with the approval of the government of Liberia.'' He appeared relaxed at the news conference and impervious to the threat from the advancing rebels. ``Remember that tough times don't last, only tough people do,'' said Doe, who celebrated his 40th birthday and 10 years in power this year. He sidestepped questions about unruly soldiers who have killed more than a dozen people in the capital in tribal reprisals against people of the Gio and Mano tribes. Many of the rebels belong to those tribes, and Doe's soldiers also are accused of killing hundreds of Gio and Mano civilians in the countryside. ``I am in full control of the army,'' he said. U.N. officials were evacuated on Thursday, a day after government soldiers allegedly attacked the U.N. compound, where 1,000 refugees from tribes that support the rebels had gathered to seek protection and safe conduct out of the country. U.N. spokesman Francois Giuliani said about eight masked soldiers killed a guard and abducted about 30 people. The bodies of three abducted men and a youth were found later dumped outside the capital. Doe denied responsibility and said he would punish those responsible. U.N. officials moved all the refugees to a nearby Lutheran Church compound, where they remained today. Doe said his government was discussing with the United Nations and the Carter Center in Atlanta set up by former President Jimmy Carter initiatives ``to actively intervene in the restoration of peace in Liberia and to help us start the process leading to the election.'' Doe said he decided not to run for the presidency after the national legislature this week turned down his request to hold early elections and set up an interim government. Legislators said they wanted Doe to resign. Doe said he had survived 35 or 36 coup attempts and would be happy to leave the ``burden of leading a country ... the political harassment'' to somebody else. He seized power in a bloody 1980 coup that ousted elitist descendants of American slaves who discriminated against native Liberians. Liberia, a country of 2 million, was founded in 1847. The current rebellion began Dec. 24 with an invasion of 200 rebels from the Ivory Coast. What started as a minor rebellion escalated into a war because government attacks against civilians won the rebels thousands of recruits. The West African nation has great strategic importance for the United States. It is the base for all diplomatic messages to and from U.S. missions in Africa. There is a huge Voice of America transmission station a few miles from Monrovia, and the country also has a powerful Omega marine transmitter responsible for guiding all U.S. shipping in the Atlantic Ocean.

DOC.HEAD: PLO Involvement in Guerrilla Raid a Blow to Peace Prospects
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 7-17 grafs pvs, `The attack...the attack.' with 13 grafs to ADD faction saying its targets are all military, Israeli official saying Arafat probably didn't know of attack beforehand. Pickup 18th, `The extent...'
DOC.HEAD: An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: The attempted attack on Israeli beaches and hotels by PLO guerrillas has delivered another stinging blow to the prospects for Middle East peacemaking. Israelis across a wide political spectrum were angered by the attack and said it eroded PLO chairman Yasser Arafat's credibility as a peacemaker. Arafat said Thursday the PLO was not responsible for the raid. Even though the army foiled the attack, killing four guerrillas and capturing 12, it was viewed as a chillingly narrow escape for Israeli civilians. Tens of thousands of Israelis had gone to the coast to swim and picnic on the Jewish holiday of Shavuot. During a call-in show on army radio, a series of Israelis vented their feelings. One woman said the soldiers should have killed the guerrillas instead of capturing them. ``Why don't we just cut them down for God's sake? Why do I need these murderous terrorists in the state of Israel where we have to guard over them?'' Asher Susser, a Middle East expert at Tel Aviv University, said the attack reflected a basic fallacy in the PLO's strategy _ aiming its policy toward the United States and Western countries instead of trying to make Israelis more receptive to Arafat's peace proposals. ``It's a radical example of what has been a universal failing in the PLO leadership,'' he said. ``That is the need to make a serious effort to see Israeli society as the target of their policy instead of trying to bring the rest of world opinion crashing down on Israel.'' The Palestine Liberation Front, a PLO faction headed by Mohammed Abbas, also known as Abul Abbas, claimed responsibility for the attack. In a statement issued in Baghdad, the front said today that its targets were only military. A prominent Palestinian figure in Jerusalem, Faisal Husseini, questioned whether the targets were civilian or military but conceded the impact would ultimately be ``a step backward, a negative one.'' The involvement of a PLO faction strengthened the hand of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, who immediately called on Washington to abandon the dialogue it began with the PLO on Dec. 15, 1988. The Bush administration has unsuccessfully sought to involve Israel in talks with a PLO-approved delegation of Palestinians as a first step toward peace. Shamir objected to any role for the PLO, even an indirect one. Foreign Minister Moshe Arens said on Israel Television, ``I assume that we won't hear any more from the American administration about how the PLO is not a terror organization or that Yasser Arafat has abandoned terror.'' He made his comments before Arafat said in Baghdad on Thursday that the PLO was not involved in the attempted attack. The White House on Thursday condemned the foiled attack as a ``cowardly attempt to target innocent people.'' But when asked if the United States was reviewing its dialogue with the PLO in light of the failed attack, White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater replied, ``No, not at this point.'' The United States opened its dialogue with the PLO after Arafat renounced terrorism in December 1988. Security sources said Israel sent transcripts of interrogations and other supporting evidence to Washington to prove the intent of the guerrillas and PLO involvement. Israeli officials initially claimed Abbas, who masterminded the 1985 hijacking of the cruise liner Achille Lauro, had met Arafat in Tunisia five days before the attack. However, in an interview published today by the Yediot Ahronot daily, Israel's top military intelligence chief said Arafat probably did not know beforehand about the seaborne raid. ``We don't have information pointing to the fact that he knew ahead of time,'' Maj. Gen. Amnon Shahak was quoted as saying. The extent to which Arafat renounced terrorism is a subject of debate. In his speech to the United Nations in Geneva in 1988, he recognized Israel and condemned ``terrorism in all its forms.'' At the same time, however, he endorsed the 1985 Cairo declaration, which left open the possibility of hitting military targets in Israeli-held territory. Despite the qualification, a report released by Shamir's anti-terror adviser, Yigal Carmon, said that the U.S. ambassador assured Israel that ``no American administration can sustain the dialogue if terrorism continues by the PLO or any of its factions.'' The message from the American ambassador at that time, Thomas Pickering, also said the PLO was required to ``publicly disassociate yourselves from terrorism by any Palestinian group operating anywhere.'' To date, Israeli officials claim PLO groups have been involved in 16 of the attempted 21 acts of terror carried out by Palestinian groups in Israel since Arafat renounced terrorism. One was a recent attempt by Arafat's Fatah faction to plant a car bomb on Jerusalem's Jaffa Road, a major shopping street, they said. Yossi Olmert, head of the Government Press Office, said the attempted raid Wednesday was part of an overall increase in Arab-Israeli tensions that has developed in recent weeks. ``There is an amosphere of war talk and war mongering. If you start talking about war, you create a climate where there is more tension than before,'' he said.
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Nicolas B. Tatro is chief of The AP bureau in Israel and has covered Middle East affairs for more than 10 years.

DOC.HEAD: Arafat Denies Responsibility for Attempted Raid on Israel
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS spelling of guerrilla in lead. Inserts two grafs after 12th, `Israeli officials...' to ADD Israeli official saying Arafat probably didn't know about raid beforehand. Pickup 13th, `Asked whether...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Israel-Peace
DOC.TEXT: PLO chief Yasser Arafat has denied Israeli allegations that the PLO was involved in an attempted guerrilla attack on Israel's crowded coastline, but he did not condemn the act. Arafat also said Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's policies toward the Palestinians were the main cause of tension in the area. ``I have always warned that Israeli violence against my people will lead to a situation of instability and will lead to reactions,'' Arafat said Thursday. In Washington, the White House rebuffed Israel's plea to end all contacts with the Palestine Liberation Organization in the wake of the attack. But White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater condemned the action, and said: ``We are deeply concerned about the responsibility for this attack and we are looking into it.'' Other officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, stressed that no decision had been made on whether to keep talking with the PLO. The Palestine Liberation Front, a PLO faction, claimed responsibility for the attempted raid Wednesday. Israeli forces foiled the raid as the guerrillas headed for the Israeli coast in speedboats. The beaches near Tel Aviv were filled with Israelis celebrating the Jewish holiday Shavuot. The PLF is headed by Mohammed Abbas, also known as Abul Abbas. He masterminded the 1985 hijacking of the Italian cruise ship Achille Lauro. Asked whether he would expel Abbas from the elected PLO Executive Committee, Arafat said: ``He was elected in a democratic way by the Palestine National Council, and only the council has a say on that.'' Arafat, chairman of the PLO and recognized by Arab countries as president of a state of Palestine, said ``we are a democratic organization and decisions should be taken democratically.'' Israeli officials have urged the United States to suspend its 17-month dialogue with the PLO. They say the raid proved Arafat had violated his 1988 pledge to renounce terrorism. That pledge led the United States to open a dialogue with the PLO. Israeli officials claim Abbas met Arafat in Tunisia five days before the attempted raid. However, in an interview published today by the Yediot Ahronot daily, Israel's top military intelligence chief said Arafat probably did not know beforehand about the seaborne raid. ``We don't have information pointing to the fact that he knew ahead of time,'' Maj. Gen. Amnon Shahak was quoted as saying. Asked whether he condemned the raid, Arafat told reporters, ``We in the PLO are not responsible for the operation and we have no connection with it.'' Asked again if he could give a flat statement condemning the raid, Arafat responded, ``What I declared was clear and obvious.'' Queried another time, he said, ``When I say that we have no connection with this raid, I mean the PLO forces.'' Arafat said the raid could be used by Israel as a pretext to attack Arab countries in retaliation, even though no Israeli casualties were reported Wednesday. Four Palestinian guerrillas were killed and 12 were captured. State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said Wednesday that if the PLO were behind the attack, the United States would ``view this as a very serious matter.'' The extent to which Arafat renounced violence is a subject of debate. In his speech to the United Nations in Geneva in 1988, he recognized Israel and condemned ``terrorism in all its forms.'' At the same time, however, he endorsed the 1985 Cairo declaration, which left open the possibility of hitting military targets in Israeli-held territory.

DOC.HEAD: Prisoners Riot, 70 Treated for Smoke and Tear Gas Inhalation
DOC.TEXT: Fifteen to 20 Cuban detainees rioted at a jail, smashing a wall, setting fires and throwing chunks of concrete at guards before authorities used tear gas to regain control, deputies said. Two guards and four prisoners suffered minor injuries during the 20-minute melee Thursday at the Avoyelles Parish jail, and about 70 prisoners were treated for inhalation of smoke and tear gas, deputies said. The disturbance, in a dormitory that houses 72 Cuban prisoners held for the federal Immigration and Naturalization Service, began when one became angry at the guard waking inmates, deputies said. During the violence, 15 to 20 of the Cuban inmates smashed a cinder-block partition wall with metal footlockers, threw pieces of concrete at guards and ignited the contents of several trash cans, deputies said. The deputy who had been waking up the inmates was temporarily trapped inside the dorm with the rampaging prisoners, deputies said. He was hit on the head with a piece of concrete, said the chief deputy, Maj. Harry Lemoine. Chief Detective Bob Venable said the inmates were attempting to barricade a door leading to the dormitory when deputies used a canister of tear gas to quell the upheaval. Damage to the jail was confined to broken windows and the smashed wall, Venable said. The same dormitory was the site of an intense skirmish involving Cuban prisoners in June 1988 in which nine deputies and 14 prisoners were hurt. Immigration spokesman Russ Bergeron said the detainees involved in Thursday's incident came to this country in the ``freedom flotilla'' boatlift from the Cuban port of Mariel in 1980. Some of those refugees were placed in detention because their immigration status in the United States is in jeopardy because of crimes. The detainees are awaiting a review of their cases by the INS and the Department of Justice. Mariel Cubans were sent to various parish jails in Louisiana after the November 1987 riots in the Federal Detention Center in Oakdale. In eight days of rioting, while 28 employees were held hostage, much of the $17 million complex was burned down. It was rebuilt.

DOC.HEAD: Five-Day Prison Revolt Ends in Hamburg
LaserPhoto HBG4
DOC.TEXT: A five-day prison revolt by up to 250 inmates ended today when the mutineers surrendered. The revolt started on Monday, as inmates climbed atop a roof at the Fuhlsbuettel prison to protest conditions there and refused to move. The number of inmates fluctuated during the revolt from a high of 250. On Thursday night, 13 inmates remained on the roof after the others had returned to their cells. Tensions rose during the night as some inmates ripped off five prison doors and started throwing objects around, said Hamburg Justice Senator Wolfgang Curilla. This morning, 80 prison guards wearing protective helmets marched into the prison and were able to lock up the inmates without any resistance, said Curilla. One inmate stayed on the roof, hurling stones to try to keep guards away, Curilla said. Eventually, he was forcibly taken away. Curilla did not say whether there were any injuries in the revolt.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Pours on the Charm
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail Gorbachev is pouring on the charm, disarming critics and admirers with his candor and telling average Americans on the street he feels ``really at home'' with them despite U.S.-Soviet differences. ``All people,'' he said in one sidewalk exchange Thursday, ``want a better tomorrow. And the rest is not too important.'' Whether teasing Henry Kissinger at an embassy lunch, parrying with reporters at the White House, or spontaneously departing his motorcade to shake hands with tourists and federal workers, Gorbachev went about town surprising and delighting his audiences. As if summitry were an afterthought, he kept President Bush waiting at the White House late this morning while he answered questions from congressional leaders who accepted his invitation for breakfast at the Soviet Embassy. The lawmakers have tried to hold up a U.S.-Soviet trade agreement until Gorbachev ends a partial economic embargo against Lithuania. Gorbachev defended his refusal to let the Baltic republic secede without a popular referendum. The Soviet president also explained in great detail his decision to make people in his homeland embrace a market economy by tripling the price of bread, one commodity in plentiful supply. The televised give-and-take showed Gorbachev willing to engage American legislators in a forum he has not afforded those in his own country. He made light of his differences with Bush, saying both men were open to discussion of the issues on which they couldn't agree. ``We have a good mutual understanding with the president, even if sometimes we draw different conclusions,'' he told reporters who had staked out the White House driveway. ``We both have a willingness to listen, and so our dialogue is very substantive.'' ``We want to further our relationship,'' the Soviet president said. Bush, too, was impressed by the man he was meeting as a summit partner for the second time. ``I feel very comfortable with him,'' the American president said at the end of the first day of their formal talks. ``I feel very free to bring up positions that I know he doesn't agree with.'' ``I'm very pleased with that mood of his wanting to understand the U.S. position,'' Bush added. ``He's not trying to hide anything, nor is he trying to wring his hands,'' over challenges to his leadership. Gorbachev faces daunting problems at home, with some republics trying to secede, others torn by ethnic strife, and panicky consumers stripping store shelves in a stark demonstration of the lack of confidence in his economic reform plan. But if he has been weakened by the onslaught or the rise of maverick Boris N. Yeltsin as a political rival, Bush said it didn't show. ``There's a certain strength and confidence that was there in Malta (in December) and is there now,'' Gorbachev's counterpart said. ``I don't feel a weakened nature or anything of that nature. I feel a man who is determined to do his job.'' ``I believe that it shows that we have not been able for so long to realize our potential,'' Gorbachev told a luncheon he gave for an eclectic group of American intellectuals, entertainers, politicians and public figures. ``We are a huge nation speaking 120 languages, that means representing 120 nationalities, but that is not all.'' ``We'll figure out how to proceed in our country,'' he said. ``We haven't yet done that, but the main thing has been done. ...We have come to the conclusion that we cannot proceed as we have been doing all along.'' He didn't pretend to have all the answers and even admitted mistakes had been made, but he told his guests at the Soviet embassy, ``We'll have to travel down this road because we have no other choice, and the only thing to decide is how rapid our progress should be.'' ``Like never before, we want to be understood right now,'' he said. Former Secretary of State Kissinger, whom Gorbachev described as ``my old man who always contests things,'' was just one of several leading Americans the Soviet leader picked out at the luncheon for praise or gentle teasing. Kissinger later called him ``serene.'' Having warmed up on a sympathetic audience, Gorbachev invited some tougher customers to join him on Friday for a suerpower breakfast. Under fire in Congress for his embargo of Lithuania following that republic's March 11 declaration of independence, Gorbachev asked at least ten leading members of the House and Senate from both parties to discuss their concerns with him personally.

DOC.HEAD: Billboard Protester Not Indicted, Still Faces Misdemeanor Prosecution
DOC.TEXT: A county commissioner still faces prosecution for whitewashing alcohol and tobacco billboards in a church-group protest despite a grand jury's refusal to indict him, the district attorney says. Dallas County District Attorney John Vance said he can prosecute County Commissioner John Wiley Price on misdemeanor criminal mischief charges. Grand jurors Thursday declined to issue felony charges carrying a maximum 10-year prison term. Price, who is black, was the only person arrested in a March 18 protest involving at least a dozen people whitewashing billboards in a predominantly black neighborhood. The protest was part of a movement against the targeting of alcohol and tobacco products at black, Hispanic, female, blue-collar and inner-city consumers. After his arrest, Price defended his actions on television newscasts. In light of that, Vance said failing to prosecute would send the wrong message. ``He is representative of Dallas _ racist to the core,'' Price countered. ``If he wants to waste taxpayer money and turn this into a national trial, then so be it.'' But Vance said race had nothing to do with it. The misdemeanor charge carries a maximum one-year jail term and would not affect Price's ability to hold office. Price said the grand jury's decision not to indict was a significant victory for opponents of the tobacco and alcohol industries. ``I am ecstatic over the ruling,'' he said. ``The issue is larger than me, and it's larger than Dallas.'' Billboard company representatives were not happy. ``We hope it doesn't send a message out that the way to beat the drum for a particular cause is to break the law,'' said George Reynolds, president of the Outdoor Advertising Association of Dallas. Grand jury foreman Otto Fridia declined to comment on the panel's decision.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Asks Trade Help, Chides Congress for Baltics Link
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs, with editing.
DOC.TEXT: Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev chided congressional leaders today for linking favored trade status for his country to Moscow's handling of the Lithuanian drive for independence. At a meeting with a dozen Democrats and Republicans from Capitol Hill, Gorbachev accused the United States of having a double standard on intervening in the affairs of other countries. He pointed to the U.S. invasion of Panama last December. ``We have embarked on democratization,'' Gorbachev said. ``We are changing ... When we hear there is a debate in Congress about our affairs, this is resented in our society.'' He called Lithuania's bid for independence, which U.S. lawmakers have said must be resolved before trade concessions can be granted to the Soviet Union, ``a matter of sovereignty and national dignity'' for his country. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, defended the Panama invasion, saying it was different from Gorbachev's crackdown in the Baltic because the people in Panama favored the U.S. action. But Mitchell did not disagree when Gorbachev noted that President Bush has been inconsistent by granting unconditional most-favored-nation status to China, which a year ago brutally crushed a democracy movement. Gorbachev said opening trade channels would be an important political plus for him as he seeks to restructure the Soviet economy to a more Western model. He added, ``We cannot wait for Congress and the congressional leadership to mature. Congress is a problem right now.'' But he said he would not beg for concessions and that a sound, stable Soviet Union is in America's interests. ``We hear voices here in America saying ... `maybe the Soviet Union is so weak that we can defeat him with just one step.' That's not serious,'' Gorbachev said in televised opening remarks at the meeting at the Soviet Embassy with congressional leaders. ``I'm not going to ask for anything, to beg for anything, even when I, for example, raise important matters such as trade. And it's important for us now to expand trade because we are moving toward a market economy and it's important for us to have the Americans participating in that process. ``But certainly we are not asking for a free ride. We will be asking for normal credits, and of course we will be paying, and paying the interest. For us it would humiliating if we were to ask, to beg for something from you.'' ``This is a genuine revolution,'' Gorbachev told the lawmakers, who sat around a long, green-felt-covered table. ``Please don't be frightened, because you can frighten us, too, if you get frightened.'' ``We have to turn around our brains, as it were,'' he said. ``This is a most difficult turnaround to make. Here, too, we hope we will find a mutual understanding and you will be able to find certain ways of supporting us, so that we could interact.'' ``Does the United States want (a) Soviet Union which is weak, torn by complexes and problems and turmoil? Or do you want a dynamic Soviet state that is open to the outside world... A realistically minded person can give only one answer,'' Gorbachev said. Among those at the meeting was House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., who stirred a political controversy earlier this year when he said it was time for the United States to consider offering direct economic aid to help ensure the success of Gorbachev and his reforms. ``Of course, the president of the United States has the dominant role in foreign policy,'' Gephardt said in advance of the meeting. ``But it is also important for Mr. Gorbachev to hear from members of Congress. We will be asked to approve trade and arms control agreements, and we most closely represent the views of the people who elect us.'' For Mitchell, the top-ranking lawmaker invited for the session at the Soviet Embassy, it was chapter 2 in a lively dialogue initiated with Gorbachev during a visit to Moscow in April. A day after that meeting, Gorbachev implemented his economic squeeze against breakaway Lithuania, a move Mitchell condemned as a breach of the Soviet president's promise to seek a political solution with all the Baltic states. Mitchell has been a strong proponent of most-favored-nation trading status for the Soviet Union. But following Gorbachev's economic crackdown on Lithuania, he helped push through a Senate resolution, approved 73-24 on May 1, which called on Bush to withhold a new U.S.-Soviet trade agreement until the sanctions are lifted and the Kremlin begins negotiations to recognize Lithuania's independence. Those standards are important ``to all Americans who value freedom and self-determination,'' Mitchell said. A trade agreement was proving to be one of the summit's difficult issues. Soviet spokesman Arkady Maslennikov on Thursday called U.S. reticence to conclude it ``quite unnatural'' and said it was ``in nobody's interest'' not to have an agreement.

DOC.HEAD: Family Hopes to Show Gorbachev Typical American Farm
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to restore dropped first reference to Greg Brand.
DOC.TEXT: Nothing's official yet, but word that Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev might visit their farm Sunday, maybe even sit at their picnic table, has the Brand family in turmoil. ``I'm kind of overwhelmed,'' said Greg Brand, 31, who operates the farm with his parents, Richard and Cecilia, and his 27-year-old brother, John. There was too little notice for the Brands to do a lot of preparation: about enough time to get the barn cleaned and the lawn mowed. If possible, they'd like to paint the picnic table. That's where the Brands hope to sit and talk with Gorbachev and his wife, Raisa, telling them about their family and the farm. The talk would shift to the kitchen table in the event of rain. ``I'll clean the house if I have time,'' said Mrs. Brand, who learned of the possible visit on Wednesday. ``We think of ours as a typical American farm and want to convey what American farm life is like,'' she said. ``We want to welcome them here. This is our opportunity to promote some little bit of international understanding.'' A farm stop had been suggested for Gorbachev's visit but later ruled out because he expected to spend only six hours in Minnesota. The prospect resurfaced Wednesday, however, and state agriculture officials came up with the Brand farm, in part because it's just 45 minutes from downtown Minneapolis and near the Minneapolis-St. Paul International Airport. Mrs. Brand said she had been told the Soviet president probably would arrive at the farm about 6:30 p.m. Sunday, after his meeting with business and agricultural leaders in downtown Minneapolis. How long he'll stay isn't clear, but it won't be long. Richard and Cecilia Brands have 75 dairy cows and raise alfalfa, corn and soybeans on the 240-acre farm they've held for 32 years. It's a picturesque farm with a large white barn, two white machine sheds and a two-story white house with black shutters where the elder Brands live. The Brands aren't strangers to the job of entertaining foreign visitors, and think that may be one reason they were chosen as potential hosts to the Gorbachevs. ``We do have a lot of foreign people who come here. We've had several Chinese and Japanese and quite a few European groups,'' Mrs. Brand said. The farm's easy access from the Twin Cities could help explain why state officials frequently steer visitors her way. Despite the farm's proximity to the city, the black and white Holsteins sunning themselves in a large meadow surrounded by electric fence present the perfect photo opportunity for a quick shot of rural America. The Gorbachevs, however, would be the first famous visitors. All the activity wasn't having much effect on Mrs. Brand's 4-year-old granddaughter, Allison, who was more interested in playing with the gray kitten that wandered up than with preparations for the Gorbachev visit. ``She just knows that the Russians are coming,'' said her mother, Brenda Brand.

DOC.HEAD: Two More Students Arrested, Security Tightened in Capital
DOC.TEXT: Three students were arrested for alleged ties to a secret anti-government group as part of tightened security prior to the anniversary of last year's crackdown on the democracy movement, fellow students said today. In another development, Chinese sources said three political activists who dropped out of sight Thursday were believed to be in official custody. Well-known singer Hou Dejian, university newspaper editor Gao Xin and scholar Zhou Duo had planned to deliver an open letter to Chinese leaders appealing for the release of political prisoners, including university professor Liu Xiaobo. Liu had joined the three in staging a hunger strike in the final days of last summer's democracy movement. Of the three students arrested May 25, two were undergraduates at Beijing University and a third was biophysics graduate student Peng Rong, other students said on condition of anonymity. They said Peng's arrest appeared related to a petition he and several other graduate students put up urging foreign governments to end economic sanctions. The other two students who were arrested were not involved in the petition. Fellow students identified one as Zheng Guanli of the economics department but said they did not know the name of the other one. All three were accused of having connections with an underground group outside Beijing that allegedly has engaged in counterrevolutionary activities, including distributing leaflets, fellow students said. They said student representatives from each university department were summoned to a meeting at which school authorities announced their arrests. Communist Party organizations in each department also have met recently to remind faculty to keep strict order with the approach of the June 3-4 anniversary of last year's military crackdown on student protesters. Teachers have been told they cannot take students on off-campus study trips until mid-June, and the school has scheduled several movies and dances to distract students over the weekend. On June 3-4, 1989, army troops backed by tanks shot their way into Beijing and crushed the student-led pro-democracy movement. Hundreds, and perhaps thousands, of unarmed civilians were killed. To maintain social order during the anniversary, security has been tightened in Beijing and other cities in recent weeks. The official press has carried numerous reports in the past week of arrests of vagrants and petty criminals and executions of robbers, murderers and rapists as well as an arsonist who set fire to an army jeep during last year's protests. Central Beijing's Tiananmen Square, which was the center of the democracy movement, will be closed to the public for the next three days. The Beijing Youth News said the square will be filled Saturday with tens of thousands of children celebrating International Children's Day. On Sunday, authorities plan ``a large activity to commemorate the 150th anniversary of the Opium War,'' the newspaper said without elaborating. And on Monday, June 4, 2,000 taxi drivers will gather on the huge square with their vehicles for training in preparation for the Asian Games, to be held in Beijing in September.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Proposes `Council of Europe' to Tackle German Issue
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 new grafs after pvs 3rd graf bgng, ``We are,'' with Gorbachev quote today; SUBS pvs 8th graf bgng, At one point, to delete ``this week;''TRIMS to tighten.
DOC.TEXT: Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, moving to break a summit stalemate over Germany's future, has proposed that the military role of a united Germany be decided by a new ``council of all Europe'' with direct U.S. and Soviet participation, U.S. sources said today. Gorbachev made the proposal to President Bush at their opening summit session on Thursday, the sources said, and the two leaders assigned their top diplomatic aides to pursue the concept next week in Copenhagen, Denmark, and again in Berlin two weeks later. ``We are prepared to work with it. It is not something we would reject out of hand,'' said one U.S. official familiar with the terms of the Soviet proposal, who spoke only on condition he not be identified. As he began his second day of summit talks with Bush, the Soviet leader was asked if assigning the German issue to a European council would allay his concerns about a revival of German militarism. ``The president and I are discussing precisely these matters, and I must say that this is a very substantive discussion, a discussion in which we are engaged in a spirit of great responsibility and cooperation,'' Gorbachev replied. Gorbachev's plan calls for annual meetings of the leaders of the 35 Western, neutral and Eastern states that make up the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe. There would be more frequent meetings of their foreign ministers, a permanent secretariat or administrative staff and creation of military and civilian ``conflict management'' centers. Bush and Gorbachev, in effect, agreed to disagree for the duration of their four-day summit on the military face of a united Germany, and are directing high-ranking aides to ``meld'' their concerns. U.S. analysts saw Gorbachev's proposal as stemming from his concerns over the unraveling of the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact and a desire to be included more prominently in European consultations. ``They are afraid that the process of German unification is increasing their isolation,'' one U.S. official said. Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze earlier had suggested placing a united Germany in both NATO and the Warsaw Pact, but the U.S. reaction was cool. Now Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Shevardnadze will explore the proposal for a new European council when they attend a human rights conference in Copenhagen next Tuesday and then at a meeting in Berlin tentativety set for June 22. ``They (the Soviets) want one game in which they are an equal player,'' said the U.S. official. ``It is not something we are opposed to in principle. It is an extension of ideas we are prepared to work with.'' The European security conference consists of 34 nations and the Vatican which signed the 1975 Helsinki agreement intended to east East-West tensions in Europe and promote human rights. An administration official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Bush was speaking to West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl by telephone today to assure him that the U.S. position on the future of a united Germany is unchanged as a result of the summit talk. The White House announced that Bush had invited Kohl to a White House dinner next Friday. A spokesman said the dinner was arranged before the summit and was not based on developments over the German issue. The official said Bush would seek to assure Kohl today and at the dinner next week that the United States supports the position taken by Kohl, who wants a unified Germany to be part of NATO. Meanwhile, Bush and Gorbachev were set to sign a declaration of basic agreement today to cut their long-range nuclear missiles, bombers and submarines, to pledge quick consideration of even deeper cuts and to announce an end to chemical weapons production. Bush and Gorbachev exchanged what the Soviet leader called new approaches on Thursday, and Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, said optimistically: ``The ideas presented amount to a way to meld the concerns of the United States and the Soviet Union.'' Later, after a state dinner at the White House, National Security Adviser Brent Scowcroft said the questions over Germany had produced ``a lively discussion'' at the afternoon meeting between the two presidents. But ``We're not there yet,'' he said, when asked of prospects for a breakthrough. ``There's a lot to talk about, different ways of putting things together.'' Bush is determined to secure NATO membership for the new Germany once it is created via the merger of East and West Germany, while Gorbachev is equally intent on keeping the country out of the Western alliance or at least restricting the size of the German army. ``I hope that we understand each other's concerns better,'' Gorbachev said as he left the White House Thursday. ``This exchange of views now requires that our foreign ministers have a more in-depth discussion,'' he told reporters. ``I think it is not here that the German question will be resolved.''' ``Fundamental positions have not changed,'' Bush said.

DOC.HEAD: Judge: Texas Owes Counties Who House Overflow Of State Inmates
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Rossanna is cq in 4th graf.
DOC.TEXT: A judge today ordered the state government to pay counties $40 a day for each convicted felon they house in their jails because of overcrowding at the state prison. State District Judge Joseph Hart said the state must either take the prisoners or reimburse the 12 counties who challenged the state's practice. The 12 counties said they are holding some 6,000 felons who have been sentenced to state prisons. But the Texas prison system is so overcrowded that there hasn't been room for the felons inside the state institutions. Rossanna Salazar, press secretary to Gov. Bill Clements, didn't immediately return a telephone call seeking comment on the ruling. The governor in the past has said he opposed paying the counties. Ron Dusek, spokesman for attorney general Jim Mattox, said the state planned to appeal Hart's ruling to the Austin-based 3rd Court of Appeals. Today's ruling affects only those counties that sued the state, officials said. But it could set a precedent for others to follow, said Ann Clarke Snell, the lawyer who represented 11 of the counties. ``Certainly it seems to me this ruling would be very important to any county that wanted to go to court and seek similar relief,'' she said. The counties that challenged the state were Nueces, Bexar, Collin, Dallas, El Paso, Galveston, Hidalgo, Hunt, Lubbock, Tarrant, Travis and Victoria. Statewide, there are an estimated 12,000 convicts awaiting transfer from all county jails to the Texas Department of Corrections. A federal judge has placed a ceiling on the state prison population. Several county sheriffs have complained that the backlog of state prisoners is crowding their jails. Hart, in a letter to lawyers in the case that was originated by Nueces County, said payment to the counties should begin seven days after an inmate is sentenced to state prison. The judge also told lawyers for the counties to calculate how much the 12 counties already are owed for prisoners they've been holding in the past.

DOC.HEAD: Events in the Soviet Union
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with developments today.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Summit Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a look at events in the Soviet Union:

BALTICS _ Boris N. Yeltsin promised Lithuania's president that the vast Russian republic will foster close ties with the secessionist Baltic region, Lithuanian sources said. Yeltsin, who was elected president of the Russian republic on Tuesday, met with Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis in Moscow. On Thursday, the legislature of Soviet Moldavia voted to recognize Lithuania's independence, the Tass news agency reported, making it the first Soviet republic outside the Baltics to do so. The move by the southwestern republic represented a direct challenge to Mikhail S. Gorbachev's efforts to isolate Lithuania from the rest of the Soviet Union. Liaonas Asmontas, Lithuania's energy minister, told the republic's legislature that the energy situation was becoming critical as a result of the energy blockade imposed by the Kremlin after the Baltic republic declared itself independent March 11.
YELTSIN _ Yeltsin, seeking to ease the fears of Soviet deputies about his stormy relationship with Gorbachev, pledged to put aside his personal differences with the Soviet leader.
LEGISLATURE _ The Supreme Soviet legislature debated a new bill that would create equal conditions for state, leased, collective, cooperative and individual business enterprises.
CABLE CAR _ At least 20 people were killed and 15 injured in a cable car accident in the Georgian capital, Tbilisi.
JAPAN-FISHING _ Moscow protested illegal Japanese fishing in Soviet waters and said it wants millions of dollars in compensation for what it calls economic damage.

SPACE _ An unmanned module containing facilities to produce high-quality semiconductors in orbit was launched from Soviet Central Asia to rendezvous with the Mir space station. The Kristall space module is to link up with the Mir on June 6.

DOC.HEAD: 20 Killed in Cable Car Accident in Soviet Union
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with conflicting reports about how many cable cars were involved, name of tourist destination. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A gondola traveling above a Soviet city broke from its cable and slammed into a support pole today, hurling its passengers onto the roof of an apartment building. Twenty people were reported killed and 15 injured. The accident occurred in the republic of Georgia, where the aerial tramway system carries tourists through downtown Tbilisi and to a popular nearby tourist attraction, Mount Mtatsminda. There were two gondolas on the cable, and the Soviet news agency Tass said both plunged to the ground. But Iveria, the unofficial Georgian information agency, and witnesses indicated that only one car was involved in the accident. ``One of the cars seemed to explode,'' said one witness, Graig Line, an American photographer. ``The car just disintegrated.'' Iveria said: ``The leading steel cable burst and one of the two cars started to slide down, accelerating very quickly on the other cable. Halfway down, the car collided with a support pole and split in two at full speed.'' ``The passengers fell out of the car onto the top of a six-story apartment building and into its yard,'' Iveria said. It quoted the Georgian Interior Ministry as saying that at least 20 people died, including several children and soldiers, and that 15 people were injured. Tass said ``there is a loss of life'' but did not give a death toll. It said a government commission was formed to investigate. Sergei Dandurov, another witness, said in a telephone interview that the floor of the cable car appeared to have split open and that at least 20 people fell to their deaths.

DOC.HEAD: PLO Faction Says It Will Continue Attacks Against Israel
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs grafs 5-14, `Yasser Arafat...religious holiday.' with 12 grafs to ADD quotes from faction's statement. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Israel-Attack
DOC.TEXT: The PLO faction that launched this week's raid along Israel's coast vowed today to keep attacking the Jewish state, but it claimed its targets were all military. The statement was issued by the Palestine Liberation Front in Baghdad, where it is believed to have its main headquarters. The group is headed by Mohammad Abbas, who is also known by his nom de guerre Abul-Abbas. He is a member of the Palestinian Liberation Organization executive committee who masterminded the 1985 hijacking of the Italian cruise ship Achille Lauro. One American was killed on the ship. The Palestine Liberation Front claimed responsibility for the seaborne guerrilla raid on the Israeli coast on Wednesday. In today's statement, the faction said, ``Our valiant naval forces translated the determination of our Palestinian people to liberate their national land and escalate armed struggle.'' Yasser Arafat, chief of the PLO umbrella group, denied responsibility for the raid but did not condemn it. That angered the United States, which opened contacts with the PLO after Arafat renounced terrorism and recongized Israel's right to exist. PLO officials have said Arafat's declaration renouncing terrorism did not include attacks on military targets in Israel. During Wednesday's seaborne assault, four members of the Palestine Liberation Front were killed in a gunbattle with soldiers, and 12 were captured, according to Israeli authorities. No Israelis were injured, through one craft with raiders landed on a beach near a crowded club. But in its statement today from Baghdad, the Palestine Liberation Front claimed that only two Syrians and 12 Palestinians took part in the raid. The PLO serves as an umbrella organization for several guerrilla factions that sometimes fight among themselves and launch independent attacks on Israeli targets.
