The largest group is Arafat's mainstream Fatah. Israeli leaders charged that the raid Wednesday proved that Arafat violated his December 1988 pledge to renounce terrorism. But PLO officials insisted that the Arafat pledge was only to halt attacks on Israeli targets abroad and civilians inside Israel. The pledge did not include military targets, they said. The Front's statement today said its guerrillas did not try to approach any civilian target inside Israel during the coastal raid. They said its fighters had instructions to hit military sites only. The group said its attack was directed at military sites in an area 50 miles wide extending from Herzliyya north of Tel Aviv to Ashqelon south of Tel Aviv. ``As for civilian targets, the naval operation proved that our combatants avoided approaching them or having any contact with them,'' the statement said. However, Israel claimed maps carried by the guerrillas showed their targets were civilian beach hotels, crowded with guests on a religious holiday.

DOC.HEAD: Rebels, Political Parties Agree on Moves to End Fighting
DOC.TEXT: Guatemalan rebels and nine political parties reached agreement today on moves aimed at ending 28 years of armed conflict in the Central American nation. A joint statement released after five days of talks in a hotel outside Madrid said the rebel Guatamalan National Revolutionary Union will join the parties in an assembly next year to revise Guatemala's Constitution. The political parties represented at the talks _ including the Christian Democrats of President Vinicio Cerezo _ accepted the guerrillas' demand that paramilitary civil patrols be disbanded and that the armed forces subjected to increased political control. In today's statement, the guerrillas pledged not to disrupt Guatemala's general elections, set for November. However, a rebel spokesman said this would not mean a general cease-fire in the fighting. The statement was released at a news conference after closed-door talks in El Escorial, 25 miles north of Madrid. The agreement is expected to serve as a framework for future negotiations among the guerrillas, Cerezo's government and top military officers. Before then, the guerrillas are likely to open talks with representatives of Guatemalan trade unions, businessmen and the Roman Catholic Church, a rebel spokesman said this week. The Guatemalan conflict, set off by rebel army officiers in 1962, has claimed between 30,000 and 60,000 lives, according to government estimates. The rebels say 100,000 people have died and that 50,000 are missing. A first round of peace talks held in 1987 in Madrid ended in deadlock. This week's negotiations were moderated by the six-member National Reconciliation Council, headed by Guatemala Archbishop Rodolfo Quesado. U.N. official Francesc Vendrell attended the meeting as an observer. Three rebel leaders took part in the negotiations, including veteran guerrilla chief, Rodrigo Asturias, also known by the code name Cmdr. Gaspar. The party leaders included former Guatemalan vice-president Mario Sandoval, founder of the ultra-conservative National Liberation Movement. The negotiations form part of a process begun after the 1987 Esquipulas II Central American peace accords. The region's five presidents agreed that conflicts in their Central American nations should be ended through democratic reforms and political negotiations between governments and rebel movements. The United States has expressed support for the Guatemalan talks.

DOC.HEAD: Tanker Grounds In Delaware River Between Pennsylvania, New Jersey; No Leak
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with tanker refloated, no damage. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A tanker carrying 375,000 gallons of fuel oil ran aground today in the Delaware River but was refloated a few hours later without any apparent leaks, authorities said. The Norwegian tanker Manhattan Princess, operated by Ahlers Shipping of Belgium, grounded on a muddy bottom on the New Jersey side of the river at 12:45 a.m. today, said Coast Guard Lt. Pete Hoffman. Coast Guard Lt. Pete Hoffman said two tugboats pulling on the tanker got it off the bottom with little trouble after high tide arrived about 9:15 a.m. Investigators found no leakage or ship damage, he said. The ship, drawing 37 feet of water, was en route to the Hess terminal in Pennsauken, N.J., when it wandered out of the 40-foot deep channel. An investigator went along with the tanker to look into the cause of the grounding, Hoffman said. The ease of refloating the tanker was an indication that the tanker wasn't very hard aground on the soft, muddy bottom, Hoffman said, and it also suggested that there wouldn't be any damage to the hull.

DOC.HEAD: Rajneesh's Doctor Says Screaming Can Stop Hooliganism
DOC.TEXT: The doctor of the late free-love guru Osho Rajneesh claimed Friday that he has discovered a cure for soccer hooliganism: screaming. Swami Amrito, a British physician, said if soccer fans screamed for 10 minutes before and after every match, there would be no reason to worry about violence. ``All that's needed to stop the rising tide of soccer hooliganism around next month's World Cup match in Italy is that all soccer fans should have a good catharsis,'' Amrito said, according to a press release issued by the Rajneesh commune in Poona. Amrito said players should also participate in the ``screaming meditation.'' ``That will reduce the violence on the field as well as encourage some poetry and grace in their play,'' he said. Amrito has been one of the leaders of the Rajneesh commune since the guru, who was once known as Bhagwan Shree Rajneesh, died in January. Rajneesh preached a philosophy of quick-fix enlightenment, telling his followers that only through the indulgence of sensual pleasures could one achieve ``inner peace.'' He was expelled from the United States in 1985 for violating immigration laws. At one time his group operated a huge commune in Oregon.

DOC.HEAD: Children Jam Tiananmen Square On Children's Day
LaserPhoto BEJ3
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of children danced and sang on Tiananmen Square on Friday for Premier Li Peng and other Chinese leaders who ordered the military sweep of student activists on the square one year ago. Some 10,000 children were bused into the symbolic political center of China to mark International Children's Day. It was one of the biggest organized gatherings on the square since last June, when university students led huge pro-democracy rallies with crowds numbering in the hundreds of thousands. Speakers this year said it was due to the army's action in crushing the ``counterrevolutionary rebellion'' that the children were able to have their festive day on the square. Annual Children's Day activities on Tiananmen were cancelled last year because the square was occupied by student demonstrators. The military moved in on June 3-4, killing hundreds and perhaps thousands of people as they drushed the pro-democracy campaign. Hundreds of police patrolled the square Friday. Foreign journalists were subjected to tight security checks because of the appearance of China's top two officials, Premier Li and Communist Party General Secretary Jiang Zemin. Around the monument to revolutionary martyrs in the center of the square, large balloons lofted streamers reading ``long live the great Communist Party'' and ``long live our great socialist motherland.'' Stress on ideological training has increased dramatically since the government crushed the democracy movement. Young people in particular are constantly being reminded that they must remain loyal to the party and the socialist system. Thousands of doves were released over the square to open the ceremonies.

DOC.HEAD: Top Administrator of Punjab State Resigns
DOC.TEXT: The top administrator of strife-torn Punjab state resigned Friday after less than six months in office, news reports said. Gov. Nirmal Kumar Mukarji submitted his resignation to President Ramaswamy Venkataraman, United News of India reported. Mukarji, who took office on Dec. 8 last year, did not give any reason for the resignation, the news agency said. However, newspapers have been saying for some days a change was imminent because Mukarji has been largely ineffectual in controlling the Sikh insurgency sweeping the state. The Statesman newspaper reported Friday that Mukarji would be replaced by P.K. Kaul, a former top-ranking bureaucrat who has also served as India's ambassador to the United States. However, Press Trust of India quoted an unnamed government spokesman as saying no decision had been taken about Mukarji's replacement. At least 980 people have been killed in the state this year by Sikh militants' hit-and-run attacks and bombings. The militants are demanding an independent state because of what they call discrimination against Sikhs by Hindus, India's majority community. Sikhs are in a slight majority in Punjab but form only 2 percent of India's 880 million people. Hindus make up 82 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Council Threatening Eviction Over Satellite Dishes
DOC.TEXT: A municipal council in south London is threatening to evict public housing tenants who refuse to remove satellite TV dishes from their homes. ``We don't like this architectural acne erupting all over the borough,'' said Sutton council spokesman Howard Spencer. Nationally, some 700,000 dishes have been installed to receive the Sky television channels, owned by Rupert Murdoch's The News Corporation, according to the Financial Times of London. A rival service, British Satellite Broadcasting, entered the market this year. Nearly 100 local authorities are pressing the government to stop the growth of satellite dishes, but the Sutton council is the first to take such a step. Sutton council said Thursday that 150 public housing tenants who had installed the dishes on outer walls violated tenancy agreements forbidding alterations to the buildings. If tenants want to receive satellite TV, Spencer said, they could place free-standing dishes in their gardens or on balconies. Legislators said they would give people 28 days to remove the dishes. ``We don't want to see people out on the street, but we want to protect our property,'' Spencer said.

DOC.HEAD: New Commander Named for U.S. 7th Air Force
DOC.TEXT: Maj. Gen. Ronald Fogelman, who flew 240 combat missions in Vietnam, has been named commander of the U.S. 7th Air Force based in South Korea, officials said Friday. Fogelman is expected to take over his new post in July, moving from an assignment at the Pentagon in Washington, Air Force officials said. The 7th Air Force is based at Osan, 30 miles south of Seoul, and includes about 10,000 airmen and support personnel. Fogelman is a 1963 graduate of the Air Force Academy and has had assignments in West Germany and the Netherlands.

DOC.HEAD: Arson Fire Hits Storage Room of Once-Grounded Luxury Liner
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with officials saying fire was arson. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Someone set a fire early today in a storage room on the luxury liner Regent Star, five days after the ship ran aground in Delaware Bay because of another fire that cut off power, authorities said. No passengers were aboard and no injuries were reported in the 5 a.m. blaze, which was controlled within 90 minutes, said Patrick McKee, a dispatcher for the city fire department. ``The fire on the Regent Star was started in a maintenance storage room,'' said Lt. Jack Christmas, a fire department spokesman. ``The fire marshal investigating has determined ... that the fire was intentionally set.'' There were no immediate suspects and no immediate evidence to indicate that the fire was linked to the earlier fire, Christmas said. The 20,000-ton liner was on its way from Jamaica to Philadelphia on Sunday when a small fire prompted a power loss, allowing the ship to drift onto a sandbar. The 885 passengers left the ship by ferry Monday, a day after they were supposed to return. No one was injured. The liner was freed Tuesday, and the ship was then docked while the Coast Guard makes safety checks. Thursday, Coast Guard Petty Officer Ken Beatty said the ship passed all inspections and there was no serious damage from the grounding. The ship had been due to start on a two-day cruise later today, but that was canceled after the second fire broke out, authorities said. The Coast Guard has said it might be months before a final report on the grounding is complete. An hour after this morning's fire was controlled, about 300 crew members sat or stood in small groups alongside the Port of History Museum where the ship was tied up. Many still wearin the orange life preservers they had put om when they abandoned the ship. Others were sitting on the preservers. Many of them said they didn't speak English, and one who did refused to be identified and said he didn't know anything about what happened.

DOC.HEAD: Fletters' Flutter Fight Finally Fails
DOC.TEXT: A 72-year-old error in the naming of Flutter Road will go unfixed. The Allen County Commissioners declined to change the name from Flutter to Fletter even though 75 people who live along the road signed a petition favoring Flutter. Leonard and Harold Fletter argued that a clerical error on a 1918 petition to the commissioners caused the }-mile road in St. Joseph Township to be called Flutter instead of Fletter. It was supposed to have been named after their ancestor, Samuel C. Fletter, who owned a farm there and donated adjacent land for a school. But residents said they don't want to be troubled with having to change stationery and legal documents. The commissioners went along with them at their Tuesday night meeting. Resident Orlyn Myer used alliteration to get his point across in a letter to the commissioners. ``After finding the flap about Flutter from the Fletter families from Fort Wayne and Florida, I felt like flipping,'' wrote ``the father of a Flutter Road family.'' He concluded: ``If, by chance, Mr. Fletter can find the funds to fetch a secretary for me and finance the stamps to fix upon the envelopes to change all of ... (his personal) records, I might reconsider the decision. Otherwise, after nearly 72 years, why not leave well enough alone?''

DOC.HEAD: Imelda Marcos Recovering After Courtroom Collapse
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with today's condition much improved, judge's decision blocking subpoena of Diane Sawyer.. Picks up 4th graf, `Mrs. Marcos' chief...' DELETES now-redundant 10th graf pvs, `Erosive gastritis...'.
DOC.TEXT: Former Philippines first lady Imelda Marcos was recovering today from a stomach inflammation that halted her fraud trial when she collapsed in the courtroom and coughed up blood. The judge in the trial disposed of a side issue by quashing a subpoena seeking testimony from television journalist Diane Sawyer about a ``60 Minutes'' interview with Mrs. Marcos. He said he was not persuaded that the material was necessary enough to the prosecution to overcome objections by CBS, which did not want to turn over cartons of outtakes and related material to the defense. The judge had told lawyers of his decision Thursday and issued a written opinion today. Mrs. Marcos remained at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, where she was taken by ambulance Thursday. She was diagnosed with erosive gastritis, which is caused when stomach acid erodes the the organ's lining, said Jonathan Weil, a hospital spokesman. He said Mrs. Marcos was treated with intravenous antacid. ``Mrs. Marcos' condition is much improved and she is stabilized,'' Kathy Robinson, another hospital spokeswoman, said today. ``The abdominal pain that she was experiencing is no longer present and if she remains stabilized, her doctors will probably allow her to go home on Sunday in care of her personal physician.'' Mrs. Marcos' chief attorney, Gerry Spence, had just completed his cross-examination of Robert Shaheen, a former chief aide to Saudi financier Adnan Khashoggi, when Mrs. Marcos suddenly slumped in her chair, lay her head on the table and coughed up blood into a black handkerchief. Mrs. Marcos' sudden illness threw U.S. District Court into a tumult. ``When I saw her face and throwing up blood, I thought she was going to die right there in the courtroom,'' said another of her lawyers, Benjamin Cassiday, who was seated next to her. Attorneys and doctors rushed to her side. Judge John F. Keenan dismissed the jury and called a recess until Tuesday. ``It was very sad. I never saw so much blood come out of someone,'' said Kashoggi, Mrs. Marcos' co-defendant, who was seated at another table about 10 feet away. It was the third time in five weeks that Mrs. Marcos, 60, had fallen ill during the trial. On the other two occasions, doctors said her blood pressure shot up alarmingly. Dr. David Case, an internist who has been treating Mrs. Marcos for high blood pressure, said Thursday's illness appeared unrelated to that condition or to medication she has been taking. Case said there were numerous possible causes, including stress. Defense lawyers said it was too soon to know how the illness might affect the trial, which began March 20. Mrs. Marcos faces charges of racketeering, racketeering conspiracy, mail fraud and obstruction of justice. She is accused of helping her husband, the late Philippines President Ferdinand Marcos, steal about $220 million from their nation's treasury, using the money for their own purposes, including the secret purchase of artwork and four New York office buildings. Khashoggi faces charges of faking documents to show that he, not the Marcoses, owned the properties before the Marcoses' assets were frozen by a U.S. court order.

DOC.HEAD: Air Controllers And Train Engineers Join World Cup Truce
DOC.TEXT: Air traffic controllers and train engineers on Friday backed off from previous strike threats and announced they were ready to join a labor truce during the month-long World Cup competition. The government is exerting strong pressure on labor movements to not strike during the World Cup, which begins June 8. Air controllers called off strikes scheduled for June 4-6. Railway workers, members of splinter unions that are increasingly challenging the established labor federations, said they were prepared to suspend strikes planned June 7-8 and June 13-14. They acted after Transport Minister Carlo Bernini said he was ready to negotiate with them. The workers threatened to strike over pay demands.

DOC.HEAD: Security Heightened at U.S. Base in Philippines
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with restrictions at U.S. base, report that U.S. troops to accompany Filipinos on patrol, Mrs. Aquino won't ask for renewed emergency powers. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: U.S. officials today imposed new restrictions on American troops at Clark Air Base because of a security threat in the area where Communist rebels killed two airmen last month. Maj. Gen. Cesar Nazareno, chief of the Philippine Constabulary, said he ordered heightened security patrols because of the Communist threat. He said he was also honoring a U.S request to let American troops accompany Philippine forces providing security outside the bases in ``areas where there are visible American targets.'' He said the request came from Rear Adm. Roger Lee Rich, commander of the Subic base 50 miles west of Manila. But there was no confirmation from U.S. officials. In 1987, U.S. troops joined Filipino police in off-post patrols after the slaying of three Americans near Clark Air Base. However, the arrangement raised an uproar from Filipinos who considered the patrols a breach of sovereignty. Also today, President Corazon Aquino said she will not seek a congressional extension of her emergency powers, which expire June 8. However, she left open the option of calling a special legislative session if she changes her mind. The emergency powers include the authority to control prices and increase state regulation of utilities, transport and vital industries. The Philippine Congress approved the powers following a coup attempt led by rebel soldiers in December. It was one of six coup attempts aimed at toppling her struggling government. In another development, a newspaper reported today that authorities are investigating a report that a professional killer from Los Angeles may have entered the country last month to assassinate the president. At Clark Air Base, spokesman Lt. Col. Ron Rand, said today's regulations prevent U.S. troops, Defense Department civilians and military dependents from leaving the bases except on essential business. ``Local, current conditions dictate we take action right now,'' Rand said in an announcement broadcast by the U.S. military's television station. He did not elaborate, but the announcement came one week after U.S. officials relaxed similar restrictions imposed because of the May 13 killings of the two U.S. airmen outside the base. After the killings, military personnel at Clark and the other five American installations in this country were barred from leaving the bases, except on essential business. On May 25, U.S. officials announced that troops were allowed off-post between 7 a.m. and 7 p.m. But they were told to stay within a half mile of the gates. Rand said that ``local liberty'' has now been suspended until further notice. The new measures apply to the 20,300 troops, U.S. civilian employees and dependents at Clark, he said. Clark Air Base, one of the largest American garrisons abroad, is located 50 miles north of Manila in a stronghold of the Communist New People's Army. The Communists are waging a 21-year insurgency to establish a Marxist state. They have vowed to continue attacking Americans until all U.S. troops leave the Philippines. In its report today, the nationally circulated Philippine Daily Inquirer quoted police sources as saying a 50-year-old, unidentified professional killer arrived in the country from the United States last month and was to have attempted the assassination of Mrs. Aquino sometime between May 15 and 20. But the plot was discovered through a tip from an informant in San Francisco, the newspaper said. The assassin is still believed to be in the country, it said. The newspaper did not specify which group reportedly hired the would-be killer. Col. Voltaire Gazmin, chief of Mrs. Aquino's security force, confirmed receiving a report during the second week of May of an assassination plot but said the information had not yet been verified. He gave no further details about the alleged plot. Mrs. Aquino and other government officials played down the report. ``I face the same risks as any president normally does and our security has been equal to the task,'' Mrs. Aquino said in a statement today.

DOC.HEAD: Fighting Escalates Before Tokyo Peace Talks
DOC.TEXT: Cambodian guerrillas have launched major attacks and seized areas of several provinces in recent days as Cambodia's warring factions prepare to meet next week to discuss a cease-fire. Guerrilla leaders and diplomats say the Khmer Rouge have made the most substantial gains, but the pro-Hanoi government of Prime Minister Hun Sen has also been active on the battlefields. Leaders of the three-party guerrilla coalition, which includes the communist Khmer Rouge, are to meet with Hun Sen in Tokyo on Monday and are expected to announce a cease-fire in the 11-year-old war. Sources say the Khmer Rouge launched a series of coordinated attacks in Kompong Speu, Siem Riep, Kompong Thom and Battambang provinces in recent days. The provinces are in northwestern, northern and central Cambodia. The Khmer Rouge captured the district seat of Roluos in Siem Riep Province earlier this week and have established front-line positions only 3.6 miles from the provincial capital, according to senior resistance and Thai intelligence officials. ``There has been heavy fighting recently, and the Khmer Rouge seem to be coming out on top,'' said a senior Thai intelligence official. Fighting in Kompong Speu province has forced government offices to suspend foreign relief projects there, according to Western relief workers returning to Thailand from Phnom Penh, the Cambodian capital. Guerrilla and diplomatic sources say the Khmer Rouge now control large sections of the province and maintain truck supply routes all the way to the Thai border. Kompong Speu city is 24 miles southwest of Phnom Penh. Diplomats say increased fighting is expected this month as the rainy season terrain favors guerrilla advances. In the past, the warring sides have also stepped up fighting before peace negotiations to gain leverage. The Thai intelligence official said it made sense for the Khmer Rouge to make a military move before the Tokyo talks. Thai intelligence sources and diplomats say the Khmer Rouge are against a cease-fire agreement until there is an international verification of the pullout of Vietnamese forces from Cambodia. Vietnam claimed it pulled the last of its soldiers from Cambodia in September, but the guerrillas claim some remain. The Khmer Rouge are joined in a resistance coalition with followers of Prince Norodom Sihanouk, Cambodia's former head of state, and the Khmer People's National Liberation Front. The Khmer Rouge were in power in Cambodia in 1975-1978. They were ousted after Vietnam invaded in late 1978 and set up a pro-Hanoi government. The Tokyo meeting is expected to include announcement of a cease-fire; reconvening of a Paris peace conference that ended in failure last year; and the formation of a Supreme National Council. The council would include all four warring factions and be charged with monitoring a cease-fire. But guerrilla officials say there are no provisions for enforcing or monitoring a cease-fire, and they are pessimistic it can be effectively implemented on the battlefield. ``So far, they can't even agree on seating arrangements in Tokyo,'' said a Thai official involved in the preparations. ``Hun Sen wants to sit across from Sihanouk, but the Khmer Rouge and the KPNLF won't accept this.''

DOC.HEAD: Councilman: Toxic Tortillas Threaten Deli Belly
DOC.TEXT: New York's new lunchtime order: Make it a ham on rye _ and hold the streptococci. So advises City Council President Andrew Stein, who said Thursday that all but two of a dozen take-out lunches he had tested at a private laboratory were contaminated with illegal levels of bacteria. Stein, whose aides collected each sample at a different restaurant, blamed a lack of inspections by the Health Department. The possible result: deli belly, the nausea, cramps and diarrhea caused by eating tainted food. Toxic tortillas? Lethal lunchmeat? Baloney! Health Commissioner Woodrow Myers Jr. responded. He called it ``categorically untrue'' for Stein to suggest that the public was endangered by lax enforcement. While the restaurant inspection staff remains smaller than desired, Myers said, it is being increased and all complaints are followed up. He noted that the city has not experienced an increase in food poisoning reports. Myers also said he had ``serious questions'' about the scientific value of Stein's study. Among other problems, he suggested that Stein's aides themselves could have contaminated the food, and he said the laboratory tests were simply for bacteria in general, rather than for those bacteria that cause illness. Stein, the city's chief ombudsman, also recently reported finding bug parts in imported packaged foods he had tested. Federal inspection officials said the particles he'd found didn't really threaten anyone. Thursday, Stein described his restaurant sampling as ``random,'' saying his aides simply picked up lunches at Manhattan eateries that appeared to them to be representative. He declined to identify the establishments, saying that would be unfair, but sent their names to the Health Department. ``I believe that there are hundreds, probably thousands of establishments that have the same problem,'' he said. ``If you don't have enforcement, and you don't have inspections, then you're going to have problems.'' Stein noted that the Health Department fired many of its inspectors in a bribery scandal three years ago, and regular inspections have yet to resume. ``Common sense will tell you that if the establishments know that they're not ever getting inspected on any regular basis, then they're going to be more lax than if they are getting inspected,'' he said. ``The city has a duty here to do some regular inspections.'' Myers, at his own news conference, said the city has 15 food inspectors working now and 43 in training who will be available Sept. 1. He said his department was checking the restaurants that Stein named, but noted that four of them are markets that fall under state, not city, jurisdiction. ``The Health Department is not lax when it comes to food safety,'' he said. ``While we question Mr. Stein's laboratory results and refute his conclusions, we are, nonetheless, investigating the food establishments in question.''

DOC.HEAD: Numbers Show Continued Decline in Building Industry
With AM-Unemployment, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Construction spending fell 0.7 percent in April for the second consecutive month, the government said in a report that analysts said signalled a weakening building industry. The Commerce Department said residential, non-residential and government construction spending totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $432.4 billion in April. The revised 0.7 percent March decline was improved from the 1.4 percent drop first reported last month. The decreases in March and April spending followed gains of 3.2 percent in February and 2.4 percent in January and resulted in the loss of 159,000 construction jobs. ``We had strong construction employment in the first quarter when we had great weather,'' David F. Seiders, chief economist for the National Association of Home Builders, said. ``But if you look at the next two months, that's really quite a decline.'' The construction spending report ``combined with the employment numbers are two more signals of a pretty sluggish economy,'' Seiders said. Two other reports portend further weakening. The government overall job figures released Friday showed the unemployment rate fell to 5.3 percent in May as weak job growth continued. The Labor Department reported 20,000 more construction jobs were lost in the month. And on Wednesday, the F.W. Dodge division of McGraw-Hill Inc. reported that contracts for new construction declined 6 percent in April, a four-year low. Analysts attribute the construction slump to high interest rates and tighter restrictions on lending. Residential building edged down 0.3 percent to an annual rate of $202.7 billion after rising 2 percent in March, even better than the 1.8 percent increase first reported last month. Single-family building dropped 2.2 percent to an annual rate of $120 billion after a 1.2 percent increase in March. Apartment construction, on the other hand, rose 6 percent to $21 billion. It had dropped 4.3 percent in March. With mortgage rates in the double-digits and sales of new homes declining, residential construction ``is destined to keep going down,'' Seiders said, adding that the jump in multi-family building was an aberration. ``The multi-family sector has been really weak and sliding for some time and will resume its downward path next month,'' he predicted. Non-residential construction such as office and industrial buildings edged up 0.6 percent to $104.2 billion after rising 2.4 percent in March. The volatile government sector fell for the second straight month, down 3.5 percent to $87.6 billion. Highways and streets spending paced the drop with a 8.2 percent decline. Government construction spending had fallen 4.9 percent in March after gaining 5.2 percent in February. Overall construction spending in April was 5 percent above that of the same month in 1989, when it totaled $411.9 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Segregation of All Public Amenities to End by October
DOC.TEXT: The white minority government introduced legislation Friday to remove one of the pillars of apartheid, racial segregation of public amenities such as parks, libraries and bathrooms. The Separate Amenities Act, passed in 1953, has granted provincial governments, municipalities and privately owned entertainment establishments the right to reserve facilities for whites. A bill that would repeal the act was published Friday and is expected to be passed in mid-June, the South African Press Association reported. It was the latest move by the government of President F.W. de Klerk to dismantle apartheid. The Conservative Party, the largest white opposition party, is the only parliamentary group expected to oppose the bill, but the party does not have enough votes to block it. Hernus Kriel, minister of provincial affairs and planning, said the bill would not take effect until Oct. 15, to give those affected time to prepare. The bill would remove local governments' authority to racially segregate public facilities such as libraries, toilets, parks and buses. It also would remove the legal protection of individuals who want to reserve restaurants, hotels, resorts and other public facilities for whites. In most major cities, such as Johannesburg and Cape Town, public amenities have been desegregated in recent months. But in hundreds of smaller cities, towns and villages, there are either no public facilities for blacks in the city centers, or there are inferior, separate amenities. The Separate Amenities Act is considered one of the pillars of apartheid, the system of racial separation and white domination encoded in law by the National Party when it came to power in 1948. Other pillars are the Population Registration Act, which classifies every South African by race; the Group Areas Act, which establishes racially segregated neighborhoods; the Land Act, which reserves most of the country for white ownership; and the voting laws, which place political power in the hands of the white minority by denying a national vote to the black majority. De Klerk has said he intends to end apartheid and give blacks an equal vote with whites by 1994 under a system he hopes to negotiate with black leaders. However, de Klerk opposes one-person, one-vote majority rule, and instead suggests a system where cultural, social and ethnic groups would be assured representation in the government. Since taking office last year, de Klerk has legalized dozens of outlawed black political organizations, freed scores of political prisoners, and ordered hospitals integrated. The Conservative Party and white extremist organizations have denounced de Klerk's actions as treason to the white Afrikaners who control the government. Some have said they will protect apartheid by force, if necessary. The complications of changing 42 years of practice are reflected in the amount of time it will take to repeal the Separate Amenities Act if the national legislature votes to do so. Hundreds of local ordinances may have to be repealed to comply with the national law, and Conservative-controlled municipalities can be expected to resist any changes. Upholding the new law will also depend on government employees, many of whom support the Conservative Party or generally oppose the rapid changes taking place in South Africa. Two weeks ago, Health Minister Rina Venter announced that segregation of all hospitals had ended. However, this week, the administrator of the country's 44 white hospitals said whites would still be given preference of admission because the hospitals were meant to serve the local community. Although segregation at government-owned resorts and recreation areas was officially ended months ago, blacks, Indians and people of mixed-race continue to be turned away. In recent cases, resort administrators, who are government employees, say they haven't received direct orders to admit people who are not white.

DOC.HEAD: Three Twisters Whip Through Texas Panhandle City
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 5 grafs to update with contradictory report from weather service, picking up at the 3rd graf previous.
DOC.TEXT: Residents and witnesses said three funnel clouds didn't quite touch down but still caused $5.5 million worth of damage, while the weather service says one tornado did scour the surface. No injuries were reported, but about 80 percent of the city was blacked out and phone service was spotty until this morning. ``There was one that hit Spearman itself, and there were multiple tornadoes in the vicinity of Spearman for several hours last night,'' said Steven Cooper of the National Weather Service office in Amarillo. ``There were about three different storm systems. Two dropped tornadoes.'' The funnel clouds were ``too numerous to count,'' he said. State Trooper Wayne Beighle of Amarillo said 10 twisters were spotted in the area Thursday night. ``We were up there until 1:00 (a.m.), and there were still tornadoes dancing around. They were all over the place,'' Beighle said. ``None touched the ground _ they were hovering just above the ground, but that was enough to do the damage.'' Ten mobile homes and 10 houses were reported destroyed, Beighle said. Some of the mobile homes were ``smoothed off to the ground,'' said Mayor Burl Buchanan. The mayor estimated that 5 percent of the town of 3,500 had property damage. He said early warning gave people time to take shelter and prevented injuries. ``It could have been a lot worse,'' he said. A church was demolished and a barbecue restaurant was seriously damaged. The storm ``blew the porch off and blew it back on top of the building. It just flipped it up and laid it up on top of the roof,'' Buchanan said. Many homes had damaged windows and roofs, and some power lines were reported down. Buchanan said tree limbs and one mobile home needed to be cleared from streets to make them passable.

DOC.HEAD: Yeltsin Reportedly Vows to Foster Russian-Lithuanian Ties
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Stands for AM-Yeltsin on news digest.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MOS8
DOC.TEXT: Boris N. Yeltsin promised Lithuania's president Friday that he would foster close ties between the huge Russian republic he now heads and the secessionist Baltic region, Lithuanian sources said. Yeltsin's offer openly defied Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, who ordered a partial economic blockade against Lithuania in an effort to force it to back off its March independence declaration. Yeltsin, who was elected president of the Russian Federation on Tuesday, met with Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis for ``a very friendly talk with full mutual understanding,'' said Natasha Boganova, secretary of the Lithuanian representation in Moscow. ``Yeltsin is prepared, as soon as Russia gets its sovereignty, to cooperate fully with the Baltic republics, and Lithuania first of all,'' she said. Lithuania, struggling to circumvent the Kremlin blockade, has been seeking direct ties with newly elected radical leaders in various parts of the country. On Thursday, the legislature of the republic of Moldavia recognized Lithuania's independence, the official Tass news agency reported. It was the first Soviet republic outside the Baltics to do so. Gorbachev has said Lithuania must suspend its declaration of independence before he will lift the economic blockade and begin talks with Lithuanian leaders. Lithuanian lawmakers have offered compromise measures but balked at suspending the declaration. Yeltsin has said he expects the Russian parliament to declare the Russian Federation's sovereignty within the first 100 days of his term. The Russian Federation is the Soviet Union's largest republic, with two-thirds of its territory and just over half its population. Sovereignty would mean republic authorities would have final say over which Soviet laws are valid on Russian territory, and greater independence in general from the national government, including on economic issues. If Russia were to resume supplying Lithuania with natural gas, oil and other raw materials, it would mean the virtual end of the Kremlin's sanctions _ without Gorbachev's consent. But even if such an accord could be worked out, it might not be soon enough for the Lithuanians, who are pressing to find alternate sources of gas and oil before they run out entirely. About 46,000 people have been laid off and eight factories closed because of the blockade, Lithuanian radio has reported. Many residents of Vilnius, the Lithuanian capital, have been without hot water for weeks. Lithuanian radio reported that Poland will begin supplying the republic with cooking oil and sugar _ at steeper prices than Soviet suppliers commanded. In neighboring Latvia, which declared May 4 that it had begun its move toward independence, rationing of several food staples began Friday, Tass said. The Kremlin has not extended its economic sanctions to Latvia, but residents fearing a blockade began panic-buying after the May 4 declaration. Yeltsin said repeatedly during his election campaign that he would seek direct ties with Lithuania, Latvia, and Estonia, which is also seeking independence. Friday's meeting was his first reported concrete move to begin establishing those ties. All three Baltic republics were forcibly annexed by the Soviet Union in 1940. Estonian President Arnold Ruutel, speaking at a Stockholm news conference, said Yeltsin's election ``is important to the political life in the whole of the Soviet Union and is certain to influence the situation in the Baltic region.'' Despite his defiance of Gorbachev's economic sanctions, Yeltsin told reporters Friday he still hoped to meet with the Soviet leader soon to resolve their differences, Tass reported. ``We have got to meet and discuss important questions,'' Tass quoted Yeltsin as saying during a break in the Russian Congress. ``I am prepared to go a good part of the distance toward Gorbachev, throwing aside everything personal that has piled up recently. I hope that he, too will cover part of the road.'' Yeltsin noted that he had not met personally with Gorbachev for more than a year. Gorbachev brought Yeltsin to head the Moscow Communist Party committee, but the two men clashed in late 1987 over the pace of reforms and have attacked each other's positions publicly ever since. They also appear to bear personal grudges against each other. Gorbachev actively opposed Yeltsin's election to the Russian presidency. There have been no reports that Gorbachev has sent Yeltsin congratulations on his election.

DOC.HEAD: Students Arrested for Sailing Paper Planes at Teachers
DOC.TEXT: Two students were arrested and charged with mischief after they sailed paper airplanes at the teachers' section during high school graduation ceremonies, authorities said. Livingston High School officials requested the charges and arrests may be made, Chief Deputy Sheriff Willie Graves said Thursday. ``Everything went beautifully until almost the end,'' said assistant principal Frances LaFleur. ``I was calling out names, and Principal Owen Norgess was handing out diplomas. ``A gentleman in the balcony stood up and blasted an air horn, not once, but twice. Then the students threw the paper airplanes at the teachers' section. Two hit a teacher. His face turned blood red, and he was very embarrassed. ``All the faculty was outraged and upset over the lack of respect.'' Jared S. Vicknair, 17, and David D. Wallace, 18, were released on $500 property bonds, accused of throwing airplanes during the May 25 ceremonies. Jonnie Drago Jr., 43, Wallace's uncle, was charged with disturbing the peace by blowing the air horn, Graves said.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING a0619 to fix category code
Barbara Bush, Raisa Gorbachev Speaking To Wellesley Grads
DOC.TEXT: Barbara Bush, in a commencement speech clouded by controversy over women's roles in modern American life, exhorted Wellesley College graduates today to put friends and family first in their lives, whatever careers they pursue. She was joined at the women's college graduation by Raisa Gorbachev, who delivered her own words of advice to the 575 graduates and nearly 5,000 other guests gathered inside a white tent on this sylvan campus. Even as the first ladies arrived, some of the seniors who protested the choice of President Bush's homemaker wife as their commencement speaker fired off a new letter urging Mrs. Bush to ``take a definitive and vocal stand'' on abortion rights and other issues. Copies were placed on each of the chairs inside the tent. Mrs. Bush sounded the same themes she usually discusses at commencements, but acknowledged with a joke the controversy over her appearance. ``I know your first choice for today was Alice Walker, known for `The Color Purple,''' she said. ``Instead you got me, known for the color of my hair,'' said the woman George Bush affectionately calls the Silver Fox. Mrs. Gorbachev, dressed in a gray suit rather than the traditional gown worn by commencement speakers, told the graduates that women ``have our special mission.'' ``Always, even in the most cruel and troubled times, women have had the mission of peacemaking, humanism, mercy and kindness,'' she said. ``And if people in the world today are more confident of a peaceful future we have to give a great deal of credit for that to women.'' The lone note of discord came during the playing of the Soviet national anthem when a handful of protesters held up a banner that read, ``Free the Baltics.'' Mrs. Bush urged the women to ``cherish your human connections, your relationships with friends and family.'' ``You will never regret not having passed one more test, not winning one more verdict or not closing one more deal. You will regret time not spent with a husband, a friend, a child or a parent,'' she said. Closing with a device she has used before, Mrs. Bush said, ``Somewhere out in this audence may even be someone who will one day follow in my footsteps and preside over the White House as the president's spouse. I wish him well!'' ``The controversy ends here, but our conversation is only beginning,'' she said. Prior to the speech, Peggy B. Reid and Susana R. Cardenas had their new broadside waiting on each of the chairs. Cardenas was one of the main organizer's of the petition drive in April protesting the choice of Mrs. Bush as commencement speaker. ``We ask you, Barbara Bush, as a concerned mother and as a symbol of service to others, to take a definitive and vocal stand on the following critical issues that shape the lives of women in the United States,'' they said. The issues include the ``deterioration of women's reproductive rights''; passage of a family and medical leave act that President Bush has threatened to veto, and affordable day care. Some 150 students signed a petition in April questioning whether the president's homemaker wife was a suitable model of female accomplishment. Mrs. Bush, a college dropout, tendered her invitation to Raisa Gorbachev _ a philosophy Ph.D. and former university lecturer _ before the Wellesley students mounted their protest. Mrs. Bush, who turns 65 on June 12, dropped out of Smith College in 1944 in her sophomore year to marry her teenage sweetheart, George Bush, then a torpedo-bomber pilot for the Navy. Before returning to Washington in mid-afternoon, the first ladies were expected to take a driving tour of downtown Boston with a stop at the Boston Public Gardens and a meeting with about 30 students from the Mathers School, the oldest public school.

DOC.HEAD: Sued Businessman Found Dead on Golf Course
DOC.TEXT: A businessman accused of bilking celebrities and other investors out of millions of dollars was found dead on a golf course from an apparently self-inflicted gunshot wound to the head, authorities said. The body of Richard M. Wood, 56, was found Wednesday afternoon, sitting in a golf cart near the fifth tee and holding a handgun, said Cindee Singletary, spokeswoman for the Charlotte County Sheriff's Department. Investigators tentatively concluded it was a suicide, she said Thursday. In recent months, the Tampa corporate and tax lawyer had been the target of lawsuits and claims totaling $17.5 million in Florida, North Carolina and Michigan. Sportscasters Merlin Olsen and Dick Enberg and 11 other investors sued Wood in January, claiming he siphoned $9 million in profits they should have received from an Ann Arbor, Mich., commercial real estate venture. Other investors, including a Florida lottery winner, claimed in lawsuits that Wood owed them money given to him for investment purposes. Wood's Tampa-based Richard Wood & Co. closed its offices last fall. An office in Ann Arbor closed in February. In 1987, Wood estimated his net worth at up to $46 million. But NCNB National Bank of Florida later foreclosed on his Tampa home, saying he defaulted on loans worth $1.6 million.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-, AM-Summit-First Ladies
DOC.TEXT: Following are excerpts from Barbara Bush's speech Friday at Wellesley College: I'm really thrilled to be here today, and very excited, as I know all of you must be, that Mrs. Gorbachev could join us. These are exciting times. They're exciting in Washington. And I had really looked forward to coming to Wellesley. I thought it was going to be fun. I never dreamt it would be this much fun. More than 10 years ago, when I was invited here to talk about our experiences in the People's Republic of China, I was struck by both the natural beauty of your campus and the spirit of this place. Wellesley ... is not just a place, but an idea _ an experiment in excellence in which diversity is not just tolerated, but is embraced. The essence of this spirit was captured in a moving speech about tolerance given last year by a student body president of one of your sister colleges. As that very wise young woman said, ``Diversity, like anything worth having, requires effort.'' Effort to learn about and respect difference, to be compassionate with one another, to cherish our own identity, and to accept unconditionally the same in others. You should all be very proud that this is the Wellesley spirit. Now I know your first choice today was Alice Walker ... Known for ``The Color Purple.'' Instead, you got me, known for the color of my hair! Alice Walker's book has a special resonance here. For four years, the class of '90 has worn the color purple. Today, you meet ... to say goodbye to all of that, to begin a new and a very personal journey, to search for your own true colors. In the world that awaits you beyond the shores of Lake Waban, no one can say what your true colors will be. But this I do know: You have a first-class education from a first-class school, and so you need not, probably cannot live a paint-by-numbers life. Decisions are not irrevocable, choices do come back, and as you set off from Wellesley, I hope many of you will consider making three very special choices. The first is to believe in something larger than yourself, to get involved in some of the big ideas of our time. I chose literacy because I honestly believed that if morepeople could read, write, and comprehend, we would be that much closer to solving so many of the problems that plague our nation and our society. And early on, I made another choice, which I hope you will make as well. Whether you are talking about education, career, or service, you are talking about life and life really must have joy. It's supposed to be fun. One of the reasons I made the most important decision of my life, to marry George Bush, is because he made me laugh. It's true, sometimes we laugh through our tears, but that shared laughter has been one of our strongest bonds. Find the joy in life because as Ferris Bueller said on his day off _ ``Life moves pretty fast and if you don't stop and look around once in a while you are going to miss it.'' The third choice that must not be missed is to cherish your human connections, your relationships with family and friends. For several years you've had impressed upon you the importance to your career of dedication and hard work, and of course that's true. But as important as your obligations as a doctor, a lawyer, a business leader will be, you are a human being first and those human connections with spouses, with children, with friends are the most important investment you will ever make. At the end of your life, you will never regret not having passed one more test, winning one more verdict, or not closing one more deal. You will regret time not spent with a husband, a child, a friend, or a parent. We are in a transitional period right now _ fascinating and exhilarating times, learning to adjust to changes and the choices we _ men and women _ are facing. Now, maybe we should adjust faster and maybe we should adjust slower. But whatever the era, whatever the times, one thing will never change: Fathers and mothers, if you have children, they must come first. You must read to your children and you must hug your children and you must love your children. Your success as a family, our success as a society, depends not on what happens in the White House but on what happens inside your house. For over 50 years, it was said that the winner of Wellesley's annual hoop race would be the first to get married. Now they say the winner will be the first to become a CEO.... I want to offer a new legend. The winner of the hoop race will be the first to realize her dream _ not society's dreams _ her own personal dream. Who knows? Somewhere out there in this audience may even be someone who will one day follow in my footsteps and preside over the White House as the president's spouse, and I wish him well. Well, the controversy ends here, but our conversation is only beginning, and a worthwhile conversation it has been. So, as you leave Wellesley today, take with you deep thanks for the courtesy and the honor you have shared with Mrs. Gorbachev and with me. Thank you. God bless you. And may your future be worthy of your dreams.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-, AM-Summit-First Ladies
DOC.TEXT: Here are excerpts from the speech of Raisa Gorbachev at the commencement Friday of Wellesley College: I'm pleased to be with you on this momentous and exciting day when you are leaving your college and entering a new life. I congratulate you on this important occasion. I'm grateful to Mrs. Barbara Bush and to the college administration for this chance of coming to Wellesley during our stay in America. I thank college officials, professors and all of you for your kind words and warm feelings. I distinctly remember a similar summer day in Moscow, the years of my studies at Moscow University, where we were then full of plans and hopes just like you are today. Being young is a marvelous time, a time of actions and expectations, of being confident of one's abilities, and sure that everything is still ahead. I wish that all your dreams of the future come true. The president of the Soviet Union asked me to convey to you his warm regards. He also wishes you happy roads in your life. We know that people in America show great interest in what is happening in the Soviet Union, the land of perestroika. This word nowadays sounds the same in all languages of the world. We associate with perestroika the future of our country whose millions of people speak over 120 languages. Perestroika was conceived and is being implemented for the sake of the people, their dignity and equality. Its goal is to make humane ideals and values a reality. This vast and difficult task is a tough challenge. But we are confident that perestroika will succeed. The guarantee of that is the patriotism and talent of our people, their tanacity, their strength and their desire to overcome obstacles on the way, on the road they chose. In renewing our country we want to make it open to the world. The Soviet people know the value of this. We wish to have good relations with the Americans and other peoples. First, all of us, builders and sons of our own countries and peoples are different. The Soviet Union and the United States have different histories, traditions and cultures. That, however, is not the reason for mutual estrangement and suspicion. People on both sides ... realize more and more clearly there are values that bring us closer. Such values are love for one's own native country, love for one's relatives, children. We believe in what is good and the ability to combat, wars, violence, hunger and catastrophes and other threats to mankind. These values are now more important than anything else. Hamlet's question, ``To be or not to be'' today confronts not only as individuals or nations, but the entire humanity. So, what will our society be like? Not only the leaders of states, but the world community as a whole share this responsibility. We women have our special mission. Always, even in the most cruel and troubled times, women have had the mission of peacemaking, humanism, mercy and kindness. And if people in the world today are more confident of a peaceful future, we have to give a great deal of credit for that to women who are active in advocating friendship, cooperation and mutual understanding among nations. You are entering a complex and multi-faceted world. Your generation will soon assume the responsibility for everything that takes place on our planet. May good luck and happiness be with you. I wish you many good accomplishments. Thank you.

DOC.HEAD: N.H., Maine Heading For Supreme Court Battle Over Shipyard
DOC.TEXT: New Hampshire and Maine are on a crash course for a U.S. Supreme Court battle over what King George II really meant when he drew their mutual boundary. The outcome could affect thousands of jobs. Rep. Bob Smith, R-N.H., scheduled a news conference Monday to discuss a three-year research project involving the Library of Congress that was triggered by an irate worker at the Portsmouth Naval Shipyard. Smith is expected to announce that King George's 1737 ruling has been misinterpreted and that the shipyard, on an island in the Piscataqua River and listed in Kittery, Maine, is and always has been New Hampshire property. Maine officials disagree. ``I don't think there is any doubt that the shipyard hasn't been moved since Maine became a state in 1820,'' Maine Attorney General James Tierney said Thursday. He criticized Smith, who is running for U.S. Senate, for leading the investigation. The border skirmish provokes strong emotions because it affects people in their wallets. Maine collects about $3 million in income taxes annually from about 4,300 New Hampshire residents working at the shipyard. If the shipyard were in New Hampshire, they'd pay no income tax; the state is one of two that have no general sales tax or general income tax. Victor Bourre, a shipyard worker and New Hampshire resident, started exploring the question in 1987 because he was tired of paying Maine income tax. ``Everybody has always said the shipyard is in New Hampshire, so I set out to prove it,'' said Bourre, 42. ``The more I dug into it, the more I realized it's in New Hampshire and I had the proof. It's clear cut.'' According to Bourre, the territory now known as Maine originally included all land beyond _ north and east of _ the Piscataqua River. The king's 1737 ruling settled a border dispute between New Hampshire and Massachusetts, then both British colonies. That ruling moved the boundary between New Hampshire and Maine, then part of Massachusetts, to the middle of the river, he said. The recognized line today is in the channel between the shipyard and Portsmouth, N.H. But Bourre said documents, some from the 1600s, show that in 1737 the river was considered to flow between Kittery and five islands that were filled in to become Seavey Island, on which the shipyard was built in 1800. The king's middle of the river thus was between Kittery and the shipyard, putting the shipyard in New Hampshire, he said. ``That's the true boundary between Maine and New Hampshire,'' Bourre said. ``I've got the documents, and that's what they considered the river back then.'' Bourre sent his information to Smith, who relayed it to the Library of Congress. Bourre said a Library of Congress investigation upheld his assertion, and Smith sent the ensuing report to Gov. Judd Gregg. Gregg asked his attorney general's office to investigate earlier this year. Though no lawsuit has been filed, New Hampshire appears headed in that direction to claim the shipyard. ``I'm sure there will be amicable discussions with Maine, which will prove fruitless, after which I expect we'll move to file before the Supreme Court,'' New Hampshire Attorney General John Arnold told The Wall Street Journal recently. Arnold did not return telephone calls from The Associated Press, and Assistant Attorney General Dana Bisbee refused to comment. It's not the first trip to the Supreme Court for the two states. Maine and New Hampshire also went to the nation's high court in 1976, when the court ruled in Maine's favor in an offshore boundary dispute between lobster fishermen. Bourre said the shipyard dispute is complex and the relevant information is not easily obtained. ``No one knew any different. It's too complicated,'' he said. ``When you hear all the facts, you'll know why they never figured it out.'' In fact, there's even been a New Hampshire ruling in favor of Maine. In 1969, New Hampshire's then-Attorney General George Pappagianis ruled that Maine was the shipyard's rightful owner. He also based his decision on King George II's 253-year-old ruling.

DOC.HEAD: Spoleto Festival Stages Its First Wagner Opera
DOC.TEXT: For some performers at the Spoleto Festival U.S.A. success depends, literally, on a wing and a prayer. For the first time in the 14-year history of the arts festival an opera by Richard Wagner opera is being presented. ``Parsifal'' will be the festival's largest operatic production ever. A total of 269 people are involved, including performers, orchestra, choir and production staff. And three pigeons. The opera, directed by festival founder and artistic director Gian Carlo Menotti, tells the story of Parsifal and his quest for the Holy Grail. ``Parsifal'' is the last opera written by Wagner and was directed by Menotti in 1987 during Spoleto's companion festival, the Festival of Two Worlds in Spoleto, Italy. The role of Parsifal is being reprised by William Pell, who performed it at the Italian festival. Ruthild Engert-Ely, who also appeared in Italy, will again perform the role of Kundry. Both are members of the Deutsche Berlin Opera. In one scene, a pigeon flies to Parsifal as a sign from God. The opera calls for a dove to land on Parsifal's shoulder but that won't exactly happen at Spoleto. Instead, fancy pigeons are being used. They're white like doves but larger so they show up better on the stage. Also, since trainer Sherri Kaiserman and the three pigeons only arrived Thursday and the opera's first show is Saturday, there won't be time to train them to fly to the actor's shoulder. ``We're just getting it to fly to him and if it gets near him, it's a big plus,'' said Ms. Kaiserman, a trainer with the Dawn Animal Agency in New York City who has worked with animals for a decade. ``It's less common for a pigeon to land on somebody's shoulder,'' she said. ``They are more secure on a fixed object.'' The pigeons have been living in Gaillard Municipal Auditorium, where the opera will be performed, since they arrived so they can become familiar with the surroundings, Ms. Kaiserman said. ``What you have to do is spend a lot of time with them and reinforcing things,'' she said. Some birds work to noise cues and some to visual cues and the trainer must decide which bird works best in which situation, she said. ``The less intelligent the animal is, the harder it is to work with,'' said Kaiserman, who has also worked with dolphins. ``You have only their instincts to work with. It's not as simple as a dog when you give it some food and tell it to come. ``What works for one bird may not work for another,'' she added. The production also will be staged Monday. The auditorium, newly reopened, was badly damaged during Hurricane Hugo on Sept. 21 hurricane, leaving 29 dead and $5.9 billion damage in South Carolina.

DOC.HEAD: Wife May Try to Succeed Kentucky Gov. Wilkinson
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Brereton 7th graf cq
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Wallace Wilkinson says a prospective campaign by his wife to succeed him is not an effort to get around the state constitution limiting him to a single, four-year term. ``She makes up her own mind about what she wants to do and she goes and does it,'' he said in an interview. Martha Wilkinson registered a committee Wednesday to raise money for a campaign for the Democratic nomination in 1991. Her husband said his political action committee would contribute to the effort. Mrs. Wilkinson has maintained a high profile during her husband's 2{ years in office, championing adult education and the General Educational Development program. Her image appears on posters and billboards across the state promoting ``Martha's GED Army.'' She said she planned to organize and raise money for six months before making a formal announcement. ``Along about Christmastime we'll see what unfolds,'' she said. ``I think you have to consider her a very formidable potential candidate,'' said Lexington Mayor Scotty Baesler, an announced Democratic candidate. Also running in the primary are Lt. Gov. Brereton Jones and Gatewood Galbraith, a Lexington lawyer who advocates legalization of marijuana. Dr. Floyd G. Poore, a key Wilkinson supporter in 1987, is an all-but-announced candidate. Mrs. Wilkinson, who has scheduled her first fund-raiser for June 13, said she wanted to carry on her husband's programs and policies. But her husband dismissed any comparison to the surrogate election in 1966 of the late Lurleen Wallace to succeed her husband, former Alabama Gov. George C. Wallace. Wilkinson has refused to say whether he is considering running for lieutenant governor in 1991.

DOC.HEAD: Duchess of York Visits Museum on Trip to New York
DOC.TEXT: The Duchess of York, Sarah Ferguson, arrived in New York Friday and barely unpacked her bags before dashing off to the Museum of Modern Art. She arrived in the morning at the Plaza Athenee hotel and quickly left for the museum, where she toured privately, said Jessica Schwartz, a museum spokeswoman. Her formal trip begins Monday, when she will be joined by Britain's Prince Andrew, the Duke of York.

DOC.HEAD: Justice Won't Appeal Computer Virus Sentence
DOC.TEXT: The Justice Department said Friday it won't appeal the sentence of a suspended Cornell University graduate student placed on probation for paralyzing a nationwide computer network. The Justice Department, which had sought a prison term for Robert T. Morris Jr., decided last month not to appeal the lighter sentence imposed May 4 by a federal judge in Syracuse, N.Y. The decision was made after a recommendation by Assistant Attorney General Edward S.G. Dennis Jr., head of the criminal division, officials said. Morris, 23, convicted of unleashing a computer virus in 1988 that immobilized 6,000 computers linked to a government network, was placed on three years' probation, fined $10,000 and ordered to perform 400 hours of community service. The son of a government computer scientist, Morris was the first person convicted under the 1986 Computer Fraud and Abuse Act. He was found guilty in January of breaking and entering the Internet Computer Network by designing and unleashing a computer virus. Under procedures that took effect in 1987, both the prosecution and defense may appeal the judge's sentence. Justice officials felt prosecutors made their point by obtaining the felony conviction, said spokesman Doug Tillett. ``In terms of deterrent value, our point was made by the fact we brought the case,'' Tillett said. ``It was up to the discretion of the judge to mete out a proper sentence.'' Justice officials regarded Morris as ``a bright kid who shouldn't have done what he did,'' Tillett said. The case was seen as an important test of the computer fraud law. The defense argued that the government was over-reacting in trying to brand Morris a criminal. Morris' lawyers said their client didn't benefit from the computer virus, noting that others convicted of such crimes had stolen money. Morris testified that the computer virus, which he admitted designing to invade Internet, was an experiment that got out of control. Prosecutors contended that Morris carefully plotted an assault on the nationwide network of government, military and university computers that was disabled in November 1988 by the virus that originated from Morris' computer at Cornell. Defense lawyer Thomas Guidoboni said he was pleased about the government's decision not to appeal. Morris, suspended from Cornell's graduate program in computer science, must apply for readmission if he wants to return, Guidoboni said.

DOC.HEAD: Iran Ready to Talk to Britain About Rushdie
DOC.TEXT: Despite broken diplomatic ties, the government would agree to talks with Britain if they focus on the Salman Rushdie novel that has raised an uproar in the Moslem world, an Iranian official said Thursday. Hussein Musavian, director-general of the Foreign Ministry, also said Iran would continue its efforts for release of all hostages in Lebanon. His stand was at odds with statements in recent weeks by Iranian hard-liners, including former Interior Minister Ali Akbar Mohtashemi. They have said Iran should not help win release of foreign hostages in Lebanon until Washington makes a gesture of good will. Such a gesture would be to thank Iran for its help in winning the release of two American hostages in April. In his comments Thursday, Musavian said the Indian-born Rushdie's book, ``The Satanic Verses'' was ``the greatest obstacle in Tehran-London relations.'' Britain and Iran severed ties in February 1989 after the late Iranian leader Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini called on Moslems worldwide to kill Rushdie for allegedly blaspheming Islam in the novel. ``If direct talks were proposed to discuss Rushdie's blasphemous book and to exchange views about the difficulties in the way of resuming relations, we would not reject such a proposal,'' he said. He said Britain would ``have to make it clear that it respects Islam and Moslems and condemns insults to Islam, such as those contained in Rushdie's book.'' Musavian said if Britain revised its blasphemy law, it would be ``a great step'' toward resumption of ties. British Moslems angered by Rushdie's book have demanded that the law, which only applies to insults to Christianity, be changed to include Islam. Hussein Musawi, leader of the Shiite Moslem fundamentalist Islam Amal in Lebanon, called last month for Rushdie's deportation from Britain. He said if Britain expelled the author, it would help gain release of British hostages in Lebonon. British officials said they would not deport Rushdie. Musavian said he refused direct talks in Dublin, Ireland, with a British official last month because ``it was not clear what was on the agenda.'' A British Foreign Office spokesman had said it was London's understanding that the Iranians wanted a meeting. Asked whether Iran would boost its current efforts to gain release of four Britons missing in Lebanon if diplomatic ties were restored, Musavian replied ``I cannot deny this.'' The 16 Western hostages in Lebanon, including six Americans, are believed held by pro-Iranian Moslem factions. The longest-held is Terry A. Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press. He was kidnapped March 16, 1985. Musavian also said ``Iran's efforts will continue for release of all the hostages without any preconditions and for humanitarian reasons.'' He said these efforts are unrelated to ``nationality, bilateral relations, negotiations or deals.'' But he condemned the United States, saying it had refused to make a goodwill gesture to Iran and the kidnappers since the two American educators were released. He said Washington should help release hundreds of Lebanese and Palestinian Moslems imprisoned in Israel and in south Lebanon. ``If the United States and the West show good will and gain the release of most of the Palestinian and Lebanese Moslems, I have no doubt this will result in the release of all the hostages,'' he said. President Bush has said he will make ``no deals'' to free the U.S. hostages.

DOC.HEAD: Cast-Iron Fire Boxes are Collectors' Items, for Some
DOC.TEXT: How do you thank a man who worked 60 years in the fire department? Give him his own fire box, of course. The village no longer uses the old cast-iron fire boxes and is selling 50 of them for $45 each. One box was also given to Dick Tenney, who spent 60 years with the Walden Fire Department. Tenney said he didn't want one, but others feel differently, buying all but about a dozen so far. ``I don't know what the heck they want them for,'' Tenney said. ``Maybe they'd make good anchors.'' Tenney said the alarm box system served Walden well for more than 100 years. Residents would pull the alarm and then direct the fire company to the exact location of the blaze when firefighters arrived. But the alarm box system has deteriorated in recent years to the point where it was uneconomical to keep them in service, said village manager Patricia Dwyer. The fire department now depends on phone calls and automatic alarms.

We are in a transitional period right now _ fascinating and exhilarating times, learning to adjust to changes and the choices we _ men and women _ are facing. As an example, I remember what a friend said on hearing her husband complain to his buddies that he had to babysit. Quickly setting him straight, my friend told her husband that when it's your own kids, it's not called babysitting. Now, maybe we should adjust faster and maybe we should adjust slower. But whatever the era, whatever the times, one thing will never change: Fathers and mothers, if you have children, they must come first. You must read to your children and you must hug your children and you must love your children. Your success as a family, our success as a society, depends not on what happens in the White House but on what happens inside your house. For over 50 years, it was said that the winner of Wellesley's annual hoop race would be the first to get married. Now they say the winner will be the first to become a CEO. Both of those stereotypes show too little tolerance for those who want to know where the mermaids stand. So, I want to offer a new legend. The winner of the hoop race will be the first to realize her dream _ not society's dreams _ her own personal dream. Who knows? Somewhere out in this audience may even be someone who will one day follow in my footsteps and preside over the White House as the president's spouse, and I wish him well. Well, the controversy ends here, but our conversation is only beginning, and a worthwhile conversation it has been. So, as you leave Wellesley today, take with you deep thanks for the courtesy and the honor you have shared with Mrs. Gorbachev and with me. Thank you. God bless you. And may your future be worthy of your dreams.

DOC.HEAD: Liberian Rebel: Capitalism, Yes; Democracy, No; Theft, Innocent
With AM-Liberia, Bjt
DOC.TEXT:
Charles Taylor, the U.S.-educated rebel leader whose army bore down on the capital this week, is a former bureaucrat who speaks enthusiastically about capitalism _ but not democracy. Taylor denies government allegations he embezzled $1 million while he ran the General Services Administration, Liberia's purchasing agency. He is wanted in the United States for escaping custody pending extradition to Liberia. Taylor, 42, spent the 1970s working as a mechanic at a plastics factory in Boston before graduating with an economics degree from Bentley College in Waltham, Mass. During those years, Taylor says he headed an organization of 35,000 Liberian exiles in the United States. He said they were working to overthrow the rule of his country by the descendants of freed American slaves who founded the nation in 1847. Taylor returned to Liberia after Samuel Doe took power in a 1979 military coup, giving the indigenous population control of the West African country for the first time in its history. Doe named Taylor head of the General Services Administration. Taylor fled to the United States in 1983 to escape charges of embezzlement. He was arrested in the United States but escaped before he could be extradited. ``I skipped from jail to escape Doe's lies,'' Taylor has said. He said all charges would be dropped if he toppled Doe's government. Taylor's revolt began Dec. 24, 1989, when he crossed the Ivory Coast border into Liberia with a small band of men. They accused Doe of corruption, mismanagement and human rights abuses. Taylor based his men in Nimba County, an area traditionally hostile to Doe. Doe's forces responded with savage attacks on tribal groups that supported Taylor. International agencies say hundreds were killed, and the atrocities appeared to have increased support for Taylor. Taylor has made good use of the news media, making frequent telephone calls to the British Broadcasting Corp. and other news organizations. Last month, he gave a news conference for foreign journalists in Tapeta, in the heart of rebel-held territory about 100 miles northeast of Monrovia, the capital. The bearded rebel said he wanted to assure the United States, Liberia's main foreign aid donor, that he was committed to good relations. ``The United States has permanent interests in Liberia, and not permanent friends,'' he said. ``I would hope that we would have a real good marriage and a real honeymoon.'' But his declarations on democracy have provided little cheer to the opposition parties that had been contesting Doe's power. Taylor said he wouldn't share power with opposition parties. ``Don't think we are going to turn the government over to someone to screw up,'' he said. He said his plans do not include elections for at least three years and perhaps five years. As a civilian, however, Taylor insists he is different from Doe, who made his career in the military. He said he was leading ``a grass-roots civilian uprising to get rid of a dictator'' but harbored no dictatorial ambitions himself. ``It is so easy to make a dictator in Liberia, and I am not going to permit myself to be one,'' he has promised.
Taylor describes himself as a ``church-going Christian'' and pledges to restore traditional Christian values. ``Before, Liberians were interested in school, in church,'' he said. ``Nobody thinks of going to church anymore. Everybody talks of ritualistic killings.'' The vast majority of the country's 2.5 million people practice traditional African beliefs. Black magic, or juju, is widely practiced. Taylor wears two woven amulets around his neck. His guerrillas say the amulets are magic charms that protect the wearer from bullets.

DOC.HEAD: North Testifies Before New Grand Jury Investigating Iran-Contra
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 3-4 beginning `North repeatedly ...' with 4 grafs to UPDATE with North lawyer shouting at prosecutor. Picks up 5th graf psv `Walsh's office ...' ^By PETE YOST
DOC.TEXT: Oliver North testified Friday before a newly empaneled federal grand jury that is continuing the investigation of the Iran-Contra scandal. The former White House aide was accompanied into the grand jury room by a prosecutor from the office of independent counsel Lawrence Walsh. North repeatedly left the secret proceedings during an entire day of testimony to confer with his attorneys in a courthouse hallway. Periodic exits from grand jury proceedings enable witnesses to receive legal advice and to keep their lawyers informed about what areas of questioning the government is interested.
