During one break, North lawyer Brendan Sullivan began shouting at Iran-Contra prosecutor Craig Gillen. ``You don't intimidate me and I don't intimidate you,'' replied Gillen, who then returned to the grand jury room. North followed a few minutes later. Walsh's office is trying to determine the precise roles that then-President Reagan, then-Vice President Bush and others played in the affair, sources familiar with the investigation said in April. The sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said North and former national security adviser John Poindexter were likely to be subpoenaed and granted immunity from prosecution in exchange for their grand jury testimony. North appearedn federal court a week ago in a closed session for which all records are under seal. The grand jury delving into the scandal began meeting last month, after Poindexter's April felony convictions. Walsh's office has repeatedly refused to make any comment on the latest phase of its 3{-year-old investigation. Iran-Contra prosecutors have had more than a year to pore over about 2,800 pages of notebooks that North kept while he worked at the National Security Council. The daily notebook entries refer to occasional meetings with Bush and Reagan. They also refer to dozens of contacts with CIA officers such as Alan Fiers and State Department officials such as Elliott Abrams who kept track of the Nicaraguan Contras. North, 46, was convicted May 4, 1989, of aiding and abetting an obstruction of Congress, altering and destroying National Security Council documents and receiving an illegal gratuity. An appeal of his convictions is pending before the U.S. Court of Appeals. Poindexter, convicted in April of conspiracy, obstructing Congress and making false statements in the scandal, is scheduled to be sentenced June 11. The former national security adviser faces up to 25 years in prison and $1.25 million in fines.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Greets Crowds Second Straight Day
With AM-Summit Rdp Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev hopped out of his limousine Friday and worked the crowds for a second straight day to the delight of passersby in downtown Washington. ``He was a very warm, very personal type of person,'' said Keith White, who was among those Gorbachev greeted on busy Connecticut Avenue. Gorbachev's brief stop came as his entourage was returning to the Soviet Embassy from a summit session at the White House. He also left his limousine on Thursday, to the applause and cheers of a crowd of about 500 onlookers. On Friday, Gorbachev greeted pedestrians about a half-block from the spot where he had surprised security agents in 1987 by doing the same thing. Some people who remembered the 1987 incident had gathered there in hopes Gorbachev would repeat the performance. The Soviet president shook hands with several people, at one point crossing the wide avenue to greet more people. ``As opposed to him being afraid, he initiated all of the conversations and the handshakes,'' White said.

DOC.HEAD: Romania, Bulgaria Begin Assessing Damage of Quake
DOC.TEXT: Romania and Bulgaria on Friday began assessing the damage of an earthquake and more than 120 aftershocks that jolted central Europe. Fourteen people were reported killed and 1,000 injured as the quake rumbled through five countries Wednesday. Nine people were killed in Romania, one in Bulgaria and four in the Soviet Union. The quake also struck Turkey and Yugoslavia, but no deaths were reported in those countries. The strongest aftershock rocked the greater part of Romania and northern Bulgaria at 3:18 a.m. Thursday. Thousands of people jumped from their beds and fled into the streets, where many spent the rest of the night. The aftershocks continued Friday. The Romanian government, trying to cope with its third major earthquake in 13 years, said in a communique Friday it would give top priority to repairs to buildings. The Ministry of National Economy said it had no estimate of damage. The northern Bulgarian city of Silistra on Thursday appealed for aid, saying it urgently needed glass, cement, bricks and tiles to repair damaged homes, schools and a hospital, the Bulgarian news agency BTA reported. Citing ``preliminary data,'' BTA said the quake destroyed 39 residential buildings, made 153 unfit to live in and damaged 6,018 more across the nation. Nineteen school buildings, 11 kindergartens, three hospitals and 63 public and farm buildings also were damaged, BTA said. Dumitru Enescu, director of Romania's Earth Physics Institute, said the quake and main aftershock were centered in the Vrancea Mountains, part of the Carpathian range about 200 miles northeast of Bucharest. ``We estimate that this seismological activity in Vrancea and the aftershocks are going down and losing intensity,'' he said. Richter scale readings of Wednesday's quake from seismological stations around the world ranged from 6.5 to 7.5, putting it in the range of major to extremely powerful. The Richter scale is a gauge of the energy released by an earthquake, as measured by the ground motion recorded on a seismograph. Every increase of one number means that the ground motion is 10 times greater. Enescu said he believed the quake had a magnitude of between 6.5 and 6.8. The Uppsala Seismological Center in Sweden said the quake was very deep, about 63 miles, causing it to be felt so widely. Focsani, capital of Vrancea County where the quake was centered, escaped without a shattered window. But up to 20 Romanians were slightly injured in Thursday's powerful aftershock, and two others were hurt more seriously, medical assistant Grigore Nica said. A prefabricated block of 64 apartments and the local bank suffered severe structural damage Thursday. City Hall suffered major cracks in the ceiling and walls. Locksmith Vasile Ignat aid there was panic in Focsani when the aftershock struck. ``The power was cut off in certain areas. People hit the street. They panicked that another quake would come,'' he said. ``In the evening, they no longer dared to go into their homes.'' In Bucharest, a few camped out again in tents on Thursday night but the panic subsided by Friday. Some buildings in the capital suffered serious structural damage, but otherwise the city escaped serious damage. In northern Bulgaria, cities and villages on the Danube river _ including Ruse, Silistra and Svishtov _ ``were panic-stricken'' after Thursday's strong aftershock, BTA reported. It said thousands of people milled in the streets all night or fled in their cars.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Commander of Quantico Marine Base Retires
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Marine Corps' first woman general is retiring and the service said farewell with a battalion-strength parade. Hundreds of civilian and military observers were on hand for Thursday's ceremony at the Quantico Marine Corps Base marking the retirement of Brig. Gen. Gail M. Reals. ``You saw many firsts. But most importantly, you were first a Marine,'' Marine Commandant Gen. Al Gray wrote to Reals, commander of the base. Reals, 54, had more than 35 years of military service. ``I've been thinking, I'll be unemployed for the first time since I was 13 years old,'' she said. ``I leave 20 pounds lighter than I was at 19, when I joined the Marine Corps.'' Reals began her military career in 1954; her first assignment was as a stenographer. She became a commissioned officer in September 1961 and rose to her current rank in February 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Proposes `Council of Europe' to Tackle German Issue
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts news grafs 7-10 with comment from briefing, ``White House xxx''
DOC.TEXT: Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, in a move to break a summit stalemate, has proposed the creation of a new ``Council of all Europe'' to play a decisive role in shaping the military future of Germany, U.S. sources said Friday. The United States and the Soviet Union would participate in the deliberations along with other members of the NATO and Warsaw Pact alliances as well as neutral countries. Gorbachev raised the idea with President Bush at their opening summit session Thursday, the sources said, and the two leaders assigned their top diplomatic aides to pursue the concept next week in Copenhagen, Denmark, and again in Berlin later this month. ``We are prepared to work with it. It is not something we would reject out of hand,'' said a U.S. official familiar with the details. He spoke only on condition he not be identified. At the start of his second day of summit talks with Bush, Gorbachev was asked if Soviet concern about a revival of German militarism would be allayed by assigning the issue to the European Security Conference, under which the new council would function. ``The president and I are discussing precisely these matters, and I must say that this is a very substantive discussion, a discussion in which we are engaged in a spirit of great responsibility and cooperation,'' Gorbachev replied. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said without elaboration that ``some different formulations of the problem'' were discussed at the summit. He said the Bush administration was interested in strengthening both NATO and the European Security Conference and also ``taking a look at their functions.'' However, Fitzwater said, ``that was not focused on in any detail at yesterday's meeting.'' The Soviet spokesman, Arkady A. Maslennikov said Moscow wants to create ``a kind of permanent structure which will create stability and cooperation in Europe,'' perhaps by combining existing organizations or possibly setting The Soviet plan calls for annual meetings of the leaders of the 35 Western, neutral and Eastern states that make up the conference, There would be more frequent meetings of their foreign ministers, a permanent secretariat or administrative staff, and military and civilian ``conflict management'' centers would be set up. Bush and Gorbachev have concluded they cannot solve the German question before the windup of their summit on Sunday. Consequently, they assigned high-ranking aides to explore avenues of settlement. Gorbachev's proposal stems from his concerns over the unraveling of the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact and a desire to be included more directly in European consultations, especially on Germany. ``They are afraid that the process of German unification is increasing their isolation,'' a U.S. official said. Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze earlier had suggested placing a united Germany in both NATO and the Warsaw Pact, but the U.S. reaction was cool. Now Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Shevardnadze will explore the proposal for a new European council and possibly other approaches when they attend a human rights conference in Copenhagen next Tuesday and then a meeting on Germany in Berlin tentatively set for June 22. ``They (the Soviets) want one game in which they are an equal player,'' the U.S. official said. ``It is not something we are opposed to in principle. It is an extension of ideas we are prepared to work with.'' The European security conference consists of 34 nations and the Vatican which signed the 1975 Helsinki agreement to ease East-West tensions in Europe and promote human rights. An administration official said Bush was telephoning West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl to assure him that the summit had not altered the U.S. position on the future of a united Germany. The White House announced that Bush had invited Kohl to a White House dinner next Friday. A spokesman said the dinner was arranged before the summit and was not based on developments over the German issue. Bush and Kohl insist on full membership in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization for the new Germany to be formed by the unification of East and West Germany. In Bonn, meanwhile, West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher, who has been the point man for the Western allies in seeking accommodation with Moscow, urged the superpowers to lay the foundation for a ``new Europe.'' Genscher, who will meet with Baker in Copenhagen next Tuesday, said Germany should reduce its military forces to help ease Soviet jitters over a united Germany.

DOC.HEAD: Condemned Killer Awaits Court Ruling, Execution Now Set For Saturday Night
DOC.TEXT: A murderer whose execution was delayed even though he wants to die could be put to death Saturday night. The 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals issued a stay Thursday night for Thomas Baal, hours before he was to be executed. The stay expires at noon Saturday and Baal's death warrant is good through the weekend, said Warden Pete Demosthenes. The execution, by lethal injection, was reset for Saturday night. Baal, 26, was sentenced to die for killing a bus driver during a 1988 robbery in Las Vegas. He was housed in a last-night cell next to the death chamber at the Nevada State Prison and spent his time Friday talking on the telephone, the warden said. Demosthenes said Baal had calmed down following an outburst when he was advised of the temporary stay issued by the 9th Circuit. The stay came on a request from Baal's parents, who contend that long-term mental problems and possible brain damage prevent their son from making a rational decision about his appeals. When Baal heard about the stay, he threatened to escape and commit more crimes if he was sent to a mental institution, according to State Prison Director Ron Angelone. Angelone said Baal was irate at his attorney, public defender Pat Flanagan, who won the delay. ``He got real upset and he called his public defender and told him he didn't want anyone to get involved, that he had no right to get involved in it,'' Angelone said. The appeals court, in a 2-1 decision, said the delay was needed to get more information from U.S. District Judge Howard McKibben, who earlier Thursday denied a stay for Baal. Justice Harry Pregerson, who wrote the decision, questioned whether Baal had received a proper competency hearing to determine if he was capable of making a rational decision to give up his appeal. Justice Alex Koznski dissented. McKibben ruled Baal was competent after he told the judge, in a hearing conducted by telephone: ``I just want to go die and be free. That's all.'' Baal's execution would be Nevada's fifth and the 129th nationally since the U.S. Supreme Court in 1976 cleared the way for states to resume use of the death penalty. Nevada's last executions were in June 1989. In the same week, confessed murderers Sean Flanagan and William ``Bud'' Thompson were given lethal injections after both said they wanted no further appeals.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Lawsuit Over Feline Appraiser Argued
DOC.TEXT: Toby really wasn't qualified to be a certified real-estate appraiser, but the cat's owner shouldn't be punished for getting him a license, a federal judge ruled Friday. U.S. District Judge Ernest C. Torres dismissed a lawsuit by the National Association of Real Estate Appraisers claiming that Toby's owner, Roy C. Schaeffer, made the organization look foolish by admitting a cat as an appraiser. Torres said the association did not prove its contention that it was defrauded and defamed when Toby _ listed on his appraiser certification and in court documents as Tobias F. (for feline) Schaeffer _ was admitted. There was no question that Schaeffer had submitted a false, although incomplete, application in the cat's name, Torres said. But it was true that the cat had been granted a professional designation, which was all that Schaeffer claimed. ``There's no evidence that anyone understood or reasonably could have understood that Mr. Schaeffer ... said that plaintiffs knowingly admitted cats,'' Torres said. ``The plaintiff has failed to prove that the statements in question were false, and, hence the claim for defamation is (dismissed).'' Although there were muffled giggles throughout two days of testimony, both sides said the issues were significant. The association and its owner, Robert G. Johnson, claimed Schaeffer made the organization the laughingstock of the industry when he publicized his cat's membership. Schaeffer claimed the integrity of his industry was at stake. He said he submitted his cat's name for membership in the National Association of Real Estate Appraisers to prove his contention that it did not have high professional standards. He successfully used the incident to press Congress to approve a national registration and licensing system for appraisers. The association's attorney, Michael Dady, had asked Torres to rule against Schaeffer on the grounds that any national organization could be duped into admitting unqualified people. ``If we had to verify everything in this country, the whole system would shut down,'' Dady argued in court Thursday. Torres said Friday that argument had no weight. The judge said ``seemingly elementary steps,'' such as asking Rhode Island members of the association about Tobias F. Schaeffer or requiring a completed appraisal from him, could have avoided the incident.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev: Israelis Using Emigres to Complicate Mideast Problem
DOC.TEXT: Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev said Friday Israeli officials are using Jewish emigres from the Soviet Union to stymie peace efforts in the Middle East. ``We are really in a difficult situation now as a result of certain actions of the Israeli government,'' Gorbachev told congressional leaders at a Soviet Embassy meeting Friday morning. ``The situation there is very difficult now, (and) has been exacerbated recently.'' He said the Soviet Union wanted to work with the United States to find a solution for Middle East peace, and noted the Soviet step toward easing restrictions on the Jewish emigration. ``People are leaving, and they settle them on (the) occupied territories and provoke clashes,'' he said. ``They are provoking a problem between us and the Arabs. The Arab presidents are remonstrating with us.'' ``This is something that I think the Israelis are doing on purpose in order to make a solution very difficult,'' he added. Gorbachev also said reaching a solution to Middle East peace must be reached internationally, following Arab proposals rejected by Israel that talks be held under the aegis of the Soviet Union, United States and other major powers. ``If we begin with internationalizing that process, we will be able to restore diplomatic relations with Israel,'' Gorbachev said. ``We are ready to be with you, the guarantors of independence and security of the state of Israel, of all Middle Eastern states including Israel.'' He urged the United States to work with Palestine Liberation Organization Chairman Yasser Arafat. ``He is the person with whom you can work for a settlement,'' Gorbachev said. ``He has the kind of attitude that makes that possible. And if you are able to work with him to apply some influence, I think that he may evolve even further.''

DOC.HEAD: Soviet `Refuseniks' Demonstrate in Downtown Moscow
With AM-Summit Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: About 50 Jewish ``refuseniks'' rallied in downtown Moscow on Friday evening, urging that their plight to emigrate not be forgotten as Soviet and U.S. leaders met in Washington. The half-hour demonstration on a puddle-filled square in front of the Lenin Library was timed to coincide with one in Washington. It occurred with little harassment from Soviet authorities. Two vans filled with police were parked nearby. Several plainclothes police who made little attempt to hide their walkie-talkies milled in the crowd. But only one uniformed officer walked up to the demonstrators and asked them to disperse. The officer walked away when protesters showed that they had applied to the authorities to hold the rally. They held up posters and unfurled banners that said ``Refuseniks are the hostages of perestroika!'' and ``Shame on anti-Semitism.'' ``Our demonstration is synchronized with a demonstration in Washington. We insist that our human rights are violated,'' said Mike Shapiro. He said he has been denied an emigration visa even though he stopped his secret work for the Soviet government more than 12 years ago. Stephen Cohen of Palm Beach, Fla., a member of the board of directors of the Union of Councils for Soviet Jews, said there are 400 to 500 families of Jews who have been refused permission to emigrate because Soviet officials say they have knowledge of state secrets. In November, the Supreme Soviet legislature gave preliminary approval to a bill that allows emigration for virtually anyone who has entry permission from another country and no outstanding alimony obligations, criminal charges or recent knowledge of state secrets. It sets a limit of five years on the period a citizen can be kept from emigrating because of access to secrets. But Jewish activists claim that the bill is vaguely worded and might still be used to restrict emigration. The bill has not yet come up for a final vote. The United States is withholding action on loosening trade sanctions on the Soviet Union until the immigration law is passed. Leonid Stonov, one long-time refusenik who was told in recent weeks that he will be allowed to emigrate in August, said anti-Semitism is on the rise and that he sees a difficult future for Jews in the Soviet Union. ``All the Jewish culture, Jewish tradition, Jewish life _ everything was ruined here during the Stalin era and Brezhnev era. There is no basement, no foundation for establishing here a real Jewish life,'' he said. Mark M. Kotlyar, a refusenik from Kiev, was asked how he felt when he saw President Mikhail S. Gorbachev cheered on the streets of Washington this week. He smiled and said it was a difficult question to answer. ``On the one hand, it's important that people be friendly, that they meet our leaders, that they give them a warm reception,'' Kotlyar said. ``But on the other hand, I think that they are too rapturous about Gorbachev. He is not that good. He is not.'' Pamela Braun Cohen, national president of the Union of Councils for Soviet Jews, acknowledged that Gorbachev has brought change to the Soviet Union. ``The fact that we are here holding this demonstration today and the fact that the people who have held the demonstration were not taken away _ you can't dismiss it,'' she said. But she said the American public needs to be ``more tempered'' in its approach to Gorbachev, and that might ``better serve the human rights movement here in this country and better serve the United States in their relationship with the Soviets.''

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Official: Guerrillas Planned to Attack U.S. Embassy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: COMBINES a0683 and a0631, with minor editing throughout. DELETES final four grafs to trim. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Palestinian guerrillas who launched a seaborne attack on Israel this week planned to attack the U.S. Embassy in Tel Aviv as well as hotels and stores, a top Israeli official said today. Maps carried by the guerrillas indicated killings would be carried out in the densely populated Tel Aviv beachfront hotel district where the embassy is located, said the source, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Locations circled on the maps indicated a large Tel Aviv department store as another potential target, he said. Four guerrillas were killed and 12 captured in Wednesday's raid, which was masterminded by Mohammed Abbas, the leader of a PLO faction. ``During the debriefing (of the guerrillas) ... it was established that one of the targets in the vicinity of the hotel district was the U.S. Embassy,'' the source said. ``Wherever they can, they try to accomplish a spectacular mass killing. The U.S. Embassy was a good target that would make headlines,'' he said. The comment was the first indication the guerrillas had planned to attack the U.S. Embassy. Earlier today, Israel's military intelligence chief was quoted as saying PLO chief Yasser Arafat probably did not know beforehand about the raid. The comment by Maj. Gen. Amnon Shahak contradicted Foreign Ministry officials who claimed Arafat met last week with Abbas and almost certainly knew of the planned strike. Abbas leads the Palestine Liberation Front, the PLO faction that claimed responsibility for Wednesday's foiled attack. Israel claims Libya helped mount the strike, which was aimed at crowded Israeli beaches, and Shahak's comments in an interview with the Yediot Ahronot daily provided the most detailed account yet of that alleged involvement. But a Libyan official today denied Libyan involvement in the raid. Gadallah Azouz el-Talhi, Libya's foreign minister, said: ``Some news media claimed that a Libyan ship carried the speedboats that tried to go to shore. Libya has no connection at all with the operation,'' el-Talhi said during a visit to Egypt. Shahak also said Israel knew ``with complete certainty'' that the PLO has planned attacks on Soviet Jewish immigrants to Israel ``in every possible location and at every opportunity.'' The statement was the first public comment by security officials about threats against Soviet immigrants. Israeli newspapers have quoted officials as saying Israel stepped up security because of expected guerrilla attacks on Soviet Jews. Shahak said Arafat probably didn't know about Abbas' plans to attack Israel. ``We don't have information pointing to the fact that he knew ahead of time,'' Shahak said. Arafat said Thursday the PLO was not involved in the raid. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir called on Washington to abandon the dialogue it began with the PLO in December 1988 after Arafat renounced terrorism. Arafat avoided condemning the raid outright, and said he could not expel Abbas from the elected PLO Executive Committee for the attempted raid: ``He was elected in a democratic way by the Palestine National Council, and only the council has a say on that.'' Abbas' faction said today in a statement issued by its office in Baghdad, Iraq, that it would continue its attacks. U.S. Ambassador to Israel William Brown said today that Arafat's response was unacceptable. ``He has ... attempted to absolve the PLO from responsibility. Rest assured that we're going to continue to look at that very, very seriously,'' Brown said during a tour of the northern Israeli town of Migdal Haemek. Israel radio, which carried the remarks, said Brown did not say whether the United States would end its dialogue with the PLO. Shahak said the guerrillas involved in the seaborne raid trained in a camp set aside for them by Libyan authorities on the Mediterranean coast. ``The investigation shows beyond doubt that Libyan military personnel were involved in all stages of preparation,'' Shahak said in the newspaper interview. Earlier reports have said the guerrillas boarded a Libyan merchant ship in Libya's port of Benghazi that also transported speedboats to carry out the attack. ``Libyans helped to move the terrorists to the ship. The ship itself had a Libyan crew, and aboard was a Libyan military officer,'' Shahak said. The intelligence chief also said some of the guerrillas had been in Libya for more than two years, and that training for the attack began several months ago. Israeli officials have refused to comment on speculation that Israel would retaliate against Libya. Former military intelligence chief Yoshua Saguy called for such a military strike. ``Libya needs to know that, like we reached them in the past, we will reach them again,'' Saguy told army radio. Saguy, a member of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's right-wing Likud bloc, also suggested that Israel was reponsible for the April 16, 1988, assassination of PLO military commander Khalil Wazir in Tunis. The slaying was widely attributed to Israeli commandos, but Israel has denied any involvement.

DOC.HEAD: Verdict From the Sunglasses Set: Gorby's `An All-Right Guy'
With AM-Summit Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: While Mikhail Gorbachev was talking to George Bush in the White House Friday, some of the landlords _ the American people _ inspected their property. They gawked at the portraits and the dinnerware, treading the floors that Lincoln trod. Later, on the street, they said they liked this man Gorbachev, and wished him well. ``I think he's wonderful, a great man; he has a wonderful personality,'' said tour bus driver John Lauro, his bare arm still carrying the girlie tattoo acquired as a submarine seaman during the Vietnam War. ``The hard part will be changing the minds of the old guard _ in both countries.'' ``I would want him to know that he has a lot of support among the American people,'' said Kristin Garner of Richmond, Va., whose mother, Ann, brought her here for the day, sort of a college graduation gift. What would Kristin say to Gorbachev, if she had the chance? ``Zdrastvyuitye, tovarish, Gorbachev!'' she beamed, proud of her year's study of Russian at the University of North Carolina. ``Hello, comrade Gorbachev!'' Mrs. Garner wanted to see the Impressionists at the National Gallery of Art; Kristin insisted they first stand outside the White House, on the chance that Gorby would come by. The gamble paid off: The whole screaming motorcade streaked through the White House gates while they waited. Comments from these random tourists _ cameras strung around their necks, some wearing the official tourist uniform of T-shirts and shorts _ put meat on the bones of the latest opinion samplings. Last week, pollsters Peter Hart and Robert Teeter reported that 59 percent of Americans view Gorbachev positively. None among these tourists on the White House sidewalk had anything negative to say, although a caveat came from 52-year-old schoolteacher Edward Schneider, who brought 38 student government representatives from District 10, the Bronx, N.Y., to Washington. ``He's running into the same problems Nixon had _ loved outside the country more than inside,'' Schneider said. ``Gorbachev's a smart politician but I'm not sure he's calling the shots. I think the army told him, `do something about the economy before we do.' ``The Afghanistan war was his Vietnam,'' Schneider said. ``He didn't let Eastern Europe go because he loves democracy. He let them go because he couldn't afford to keep them. I think he was shocked by the complete rejection of communism in East Europe. That came as a surprise.'' Robert and Arlene Schroeder of Mequon, Wis. were delighted to share Washington with Gorbachev, even though Mrs. Schroeder feared the White House would be closed to tourists _ just as it had been on two previous visits, one during World War II and one while Harry Truman was having the place renovated. Schroeder, a salesman, said he figured the Cold War is pretty much over. ``Sooner or later, I assumed something had to happen, good or bad.'' he said. ``He's done more for the Russian people than anyone in my lifetime,'' said Mike Erixon of Denver, Colo., who runs a company that makes batteries for the aerospace industry. The end of the Cold War could be bad for the battery business, acknowledged Erixson. ``But I'm all for world peace.'' Louis Mattingly, 14, was one of the 43 eighth graders from Bardstown, Ky. who rode 11 hours through the night on John Lauro's tour bus. Louis wore a fluorescent red cap that he'd acquired at a souvenir stand outside the Roy Rogers fast-food restaurant. ``I think of Gorbachev as a person who is trying to make peace between two countries and doing a good job of it,'' he said. Chimed in Lauro: ``I like to talk to people on my bus. These kids think Gorbachev is an all-right guy and is trying to bring peace to the world.''

DOC.HEAD: Wellesley Seniors Applaud Barbara Bush, Raisa Gorbachev
With AM-Summit-First Ladies, Bjt
LaserPhotos XWEL1, LaserColor XWEL103
DOC.TEXT: Barbara Bush on Friday easily won over most of the Class of 1990 of Wellesley College with charm and a spirited speech that put to rest much of the controversy about her selection as commencement speaker. Mrs. Bush's address, in which she urged graduates of the elite women's school to follow their dreams and be true to themselves, was wildly applauded. The 575 seniors arriving for the speech were greeted by letters placed on their chairs urging Mrs. Bush to be a stronger proponent of women's issues. Mrs. Bush, who appeared with Soviet first lady Raisa Gorbachev, received her loudest cheers as she closed by saying: ``Somewhere out in this audience may even be someone who will one day follow in my footsteps and preside over the White House as the president's spouse. I wish him well!'' One senior had painted on her mortar board ``Barbara Bush for President 1992.'' One wore a picture of President and Mrs. Bush, with the first lady dressed in a suit and power tie, the president wearing a dress. The conflict over Mrs. Bush stemmed from a petition signed last month by 150 of Wellesley's 2,200 students. The petition complained that her selection as speaker ran counter to the school's philosophy that women should be honored for their own career achievements. ``I thought it was lovely _ and I was one who signed the petition,'' said Betsy Pollard, 21, a graduating senior from Pepper Pike, Ohio. ``I was very moved by it. I thought she was great. She knew all about us and all about our class and I appreciated it.'' Deana Smythe, 21, a senior from Medina, N.Y., said she did not sign the petition and was in favor of Mrs. Bush as commencement speaker. ``I thought it was wonderful,'' Smythe said. ``I especially liked the spirit of the two of them up there together.'' The seniors who drew up the letters that were placed on the seats said they would give a copy to Mrs. Bush. The students also made available purple armbands _ the class color _ to be worn by students sympathetic with the letter, which asked Mrs. Bush to support such women's issues as day care, family leave and reproductive rights. But the letter also said that ``in honoring Barbara Bush as our commencement speaker, we celebrate all the unknown women who have dedicated their lives to the service of others. The purple armbands you see today are in honor of these very women.'' When college President Nan Keohane cited that section in her remarks, loud applause erupted. Mrs. Gorbachev and Mrs. Bush smiled broadly and clasped hands. The original petition, co-authored by seniors Peggy Reid, 21, and Susana Cardenas, 21, gained national attention. Cardenas said students never wanted publicity about the controversy and did not want to be ``discourteous'' to Mrs. Bush. But the issue divided the students, as did the letter. Before the ceremony, Jennifer Swihart, 21, of McLean, Va., said, ``I probably won't wear the armband. I didn't sign the petition. I think she's a cool lady, and that telling women what they can do is a form of reverse oppression. But I think this has been good to open up dialogue.'' But Susan Brandzel, 21, of Seattle, said: ``We're wearing the armbands as a tribute to the kind of work she has done. But we hope it encourages her to speak out on issues, and we hope it encourages her to use the power she has to work more for women's issues.'' Many students, teachers and alumnae, alarmed by the presence of a large media podium inside the enormous tent, complained of a circus atmosphere. But the mood was largely a happy one at the 112th Wellesley commencement, set up for 5,500 guests, the largest graduation gathering ever. Mrs. Gorbachev's speech focused on perestroika, which, she said, had helped pave the way for easing tensions around the world. ``We know that people in America showed great interest in what is happening in the Soviet Union, the land of perestroika. This word now sounds the same in all languages of the world,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: History's Ghosts Conjured Up as Germans Placed in Summit Spotlight
With AM-Summit Negotations, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Some unpleasant memories confronted Germany as this week's summit talks turned to German unification _ among them the rise of fascism and European suffering at the hands of Germans twice this century. But the Germans have played a big role in recalling the memories, convinced that is the best way to show the Soviet Union and the rest of the world they do not want a replay of the past. The main German question under discussion by Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and President Bush is the military status of a united Germany. The United States and West Germany have insisted the state belong to NATO, but Gorbachev has proposed letting the 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe settle a united Germany's military future. West Germany initially responded cautiously. A government official in Bonn pointed out Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher has already called for strengthening of the council. However, no West German leaders have suggested the council should decide what military alliance West Germany should belong. Friday's Frankfurter Rundschau newspaper said the summit's success hinges on the ``German question.'' It noted that the 1987 summit between Gorbachev and former President Reagan was a success by virtue of an agreement to begin scrapping intermediate-range nuclear weapons. But it said in a commentary that the German military issue far outweighed any other considerations at the current summit. ``When Mikhail Gorbachev and Ronald Reagan got together, the luster of the disarmament treaty cast a gleam on the meeting. ``But not much of a show can be made of that (disarmament) in view of the question of German unity and German alliance membership,'' said the newspaper. The Soviets have said a big reason they oppose a united Germany in NATO is the deep-seated memory of the Nazi Third Reich and the carnage World War II brought to the Soviet Union. But West Germans have tried to use the past to reassure the Soviets, and to state Germans' right to make their own decisions. Shortly before the summit, Kohl pointedly reminded Moscow that pushing Germany ``into isolation'' has a historic precedent. ``There must be no second Versailles,'' Kohl said, referring to the 1919 treaty that humiliated Germany and has been linked to the rise of fascism. ``Whenever Germany chose _ out of overbearing blindness or criminal hubris _ to pursue a separate path or when former enemies forced it into isolation following its defeat, the immediate consequence for Europe was conflict, instability and uncertainty,'' Kohl said. West German leaders believe that anchoring a united Germany to NATO is actually the best means of protecting the Soviet Union's security interests. ``A Germany that is not bound into an alliance in a clear and effective way must also appear to the Soviet Union as a greater danger for stable development in Europe,'' said Uwe Ronneburger, chairman of the Defense Committee in West Germany's parliament, the Bundestag. Burkhard Dobiey, a high-level official for the West German Inter-German Relations Ministry, said he believed the Soviets are truly worried about German military might. ``But the reality is, Germany is a state that has renounced every use of violence or threat of violence,'' he said in a radio interview Thursday night. ``It represents no threat to other nations, also not to the Soviet Union. ``I think the real problem for the Soviet leadership is that for decades NATO has been portrayed in Moscow as the arch-enemy. The problem is, how one changes this picture.'' Genscher has suggested broader financial ties between the Soviets and the West, coupled with drastic disarmament and the eventual development of new security institutions, as ways to help preserve European stability. He said Friday that the alliance debate concerns creating conditions in Europe that make NATO membership ``attractive also for the Soviet Union.'' ``This means, the fundamental change in Europe will transform a confrontational relationship to one of cooperation,'' he said on Deutschlandfunk radio.

DOC.HEAD: Five Former USDA Leaders Urge Upgraded Ties with Soviets
With AM-Soviet-Economy
DOC.TEXT: Five former agriculture secretaries and more than two dozen farm-related groups called Friday for an upgrading of trade ties with the Soviet Union so far resisted by the Bush administration. ``There is a large potential for further development of this market to the mutual benefit of the United States and the Soviet Union,'' said the statement. It came as Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev was visiting the United States and followed a meeting at which Gorbachev urged cooperation from members of Congress who have resisted granting Moscow better trade ties. The statement called for granting the Soviets most-favored-nation status, which would give them the same preferential tariffs given the United States' other top trading partners. The Soviet Union was the second largest single-nation importer of U.S. farm products last year, buying a record $3.6 billion. President Bush said recently it was too early to grant most-favored-nation status to the Soviets, although he recently renewed that standing for the Chinese despite protests over last year's bloody crackdown in Tiananmen Square. Trade negotiations are currently under way between the United States and the Soviets. ``An important part of that agreement would be most-favored-nation status for the Soviets, giving the Soviets the same access to our market as enjoyed by most of our trading partners,'' the statement said. The signers included former agriculture secretaries John R. Block, Orville L. Freeman, Earl L. Butz, Bob Bergland and Richard E. Lyng. The statement was issued by National Agricultural Advisory Committee of the Citizens Network for Foreign Affairs, whose directors include former top government officials as well as business and labor leaders. ``While MFN will not solve the Soviet Union's economic problems, it would help to build a relationship that all sides can count on for the long term and be a basis for bringing the Soviet Union more fully into the world trading system,'' the statement said. It did say that to ``strengthen trade and investment ties between our two countries, the Soviet Union must continue to expand individual freedom, including the right of self-determination and emigration and reach a peaceful and equitable resolution of the Baltic situation.'' Other signers ranged from the American Farm Bureau Federation to the National Farmers Union to Cargill Inc., the agricultural export-import giant. They included producer groups specializing in meat, oats, soybeans, wheat, corn, pork and rice.

DOC.HEAD: Doctors Say Imelda `Much Improved,' Lawyers Say Not Enough
DOC.TEXT: Imelda Marcos remained hospitalized Friday for a stomach ailment that had her coughing blood in court, and her attorney said the former Philippines first lady was too ill to resume her trial on schedule. Also Friday, the judge granted a request by CBS to quash a subpoena to compel journalist Diane Sawyer to testify about a 1986 interview with Mrs. Marcos. Officials at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center said Mrs. Marcos could be out of the hospital by Sunday, but lawyer John Tigue said there was ``no way'' she could be ready for a scheduled Tuesday court session. Mrs. Marcos was visited at the hospital Friday by her lawyer, Gerry Spence, her two sisters and her son, Ferdinand Jr., said family spokesman Roger Peyuan. She rested well overnight and was feeling better, Peyuan said. ``Mrs. Marcos' condition is much improved and she is stabilized,'' the hospital said in a statement. Mrs. Marcos was admitted to the hospital Thursday after she collapsed and coughed up blood during her federal racketeering trial. Doctors diagnosed her illness as erosive gastritis, an inflammation of the stomach caused by excessive acid. They said the ailment could have been caused by stress, but did not appear related to a high blood pressure condition for which she has been treated during the trial that began March 20. Mrs. Marcos, 60, is accused of having helped her husband, the late President Ferdinand Marcos, steal $220 million from their nation's treasury, using the money for their own purposes. Her co-defendant, Adnan Khashoggi, is charged with having faked documents to show that he, not the Marcoses, owned the properties before the Marcoses' assets were frozen by a U.S. court order. The government had sought to testimony from Ms. Sawyer to verify the authenticity of an interview she conducted of Mrs. Marcos on CBS-TV's ``60 Minutes.'' But U.S. District Judge John F. Keenan ruled that the public's interest in a ``vigorous, aggressive and independent'' media outweighed the necessity of the testimony to the prosecution's case. The judge made his decision in a written opinion, although he told lawyers about his intention Thursday. In the interview, Mrs. Marcos said her signature on a Swiss bank record found in the presidential palace in Manila was a forgery. Prosecutors sought to show that Mrs. Marcos was lying because handwriting on the document, which was presented as evidence at the trial, had been positively identified as hers. They also said the interview would counter defense arguments that Mrs. Marcos had no involvement in financial dealings.

DOC.HEAD: Arafat Denounces U.S. Veto of Security Council Resolution
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Inserts graf after 5th, `A PLO...' to ADD official's claim that U.S. Embassy was target of raid. Pickup 6th pvs, `Arafat met...
DOC.TEXT: PLO leader Yasser Arafat on Friday denounced the United States for its veto of a U.N. resolution urging the deployment of United Nations observers to the Israeli-occupied territories. ``I only ask why the United States keeps protecting and covering the crimes Israel is committing against the Palestinian people,'' Arafat told a news conference. ``Why does the United States champion human rights everywhere but stop doing that when Palestinian human rights are concerned?'' The United States on Thursday vetoed a U.N. Security Council resolution that called for a fact-finding mission to visit the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Of the 15 voting members, only the United States opposed the measure. As a permanent Security Council member, it has veto power over resolutions. Its veto came a day after Israel foiled an attack on its coastline by Palestinian guerrillas. Four guerrillas were killed and 12 captured. No Israelis were harmed. A PLO faction, the Palestine Liberation Front, claimed responsibility and said the action was in part to retaliate for the murder last week of seven Palestinian laborers by an Israeli civilian. Arafat has said neither he nor the PLO was involved in Wednesday's incident. A high-ranking Israeli official said Friday in Jerusalem that the guerrillas' intended targets included the U.S. Embassy in Tel Aviv. The official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the information was based on maps seized from the Palestinians. Arafat met Friday with ambassadors of the Soviet Union, China, Italy, France and Ireland and urged their governments to reopen U.N. discussion of the renewed upsurge of violence in the occupied territories. He also urged them to press for deployment of a U.N. observer group to the territories, despite the U.S. veto, and to ensure protection of Palestinians in the occupied territories. Arafat also said he instructed the PLO ambassador in Tunis to meet with U.S. Ambassador Robert Pelletreau to protest the U.S. veto. Palestinian leaders in Israel declared a boycott on contacts with American diplomats to protest the U.S. veto. They accused the United States of ``total bias'' toward Israel. Palestinian contacts with American consulate officials have been held periodically for the past two years, mainly to discuss the political situation. ``What the United States did yesterday in the Security Council was a shock, a slap at all those people who believe in peace in this area,'' said Faisal Husseini, a pro-PLO activist in Jerusalem. Another Palestinian leader, Salah Khalaf, said the PLO will ``shed no tears'' if the United States breaks off dialogue with the group because of the attempted raid. In condemning the abortive raid, the State Department left open the possibility the incident could affect U.S. dialogue with the PLO. That dialogue began after Arafat in 1988 denounced terrorism. ``We will not break off the dialogue, but if the United States does, we won't be upset because we stand to lose nothing,'' said Khalaf, second in command to Arafat in the PLO's mainstream Fatah organization. He was quoted by the London-based newsletter Mideast Mirror. A copy of the published interview was telefaxed to The Associated Press in Bahrain. He repeated Arafat's claim that the PLO was not involved in the raid. ``We are against the killing of innocent people of all nationalities, but we cannot be expected to be the only ones who stand against such killings,'' Khalaf said. ``When our people are slaughtered like sheep, let no one ask us to be angels, to rise above our wounds and say, `Why did such an operation take place?''' He was referring to the deaths of Palestinians during the 2{-year-old uprising against Israeli rule of the West Bank and Gaza Strip. At least 714 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians during the uprising. An additional 217 Palestinians have been killed by fellow Arabs, most on suspicion of collaborating with Israel.

DOC.HEAD: West Germany, Luxembourg Join in British Meat Ban
DOC.TEXT: West Germany and Luxembourg joined France on Friday in banning British beef imports because of ``mad cow'' disease, but the European Community offered to buy British meat to support that nation's troubled cattle industry. France, which normally purchases more than half of exported British beef, imposed a ban Wednesday. It said some meat might be tainted by bovine spongiform encephalopathy, an incurable and fatal nervous disorder. The disease, identified in Britain in 1986, is blamed for killing 13,648 cows there. West Germany had already barred imports of British beef still on the bone but followed France by extending the ban to canned beef Friday. Luxembourg later announced a ban on British beef imports, said an EC Commission spokesman in Brussels. West Germany's Agriculture Ministry said in Bonn that it feared British beef normally destined for France might be rerouted to West Germany. A ban was necessary ``to protect consumers from infection,'' the ministry said. But British officials accused France and Germany of seeking to protect their domestic beef industries and exaggerating their concern for public health. The bans are ``totally unjustified, unwarranted and contrary to EC law,'' said Britain's Ministry of Agriculture spokesman. The president of Britain's National Farmer's Union, Sir Simon Gourlay, called for a retaliatory ban of beef imports from all EEC countries ``to bring the Community to its senses.'' ``We cannot allow the situation to drag on through cynical delaying tactics by some other governments,'' he said. European Community officials denounced France's ban Thursday as illegal and demanded it be revoked. In Brussels, Belgium, EC headquarters said Friday the Community would buy 20,600 tons of British beef to help prop up falling meat prices. The British Meat and Livestock Commission said bans and fears arising from ``mad cow'' disease were costing their industry about $850,000 a day. Beef sales reportedly have fallen by about 30 percent in Britain. A team of French veterinarians sent to Britain to assess ``mad cow'' disease returned Friday to submit its report. France's Agriculture Ministry said no decision on the duration of the ban would be made until after a meeting of the European Community's veterinary committee. However, British agriculture officials said the committee meeting had been postponed indefinitely. The cause of ``mad cow'' disease is unknown. Because the symptoms are similar to scrapie, a sheep disease, it is assumed the disease was transmitted through cattle feeds. They use sheep offal as a protein supplement.

DOC.HEAD: Russian Art Exhibit Premieres in Seattle
DOC.TEXT: Art treasures from five centuries of Russian history and culture _ from the medieval to the avant-garde _ go on display Saturday in their first exhibition outside the Soviet Union. More than 250 items are in ``Moscow: Treasures and Traditions,'' which runs through Sept. 30 at the Washington State Convention and Trade Center. The unique collection, compiled from the Kremlin, Soviet state museums and artists' studios, includes icons, engravings, metalwork, porcelain, and historic costumes which have played important roles in Russian history. Some highlights are: _A 15th century icon, ``Miracle of St. George and the Dragon,'' executed in egg tempera on wood. _A 17th century suit of chain mail armor and an early musket. _An altar cross donated to a monastery by Ivan the Terrible and a helmet belonging to his son. The exhibit is making its world premiere here as the largest component of the Goodwill Arts Festival, an international cultural bash coinciding with this summer's Goodwill Games. ``With the many athletes coming from the Soviet Union, we wanted to give the American public a broader understanding of this world power we know little about,'' said C. David Hughbanks, managing director of the exhibition. ``We've come to expect so-called `socialist art' where the Russian tradition is concerned. This show offers a much broader perspective, a whole history of the people of Moscow.'' The collection illustrates historical events in Russian life in seven separate themes, including the significance and place of Christianity in 15th century Russian society. Other themes portray the hopes, dreams, and realities of Soviet life, including the desire for social reform. ``The exhibit is a celebration and a tribute to a city and its people as seen through the eyes of artists and craftsmen, most of whom are little known to the Western world,'' Hughbanks said. Officials from the Soviet Ministry of Culture and from four of the 20 museums which lent their works to the exhibit accompanied the art to Seattle. The exhibit will be displayed at the Smithsonian Institution in Washington, D.C., beginning in November, before returning to the Soviet Union in February 1991.

DOC.HEAD: Walesa Proposes Baltic Republics for Nobel Peace Prize
With AM-Soviet-Baltics, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Lech Walesa, himself a Nobel laureate, suggested on Friday that the 1990 Nobel Peace Prize go to the people of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia for their peaceful drive toward independence from the Soviet Union. His proposal came in a letter to the Norwegian Nobel Committee, PAP news agency said. Walesa won the award in 1983 for his role in creating the independent Solidarity trade union three years earlier. ``Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia are the countries that march on the road to independence, all alone. With the passive attitude of the world, they manifest in a very bold way, their attachment to the ideas of freedom and self-determination of nations, ideas embodied in the constitutions of all democratic nations,'' Walesa wrote. The three Baltic republics have declared their determination to peacefully regain the independence lost when they were forcibly incorporated into the Soviet Union in 1940. Walesa and the Polish government and legislature have expressed support for the right of the Baltic republics to self-determination, but Poland has not officially recognized their new democratically elected governments.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Reconsiders Visa Denial for Salvadoran Union Leader
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Embassy in El Salvador has reversed itself and granted a visa to the top union official representing Salvadoran coffee workers, Rep. James Scheuer, D-N.Y., said Friday. Scheuer said the embassy agreed Thursday to give a visa to Julio Garcia Prieto, head of SICAFE, the union representing workers who process coffee beans. ``This is a significant step toward creating a free, open exchange of democratic ideals with the people of El Salvador,'' Scheuer said in announcing the visa. The U.S. Embassy had denied Garcia Prieto a visa because his salary in El Salvador is so low, officials thought he might stay in the United States after the visa expired, Scheuer said. Scheuer said Garcia Prieto would be visiting the United States ``in the very near future.'' Scheuer, Sen. John Kerry, D-Mass., Reps. Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., Ed Towns, D-N.Y., Bill Green, R-N.Y., and Major Owens, D-N.Y., invited Garcia Prieto to visit them in Washington. Jack Sheinkman, president of the Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers Union, also extended an invitation, Scheuer said.

DOC.HEAD: Car Washes Reaping Bounty from Drought and Medfly Spraying
DOC.TEXT: It looks like another dry season in Southern California _ except for those who work at Los Angeles County's estimated 1,500 car washes. Up to 18 million cars a month routinely flow through car washes. Operators expect more cars this year as residents are being asked to cut water consumption by 10 percent because of the fourth straight year of drought in the region. ``Even in a drought, people will still wash their cars,'' said Gary Wimmer, who operates a dozen Southern California car washes. ``People like clean cars.'' Especially people like Pat Sukove of North Hollywood. ``I bring it in every week, sometimes twice a week. I can't afford not to take care of it. I waited a long time for this car, it's my pride and joy,'' she said. Car washes are also benefitting from the Mediterranean fruit fly infestation. That's because cars keep getting doused with a sticky mixture of malathion pesticide and corn syrup bait that is sprayed from helicopters in an effort to eradicate the pest. Spraying already has driven business up at car washes by an estimated 20 percent to 40 percent as drivers wash their cars after each spraying, car wash operators report. And car washes have received a boost from Metropolitan Water District officials, who through their literature are encouraging car owners to go to a car wash rather than wash cars on their own. That's because mechanical car washes use just a fraction of the water used by the average motorist with a hose and bucket in the driveway _ as little as 15{ gallons per car as opposed to 50 gallons used by homeowners.

DOC.HEAD: Animals Readied For Do Dah Day Parade
DOC.TEXT: Birmingham is going to the dogs Saturday, with David Letterman regular Larry ``Bud'' Melman in the lead. Melman is to be grand marshal of the city's Do Dah Day parade and judge of Birmingham's version of Stupid Pet Tricks, the competition that NBC's ``Late Night With David Letterman'' made famous. It's all to benefit the Birmingham Humane Society, which raked in $27,104 a year ago when Jessica Hahn was grand marshal. Asked what he'd look for, Melman said, ``Originality, I guess,'' as well as ``something completely different, off the beaten track, like something David would do.'' Owners whose pets can't do tricks _ stupid or otherwise _ will have other chances to compete. Prizes will be awarded for best-dressed dog, ugliest pet, best pet-owner look-alike, best non-dog entry and most creatively dressed owner. Some people bring their own pets to the parade, but the humane society is asking others to act as volunteer walkers for shelter dogs. ``It's a good chance to get the dogs adopted and get them outside in the sun and fresh air, where they can have some fun,'' said Bill North, president of the society's board of directors. ``If we can get even one animal adopted, it's well worth it.'' Any pet, including ``two guppies in a fruit jar, or even a mule,'' can take part in the parade, said activity director Hack Lloyd. ``Last year we had a turtle and a duck.'' Of the society's animals, only dogs are appearing in the parade, North said, because ``it's rare that a cat will walk on a leash. You'd end up dragging it down the street, and that just wouldn't do.''

DOC.HEAD: Presidents Roh, Bush Meeting Wednesday
DOC.TEXT: President Bush will meet South Korean President Roh Tae-woo of South Korea in Washington next Wednesday, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Friday. The meeting is to follow Monday's unprecedented meeting in San Francisco between Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and the leader of South Korea. Soviet spokesman Arkady Maslennikov on Friday continued to avoid confirming the Gorbachev-Roh plans already disclosed in Washington and Seoul. Maslennikov said only ``no comment'' when a Korean journalist asked him about the meeting and the reaction to it from communist North Korea, a longtime Kremlin ally. On Thursday, Soviet spokesman Ivan Rumiantsev described word of the meeting with Roh as ``a rumor.'' The White House also announced that Bush will host Greece's new prime minister, Constantine Mitsotakis. The visit marks the first meeting between a U.S. president and a Greek prime minister in 26 years. The United States recently signed a new agreement for continuation of U.S. bases in Greece. Bush will meet with Colombia's outgoing President Virgilio Barco at the White House on Tuesday. Barco. who could not succeed himself, leaves office in August. His is not an official working visit to Washington, but he and Bush are expected to continue their previous discussions on drug interdiction. Bush also plans to meet with United Nations Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar on Monday, Fitzwater said. Their talks will likely cover the Middle East peace efforts and changes in Central America.

DOC.HEAD: Sale of Aunt Bee Belongings Benefits Public TV
DOC.TEXT: Mayberry fans can check out velvet hats with white gloves, just like Aunt Bee would wear, a 1966 Studebaker and many other items Saturday when they gather for a sale of the late Frances Bavier's belongings. ``They're going to get a little bit of melancholy _ a little bit of Aunt Bee, a little bit of Mayberry and a lot of memories,'' Sam Williams, her attorney and close friend from Siler City, said Friday. Miss Bavier, who died in December at age 86, willed the contents of her 22-room Siler City home to the UNC Center for Public Television. More than 800 items will be offered during the sale. It's hard to tell how much money the sale at North Carolina State University's McKimmon Center will generate, say public television officials. The only financial estimate available is that 1,000 tickets to Friday's preview party were sold for $10 each. Some of the items _ such as Miss Bavier's contracts from ``The Andy Griffith Show'' and episodes of ``Mayberry RFD'' _ have value to collectors of vintage television memorabilia. Other items include funny little velvet hats with feathers and pristine white gloves _ just like Aunt Bee might have worn. But others have a more tenuous connection, such as the 24-year-old Studebaker. Miss Bavier drove it for the last time in 1983 on a trip to the grocery store. ``Frances was like every other person in the world,'' says Durham antique dealer Chris Allen, who is coordinating the sale. ``She had wonderful things, and she had junky things.'' Also being offered are Miss Bavier's personal belongings, including bits of lace she collected on her travels around the world, 1930s Queen Anne style furniture, Victorian antiques, leather-bound books and original oil paintings. ``This is what she lived with and what she sat on and what she ate, held and touched,'' says Priscilla Bratcher, director of development and community relations for the UNC Center for Public Television. Miss Bavier, born in New York, retired to Siler City in 1972.

DOC.HEAD: 20 Killed in Soviet Cable Car Accident
DOC.TEXT: A cable car broke loose Friday from an aerial tramway at a popular tourist site in Soviet Georgia, and passengers were hurled onto the roof of an apartment building. At least 20 people were reported killed. The Soviet news agency Tass and Soviet TV said another cable car was involved in the accident, but details were unclear. The gondolas had been climbing along the tramway from downtown to Mount Mtatsminda, a local tourist attraction, Tass said. Tass gave no specific death toll but witnesses and Iveria, an unofficial Georgian information agency, said at least 20 people were killed and 15 injured. Soviet TV showed footage of the accident's aftermath, including the blood-splattered interior of one of the red-and-white gondolas. The other gondola dangled from a cable above the apartment building but appeared to have been ripped apart. ``One of the cars seemed to explode,'' said Graig Line, an American photographer visiting Tbilisi who witnessed the accident. ``The car just disintegrated.'' Iveria said, ``The leading steel cable burst and and one of the two cars started to slide down, accelerating very quickly on the other cable. Halfway down, the car collided with a support pole and split in two at full speed.'' According to Iveria, ``The passengers fell out of the car onto the top of a six-story apartment building and into its yard.'' It quoted the Georgian Interior Ministry as saying at least 20 people died, including several soldiers and children, and another 15 were injured. Iveria did not say what happened to the second cable car. Sergei Dandurov, a resident who witnessed the accident, said in a telephone interview that the floor of the first cable car appeared to have split open and passengers inside fell to the rooftop below. He also said at least 20 people fell to their deaths. Tass said a government commission was formed to investigate the cause of the accident.

DOC.HEAD: No Sleep For PR Company Handling Gorbachev Coverage
DOC.TEXT: After tackling the 50th anniversary of the Golden Gate Bridge, a public relations company has taken on the enormous task of coordinating press coverage of Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev's visit _ for free. Other local companies donated eight extra phone lines and four extra facsimile machines to help the PBN Co.'s staff field requests from more than 1,000 media organizations who want credentials for more than 3,000 journalists. ``It's hopping,'' PBN founder Peter Necarsulmer said Friday. Unlike the 1987 Golden Gate Bridge celebration, which took more than a year to plan and earned PBN $600,000, Necarsulmer said he learned of the Gorbachev visit less than two weeks ago. He hopes the event will bring the company exposure and more than compensate for the long, free hours. If PBN were paid for this job, he said, the fee would run ``very, very well into the six figures.'' The work was going ``far better than I think anyone could've anticipated,'' he said, noting that the federal government, city officials, the White House, news media and security forces were cooperating well. Veteran journalists said the real test of PBN's 24-member staff will be Monday, when Gorbachev's schedule includes coffee with former president Ronald Reagan, a quick trip to Stanford University, a formal luncheon with business leaders in San Francisco, and a possible meeting with South Korean President Roh Tae-woo. ``They seem to be doing okay,'' said San Francisco Examiner Deputy Metro Editor Don Thornton. ``There seems to be so many changes and fixes, it's been a nightmare for us.'' ``They've got an impossible job,'' said Thornton. ``So far, they're meeting the challenge ... We'll know Monday.'' ``They've got a lot more to lose than gain.'' About 20 people from rival public relations agencies volunteered their time to help plan Gorbachev's visit. ``It's amazing,'' said PBN account assistant Amy Pew. ``People just really wanted to work on this.'' Sleep has been hard to come by. ``I got some last night. I think I got two hours,'' said Necarsulmer. ``But I'm feeling good. I have enough adrenaline to get me through to Tuesday morning. Which is why I, more than anyone else, hope the Gorbachevs make their plane Monday night.'' Not everyone will get press credentials. Small pools of reporters and photographers will be allowed to cover events, leaving others to watch on closed-circuit television. ``You won't believe how many photographers will claim they work for Life magazine,'' said Necarsulmer.

DOC.HEAD: Bush, Gorbachev Hit Snag in Arms Talks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs, adds grafs 12-13 with German unity details ``On a related...; signing delayed until at least 5:30 p.m. EDT
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and Mikhail S. Gorbachev hit last-minute snags on a landmark nuclear weapons agreement Friday as the Soviet leader pressed fervently for U.S. concessions on trade. Nevertheless, they were ready to sign an agreement slashing chemical weapon stockpiles. The unexpected impediments to the arms agreement marred an outwardly friendly summit, and spokesmen said they were hopeful the problems could be worked out. Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Soviet foreign minister Eduard Shevardnadze were called in to troubleshoot. The second day of superpower summitry appeared marked by tough bargaining by Gorbachev. Missing from a White House list of agreements to be signed were the arms accord, a grain-sale agreement sought by American farmers and the trade treaty that Gorbachev wants. Senate Republican Leader Bob Dole, who met with Gorbachev, said the Soviet leader ``desperately wants some give on the trade side.'' However, he said Congress was equally insistent that Lithuania must win freedom from Moscow before making economic concessions. ``I think he feels that if he doesn't get it, he's going home empty-handed,'' Dole said. Gorbachev, besieged by mounting economic problems, said a gesture on trade would be useful for him at home. Both sides expressed confidence that the outlines of an agreement for the first-ever reductions in long-range nuclear weapons would be signed before the summit ends on Sunday. Bush and Gorbachev themselves hinted at difficulties after their morning talks, but their relaxed demeanor gave no indication of major stumbling blocks. ``We always have complications but we measure it not by the glass as half-empty or the glass is half full,'' Bush said. At his side, Gorbachev said they had made ``a lot of progress.'' Despite problems with a strategic weapons pact, the leaders were ready to sign the separate accord imposing a halt in production of chemical weapons and requiring the two nations to cut their poison gas stockpiles to 5,000 tons each. Bush and Gorbachev also were unable to make progress on cutting troops and non-nuclear weapons in Europe. They issued a statement declaring ``early conclusion'' of an agreement was ``essential to the future stability and security of the continent.'' Bush had initially hoped to extract a commitment from Gorbachev at this week's summit on conventional arms cutbacks, but differences between the two sides remained. On a related front, sources said Gorbachev, trying to break a stalemate, had proposed creation of a new ``Council of all Europe'' to play a decisive role in shaping the military future of Germany. The United States and the Soviet Union would participate in the deliberations along with other members of the NATO and Warsaw Pact alliances as well as neutral countries. A U.S. official said, ``We are prepared to work with it. It is not something we would reject out of hand.'' The idea will be considered by top diplomatic aides in Copenhagen and Berlin later this month. The second day of summitry was punctuated by Gorbachev scolding congressional leaders for stalling trade benefits for Moscow. ``We are not asking for a free ride,'' Gorbachev said. He said it would be ``humilitating'' to beg for concessions. A trade treaty would be a politically important symbol for Gorbachev, burdened by deepening economic woes. U.S. officials said the Soviets were holding hostage an agreement to buy American grain _ a boost to U.S. farmers _ as a bargaining chip for the trade deal. Gorbachev said a gesture from the United States on trade would be ``especially politically'' useful for him at home. The United States wants the Soviets to ease pressure on breakaway Lithuania and guarantee protection for Jewish emigration. By itself, a trade agreement has little value. However, it is part of a package leading to most-favored-nation trade status, which would drastically reduce U.S. tariffs on Soviet goods. The superpower summit was spiced with colorful sideshows. Barbara Bush and Raisa Gorbachev were cheered at Wellesley College commencement exercises and Gorbachev once again stopped his entourage to work the noon-hour crowds on a brilliant sunny day. Both women spoke of traditional values at Wellesley. Mrs. Bush, whose selection as a graduation speaker had irritated some students, counseled them to put family and friends first in their lives. Mrs. Gorbachev said women have a special mission of ``peacemaking, humanism, mercy and kindness.'' Gorbachev began the day by confronting some of his toughest critics in Washington _ congressional leaders unhappy over Moscow's coercion of Lithuania, the Baltic republic struggling for independence. Televised live across America, it was a freewheeling exchange over trade, German unity, Lithuania and Soviet economic reforms. Gorbachev took the offensive. He said Bush was too rigid about insisting that a unified Germany be a member of NATO, and rejected any suggestion that he was politically weak. ``That's not serious,'' he said. ``This is a genuine revolution,'' Gorbachev told the lawmakers, some of whom have expressed doubts that he will survive. ``Please don't be frightened, because you can frighten us, too, if you get frightened.'' Extolling his economic reforms, Gorbachev said increased trade with the West would be an important step toward a free market system in the Soviet Union. However, Gorbachev lectured, ``I'm not going to ask for anything, to beg for anything. ... Certainly we are not asking for a free ride. We will be asking for normal credits, and of course we will be paying, and paying the interest. For us it would humiliating if we were to ask, to beg for something from you.'' When congressmen pressed him on Lithuania, Gorbachev pointed out that China had received most-favored-nation status despite the bloody crackdown in Tiananmen Square a year ago. ``Maybe we should introduce martial rule in the Baltics,'' he said sarcastically. The agreement on strategic weapons, the deadliest arms in the superpowers' arsenals, has been under negotiation for eight years. It would be the first to reduce long-range nuclear arms; previous agreements set overall limits but still allowed more weapons to be made. Even after both sides initial a treaty outline, the superpowers will face months of tedious negotiations over details to satisfy lawyers in each country. Overall, both sides would agree to destroy about a third of their long-range nuclear weapons over seven years. The chemical weapons pact would require the United States to destroy about 20,000 tons of its stockpile and mandate a 45,000 ton reduction by the Soviet Union. The United States also would be required to stop producing poison gas; the Soviet Union already has stopped. Along with the arms agreements, there also were accords expanding air travel between the United States and Soviet Union, increasing student exchanges, and making it easier for commercial ships to deliver goods to ports in one another's country. There was an agreement for closer cooperation on atomic energy and another to open reciprocal cultural and information centers in Washington and Moscow.

DOC.HEAD: Health Officials Back Drug Program Tested in Kansas City, Indianapolis
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 3rd graf to CORRECT affiliation of agency, deleting reference to being part of National Institutes of Health.
DOC.TEXT: Federal health officials said Friday they support a drug prevention program that focuses on changing the way communities view drug use _ legal and illegal _ rather than merely telling youngsters to say no. ``This program is unique because it utilizes all components in the community _ schools, parents, the media and community groups _ which contribute to changing the social norms for drug use and providing a healthy drug-free environment for all people,'' said Charles R. Schuster, director of the National Institute on Drug Abuse. Schuster's agency helped pay for an evaluation of the Midwestern Drug Abuse Prevention Research Project, a just-completed five-year study in Kansas City and Indianapolis by researchers from the University of Southern California. Researchers began tracking 5,500 teen-agers when they were in the sixth and seventh grades in 50 Kansas City schools and studied a similar group at 57 schools in Indiana. Among the major findings: _36 percent of the students who participated in the program, now high school juniors and seniors, said they drank alcohol in the last month, while 50.1 percent of those not in the program admitted the same behavior. _24.1 percent of the participating students smoked cigarettes in the last month, compared with 32 percent of those who didn't receive the program's prevention messages. _14.2 percent of the program students smoked marijuana in the past month, compared with 20.2 percent of those in a control group. A preliminary analysis of eight of the study schools found that 1.6 percent of the program students used cocaine in the last month, compared with 3.7 percent of those not in the program. Schuster said if the same percentage difference on cocaine use were applied nationally, it would mean 500,000 fewer teen-agers were using cocaine. Mary Ann Pentz, one of the University of California researchers, said reducing alcohol use among teen-agers was the most challenging because it's more widely accepted in society than tobacco or illegal drugs. ``Probably how to resist drugs is not as simple as just saying no,'' she said. Another researcher, C. Anderson Johnson, said a key to reducing harmful drug use is to engineer ``a shift in the perception of social sanctions, especially among peers.'' In other words, ``how will your friends respond?'' He said teen-agers often don't have a clear idea of the degree to which their peers respond to drug use and that one of the many facets of the program tried in Kansas City and Indianapolis was to use classroom exercises to bring about a consensus of how drug use is viewed.

DOC.HEAD: Storms And Cold Weather Abound On First Day Of June
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Munday, Texas, cq in 3rd graf.
DOC.TEXT: Rain fell from the southern Plains across the South on Friday, and up to 2 feet of new snow greeted the first day of June in the Northwest. Showers and thunderstorms extended over western Oklahoma, north-central Texas, northeastern Texas, eastern Oklahoma, western Arkansas, north-central Kansas, northeastern Louisiana, Mississippi, west-central Alabama, the southern half of the Florida Peninsula, and west-central Georgia. Showers also were scattered over southeastern Kentucky. Hail almost an inch in diameter fell at Munday, Texas, and thunderstorm wind gusted to 80 mph at Texas' Possum Kingdom Lake, the National Weather Service said. As much as 2 feet of snow fell overnight at Sherman Pass in northeastern Washington state, the weather service said. Three inches of snow fell in the Big Horn mountains of Wyoming and an additional 3 inches of snow was possible. Overnight snowfall across Utah included 3 inches at Alta, 5 inches at Park City and 6 inches north of Vernal. The unseasonable precipitation was accompanied by unseasonable temperatures, including a June 1 record low of 42 at Redding, Calif. Also in northern California, Friday's low for the Lower 48 states was 25 at both Lake Tahoe and Truckee. At lower elevations, showers were scattered over east-central Washington and the state's north coast, the Idaho Panhandle, northeastern Utah, west-central Montana, Wyoming, northern North Dakota and into northern Lower Michigan. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 42 in Idaho at both Coeur d'Alene and Mullen to 99 at Kingsville, Texas.

DOC.HEAD: Artist Appeases Protesters, Agrees to Change Title
