DOC.TEXT: An artist Friday offered to change the title of his sculpture ``Hunky Steelworker,'' and the festival displaying it agreed, quieting criticism by steelworkers and ethnic groups offended by the name. The 12-foot-tall statue is the most prominently displayed sculpture in the Three Rivers Arts Festival, which opened downtown Friday. Croatians and other Eastern Europeans in western Pennsylvania's steel towns consider the term ``hunky'' a slur. ``It's not the art, it's just the word `hunky,''' said John P. Plesh, secretary-treasurer of the Croatian Fraternal Union. ``The statue is nice.'' The stocky, fiberglass statue erected last month at Point State Park wears a dour expression and a rust-colored hat, and stands in front of a large fountain. It is to be on display until the festival ends June 17. The city's controller noticed the title while jogging, and held a news conference next to the statue last week to decry the use of what he considers an ethnic insult. The artist, Luis Jimenez of Hondo, N.M., said Friday he had hired a fiberglass company to scour the word ``Hunky'' from the base of the statue. The term originated in the late 1800s to describe people of Hungarian descent, but its use was expanded quickly as an insult toward anyone whose ancestors came from central Europe, said Sarah Thomason, a professor of linguistics at the University of Pittsburgh. Many Eastern Europeans emigrated to Pittsburgh around the turn of the century to work in the city's dozens of steel mills. Ms. Thomason said the term is similar in origin as ``honky,'' which some blacks have used to describe whites. Jimenez said no offense was intended. ``I was trying to pay homage to the men who worked at the steel mills,'' Jimenez said. ```Millhunk' was a term I had come across in my research at the library.'' Six organizations who protested the title issued a statement thanking Jimenez for changing the title. ``We thank Luis Jimenez for his sensitive handling of this situation,'' said mediator Ann Begler, reading a statement from the groups. ``By offering to cover the word, `Hunky,' he has made his sculpture a real tribute to Steelworkers of all backgrounds in this region.'' Jimenez said the decision wasn't difficult after realizing the magnitude of the flap. ``There is a portion of the community who was upset and there are some wounds there,'' Jimenez said. Titles of sculptures are meant only as a guide to the work, not as the work itself, he said. ``When the artist was making his original statements, we supported him, and when he wanted to change that, we allowed him to do that,'' said Jeanne Pearlman, executive director of the festival. Fraternal groups representing Croatians, Poles, blacks and other minorities said the matter benefited the community by prompting them to work together. The Pennsylvania Heritage Affairs Commission and the United Steelworkers union also signed the statement. ``The artist was the most amenable about the whole thing. Mr. Jimenez made the issue easy for resolution,'' said Steelworkers spokesman Gary Hubbard. Jimenez said he was disappointed with the response to his work. ``I wanted to raise certain issues about the contributions steelworkers have made. I hoped it would be viewed with a sense of pride,'' Jimenez said.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd item to CORRECT Madonna's age to 31 sted 32; SUBS 3rd item to CORRECT to Charley sted Charlie.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: There were a few fast words at the Palace, but not from the Detroit Pistons. Blame another hometown favorite this time: Madonna. ``What are you doing? Trying to make me look bad to my hometown?'' the singer joked as she tussled with two women backup singers during her soldout show. ``What does a girl from Detroit know to do? She knows how to fight.'' During her one-hour, 40-minute performance Thursday night, Madonna put on the usual moves, with spirited dancing and ever-changing revealing costumes. The concert was part of her ``Blond Ambition'' tour. The 31-year-old singer and actress graduated from suburban Detroit's Rochester Adams High School and attended the University of Michigan before heading to New York City to pursue a career in show business.

Charley Pride says he can relate to flood victims in Liberty County because his boyhood home in Mississippi was also flooded. ``I remember my dad taking me on his bike and getting us to higher ground. we had floodwater coming up to our house,'' the country singer said Thursday after touring the area. Pride, who serves as national entertainment chairman for the Red Cross, surveyed the length of the flooded Trinity River and later visited a family assistance center in Hardin. He helped Red Cross volunteers fill out forms and distribute cleanup kits or provisions to flood victims. ``It just hurts to see,'' he said. ``It's not like I haven't experienced it myself. It's not like wondering how it feels. I come from that kind of background. You know, shotgun houses and snakes and ants and et cetera.'' Pride gave autographs and in some cases signed the cardboard assistance packages handed out to victims at the center.

DOC.HEAD: Humanitarian Awards Honor Soviet Leader
DOC.TEXT: Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev received five humanitarian awards from varied U.S. groups Friday and said the recognition is ``a great incentive to me in what I'm doing.'' ``It is said that face-to-face sometimes you cannot see the face, and that the big things are seen from a distance,'' Gorbachev said during one of the low-key presentations in an ornate room at the Soviet Embassy. ``We value highly that you have seen something from a distance.'' Speaker after speaker, addressing dignitaries and celebrities packed sardine-style in the small, gilded and paneled room, said Gorbachev has proved that one person can change the course of history. As he sat impassive in a brocade chair, they called him creative, courageous and visionary. They said he had ``shattered the Cold War,'' brought freedom to Eastern Europe and inspired ``epic reforms'' in his own country. ``Your name will be forever identified with the world's leaders who have fearlessly sought peace, justice and a better life for all of the peoples of the earth,'' said William J. vanden Heuvel, president of the Franklin and Eleanor Roosevelt Institute. Gorbachev, who spoke in a low, subdued voice without notes after receiving each award, said he felt very emotional. ``I understand my role and my mission in my land and with my people,'' he said. ``And nothing will let me deviate from that course to which I am committed.'' The issue of Lithuanian secession did not come up during the ceremonies, and officials of the groups making the awards said Gorbachev's response to that crisis has not shaken their faith in him. Hans Janitschek of Friends World College, which gave him a peace prize, said one or two board members wondered what would happen if Gorbachev were to move into Lithuania with troops. ``I assured them he would not do that,'' Janitschek said. ``This is exactly why he is being honored. He is not using violence. ... If we had assumed that he could do this, our whole concept of proposing him for the award would have been wrong.'' As for the economic embargo against Lithuania, he said, ``We don't regard that as violence, as regrettable as it is.'' Vanden Heuvel, a former deputy ambassador to the United Nations, said Lithuania will ultimately benefit from Gorbachev's policies just as did the countries of Eastern Europe. ``We believe that President Gorbachev is for the independence of Lithuania,'' he said. ``It's a matter of time and procedure.'' These are the awards Gorbachev received: _The Albert Einstein Peace Prize, a $50,000 award which once went to the late human rights champion Andrei Sakharov. There was no immediate word on what Gorbachev would do with the money. It was presented by former arms negotiator Paul Warnke, who joked that ``never in my wildest dreams'' did he think he would ever have a chance to give a check to the leader of the Soviet Union. _The Franklin Delano Roosevelt Freedom Medal for promotion of FDR's ``four freedoms'' _ freedom of speech and expression, freedom of worship, freedom from want and freedom from fear. Vanden Heuvel and author Norman Cousins presented the medal. _The Martin Luther King Jr. Non-Violent Peace Prize for 1991 from the King Center for Non-Violent Social Change in Atlanta. Coretta Scott King presented a $1,000 check and a medallion bearing King's words and likeness. _The ``Man of History'' award from the Appeal of Conscience Foundation, a group of religious and business leaders. The award was a Steuben glass crystal, presented by Rabbi Arthur Schneier after he pronounced a blessing on Gorbachev. _The Martin Luther King Jr. International Peace Award from Friends World College, a small Quaker school in New York. The award, a silver sculpture of a dove encircling the globe, once went to former Costa Rican president Oscar Arias. He was at the ceremony on Friday and met Gorbachev.

DOC.HEAD: High-Ranking Policeman Ordered Arrested in Journalist's Slaying
DOC.TEXT: A court on Friday ordered the arrest of a high-ranking policeman in connection with the abduction and shooting death of a journalist who crusaded against human rights violations in Sri Lanka. The order came after the mother of journalist Richard de Zoysa claimed Senior Police Superintendent Ronnie Gunasinghe was one of the six men who had kidnapped her son from his home in a Colombo suburb Feb. 18. His body was found two days later on a beach in Moratuwa, 10 miles south of Colombo. The government has denied any police or military involvement in the incident. De Zoysa, 33, was a correspondent for the Rome-based Inter Press Service. Colombo newspapers reported Friday that the news agency and the Inter Press Institute will present their 1990 award for outstanding performance to de Zoysa as a ``small tribute to the courageous journalistic struggle de Zoysa waged against human rights violations in Sri Lanka.'' De Zoysa, a Sri Lankan, was the first journalist working for a foreign news organization to be killed in Sri Lanka. Moratuwa district magistrate Rohini Walagama asked police investigators to bring Gunasinghe to court by June 11. ``I have succeeded personally in identifying Ronnie Gunasinghe,'' said the affidavit by Manorami Saravanamuttu, de Zoysa's mother, who added she has received death threats. ``I have restrained from divulging any information to the police because of concern about my own safety and because I have no faith in the investigation the police claim they are conducting,'' the statement said. Since 1987, hundreds of civilians suspected of having links with Sinhalese extremists have been killed. The government blamed many of the deaths on pro-government vigilante groups. Most of the front's senior leaders were captured and killed late last year. The front began attacking the government after accusing it of giving too many concessions to militants from the Tamil minority, who had been fighting since 1983 for a separate homeland. About 18 percent of Sri Lanka's 16 million people are Tamils. Sinhalese account for 75 percent of the population.

DOC.HEAD: Costa Rican Government Announces Austerity Measures
DOC.TEXT: President Rafael Angel Calderon announced an austerity plan that will slash government expenses and raise rates for public services to help bring down the deficit. In a nationwide radio and television broadcast late Wednesday, Calderon said the government deficit has rise to more than $320 million this year, more than 6 percent of the gross domestic product of this Central American country of 2.9 million residents. ``This massive deficit forces us to take necessary, although hard, measures, to avoid the painful tax of inflation,'' he said. The government austerity policy will reduce spending by $70 million this year, he said, forcing an increase in the price of fuel, electricity, water and telephone services. To help reduce the impact of some of the price hikes, a food assistance plan and other aid programs will be increased, he said. Since taking office May 8, Calderon has made reducing the deficit a main priority. In 1989, under President Oscar Arias, the deficit was about $220 million, or 4 percent of the gross domestic product. Inflation was 9.9 percent in 1989, according to the government. Private economists say it could reach 20 percent for this year. Calderon has claimed the 1989 inflation rate released by the government was kept artificially low because it was an election year.

DOC.HEAD: South Koreans Applaud Roh-Gorbachev Talks
With AM-Summit-Negotiations, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: South Koreans are applauding the first meeting between a South Korean and a Soviet leader as a milestone that will spur dramatic new dialogue with communist North Korea. Presidents Roh Tae-woo and Mikhail S. Gorbachev are to meet in San Francisco next Monday after Gorbachev ends summit talks with President Bush. Seoul and Moscow have no diplomatic relations. The meeting was in the works for at least two months and has the blessing of the U.S. government, news reports said. Roh said the talks will be aimed at helping end hostility on the Korean peninsula, bitterly divided since 1945 into communist North and capitalist South. Koreans hope eased tensions will lead to unification. The border between the two Koreas is sealed and more than 1 million troops are deployed behind barbed wire on either side. Washington and Moscow have exerted pressure on their respective allies in Seoul and North Korea's capital of Pyongyang to pursue dialogue. Little progress has been made. ``Since there is no way opened for me to go to Pyongyang, I have to go there by way of Moscow,'' said Roh. In Seoul, the stock market shot up on news of the Roh-Gorbachev meeting. A Soviet trade show was flooded with Koreans as intent on buying vodka as inspecting technology. Political leaders and editorials hailed the meeting as an extraordinary moment in Korean history. North Korea released a statement, monitored in Tokyo, suggesting it may end its boycott of dialogue with South Korea. It said, ``The only way of solving the question of national unification in a peaceful way ... is to develop dialogue.'' Roh's popularity, which plunged in recent months due to labor unrest and economic worries, overnight appeared to rise. ``I believe (the meeting) will bring an epochal change in relations between South and North Korea,'' said Kim Dae-jung, head of the leading opposition Party for Peace and Democracy. ``I welcome it as a sign of great progress.'' Kim Young-sam, the leader of the governing Democratic Justice Party who met Gorbachev in Moscow last March, predicted ``a major breakthrough will be made in relations between the two countries.'' Kim also said the Soviet Union was expected ``to exercise influence upon the North to adopt an open-door or reformist policy.'' ``The projected summit will mark a historic milestone in the development of the Korean-Soviet relationship that was never dreamed of only a few months ago,'' the Korea Times said. The dissident United National Movement for Democracy said that isolating North Korea could delay unification and urged Roh to discuss total withdrawal of nuclear arms and foreign troops from the peninsula. Radicals and dissidents demand withdrawal of 43,000 U.S. troops based in South Korea, saying their presence hinders dialogue on unification. North Korea demands the United States withdraw nuclear weapons it says are kept in South Korea. The meeting represents the culmination of South Korea's ``northern policy,'' which is aimed at fostering ties with communist nations able to influence North Korea. The talks come at a time when economic ties between Seoul and Moscow are rapidly increasing. Their two-way trade doubled to $600 million last year. Korean news reports said former U.S. Secretary of State George Shultz and Anatoly Dobrynin, former Soviet ambassador in Washington and a personal adviser to Gorbachev, helped arrange the talks.

DOC.HEAD: United States Returns Military Base to Panama
DOC.TEXT: One of the bases of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega's defeated Panamanian Defense Forces was returned to Panama on Thursday by the U.S. military. Panamanian authorities said the Rio Hato military base, 75 miles southwest of Panama City and surrounded by Pacific beaches, will be turned into a tourist site. The base had been under control of the United States since American troops invaded Panama on Dec. 20 to capture Noriega, the former Panamanian strongman who is now in Miami awaiting trial on federal drug charges. His Defense Forces were abolished and are being replaced by a civilian police force under the government of President Guillermo Endara. It was the second base returned to Panama this week. Earlier, the Panamanian portion of Fort Amador, which the United States shared with Panama, was returned to Panama. The Jose Espinar Military College in the Atlantic port of Colon has not been returned to Panamanian control, nor has the remaining American-occupied portion of Fort Amador. Fort Amador housed some of Noriega's main offices. Rio Hato, which has a large landing strip, was a military school and home of the crack Machos del Monte battalion, which put down an attempted coup against Noriega in October. Rio Hato also was a key American installation during World War II. Ramon Lima, vice minister of the interior and justice, said at Thursday's ceremony that the base would be turned into an area ``attractive to national and international tourism'' and would be administered by Panamanian tourism officials for hotel construction.

DOC.HEAD: White Supremacist, Black, in GOP Lt. Gov. Runoff
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with news conference. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Republican leadership backed a black candidate for lieutenant governor Friday in a raucous news conference disrupted by his primary election opponent, a white supremacist. Kenneth ``Muskie'' Harris, a black who forced Ralph Forbes into a June 12 runoff for the nomination, said Forbes lied this week when he said Harris supports women's rights to have abortions. ``Who's lining up behind my opponent?'' Harris said, while flanked by Bob Leslie, GOP national committeeman, three Republican politicians and two members of Arkansas pro-life groups. ``The KKK. The Nazis? I don't see anyone.'' Forbes, a white supremacist and former American Nazi leader who won 46 percent of the vote in the GOP primary Tuesday, says he doesn't think blacks and whites belong in the same government. ``I believe that racial separation is ultimately the right answer,'' Forbes said Thursday. Another avowed racist _ who served prison time for bombing a black church _ is running for lieutenant governor as a Democrat in Georgia. J.B. Stoner has prompted debate among fellow candidates over whether to boycott forums he attends. And in Louisiana, David Duke, a former Ku Klux Klan grand wizard who last year was elected to the state House in an upset, is seeking the GOP nomination for U.S. Senate. The House this week passed a bill sponsored by Duke that would ban affirmative action. When Forbes appeared at the news conference Friday, Leslie said the conference room at a North Little Rock bank was reserved for Harris and refused to allow Forbes to follow his opponent at the podium. Forbes then went in the hallway and stood in front of the elevators to answer questions. He said he still speaks at Nazi and Ku Klux Klan gatherings. ``I'm an American nationalist. You burn the American flag and I'll stop you. That's right. Call me a Nazi, fine. Just spell my name right,'' Forbes told reporters. ``You're a Nazi,'' said Robert Jespersen, standing behind a mass of reporters. Jespersen later said he is a Little Rock lawyer and former Marine who happened to be in the building. ``I said I'm an American nationalist, you're right,'' Forbes responded. ``You're a Nazi,'' Jespersen said. ``You're a member of the American Nazi Party.'' ``I'm an American nationalist, you're right,'' Forbes said. ``I don't think it's time for the Republican Party to have a Nazi run their platform,'' Jespersen said. Earlier, Harris insisted he supports the Republican platform on abortion. He read from the platform, which says an unborn child has a fundamental right to life. Later, Harris said he supported abortion only in the cases of incest and rape. Forbes said Harris made pro-choice statements at a lieutenant governor's debate that got little media attention May 10. Darrell Glascock, a Democratic candidate for lieutenant governor who lost the primary, said later Friday that he also heard Harris give a pro-choice statement. But both Glascock and Forbes confirmed that Glascock was considering being Forbes' campaign manager. ``I like him and his family,'' Glascock said, adding that he wasn't sure yet if he agreed with Forbes' politics. ``That's what I'm looking at now.'' Later in the day, Forbes had a questionnaire delivered to The Associated Press in which Harris answered in favor of abortions on demand. Harris said he couldn't remember filling out the form for the Lakeside Baptist Church at Hot Springs. He said he must have accidentally put an ``X'' under the ``Yes'' column for a question about abortion on demand. ``I'm right in line with George Bush'' on the abortion issue, he said. Forbes said he will protect white and black unborn children equally.

DOC.HEAD: Text of Remarks of Bush, Gorbachev at Signing Ceremony
DOC.TEXT: Here is the text of remarks by President Bush and Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev at the signing ceremony Friday in the East Room of the White House: Bush: President Gorbachev, again, welcome to the White House. Mr. President, you and I set a course six months ago off the island nation of Malta. And at that time we agreed on an agenda, much of which was completed for this week's summit. Of course our Malta agenda remains unfinished, but we've made great progress in the last six months and in the last two days. We're about to sign agreements concerning many areas of vital interest to our countries and to the world, and to record specific understanding in joint statements that are being published today. First, we'll sign a bilateral agreement that will for the first time eliminate the great majority of the chemical weapons that our countries have stockpiled over the years. And let this landmark agreement quickly lead to a global ban on chemical weapons. Secondly, we will be signing protocols on limiting nuclear testing. After long, sometimes arduous negotiations, we both agreed on unprecedented improvements for on-site verification of the Threshold Test Ban Treaty and the Peaceful Nuclear Explosions Treaty. Third, we will sign a major new agreement that updates and expands our 1973 agreement on the peaceful uses of atomic energy. This new agreement provides for substantial U.S.-Soviet cooperation in atomic energy research and civilian nuclear safety.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Defends His Soviet Policies in Meeting With Congress
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Tops with 4 grafs to update with Gorbachev getting trade agreement, picking up in 3rd graf pvs.
DOC.TEXT: As if testifying in his own defense, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev held forth for an hour-and-half Friday, answering congressional questioners on everything from the Lithuanian embargo to the price of Soviet bread. He reasoned with them, cajoled, lectured, confessed. And just hours after his stunning televised performance, he won from President Bush the trade agreement he had hoped to take home from the summit. It is still subject to congressional approval, and the lawmakers suggested that wouldn't come easily as long as the Soviet embargo on Lithuania remains in effect. The pact wouldn't have an instant impact, Gorbachev told the lawmakers he had invited to breakfast at the Soviet Embassy, but it would open the way for American business people to participate in the Soviet Union's economic development. ``You should do some rethinking of how to act so as not to impede trade,'' he told the leaders, arguing that ``a Soviet Union which is weak, torn by complexes and problems and turmoil'' is more threatening to the United States than ``a dynamic Soviet state that is open to the outside world.'' He admitted that when he launched Perestroika five years ago, he thought he could fix the Communist system with some tinkering, such as adding private cooperatives and permitting farm leasing. But it didn't work. ``Really, we were being very naive,'' he said. ``In our system, it was just impossible. There was no incentive, there was no motivation for people to work.'' But to change the economic system, he said, he had to institute democracy to create pressure on the authorities to change. That proved so effective that ``in some regions, the entire ruling structures were swept aside by the political wave,'' and the old system was dismantled before a new one could be put in place. ``Our ship has lost anchor, and therefore we're all a little sick,'' the president said, describing the present confusion and turmoil in his country. He said that if the government doesn't move quickly to establish the new market-oriented economy he has proposed, the whole society will suffer. Gorbachev laid out for his congressional audience the enormity of his task, involving creation of new forms of ownership, including private property once considered anathema to communists. ``We need competitiveness in our economy, and that is why we will be adopting laws on entrepreneurship, on small and medium-size business. We do not have a system of markets. We do not have systems of stock exchanges, monetary or labor exchanges. So we have to be developing an entire infrastucture for the market.'' Tripling the price of bread even before the market is in place as an unpopular step, he conceded, but he insisted that bread is so cheap and plentiful in the Soviet Union that ``kids play football with loaves of bread, feed bread to cattle, and it's really outrageous.'' Congress has urged President Bush not to sign a trade agreement with the Soviet Union until it lifts its embargo of Lithuania, which has declared its independence. In an exhaustive account of the Lithuanian crisis and his efforts to solve it, Gorbachev said the Lithuanian parliament had rushed its own election process and staged a ``nighttime coup d'etat'' to secede from the union. Similar pressures exist in many Soviet republics, he said, and Lithuania can't be dealt with alone, ignoring its own minority nationalities and territorial claims by other republics. Gorbachev described himself as taking a conciliatory stance, willing to negotiate with the Lithuanians and work out procedures for eventual independence. But he insisted the republic must submit to a popular referendum and respect the rights of its ethnic minorities, including Russians and Poles. He chided Congress for permitting Bush to invade Panama, suggesting that move also was unconstitutional and failed to respect the popular will of the Panamanians. Sen. George J. Mitchell, D-Maine, interrupted with a retort that ``there are very significant differences in the two situations'' and suggesting the Lithuanian declaration _ like the Panama invasion _ had overwhelming popular support. ``All right, all right,'' he said. ``Fine. Fine. Fine. Let them do it, and we'll agree _ but only through a constitutional process.'' Asked to explain why the Soviet Legislature had not yet adopted a law liberalizing emigration, Gorbachev protested that the U.S. Congress was getting too deeply involved in his country's domestic affairs. ``This is a matter of dignity, this is a matter of prestige, this is a matter of sovereignty and national dignity, so please be careful about this,'' he said. But he went on to answer the question, saying the emigration law ``has been adopted on first reading. Its provisions are in effect. ... If you look at the reality of the situation, its provisions are in effect. The flow of emigres from Soviet Union is practically not braked. You know that this is no longer a problem.'' He suggested Congress was ``looking for a pretext in order to put a brake on this process of adopting most-favored-nation treatment'' that would lower tariff barriers for Soviet products sold in the United States. Asked how Congress could help, Gorbachev pleaded for ``a favorable gesture'' on trade. And he asked for extension of credit to finance joint ventures and the conversion to a market economy, making it ``easier for us during this difficult period.'' He promised to start paying back the money within seven years. He accused the United States of applying a double standard by withholding MFN status from the Soviet Union while granting it to China after the crushing of the democratic movement in Tiananmen Square. ``Maybe we should introduce presidential rule in the Baltics and at least fire some rounds,'' he suggested wryly.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Summit Rdp Bjt
Bush, Gorbachev Announce Wide Range of Summit Accords
DOC.TEXT: Here, at a glance, are the U.S.-Soviet agreements announced Friday by President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev at a White House ceremony: _A ``framework'' accord on the major elements of a Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty, or START, to reduce each side's arsenal of long-range nuclear weapons by about one-third over a 7-year period. _An accord ending production of U.S. and Soviet chemical weapons and eliminating all but 5,000 tons of their existing chemical stockpiles. The deal is meant as a catalyst for a global agreement to ban production and possession of these weapons. _A trade agreement that would move the superpowers closer to normal commercial relations, but still stop short of most-favored-nation status. _A protocol spelling out anti-cheating measures for existing treaties that limit nuclear tests. The verification protocol will permit both nations to ratify the 1974 Threshold Test Ban Treaty and the 1976 Peaceful Nuclear Explosions Treaty, which limit U.S. and Soviet underground nuclear tests to 150 kilotons. _An agreement expanding commercial air travel between the United States and the Soviet Union by adding four American and six Soviet cities to current airliner routes. It also will allow one more Soviet and six more U.S. airlines to run the routes. _A new 5-year atomic energy agreement to provide closer cooperation in nuclear reactor safety, fusion energy and basic atomic science. _A grain deal committing the Soviets to buying at least 10 million tons annually, starting next year, of U.S. wheat, feed grains and soybeans. That is an increase of 1 million tons annually from a current agreement that took effect in 1983. _A maritime transportation pact to make it easier for U.S. and Soviet commercial vessels to deliver goods to ports in one another's country. _An agreement to open reciprocal cultural and information centers in Washington and Moscow. _The first government-to-government agreement to increase student exchanges between the two countries.
Here are some key comments Friday from the summit between President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev.
``The world has waited long enough; the cold war must end.'' ``We always have complications but we measure it not by, `The glass is half-empty,' or `The glass is half full.'''

``I think what is happening now ... represents an event of momentous importance, not only for our two countries, but for the world.'' ``We are not asking for a free ride.'' ``In our system, it was just impossible. There was no incentive, there was no motivation for people to work.'' ``Our ship has lost anchor, and therefore we're all a little sick.''
``The United States will not give new trade benefits while the Soviet noose continues to strangle Lithuania.''

``Somewhere out in this audience may even be someone who will one day follow in my footsteps and preside over the White House as the president's spouse. I wish him well!'' ``I simply feel very at home and comfortable with Mrs. Gorbachev and I have enormous respect for her.''

``I particularly rejoice at the fact that our conversations are extremely open, sincere and friendly. And despite the fact that we might have differences, that does not change the tone.'' ``If people in the world today are more confident of a peaceful future, we have to give a good deal of credit for that to women.''

DOC.HEAD: WASHN: nuclear safety.
DOC.TEXT: In addition, President Gorbachev and I are issuing a joint statement recording major agreed provisions of a strategic arms reduction treaty as well as a joint statement in which we agree to future negotiations on nuclear and space arms designed to enhance stability and reduce the risk of war. We're also issuing a statement on the conventional armed forces in Europe, committing us to intensify the pace of the Vienna negotiations and to reach rapid agreement on all outstanding issues. You see, we agree that a (conventional armed forces) treaty is an indispensable foundation for the future of European security. There are many other agreements the United States (is) signing or announcing during this summit _ agreements that represent hard work and a lasting achievement, not just by our governments, but also for the peoples. For example, an agreement to establish a U.S.-Soviet park across the Bering Strait. This park will preserve the unique, natural environmental and cultural heritage of the Bering Sea region of Alaska and Siberia. Just as a bridge of land once joined our two continents, so let a bridge of hope now reach across the water, to join our two peoples in this spirit of peaceful cooperation. In that same spirit President Gorbachev and I'll sign an agreement that realizes our Malta objective of expanding undergraduate exchanges by 1,000 students on both sides. Allowing more of our young people to experience first-hand each other's culture and politics. To live as friends, and out of simple acts of friendship a profound revelation eventually arises, the people of the world have more in common than they have in conflict. In just a few moments Secretary of State Baker and Foreign Minister Shevardnadze will also sign four important new agreements concerning maritime boundaries, ocean studies, civil aviation and a long-term grains agreement. Minister Shevardnadze and Transportation Secretary Skinner will sign a fifth agreement on maritime transportation. And President Gorbachev and I are also signing a commercial agreement and are looking forward to the passage of a Soviet emigration law. President Gorbachev, I am very gratified by what we've accomplished over the last few days and determined to build on this solid foundation. The agreements we record today and those yet to come will advance the cause of peace, agreements in the best interests of both our nations, and all nations. Not long ago, some believed that the weight of history condemned our two great countries, our two great peoples to permanent confrontation. Well, you and I must challenge history, make new strides, build a relationship of enduring cooperation. We may not agree on everything and indeed we don't agree on everything. But we believe in one great truth _ and the world has waited long enough _ the Cold War must end. And so, today with gratitude in my heart for all those on the Soviet side and the United States side that worked so hard at all levels to bring these agreements to fruition, I say let's renew our pledge and build a more peaceful world. (Applause.) President Gorbachev: Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen, comrades, first of all I would like to thank President George Bush for presenting so well the results of our work that we have been doing over these days in Washington. So I have a problem _ what shall I talk about? (Laughter.) More

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Summit Rdp Bjt
Congressional Leaders Tell Gorbachev Lithuania Is a Big Problem
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3rd graf, Mitchell said xxx etc., with Senate majority leader's quote after the commercial agreement was signed.
DOC.TEXT: Congressional leaders said Friday they cannot approve Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's request for favored trade status _ even if President Bush should do so _ until Moscow relaxes pressure against freedom-minded Lithuania. Hours later, Bush and Gorbachev signed a trade agreement that would be a step toward granting the Soviet Union most-favored-nation status. But White House officials said the agreement would not be sent to Congress for ratification until the Soviet Union enacts a law protecting Jewish emigration _ the price Bush has set all along for granting the broader tariff-lowering trade status. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, said after the signing ceremony: ``The granting of MFN status, in my mind, is in Mr. Gorbachev's hands. He can achieve it with some rather modest changes in his policy toward the Baltic states.'' ``Anything we do needs to come with some strings attached,'' said House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., one of a dozen members of Congress Gorbachev invited for a 90-minute meeting at the Soviet Embassy. Gorbachev used the occasion, which was broadcast live on television, to argue that freer trade between the superpowers would be in the interests of both countries, and to chide Congress for linking most-favored-nation trading status to resolution of the Lithuanian situation _ a connection the Bush administration also has made. But the leaders appeared to be unmoved, saying human rights issues could not be separated from any concession on trade. ``We have a political problem, too,'' said Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., afterward. As if to illustrate that, about 1,500 Lithuanian-Americans rallied on the steps of the Capitol, waving green, yellow and red Lithuanian flags and signs such as one that read: ``Gorbachev is a Big Bully.'' ``The United States will not give new trade benefits while the Soviet noose continues to strangle Lithuania,'' said Sen. Alfonse D'Amato, R-N.Y., who spoke to the rally but was not among those invited to the Soviet Embassy. Gephardt and the others at the meeting with Gorbachev took a gentler line, saying they recognized the Soviet president's efforts to resolve Lithuania's status. ``We want it done peacefully,'' said Gephardt. ``We recognize that everybody can't get everything they want.'' ``I don't think any of us believes that all of the issues have to be finally and successfully concluded before we can do anything on a trade negotiation,'' he said. ``But we do need to see some substantial progress.'' Any suggestion by Bush to advance MFN status would be seriously considered on Capitol Hill, Gephardt added. ``I think it's conceivable that in this year, we could deal with an MFN suggestion.'' Dole agreed that ``strong personal assurances'' from Gorbachev on Lithuanian independence and free emigration might be enough for Congress to make some gesture in return. ``Members want some fairly ironclad assurances that independence will happen,'' Dole said, adding that he got the impression that Gorbachev ``desperately wants some give on the trade side.'' Democrats in the group also reacted favorably to a Gorbachev remark questioning why President Bush had recommended most-favored-nation status to China, which just a year ago crushed a pro-democracy movement, but was withholding the same treatment from the Soviet Union. ``That exposed the total inconsistency of President Bush's position,'' said Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, who has been among Bush's harshest congressional critics on China policy. The leaders indicated that another requirement for favored trade status _ free emigration, particularly for Soviet Jews _ has largely been met and is no longer a serious obstacle. But Mitchell and Gephardt added a new one: a measure of success in establishing free markets. ``The central requirement is reform of the economy,'' Mitchell said. Favored trading status alone will not increase U.S. demand for Soviet products, many of which are seen as inferior, he said, adding that MFN status would be primarily of symbolic value to Gorbachev. For his part, the Soviet leader said he was not asking for charity from the United States, only for normal credits which would be repaid and for what he called a new trade relationship that would benefit both countries. ``This is a genuine revolution,'' Gorbachev told the lawmakers as they sat around a long table covered with green felt. ``We have to turn around our brains, as it were,'' he said. ``This is a most difficult turnaround to make. Here, too, we hope we will find a mutual understanding and you will be able to find certain ways of supporting us, so that we could interact.''

DOC.HEAD: WASHN: about? (Laughter.)
DOC.TEXT: So I think that I will do some thinking aloud in this context. I would say that maybe this room has seen many important events and many agreements signed, but I think that what is happening now and what you have listed as the results of our work together represents an event of momentous importance, not only for our two countries but for the world. President Franklin D. Roosevelt half a century ago spoke of a world in which four essential freedoms will triumph: freedom of speech, freedom of worship, freedom from want and freedom from fear. And this ideal has not yet been attained in the world, and it could not be attained in the world of animosity and confrontation. And therefore, while liberating the world from fear we are making steps toward a new world. And this is the important work of our two nations, of our two peoples. What is very important, I think, is that we do not just declare our commitment to moving toward a healthier international environment, toward better international relations, toward a nonviolent world. We are taking practical steps in that direction, and what you have just listed, and what we'll be signing during this visit, I think is a confirmation that both our declarations are right in that they seek to justify the hopes of our peoples and that we're also taking those practical steps. The important steps that we are taking today illustrate the degree of agreement between our two countries, despite the fact that _ and here I quite agree with you _ that there are things on which we disagree, and there are differing views that we have on certain questions. But that area of disagreement is being narrowed in the course of our work together. What we will be signing, I think, is the best demonstration that we are ready to participate at the level of our responsibility in building a new civilization. There are still many difficult challenges awaiting us.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Box Office King of Movie Business Celebrates Studio Reign
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 17th graf to CORRECT title to ``King's Row'' sted ``Kings Road.''
DOC.TEXT: Warner Bros. rededicates its sprawling 144-acre studio lot this weekend with a nostalgic extravaganza to reassert its independence and claim as the box office king of the movie business. Former President Reagan, star of more Warner movies than any living actor, joins 1,000 of Hollywood's elite for Saturday night's ``Celebration of Tradition,'' produced by Steven Spielberg, David Wolper and Jack Haley Jr. The event commemorates the full reacquisition and renaming of the studio by Warner Bros. Brothers Albert, Harry, Jack and Sam Warner bought the studio in 1929, but in 1972, Warner Bros. and Columbia Pictures joined forces and the lot was renamed The Burbank Studios. The lot was reclaimed by Warner last November as a condition of contractually releasing ``Batman'' producers Peter Guber and Jon Peters to Sony, which had acquired Columbia and wanted the pair to take its reins. Demand for tickets to the celebration was so intense, Warner chief Robert A. Daly invited 2,500 past and present employees to the studio for a Friday afternoon barbecue. The studio guards wore their new uniforms as well. Studio limousines will fetch Hollywood luminaries Saturday night and bring them to Burbank, where they will be treated to a dazzling back lot tram tour recreating Hollywood's golden age. More than 175 dancers, 100 ``flappers,'' an 80-man drill team, a 100-piece marching band, a 200-member military precision team and 300 costumed extras will be featured. So will one elephant and one Batmobile. Warner Bros., which now has the studio to itself, has been the box office king for a year with such hits as ``Batman,'' ``Lethal Weapon II'' and ``Driving Miss Daisy.'' A portion of Saturday's celebration will focus on a prominent fixture on the studio lot, the water tower, which has been declared a Burbank historical landmark. It hasn't been used since the 6.4-magnitude earthquake in 1971. The tower's newly-painted Warner Bros. logo will be unveiled during the re-christening festivities. It will be lighted in a ceremony using the same button Reagan used as president to illuminate the refurbished Statue of Liberty in 1986. Although the former president will be there, Reagan won't be pushing the button this time. Three Warner executives have that honor. Partygoers will see Stage 16, the nation's tallest sound stage at 98 feet and 31,500-square feet. It was where Spencer Tracy meditated in his boat while shooting ``The Old Man and the Sea,'' and where Jack Lemmon and Tony Curtis crossed the Bering Strait on ice floats in ``The Great Race.'' Stage 18 was also where the Ascot Gavotte scene in ``My Fair Lady,'' horses and all, was filmed. Since the 1920s, the San Fernando Valley studio lot 10 miles north of downtown Los Angeles has recreated cities, neighborhoods and exotic locales for motion pictures and television. The expansive backlot features two Western towns, a wooded jungle area, a Midwestern town, a European street, three New York City blocks and a Far East tenement. Kirk Douglas, Randolph Scott and Henry Fonda made ``Shootout at Medicine Bend,'' ``There was a Crooked Man'' and ``The Great Bank Robbery'' in the Western towns and Errol Flynn, Alan Ladd and Humphrey Bogart used the wooded area for films. The Gary Cooper, Ingrid Bergman movie ``Saratoga Trunk'' and the tree-lined streets for Reagan's ``King's Row'' were shot in the Midwestern town area. Several Doris Day movies were filmed there, as were ``Bonnie and Clyde'' and ``Cool Hand Luke.'' Rick's meeting with Ilsa at a Parisian cafe in ``Casablanca'' was shot on the lot's European street.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Arms, Trade Accords Mark Summit Half-way Mark. Updating with Baker remarks. Picks up 9th graf ... From twin.
DOC.TEXT: Celebrating the fruits of their summit diplomacy, President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev signed a sheaf of agreements Friday, including a conditional trade accord. The leaders also embraced a preliminary deal to cut long-range nuclear arms. The trade accord was thought to hinge in part on Lithuania, but Secretary of State James A. Baker said the only condition was a loosening of Soviet emigration laws _ thought to be imminent. Congress must approve any agreement, however, and Baker acknowledged that passage could be difficult unless Gorbachev starts a new dialogue with independence-minded Lithuanian officials. The centerpiece arms agreement, banning chemical arms production, was a foregone conclusion, however significant. But last-hour negotiating was necessary to settle differences on a framework for strategic arms cuts and a five-year grain deal. Gorbachev told the president and the leaders of his administration that a strategic arms reduction treaty can be signed before the end of this year, ``even though it is difficult.'' The two leaders also agreed to strive for an elusive agreement on reduction of troops, tanks and other conventional weapons in Europe. Bush said the statement they signed on that negotiation commits both sides ``to intensify the pace'' of the talks. Gorbachev said that deal, too, should be completed this year. Referring to American reaction to Gorbachev's crackdown on Lithuanian independence efforts, Gorbachev said, ``I am pleased to note that the turbulent developments in recent months after Malta have not led us astray from the goals we set together.'' Baker the commercial trade agreement will not go to Congress until the ``the (Soviet) emigration law is passed.'' Thus, most-favored-nation status awaits Soviet approval for more liberal travel abroad. Even though administration officials have said in the past that the crisis in Lithuania had a bearing on the trade agreement, White House spokesman Roman Popadiuk said: ``There has been no direct link between Lithuania and trade.'' From twin lecterns, the two presidents spoke of what they had done and what they hope to do. ``I think what is happening now . . . represents an event of momentous importance, not only for our two countries but for the world,'' Gorbachev said. He praised Bush for his efforts to reach the accords and improve U.S-Soviet relations. ``I am human in the sense that I'm emotional,'' Gorbachev said. In the applause that followed, the two leaders shook hands once, then did so again as aides brought on the chairs to seat them for the signing. Until Friday noon, it was thought the missiles and grain were all set for signatures, but spokesmen indicated otherwise. Secretary of State James Baker and Soviet foreign minister Eduard Schevardnadze led negotiating teams that talked throughout the afternoon to settle differences on the intricately linked agreements _ especially trade, grain and strategic arms. Here are details of the agreements signed Friday evening: _A ``framework'' accord on the major elements of a Strategic Arms Reduction Talks, or START, treaty to reduce each side's arsenal of long-range nuclear weapons by about one-third over a 7-year period. Negotiating teams were still trying to work out some details Friday afternoon. The push for a missiles treaty is ``designed to enhance stability and reduce the threat of war,'' Bush said. _An accord ending production of U.S. and Soviet chemical weapons and eliminating all but 5,000 tons of their existing chemical stockpiles. The deal is meant as a catalyst for a global agreement to ban production and possession of these weapons. ``Let this landmark agreement quickly lead to a global ban,'' Bush said. _A protocol spelling out anti-cheating measures for existing treaties that limit nuclear tests. The verification protocol will permit both nations to ratify the 1974 Threshold Test Ban Treaty and the 1976 Peaceful Nuclear Explosions Treaty, which limit U.S. and Soviet underground nuclear tests to 150 kilotons. _Expanding commercial air travel between the United States and the Soviet Union by adding four American and six Soviet cities to current airliner routes. It also will allow one more Soviet and six more U.S. airlines to run the routes. _A new 5-year atomic energy agreement to provide closer cooperation in nuclear reactor safety, fusion energy and basic atomic science. _A maritime transportation pact to make it easier for U.S. and Soviet commercial vessels to deliver goods to ports in one another's country. _Opening reciprocal cultural and information centers in Washington and Moscow. _The first government-to-government agreement to increase student exchanges between the two countries.

DOC.HEAD: Texas Governor Agrees to Sales Tax Hike
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Bill Clements said Friday he would approve a sales tax increase as part of a $530 million deal with legislative leaders on school financing reform, reversing his stance of the past three months. At the same time, a judge held a hearing at which a court-appointed master presented his own school finance blueprint, the result of the state Supreme Court's ruling last year that the school funding system was unconstitutional. Clements, House Speaker Gib Lewis and Lt. Gov. Bill Hobby said they hoped their deal, which includes raising the sales tax from 6 percent to 6.25 percent, would keep the courts from revamping the $13.5 billion-a-year school financing system. Texas is one of a dozen states where courts have overturned school finance systems in recent years. The others are Kentucky, New Jersey, Kansas, Wisconsin, California, Connecticut, Washington, West Virginia, Wyoming, Arkansas and Montana. Clements, Lewis and Hobby said they believed the Legislature would approve the pact, which followed two days of private talks. Clements said that on Monday he would call the Legislature into its fourth consecutive special session on schools since Feb. 27 to begin considering the agreement. The Republican governor, who since February had pledged to veto any sales tax increase, said the compromise represented concessions by him and the Democrat-controlled Legislature. He said he agreed to a higher sales tax because he saw no other option. ``I can truthfully say that I don't know anybody who is happy with this,'' Clements said. ``Maybe the judge will be. It has been a very painful process, but we did it.'' In the hearing Friday before state District Judge Scott McCown, special master William Kilgarlin recommended shifting $540 million in state education funds from wealthier school districts to poor districts that make a strong effort to raise local property taxes. In its ruling last year, the Supreme Court ordered more money be made available to poor districts. McCown voiced ``profound disappointment'' that lawmakers and Clements so far had failed to enact a plan. If the latest legislative deal passes, McCown still must give it his approval. In addition to the sales tax increase, the pact calls for budget cuts, transfers of money from other programs and increases in taxes on cigarettes and mixed drinks, and higher fees to raise a total of more than $630 million, said Mike Toomey, the governor's chief of staff. Of that, about $530 million is for school aid; about $100 million would go to bail out financially strapped programs in the departments of Health, Human Services, and Mental Health and Mental Retardation, Toomey said. Raising the sales tax would raise about $298.9 million of the total, according to Clements and his aides. About $193.5 million would come from raising the 26-cent per pack cigarette tax by 15 cents. Another $43.2 million would be raised by slightly increasing the levy on mixed drinks, raising fees to replace lost drivers' licenses and debt service on state bonds issued to help fund the superconducting supercollider project. The rest of the money, about $97.7 million, would be trimmed from other parts of the state budget. ``You can see ... we have had a very difficult time raising the funds we thought necessary for public education,'' Clements said. Clements vetoed a half-cent sales tax increase at the end of the second special session, then during the third session vetoed the actual school reform legislation because it also required a half-cent sales tax boost.

DOC.HEAD: WASHN: awaiting us.
DOC.TEXT: It is evident that to dismantle that monumental artifact of the Cold War, the accumulated arsenals of mutual destruction, is not at all a simple or even an entirely safe thing to do. The slightest imbalance, undue haste or lack of equilibrium in this process may dangerously destabilize the overall international situation. But I am sure that if we take a balanced and responsible approach, if we take into account the concerns and positions of each other even when we disagree, if we do all that, I am sure that we will be able to move ahead more resolutely and more vigorously. Mr. President, you have just mentioned Malta. Mr. President, I am pleased to note that the turbulent developments of recent months after Malta have not led us astray from the goal we set together. So, I believe that we have passed the first test. Mr. President, let me reaffirm here something that I've been saying to you during our one-on-one talks. We have had many such talks during this summit, and I welcome this style of negotiating. But let me reaffirm to both our peoples that the Soviet Union is committed to the objective set at Malta, completing before the end of this year the preparation of the START Treaty. I believe that this goal is obtainable even though it is difficult. I also can confirm what you have said, that we have agreed that during our talks that this year we will seek to sign a treaty at the Vienna talks. And, of course, we believe that in that case, there will be the CSCE European security summit meeting. I think we already have good results and a good potential to work.
