DOC.HEAD: New Limits Agreed to on Heavy Mobile Missiles Under Proposed Treaty
With AM-Summit Rdp Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with details on missile covered, inserting 4 grafs after 7th graf, The agreement
DOC.TEXT: The United States and the Soviet Union on Friday reached agreement to ban heavy mobile nuclear missiles under the treaty they are negotiating on long-range nuclear weapons. In addition, they also agreed on an extensive verification system to ensure the reductions in a wide range of deadly weapons are carried out. A joint statement, issued at the midpoint of President Bush's summit meeting with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, called also for acceleration of negotiations in Geneva to complete the START treaty by the end of the year. At the White House, Bush and Gorbachev approved the outlines of the landmark treaty Friday for the first-ever cuts in long-range nuclear missiles. Secretary of State James A. Baker III said that major issues had been settled and completion of the treaty by the end of the year was likely. Agreement on a ban on heavy mobile missiles marked an expansion of the limitations already agreed to in eight years of U.S.-Soviet talks. The verification procedure will cover 12 kinds of on-site inspections, some of them on short notice. The agreement would prevent the Soviets from putting their heavy ground-based SS-18 missiles on mobile launchers, such as trains or trucks, a senior U.S. official said. The ban would have no direct impact on current U.S. nuclear forces but would prevent the United States from basing any future heavy intercontinental missile on mobile launchers. The official, who briefed reporters on details under rules that he not be identified, said America's MX missile would not be restricted in any way under the agreement because ``it is not considered a heavy missile.'' Among the existing ICBMs in both nations' arsenals only the SS-18 will be included in the banned category. ``The far-reaching reductions and other constraints contained in the treaty will be accompanied by the most thorough and innovative verification provisions ever negotiated,'' the U.S.-Soviet statement said. Baker said both sides had made a commitment in a second round of negotiations to make cuts in heavy missiles and those with multiple warheads. On the other hand, Baker said at a news conference, ``serious substantive differences remain'' on reducing troops, tanks and other non-nuclear weapons from Europe that would not be resolved at the summit. ``In short, I think we've made workmanlike progress'' across the range of U.S.-Soviet relations, he said. Baker said the negotiations that were conducted since Sunday expanded on the nuclear weapons categories to be restricted in the treaty. In addition to adding the limits on mobile missiles, he said the presidents had reached an agreement on ``the goals and objectives'' of future negotiations to make even deeper cuts, particularly in overall numbers of warheads. Still, Baker said, they failed to resolve disagreements over the Soviet Backfire bomber, flight tests of heavy ground-based missiles, and safeguards against the transfer of nuclear weaponry to third countries.

DOC.HEAD: WASHN: to work.
DOC.TEXT: I believe that this is all possible as a result of the efforts of both sides over the past few years, including the efforts in which you, sir, have participated vigorously and actively and with great foresight in order to expand our relationship and to build on the capital of trust in our relations. (Applause.) I would like to say that we have done a great deal in order to assure this success and I would like to congratulate our two nations and I would like also to shake your hand, Mr. President, so that we congratulate each other. (Applause.) (The treaties were signed.)

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Summit Rdp Bjt
Roast Duck and Suckling Pig on Soviet Embassy Dinner Menu
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 5 grafs, updating with dinner toasts, security arrangements, etc. Picks up xxth graf pvs, bgng, ``It's just a xxx etc.
DOC.TEXT: Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev hoisted a glass of golden champagne in toast to dinner guest George Bush Friday night shortly after the pair announced a host of agreements, including the broad outline of a pact to slash stockpiles of long-range nuclear missiles. ``Now that we have recorded the progress we have made,'' said Gorbachev in an ornate Soviet Embassy dining hall, ``I would like to express the hope the ship of Soviet-American relations will continue to sail its course.'' Returning the compliment, President Bush extolled the progress of the Washington summit. But he also said that ``true peace takes more than just the laying down of arms, it also takes the reaching out of hands.'' So tight was security for the embassy dinner that large frames of bullet-proof glass were positioned in front of windows facing the busy street outside. For Bush and his wife, Barbara, and a host of top-ranking U.S. government officials, Gorbachev and his wife Raisa broke out their country's best wines to compliment a menu of roast duck, suckling pig and apple puff pastry. The Tsinandali Georgian white dry 1987 and Mookoozani Georgian red dry 1987, renowned in the Soviet union, were joined on the menu by the Soviets' golden champagne Zolotoye. The Soviet Embassy dinner came a day after the Bushes entertained the Gorbachevs at a White House state dinner, and it also featured smoked meat, and consomme with dumplings and mushroom cream. The main course was baked sevruga-fish and roast suckling pig, followed by desert of strawberry parfait, fruit, and apple puff pastry. The embassy released the menu Friday evening after tightly holding details in secrecy. The practice was even more restrictive than the White House procedure of holding details of its state dinner until just a few hours before the guests begin arriving. ``It's just a tradition. Our leaders don't like to put out an official ord on the menu,'' said Vladimir Ustimenko, spokesman for the Soviet delegation at the summit press center. A few details were available from Soviet press contacts _ the dinner guests would be entertained after coffee by opera singer Zurab Sotkilava, and pianist Mikhail Pletnev. The 80 guests would be seated in the embassy's Gold Room at seven round tables seating 10 each with a head table for top dignitaries. Before dinner, guests would gather in the Fireplace Room for drinks. Dress, in contrast to the black tie formal at the White House state dinner for the Gorbachevs on Thursday, was simple _ black business suits for men, and ``normal'' length dresses for women. That meant no mini-skirts, a Soviet spokesman said. After dessert and before coffee, the Soviet and U.S. presidents were to deliver their formal toasts, which the Soviets, who have a tendency to make lengthy remarks, referred to as speeches. When Gorbachev visited in 1987, guests at the embassy dinner dined on Russian caviar on ice, crab meat glace, cold suckling pig, baked ``Bester'' fish a la Muscovite, shashlyk of lamb and raspberry parfait. A questioned still unanswered as the dinner hour arrived was: who were the lucky 40 Americans who would join Gorbachev and his wife and some 40 Soviet dinner invitees? Calls to the embassy for the list got repeated busy signals or recordings. A Communist Party official who briefed reporters at the press center shrugged his shoulders sympathetically but replied ``I don't have a list.'' But the White House managed to come up with a fairly complete list of the Americans invited with spouses: Among the invitees was Senate Republican leader Bob Dole of Kansas, who turned down an invitation to the Soviet Embassy dinner during Gorbachev's 1987 visit when Dole was running for the GOP presidential nomination. He went instead to meet with members of the state contractors association in Manchester, N.H. Also on the list was industrialist Armand Hammer, a favorite in Moscow for his many years of business contacts with the Soviets; Katharine Graham, chairman of the board of The Washington Post Co.; Duayne Andreas, the Archer-Daniels-Midland Co. chairman, and Pepsico Inc. chairman Donald Kendall, both of whom also were invited to Wednesday's White House dinner. Others were Senate Democratic leader George Mitchell of Maine, House Republican leader Bob Michel of Illinois and businessman Thomas Minor. In addition, Vice President Dan Quayle and his wife Marilyn planned to attend, as did Secretary of State James A. Baker III, national security adviser Brent Scowcroft; White House chief of staff John Sununu; Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady; Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff; Ambassador Jack Matlock, and State Department protocol chief Joseph Reed.

DOC.HEAD: Protests Call for Favored Trade Status for Lithuania
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf pvs, `Toward the ...' to UPDATE with signing of trade agreement, comment from Lithuanian-American protesters; picks up 6th graf, `Crowds were ...' ^With AM-Summit Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Rallying under their national colors, Baltic-Americans cheered calls on Friday for President Bush to deny favored trade status to the Soviet Union and bestow it instead on Lithuania. ``We call on our government to recognize the new government in Vilnius and extend most-favored-nation status not to the U.S.S.R. but to the government of Lithuania,'' said AFL-CIO President Lane Kirkland. Some 1,500 people, many wearing national dress as they stood on the Capitol steps and lawn, applauded and chanted, ``thank you, thank you.'' Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev was a mile down Pennsylvania Avenue, conferring with Bush at the White House, but he was much on the minds of the Lithuanian-Americans, Estonian-Americans and Latvian-Americans who shouted for independence for their homelands. Later in the day, Bush and Gorbachev signed an agreement that would bring about normal economic relations between the two countries. U.S. officials said a provision granting lower tariffs on Soviet products will not go into effect until the Soviet legislature passes a law providing free emigration. But the treaty was signed without reference to Gorbachev's handling of the independence movement in Lithuania. In recent weeks, the administration had suggested it might refuse to sign a trade agreement unless Gorbachev eased up on its economic blockade of the Baltic republic. Lithuanian-Americans protesting Friday evening outside the Soviet Embassy said they were disappointed in Bush's decision. ``I think he should take a stronger stance. He should listen to the people of the United States,'' said Aras Tijunelis of Chicago. ``No concessions should be made until he sees the blockade is being lifted and oppression of Lithuania is ending.'' Toward the end of the earlier gathering, someone began burning a Soviet flag, but no arrests were made because officers were unable to identify anyone responsible, said U.S. Capitol Police spokesman Off. Daniel Nichols. It is illegal to have an open flame on Capitol grounds, Nichols said. Crowds were sparse at Lafayette Park and the Ellipse, parks just north and south of the White House where rallies had been scheduled. No arrests or violent incidents were reported. By early afternoon there were about 50 demonstrators in Lafayette Park seeking reunification of Korea, democracy for Vietnam, and an end to prison camps in the Soviet Union. ``This doesn't touch Americans at all,'' Michail Makarenko, who said he had been a Soviet political prisoner, said of the Bush-Gorbachev talks. ``It's just another film Bush will be able to use in the next elections.'' Gorbachev was portrayed on placards at the Capitol rally as a boa constrictor, strangling Lithuanian independence, as a dispatcher of tanks, as a fallen angel with a gun at Lithuania's head. ``Mr. Gorbachev, return what was stolen,'' a poster read, referring to the forced incorporation of the Baltic states into the Soviet Union in 1940. ``Bush makes no deals with terrorists _ unless they're Russian,'' read another. Over the heads of the speakers and the crowd rippled hundreds of flags: the gold, green and red tricolor of Lithuania, the black, white and blue of Estonia, the red, white and red stripes of Latvia. ``Mr. Gorbachev, understand that it's not good enough for you to talk about freedom and democracy when you are depriving the people of Lithuania of food and energy and medical supplies,'' said Sen. Alfonse, D'Amato, R-N.Y. Addressing Gorbachev in absentia, D'Amato said: ``You may have spread Gorbymania around the world but you have not fooled the American people and there will be no MFN until Lithuania is free.'' The Senate voted 73-24 last month to oppose trade concessions for the Kremlin until the Soviet economic blockade is lifted and negotiations begin on Lithuanian independence.

DOC.HEAD: Proposed Treaty Cuts Mostly Obsolete Arms, Allows Replacements
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 2nd graf to reflect lack of full agreement; Inserts new 4th graf with leaders' joint statement
DOC.TEXT: The superpowers are billing their nearly completed arms treaty as a step toward ending the arms race, but private experts said Friday its value may be mainly symbolic. The deal as outlined by President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev carries a potent political punch: It's the first treaty to reduce the number of long-range nuclear arms. But by the time the pact is fully implemented, probably in 1998, analysts say both the United States and the Soviet Union may be nearly asth nuclear arms as they are today, unless additional treaties are negotiated be well stocked wifore then. Gorbachev and Bush failed in a second day of summitry Friday to settle at least three points of dispute in the proposed treaty, but they pledged to conclude the deal by the end of the year. They also agreed to begin negotiating a follow-up treaty on strategic arms once the pending deal is finished. The military significance of the emerging agreement is diluted by decisions to ``discount,'' or exclude, some weapons from the counting rules, and to leavthe Natural Resources Defense Council, a private research group, described the treaty as making a virtue of necessity: scrapping mostly obsolete weapons while permitting both sides to continue building new ones. ``Everything is allowed, just at slightly reduced numbers,'' he said. Among the U.S. weapons that are expected to be scrapped under the START treaty, if completed in its current form and ratified by both countries' legislatures, are Minuteman II intercontinental ballistic missiles deployed between 1966 and 1969, and B-52G long-range bombers built from 1958 to 1960, Norris said. However, it's not yet clear exactly what combination of weapons would be retired in order to remain within START's overall limit on ballistic missile warheads of 4,900. The Soviets would be expected to retire several types of intercontinental ballistic missiles, including 154 of their SS-18s, which are the centerpiece of their strategic nuclear force. These missiles were deployed between 1975 and 1980. The treaty is expected to allow at least some modernization of the remaining SS-18s. This provision, however, would be the only one in the treaty to put limits on individual weapons. As a result, both sides will be allowed virtually unlimited freedom to develop and deploy newer, more accurate weapons later this decade. Frank J. Gaffney Jr., a critic of the Bush administration's negotiating efforts on START, said signing the deal without banning modernization of the SS-18 ``makes a mockery'' of the administration's assertions about the value of the treaty.

DOC.HEAD: Japan Asks Moscow to Release Fishermen
DOC.TEXT: Japan has protested Soviet detention of 18 Japanese fishermen held in one of a series of incidents involving illegal salmon fishing in the North Pacific, the Foreign Ministry said Friday. The protest appeared to be a return salvo in a fishing dispute involving Japan, the Soviet Union as well as North Korea. Spokesman Vadim P. Perfiliev said Thursday in Moscow that the Soviet Foreign Ministry had protested to Japan over ``crude violations'' of treaties that regulate harvest of the rich salmon fisheries off Soviet Asia. Shigeo Takenaka, a spokesman for Japan's Foreign Ministry, told reporters Friday that Japan did not dispute the Soviets' right to stop and seize vessels involved in illegal fishing. But he said the Soviets overstepped their powers by confiscating six Japanese fishing boats and not returning all the crew. Under the Japanese-Soviet fishing agreement, Takenaka said, ``jurisdiction belongs to the Japan side, they have to hand over the vessels and fishermen to the Japan side.'' Takenaka said the Soviets seized six Japanese boats with 52 crewmen in the May 9-13 period and took them to the Soviet island of Sakhalin, north of Japan. A trial was held, each vessel was fined $530,000 to $600,000 and the vessels were confiscated, he said. Only 34 crew members returned to Japan Friday, while 18 men remained in detention, he said. ``This is, from our standpoint, a violation of the Japan-Soviet fishing cooperation agreement,'' Takenaka said. He said Japan was requesting immediate return of the fishermen and vessels. Asked if Japan lodged a protest, Takenaka replied, ``Yes, we are requesting, and a protest is the same thing.'' He said the Soviets also were studying a Japanese request for early release of 169 Japanese crew found on 12 fishing boats flying the North Korean flag. The Soviets seized those boats about two weeks ago, starting an incident that raised eyebrows in Japan over the unusual partnership between Japanese and North Korean fishing operators. Japan and Communist North Korea have no diplomatic relations. On the fishing level, however, the lure of salmon appears to have drawn Japanese fishing companies into leasing boats and crews to North Korea, with part of the catch making its way into Japanese markets. Soviet diplomatic sources in Tokyo say Moscow has also protested to North Korea, which is a Soviet ally but has no fishing agreement with the Soviet Union. Japan has an agreement to take 11,000 tons of salmon originating in Soviet rivers. The sources, who demanded anonysmity, said the Japanese fishermen detained on North Korea-flag vessels would probably be released next week after a trial. Japanese authorities are investigating the deal involving Japanese boats under North Korean flags. The fisheries agency said it did not give the required permission for such transfers.

DOC.HEAD: Attacks Kills British Soldier in England, Another in West Germany
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with full name of victim in Dortmund, gunmen escaped. Pickup 4th pvs, `In Lichfield...'
DOC.TEXT: Two masked gunmen killed one British soldier and wounded two at the Lichfield railway station, and hours later a British army major was shot dead on Saturday in West Germany, the Ministry of Defense said. It said Maj. Michael John Dillon-Lee of the Royal Artillery was shot in Dortmund as he drove with his wife from the military base there to their home in the West German city's Gartendstadt area. Dortmund police said one police officer was injured after shots were fired at police cars chasing the gunmen in a silver metallic painted car. The gunmen escaped after the occupants fired at police, hitting one officer in the foot, police said. Dillon-Lee was shot several times in the head after he stopped his car in front of his house, said the defense spokesman, speaking anonymously in keeping with British practice. He died instantly, but his wife was not injured, the spokesman said. In Lichfield, authorities said the three soldiers were attacked while waiting on a platform for a train Friday, and witnesses said the gunfire sent commuters fleeing. The Irish Republican Army is waging an offensive against British forces on mainland Britain and on the Continent as part of its campaign to drive the British out of the province of Northern Ireland. Police said, however, that they were keeping an open mind about who carried out the Lichfield attack. The soldiers, recruits undergoing training at Lichfield army base, had purchased tickets and were waiting for their train to nearby Birmingham for weekend leave, said Malcolm Bevington, detective chief superintendent of Staffordshire Police. He said two masked men appeared on the platform, pulled out handguns and shot the soldiers, then jumped onto the tracks, ran across the line and through a builder's yard opposite the station. Lichfield is 100 miles northwest of London. All three victims were recruits to the Prince of Wales Division. The Ministry of Defense identified the slain soldier as 19-year-old Pvt. William Robert Davies of Pontarddulais, south Wales. It identified the wounded soldiers as Robert Parkin, 20, and Neil Evans, 19. Chief Inspector Tony Johnson of Staffordshire Police said Parkin and Evans spoke to police at the hospital, adding, ``Both men are sitting up in bed. They are comfortable and as well as can be expected.'' A British rail employee who witnessed the shooting, speaking on condition of anonymity, said, ``I thought they were just messing about, but suddenly there were six loud bangs. Two collapsed to the ground and the third slumped onto a bench.'' He said he jumped across the tracks to try to help the soldiers. ``I and a station employee tried to staunch the flow of blood from the chest of one of the soldiers. ``I could not believe what had happened. The soldiers were in civilian clothes, but it was obvious by their short hairstyle and the way they carried themselves that they were military personnel. ``My feelings are that these gunmen are just cowards and I do not suppose they would dream about tackling our lads if they had been armed. It is just such a shame, the soldiers seemed so young.'' Police, aided by dogs and a helicopter, searched the area. Scotland Yard said it sent an anti-terrorist squad. Taxi driver Peter Irmer said: ``There is a regular movement of troops to the station on a Friday afternoon and evening from Whittington Barracks. ``The majority of soldiers go home on a Friday and almost all of them start their weekends leave from Lichfield City Station.'' An army spokesman said the three were in the 12th week of a 21-week training schedule.

DOC.HEAD: Gold Opens Lower in Hong Kong
DOC.TEXT: Gold dropped $4.50 an ounce on Hong Kong markets Saturday, opening at $360.80. It closed at $365.30 Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Man Gets 25 Years in Murder That Tore Apart a Neighborhood
DOC.TEXT: A young man was sentenced Friday to the maximum 25 years to life in prison for the murder of a 13-year-old neighbor, a crime that tore two families and a town apart. ``No dictionary contains sufficient words to describe the brutality of your acts,'' Nassau County Court Judge Marvin Goodman said in sentencing Robert Golub, 22. Goodman added that the violence Kelly Ann Tinyes suffered last year was ``the most atrocious'' he'd seen in his 17 years as a judge. The girl was beaten, strangled, slashed and sexually mutilated. Golub, who did not testify at his trial, broke his silence with a 20-minute statement before he was sentenced. ``I did not kill Kelly Ann Tinyes,'' he said, speaking in a soft, quavering voice. ``Maybe the person is here today with us, but as sure as there is a God, it is not me.'' His parents, John and Elizabeth, sat on the edge of their chairs inside the packed courtroom, straining to hear their son's words. Golub was convicted in April of murdering Kelly Ann, wrapping her body in a sleeping bag and stuffing it into a closet in the basement of his family's home in the Long Island town of Valley Stream. Golub and his family have claimed a stranger broke into their home and committed the murder while Robert, his younger brother John J. Golub and two of John's friends were at home. The brother and his friends were not implicated. In asking for the maximum sentence, Nassau County Assistant District Attorney Daniel Cotter called Golub a psychopath and a sociopath who has ``no remorse, no concern, no conscience.'' The judge said he received more than 4,000 letters on Golub's sentencing, nearly all urging him to give Golub the maximum for second-degree murder. Kelly Ann's nude body was found the day after she was reported missing by her family on March 3, 1989. The Tinyeses and Golubs have lived three doors apart for 25 years. Outside the Tinyes home, decorated with pink and white balloons sent by a neighbor, Richard Tinyes said the family was pleased. As for Golub's statement, Tinyes said, ``He's a liar and he should rot in hell.'' A few doors away, John Golub stood outside waiting for the inevitable pack of reporters and television cameras. ``If my son was guilty I wouldn't think it was a tough sentence, but we say he is innocent, so of course it's tough for us to take,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Salvadoran Rebels Increase Sabotage on Cristiani Anniversary
DOC.TEXT: Guerrillas blew up more than 20 utility poles and high-tension wire towers Friday, leaving a third of El Salvador without electricity on the first anniversary of Alfredo Cristiani's presidency. In a speech to the legislature on his first year in office, Cristiani declared the next 12 months ``the year of peace'' and called on al sectors to work for an end to this Central American country's 10-year-old civil war. The sabotage affected eight of the country's 14 provinces, authorities of the state-owned power company CEL reported. The provincial capitals of San Miguel, Usulutan and Zacatecoluca were without power, as was much of San Salvador, the capital. Cristiani, a rightist, cited as his main achievement the resumption of peace talks with insurgents of the leftist Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front. The U.N.-sponsored talks began last month in Venezuela and are considered the most promising since the insurrection began. More than 71,000 people have been killed in the civil war, most of them civilians.

DOC.HEAD: AM-Summit Rdp Bjt
US-Soviet Trade Agreeement Reached
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 5 grafs after 14th graf, `In addition ...' to UPDATE with official saying Soviets held up grain pact until agreement reached on trade accord; SUBS grafs 4 and 6 to delete references to treaty; agreement is not a treaty; edits to trim.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev signed a new trade pact Friday that would lead to normalized economic relations between the two countries for the first time in nearly a half century. But the Bush administration emphasized that the provision most prized by Gorbachev, granting lower tariffs on Soviet products sold in the United States, will not go into effect until the Soviet legislature passes a law providing free emigration. At a White House signing ceremony, Bush said that he and Gorbachev were ``looking forward to the passage of a Soviet emigration law.'' At a briefing afterward, Secretary of State James A. Baker III said the agreement would not be sent to Congress for ratification until the emigration law is passed. The emigration law has gone through a first reading in the Soviet legislature but has yet to be brought up for final passage. The pact was signed without reference to Gorbachev's handling of the independence movement in Lithuania. In recent weeks, the administration had raised the possibility that it would refuse to sign a trade agreement unless Gorbachev eased up on its economic blockade of the Baltic republic. Deputy White House press secretary Roman Popadiuk told reporters that ``there has been no direct link between Lithuania and trade.'' However, members of Congress from both parties have insisted that there be just such a link. Said Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, ``The granting of MFN status, in my mind, is in Mr. Gorbachev's hands. He can achieve it with some rather modest changes in his policy toward the Baltic states.'' ``The United States will not give new trade benefits while the Soviet noose continues to strangle Lithuania,'' said Sen. Alfonse D'Amato, R-N.Y. He talked to reporters before Bush and Gorbachev signed the agreement. Lithuanian-American demonstrators massed outside the Soviet Embassy in Washington were clearly disappointed with Bush's decision. ``I think he's letting democracy and independence down,'' said Arunas Martinonis of Boston. ``It really upsets me.'' ``Bush should be stronger about Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia,'' said Helen Zimavicus Carter, who drove 15 hours from her Chicago home to join the protest. ``We're really shocked he doesn't stand up for their rights.'' In addition to the trade pact, the two leaders reached agreement on a five-year grain purchase agreement. U.S. officials had said that the Soviets were threatening to hold up signing this pact unless they got a trade agreement. Intense debate was taking place on the grain and trade proposals throughout much of the day as the Soviets threatened to block the grain agreement _ advantageous to U.S. farmers _ if they didn't get the trade pact they sought, administration officials said. However, larger issues in U.S.-Soviet relations appeared to play more of a role in Bush's decision to give Gorbachev the trade pact than any last-minute haggling over the grain agreement, the officials suggested, speaking on condition of anonymity. Bush administration officials in the days leading up to the summit had been vague _ presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater at one point said the vagueness was intentional _ on whether the trade agreement would be signed. The trade agreement _ sorely wanted by Gorbachev _ was always Bush's trump card, officials suggested. ``It was quite obvious that Gorbachev was seeking something on the economic front,'' said one official. ``It's obviously something that he wanted to take home.'' To emphasize the importance he placed on a trade pact, Gorbachev took his lobbying campaign directly to members of Congress earlier Friday. He told them that approval of a trade deal would be ``especially politically'' useful for him back home. American and Soviet negotiators reached agreement several weeks ago on the details for both a trade pact and a grain agreement in anticipation that both would be signed at the Washington summit. However, the outcome of both deals was in doubt up until the signing ceremony Friday. The pact would be a step toward granting the Soviet Union most-favored-nation trade status, qualifying it for the lowest tariffs granted to any country. Currently, Soviet products sold in the United States bear duties that are as much as 10 times higher than imports from other countries. By one estimate, the price of Soviet vodka could drop by $1.25 per bottle. Leading American business groups including the U.S. Chamber of Commerce and the National Association of Manufacturers have also been lobbying for approval of the agreement, warning that without the deal American companies will be at a disadvantage in trying to gain access to the vast Soviet market. The agreement would provide better copyright protection for American companies and cut down on the time U.S. companies must wait for approval to begin commercial operations in the Soviet Union. It would also clear the way for approval of government-subsidized loans and for loan guarantees from the Export-Import Bank and the Overseas Private Investment Corp. Analysts said this provision was significant because it would expand the number of U.S. companies interested in setting up joint ventures in the Soviet Union, a key goal of Gorbachev's economic reforms. Gorbachev said his quest for the trade agreement did not represent a plea for special favors. The grain accord would increase the minimum amount of U.S. wheat, feed grains, soybeans and other commodities that the Soviets would purchase from the current 9 million tons annually to 10 million tons. The Soviet Union is the largest foreign market for American grain products and new grain pact was viewed as a top objective for U.S. farm groups.

DOC.HEAD: New Florida Law Bans Clothing as Evidence in Rape Cases
DOC.TEXT: Defense attorneys in rape cases can no longer use the alleged victim's clothing as evidence to justify the attack, under a new law signed Friday by Gov. Bob Martinez. ``There is no excuse for rape under any circumstances, and this law will make it clear that the victim of sexual battery should not be persecuted as the criminal is prosecuted,'' the Republican governor said. ``This new law is a major victory for the rights of crime victims.'' The bill's sponsor, Democratic Rep. Elaine Gordon Miami, said the measure stemmed from the acquittal of a rape suspect last October in Fort Lauderdale. Jurors commented that the woman may have tempted the assailant by wearing skimpy clothing. The woman's attorney called the new law ``overkill,'' and predicted it will be challenged. The alleged victim testified that Steven Lord, 26, abducted her at knifepoint from a Fort Lauderdale restaurant parking lot in November 1988 and raped her repeatedly during a trip north on Interstate 95. She said she escaped five hours later and 120 miles north of where she'd been abducted. Defense attorney Tim Day told jurors the 22-year-old woman agreed to have sex with Lord in exchange for $100 and cocaine, but later changed her mind. Several jurors said they decided on an innocent verdict partly because the woman was wearing a lace miniskirt and no underwear. The acquittal sparked outrage and protests from many womens' groups. The woman's attorney, Alexander Siegel, said he believes enough rules already exist on what evidence is acceptable and that judges and attorneys should handle each case individually. ``In my opinion the new law is unconstitutional and unnecessary,'' said Siegel. ``Judges are quite capable of deciding what can be introduced and attorneys can be more aggressive about trying to keep things out.'' Siegel believes the law will be challenged in the first rape case in which the alleged victim's clothing could be a factor. In December, Lord pleaded guilty in a Georgia court to raping and kidnapping a Decatur, Ga., woman. Lord was sentenced to life in prison for the rape and a concurrent 20-year sentence for kidnapping.

DOC.HEAD: Rwanda Students Rampage, One Student Killed
DOC.TEXT: Rwanda Radio reported Friday that college students carrying machetes, knives and rocks went on a rampage and that one student was killed in a clash between rioters and guards at a dance hall in central Rwanda. The broadcast, monitored in Nairobi, gave no reason for the Thursday night fracas by University of Butare students, but said the president of the Central African nation, Juvenal Habyarimana, ordered local leaders and university authorities to right the situation. The radio said students damaged the regional administrator's vehicle and later erected roadblocks, halting traffic south to neighboring Burundi all day Friday. Butare, with a population of 12,000, is the second largest town in the tiny, landlocked nation. Kigali, the capital, is first.

DOC.HEAD: Networks, CNN Gird for Gorbachevs' Visit to Minneapolis, San Francisco
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf to CORRECT day of Stanford appearance to Monday sted Sunday.
DOC.TEXT: When the U.S.-Soviet summit conference concludes Sunday in Washington, the television network news anchors will head for San Francisco to cover the finale of Mikhail Gorbachev's visit to the United States. Exactly what that coverage will be is anybody's guess, network news producers said Friday afternoon, because Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev's plans for visiting Minneapolis and San Francisco still were unsettled. ``We're going to be in a `significant stand-by mode,''' said Jeff Gralnick, executive producer of ABC's summit coverage. NBC, CBS and CNN will broadcast Gorbachev's speech at Stanford University, scheduled for 3 p.m. Monday, during his daylong tour of the San Francisco Bay area, but none of the networks plan live coverage of the Minnesota visit. ``We'll stay very flexible, with the capacity to cover as much or as little as we need,'' said John Towriss, a CNN producer in Minneapolis. He said CNN expects the day's big news will be the summit's aftermath in Washington. Nevertheless, five local stations have pooled their resources to cover what will be one of the year's biggest stories in Minneapolis and St. Paul. KARE, KMSP, KSTP, KTCA and WCCO will be sharing camera crews, satellite newsgathering vehicles and editing and production resources, said Steve Blum, a spokesman for Conus Communications, the satellite TV news service. Pool ``feeds'' will be transmitted via Conus uplinks to satellite, live and unedited, to Conus' 140 subscribing TV stations worldwide. ``Wherever possible, we're using satellite newsgathering equipment,'' Blum said. That allows for a rapid deployment of equipment and staff at all the potential stops on Gorbachev's intinerary. The satellite gear also will let the pool station a camera in Gorbachev's motorcade. A portable microwave transmitter beams the signal to a nearby helicopter, which in turn relays the signal to the satellite uplink. U.S. and Soviet security officials nixed the idea of a helicopter hovering over the motorcade, but will allow it to fly three miles away from the procession. ``That's about as far as we can work and about as close as they're willing to let us get,'' Blum said. Gorbachev and his wife, Raisa, fly to the Bay area Sunday evening. They will stay with the Soviet consul-general's residence in San Francisco. On Monday morning, former President Ronald Reagan and his wife, Nancy, will join the Gorbachevs for ``coffee and conversation.'' The Soviet couple is scheduled to leave San Francisco at 9:30 p.m., or 6:30 p.m. PDT, on Monday.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Troops in Philippines Under Restrictions after Killings
DOC.TEXT: The spokesman at Clark Air Base announced Friday that U.S. troops, Defense Department civilians and military dependents could not leave the base except on essential business. U.S. officials cited an undisclosed security threat in the area, where communist rebels killed two U.S. airmen last month. ``Local, current conditions dictate we take action right now,'' said the spokesman, Lt. Col. Ron Rand, without elaboration in an announcement broadcast by the U.S. military's television station. He said 20,300 people are affected. The chief of the Philippine Constabulary, Maj. Gen. Cesar Nazareno, said Friday he ordered increased security patrols around U.S. bases because of the communist threat. U.S. officials one week ago had relaxed restrictions imposed after rebels killed Airmen John Raven and James Green on May 13, one day before U.S. and Philippine officials began talks on the future of U.S. bases here. Clark, one of the largest American installations abroad, lies 50 miles north of Manila in a stronghold of the Communist New People's Army. The Communist guerrillas have fought for 21 years to establish a Marxist state and have pledged to continue attacking Americans until all U.S. troops leave the Philippines. Eight Americans have died in politically motivated violence in the Philippines since April 1989. Stars and Stripes, the unofficial newspaper of the U.S. military, meanwhile reported Friday that dependents no longer will be allowed to accompany troops to the Philippines unless housing for them exists on the bases. It said about half the personnel at Clark live off post and the waiting list for base housing ranges from six months to nearly three years, depending on rank.

DOC.HEAD: First Ladies Extol Role of Women in Contemporary Society
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 4 grafs after 7th graf, bgng: The crowd xxx to UPDATE with Mrs. Bush comment following dinner at Soviet Embassy.
DOC.TEXT: Barbara Bush and Raisa Gorbachev gave the graduating women of Wellesley College some first-lady advice Friday and then rejoiced in their newfound friendship. ``I simply feel very at home and comfortable with Mrs. Gorbachev and I have enormous respect for her,'' Mrs. Bush told reporters as the pair toured Boston after sharing the commencement platform. Said Mrs. Gorbachev: ``I particularly rejoice at the fact that our conversations are extremely open, sincere and friendly. And despite the fact that we might have differences, that does not change the tone.'' These were words that had not publicly passed between Mrs. Gorbachev and Nancy Reagan, Mrs. Bush's predecessor. At Wellesley's graduation ceremonies, Mrs. Bush disarmed critics who had argued that she was not a suitable role model for women in the '90s. ``I never dreamed it would be this much fun,'' the American first lady said. The crowd cheered, ``Barbara, Barbara, Barbara'' as Mrs. Bush spoke unabashedly about her homemaker's life, while urging the graduates to pursue professional careers if that was their goal. ``They were nice,'' Mrs. Bush said of the students Friday night. The first lady credited Mrs. Gorbachev with the reception the two got, calling her ``my secret weapon.'' ``She's wonderful,'' Mrs. Bush said as she returned to the White House following a dinner at the Soviet Embassy. Asked how she and Mrs. Gorbachev hit it off, Mrs. Bush replied ``very well.'' Sounding some of the themes that Mrs. Bush hit, Mrs. Gorbachev _ a professional women herself _ spoke of ``the values that bring us together,'' including love of country and children. Mrs. Bush, who dropped out of college to marry George Bush as World War II raged a continent away, wore a black academic robe with a purple cowl. Mrs. Gorbachev, a philosophy Ph.D and former university lecturer, wore a plaid gray suit and pink blouse. More conspicuous were the graduates who wore purple armbands, signaling their lingering belief that Mrs. Bush's life has epitomized the victory of fealty to family over feminist emergence. Mrs. Bush got hearty applause when she said at one point: Somewhere out in this audience may even be someone who will one day follow in my footsteps and preside over the White House as the president's spouse. I wish him well!'' But while urging the graduates to pursue professional careers, if they so choose, Mrs. Bush warned, ``At the end of your life, you will never regret not having passed one more test, winning one more verdict, or not closing one more deal. You will regret time not spent with a husband, a child, a friend, or a parent.'' Speaking second, Mrs. Gorbachev's gave a serious, but upbeat, talk on the virtues of Soviet perestroika and the economic reforms undertaken by her husband, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. ``This vast and difficult task is a tough challenge, but we are confident that perestroika will succeed,'' she said. ``... Its goal is to make ideals and values a reality.'' Then, sounding some of the themes that Mrs. Bush hit, she spoke of ``the values that bring us together,'' including love of country and children. ``If people in the world today are more confident of a peaceful future, we have to give a good deal of credit for that to women,'' she said. Wellesleys' 112th commencement would have been momentous even without the student petition questioning whether Mrs. Bush was a suitable role model for the graduates of this elite Massachusetts college for women. It was the first time the two first ladies ever shared a public platform, and Wellesley President Nannerl O. Keohane called it ``another step in the glasnost that brings a new spirit of cooperation between our two countries.'' The two first ladies later toured Boston, twice emerging from their limousine to wade into tumultuous crowds of well-wishers in Wellesley Square and outside Wellesley Middle School. They joined arms and held their hands aloft to the delight of the crowd. After driving through Cambridge and by the Charles River past Harvard and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, they headed for Boston Public Garden, where children from Mather School, the oldest public elementary school in the United States, gave them copies of a classic children's book, ``Make Way for Ducklings.'' On the Wellesley campus, some graduating seniors had come up with a fresh protest Friday for Mrs. Bush _ a letter urging her to ``take a definitive and vocal stand'' on abortion rights and other social issues affecting women. The letter said that in honoring Mrs. Bush, ``We celebrate all the unknown women who have dedicated their lives to serving others.'' The armbands were purple because that was the senior class color this year. The commencement was held inside a cavernous white tent that held 5,500 people. During the playing of the Soviet national anthem, several adults held a banner in the main aisle that read ``Free the Baltic States.'' Graduate Suki Hudson of Warwick, R.I., said of the seniors' protest: ``These things are important to women. With her position, I think if she can take a stand, women's situation would improve a great deal . That's all we ask from her.''

DOC.HEAD: Package Wounds Doctor in Office
DOC.TEXT: A package addressed to a psychiatrist exploded in his office Friday, critically wounding him. Other tenants in his building said they rushed into the office of Dr. Paul Peckar when they heard the explosion around noon and extinguished a fire there. The blast shattered the window of Peckar's third-floor office and forced the evacuation of the building for several hours. A patient waiting in an outer office was taken to Mount Vernon Hospital after being hit with shrapnel, officials said. Valerie Ahmed, 52, was treated after she suffered burns on the legs and face, according to fire officials. The hospital declined to release information on her condition. Peckar, 50, was flown to the Washington Hospital Center in the District of Columbia, about 10 miles away, by helicopter. He underwent surgery of a nature that officials declined to specify, and his condition was listed as critical. Mark Appleton, 38, a podiatrist who worked in another office in the building, was treated for smoke inhalation at Mount Vernon Hospital and released. He said when the bomb exploed he ran to a bathroom, filled a garbage can with water and poured it over Peckar. A doctor who was in the building at the time and examined Peckar said he was badly burned on his hands and face, said Fairfax County officials who reported burns on about 30 percent of Peckar's body. Post Office spokesman Douglas Turner said officials will try to determine if one of Peckar's patients sent him the package. Another mail bomb injured Maryland Circuit Court Judge John P. Corderman of Hagerstown on Dec. 22.

Mikhail Gorbachev is pouring on the charm, disarming critics and admirers alike with his candor and telling average Americans on the street he feels ``really at home'' with them despite U.S.-Soviet differences. ``All people,'' he said in one sidewalk exchange Thursday, ``want a better tomorrow. And the rest is not too important.'' Whether teasing Henry Kissinger at an embassy lunch, parrying with reporters at the White House, or spontaneously departing his motorcade to shake hands with tourists and federal workers, Gorbachev went about town surprising and delighting his audiences. ``We have a good mutual understanding with the president, even if sometimes we draw different conclusions,'' he told reporters who had staked out the White House driveway. ``We both have a willingness to listen, and so our dialogue is very substantive.''

A naive young man is transformed into a corrupt, calculating bureaucrat in a recent Soviet film called ``The Villain.'' Ivan Minas-Bekov jokes that he knows him. ``I understand everything about this mafia, black-market person,'' says Minas-Bekov, a violinist who emigrated here in 1982 to be with his only daughter. ``One is my neighbor in Baku. That's my city where I was born.'' ``The Villain'' is typical of the films being shown during the superpower summit this week at a Soviet film festival. Together, they amount to a celluloid catharsis. Virtually every film is a grim look at some aspect of the Soviet Union's cruel history or current troubles. Occasionally the gloom is disguised as farce, but the themes are the same _ Siberian prisons, Stalinist oppression, heroic resistance, bureaucratic hypocrisy and the guilt of torturers.

Children under 18 are fined $25 if caught smoking cigarettes in Woodridge, Ill., one of the few places where laws against smoking by minors are enforced. ``It is well documented that these laws are seldom enforced,'' U.S. Surgeon General Dr. Antonia Novello said Thursday, noting that 44 states have statutes forbidding tobacco sales to minors. ``More than 3,000 teen-agers become regular smokers each day,'' she said. ``If current smoking rates were to continue in the United States, then about 5 million of the children now living in this country would die of smoking-related disease.'' Those statistics so concerned Woodridge Police Officer Bruce Talbot that he wrote a city ordinance against smoking by youths. He said the Illinois statute was too weak to be effective.

Researchers have taken a step they think could help them better understand AIDS, using a cloned virus to infect monkeys with an AIDS-like disease. This is the first time a laboratory-developed virus has been used to cause an AIDS-type infection, the researchers reported in a paper published today in the journal Science. ``The importance of this is that we can now ... make very precise changes (in the virus) and try and predict what will happen,'' explained Harry Kestler of Harvard University's New England Regional Primate Research Center. Because all copies of a cloned virus are identical, scientists can compare the results of an infection with the original virus with infections from a virus in which they have made specific changes.

The 1990 Atlantic hurricane season begins today amid dire warnings that killer storms on the East and Gulf coasts in the last two years may have been harbingers of a new era of destructive storms. The hurricane season runs until Nov. 30 and was ushered in by a tropical depression last week in the Caribbean that brought heavy rain to Cuba and south Florida but did not intensify into a hurricane. Many coastal communities, with swelling populations, are ill-prepared to handle a hurricane emergency, said Robert Sheets, director of the National Hurricane Center. A recent National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration report predicts the number of people in seaside counties from Maine to Texas will grow 60 percent, counting from 1960 until 2010. Some states such as Florida and Texas will experience near 200 percent growth during the period, the report said.

DOC.HEAD: Even in Countryside, Politics is a Daily Business
DOC.TEXT: E Desheng, a 27-year-old tea seller who has never left home, is a veteran traveler of the socialist road, sensitive to political nuances. E lives in rural Huashan township and says he has not ventured farther than Wuhan, the provincial capital 12 miles away. Like almost everyone in this tightly regimented nation, however, he reads the signs from Beijing, 700 miles to the north. A member of the Communist Youth League, he attends weekly meetings ``to study how to keep on the socialist road and take the lead in learning from Lei Feng,'' a legendary footsoldier venerated for selflessly doing good deeds and loving the Communist Party. Emulating Lei and protecting socialism from ``bourgeois liberalism'' are central themes of the nationwide ideological campaign that began after the government sent troops to crush the pro-democracy movement a year ago. Whatever his expressed interest in politics, the young tea seller speaks with far more animation of his two-story home and 3-year-old son. Like most Chinese in the countryside, he probably keeps up with politics only in hopes of achieving a more prosperous life. A recent press tour of Hubei province in central China, organized by the Foreign Ministry, revealed how difficult it is even for ordinary citizens to escape Beijing's latest political campaign. Zuo Wenqing, an official in Huashan, said political education had been increased. ``On orders of the central government, we strengthened the connection between cadres and workers and taught farmers to love the country, lead a simple life and work harder,'' he said. Ma Yue, executive vice president of the 80,000-worker Second Automobile Works in Shiyan, western Hubei, said classes were begun after the June 1989 crackdown to study the works of Deng Xiaoping and other party leaders. ``Political education is quite important,'' Ma said. ``We shouldn't be motivated only by money.'' People in Hubei are bombarded by political slogans on roadsides, in publications and in factories. Many deal with such mundane issues as family planning or traffic safety. Others, including stone carvings embedded in railroad embankments that read ``Long Live the Communist Party,'' probably date from the 1966-76 Cultural Revolution. One slogan in a small Huashan collective factory, reflecting the now-muzzled economic reform sentiments of the mid-1980s, proclaimed: ``Time is money, profit is life.'' Lei Feng slogans have begun appearing in every factory. ``The spirit of Lei Feng is the traditional virtue of the Chinese people,'' said one in a Wuhan machinery plant. Another, at a textile factory in Xiangfan City run by the army, read: ``The great successes of the past 40 years would be impossible without the Communist Party leadership, socialism and the government policy of democratic dictatorship.'' During the Beijing pro-democracy demonstrations last year, about 1,000 students protested in Xiangfan, young people surrounded the Second Automobile Works in Shiyan and, in Wuhan, protesters blocked the train and auto bridge across the Yangtze River for three days. Wuhan, an industrial city of 3 million, has been a center of political activism for generations. Wuhan rebels helped bring down the Qing dynasty after the turn of the century, the young Communist Party operated from there in the 1920s and some of the bloodiest fighting of the Cultural Revolution occurred in Wuhan. Despite the tradition, most Hubei residents probably are just going through the motions of the latest political campaign, like their counterparts in Beijing. As in the rest of China, all Communist Party members in Hubei factories and offices have been told to register again. The purpose is to weed out those tainted by pro-democracy sympathies, but it appears few in Hubei are in danger of expulsion. Huang Mobin, president of the Wuhan Iron and Steel Corp., which has 120,000 employees, said with pride that not a single worker went to Beijing last year to join the demonstrations. ``It's true that workers dislike unequal distribution of property and profiteering, but they are more dissatisfied with the students and instability,'' he said. Often, the rhetoric is little more than a handy way to avoid prying questions. Mayor Wu Fayu of Shiyan, after a speech attributing the city's progress to the Communist Party, the study of Marx and Mao and folowing the socialist road, was asked how Mao Tse-tung's thought guided him in his daily work. ``His general thought is a crystallization of the wisdom of the people,'' was the cryptic reply. A department store manager in Wuhan claimed following the socialist road was the key to his store's success. He then said he was adopting new marketing systems that would foster competition between different sections of the store. Blaring in the background was a soundtrack of the American movie ``Saturday Night Fever.''

DOC.HEAD: More Than One Way To Deal With Budget Deficits
DOC.TEXT: By forces only dimly understood, Americans are said to have changed their minds about one of the most fundamental financial issues of mankind, and now seem ready to accept higher taxes. A smattering of surveys indicate as much. It is considered a ``given'' in many financial and business analyses. And even the president of the United States, elected on a pledge of no increases, has suggested he might reconsider. However it was done, the selling of the idea of higher taxes might make a study worthy of the most esteemed educational institutions. Only this much is known: Many people think an increase is the only way to cut the budget deficit. That, too, might make an academic study, because only a few years have passed since the President's Private Sector Survey on Cost Control, headed by J. Peter Grace, recommended $424 billion in cuts over three years. No more use was made of the study than is made of those shellacked sets of encyclopedias that reside on shelves beside the television set and the other pieces of furniture. In 1985, the year after the study, Congress raised spending by $94.5 billion and very little has been heard of the findings since then, although Grace, chairman of W.R. Grace & Co., did his best to keep the publicity at a high pitch. The entire thesis of that volume was the wastefulness of government and the growing danger that it would bankrupt the nation unless corrected. Its subtitle could very well have been: Cut Waste Rather Than Raise Taxes. Now the deficit is thought to be at a crisis level by people in all areas of life, members of Congress to be sure, but heads of corporations too, and a tax increase is thought the only way to reduce it. It isn't the first time Congress has ignored the option of cutting spending rather than raising taxes and it isn't likely to be the last. Not if you can judge by the recent evidence. With assistance from fellow scholars, Scott Hodge, federal budget analyst for the Heritage Foundation, a Washington-based conservative think tank, came up with a list of $130 billion in cuts he says would cause minimal damage. Among other things, he would ask Congress to break its addiction to pork barrel spending. That's a lot to ask of elected officials, of course, because their success often is seen as receiving more from Washington than constituents send there. But some pork barrelling, Hodge indicates, might be of no help back home or anywhere else either. Such as $2,500 to finance a study on the causes of rudeness, lying and cheating on tennis courts, an $84,000 study of why people fall in love, and $107,000 to study the Japanese quail's sex life. Just peanuts, you say. Well, then, consider the recent aid package for Panama and Nicaragua. Congress cut it back to $420 million from the $800 million requested by President Bush. That was Congress' price for agreeing to such aid. It wasn't the only price. To the bill, members of Congress tacked on more than that amount for domestic projects, many of them their favorite spending programs. Among them: A sum of $400,000 to fill in a collapsed utility tunnel in Salisbury, N.C., sought by a congressman from that state, and $990,000 to repair a waterfront park in Bay City, Mich., by a congressman from that area. In this way did a foreign aid package for Panama and Nicaragua hide a large domestic spending program. Spending is in; cutting is out. Hodge says Congress even ignores revelations of wasteful spending by its own research arms. Last November, for example, the General Accounting Office found more than $150 billion in program waste, fraud and financial mismanagement. And only three months ago the Congressional Budget Office recommended reforms it said would yield savings of roughly $60 billion in the first year... ... if implemented.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv PMs Friday, June 1

DOC.HEAD: A Killer's Wife Sees Life On The Run and In Protective Custody
LaserPhoto BX2 of June 1
DOC.TEXT: Debra Gilbert was in her nightgown fixing breakfast when an ax broke through the front door. As a dozen police officers waving shotguns swarmed her house, she heard her husband yell, ``She doesn't know anything. She doesn't know.'' What she didn't know was that her husband of four years was connected to the mob. She didn't know he had killed three times. And she didn't know the shambles her life would become. Yet even after she knew, she stood by him when he agreed to testify against organized crime buddies, living a bizarre life of fear that included time in a three-room police station apartment. She watched as her husband manipulated authorities, serving his murder sentence while living the high life complete with thousand-dollar expense accounts and beach house vacations. When Peter Gilbert died of a heart attack in June 1988, he still was in custody, but was driving alone to go skydiving, in a Buick stocked with cocaine. ``I know a lot of people out there would say, `Boy, she's the biggest fool who ever walked this earth,''' Mrs. Gilbert said in an interview at her Brooksville, Fla., home. But ``how many people can say they loved someone enough to love them blindly?'' The case of Peter Gilbert offers an unusual glimpse into the sometimes peculiar world of crime and punishment, where a man so skilled in manipulation can take not only his wife for a ride, but also police and prosecutors. His escapade rocked Providence's police department and led Gov. Edward D. DiPrete to order a state police investigation. Fourteen officers face disciplinary action for unprofessional conduct, and a special prosecutor was named April 30 to take the case to a grand jury for possible criminal indictments. A state judge is even considering overturning a conviction that was based on Peter Gilbert's testimony because of all the lies. The ``fiasco,'' as the internal investigation calls it, is expected to cost nearly $1 million by the time all the probes are completed. ``Then the state of Rhode Island and especially myself will be able to put pieces together and not feel like there is anything missing anymore,'' Mrs. Gilbert said. A consummate con man, Peter Gilbert made up in charisma what he lacked in conscience. He told Debra their marriage was his first, when it was at least his fifth. Standing 5 feet 5 inches, with a scruffy beard and tattoos, Peter hardly seemed the lady's man. Debra knew he had children, but she wasn't one to ask a lot of questions. When they met in Florida, she was a high school dropout with three young children. Peter lived next door when the man she had married at 16 walked out. ``He was my hero that came along and loved me and my children,'' she said in her soft Southern lilt. She married him in 1981 in the Brooksville courthouse, believing he was James Harold Cassidy. The charade crumbled a year later when he was arrested for burglarizing a church and a lumberyard. Police said he was Peter Gilbert, a man who lived half his life as a criminal. ``I couldn't understand why he lied to me. I left him,'' she said. Peter told her he lied only to get away from his past. He said he stole to pay for the birth of their newborn daughter, Kiya. He wrote poems from jail to win her forgiveness: ``Now that Kiya binds our love there is no yesterday; ``Just tomorrow, just for us, our love will show the way.'' A few months later, Peter escaped by knocking out another man in a holding cell who was to go before a judge on a minor charge. Peter took his place, pleaded guilty to the other man's infraction, and walked free. He fled to Rhode Island. Against the advice of family and friends, Debra quit her waitressing job in Brooksville to join him after a one-year separation. ``I was raising four kids and they missed him,'' she said. ``He said I was his life and after calling me all the time, I believed him.'' In Rhode Island, she wondered why his beeper, supposedly for his job at an auto body shop, went off at all hours with strange messages. She asked enough to learn he was ``involved'' with drugs, but didn't pry. ``I didn't want to know, to be honest,'' said Debra, now 30. Peter's drug use became so bad he asked her to wake him by injecting him with cocaine. She refused, but stayed at his side _ telling herself he just needed help. When police stormed her Providence home in early 1985, Debra learned about the murders _ all involving drug users or traffickers. ``I tried to imagine him doing something like that,'' she said. ``I couldn't, no matter how hard I tried.'' Authorities offered Peter an unusual deal in exchange for his testimony. He would serve his 10-year sentence in Providence police custody, then be relocated. The dream of starting over helped keep Debra with her husband. So did Peter's tales of threats against the family, and prosecutors' pleas he was a more believable witness with his wife by his side. She sent her three older children to her mother in Florida and she and 2-year-old Kiya were allowed to join Peter in the police station. The three lived together in a cell for a few weeks while a former matrons' quarters was converted into a three-room air-conditioned apartment. It had a telephone, television, videocassette recorder and queen-sized water bed. But it was adjacent to the women's cells, and the noise and screaming were incessant. ``It was definitely our home,'' said Debra. ``But it was like jail, too. ... I think I always felt like I was breathing germs.'' Peter passed the time watching TV, sharing a beer with his guards, fishing with the mayor's chauffeur. He started an autobiography. He was allowed out, and sometimes stayed away overnight. Debra was immobilized by fear. Afraid to go out, she spent more time in jail than Peter. She began to fear the food might be poisoned and made her daughter wait while she tasted some first. The strain finally proved too much and she moved back to Florida. ``I couldn't take it anymore: the women screaming, the officers. My daughter was not going to be raised in that kind of environment,'' she said. Two years later, in 1988, she went back to Peter at a rural Rhode Island safe house prosecutors provided. Debra said she told police that Peter was using cocaine and packaging drugs in the cellar, but was told to keep quiet. A departmental review supports her allegation. ``It can reasonably be inferred that Gilbert supplemented his state income with his profits from narcotics sales,'' the review said. She stayed just seven weeks. Two months later, Peter, who had a history of heart trouble, died of a heart attack following a fight at a Connecticut gas station, according to a medical examiner's report. Debra continues to wrestle with her husband's lies. Peter told the children he lived in the police station because he was an undercover officer. She hasn't yet found a way to tell them the truth. But she is hopeful about the future. She recently remarried and insists, this time, she is less naive. ``I have started a new life with a very good man,'' she said. ``It's just a good feeling.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Thurs PMs, June 7

For release Mon PMs, June 4, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: NBC Affiliates Meet to Ponder Good News, Bad News
DOC.TEXT: The annual NBC affiliates' convention, normally held in Los Angeles, begins in Washington today. The main reason? A Tuesday trip to Capitol Hill by affiliate executives to discuss cable- and NBC-related matters. The executives of NBC's 208 affiliated stations should be happy, considering the network last month won its fifth straight season in prime time. But there is trouble in Peacock City. Among other things: _ NBC's prime-time ratings last season were the lowest in its history, down 9 percent from 1988-89. _ ``Today,'' whose Nielsen dive began after last year's much-criticized changes that led to the exit of Jane Pauley and the entrance of Deborah Norville, has run second to ABC's ``Good Morning America'' for 21 weeks. _ Tom Brokaw's ``NBC Nightly News'' has been third in the news ratings for seven consecutive weeks. The executives, of course, also will be pondering what incoming affiliate chairman Eric Bremner calls an ``audacious and bold'' move for next season by Fox Broadcasting _ pitting ``The Simpsons'' against ``The Cosby Show.'' ``I think Fox has taken one hell of a gamble,'' says Bremner's predecessor as affiliate chairman, James R. Sefert. ``But this is just the kind of challenge that makes Bill Cosby work all the harder.`` Although The Simpsons vs. The Coz likely will be the talk of the gathering, much of the executives' attention will be on the news division. Its president, Michael Gartner, last month commenced repair programs for ``Today'' and the ``NBC Nightly News'' in sudden, back-to-back moves that more than a few TV writers saw as two steps back to the future. For ``Today,'' he re-hired former host Joe Garagiola, who'll be on the show three days a week. With CBS anchor Faith Daniels, hired as the show's news anchor, he'll join co-hosts Norville and Byrant Gumbel on June 11. And Gartner re-hired Steve Friedman, the brash former ``Today'' executive producer who helped that show achieve dominance. Gartner made him executive producer of ``Nightly News.'' Gartner is scheduled to talk to the affiliates today about the changes and other plans. It remains to be seen whether he'll come under heavy fire from the station executives at Wednesday's closed-door final session. ``I don't know if there's going to be hostility, but there is deep concern'' about the state of the two programs, says Sefert, president of Cosmos Broadcasting Corp. in Greenville, S.C. ``We hope to get an explanation of the rationale behind moves that have been made so far,'' says Bremner, of King Broadcasting Co. in Seattle, Wash. He doubts that the fiesty Gartner will face sharp verbal attacks. ``But yes, the affiliates are very definitely concerned and anxious to see positive results from the changes that have been made,'' he says. The affiliates also will hear Gartner discuss a proposal to make an NBC News service called A-News a 24-hour news and sports-news operation, one that would resemble CNN only in its round-the-clock schedule. A-News currently sends affiliates reports from NBC News and affiliate stations seven times a day, starting at 11 a.m. EDT and ending at 2:30 a.m. EDT, NBC says. The reports are separate from NBC's regular newscasts and are for use in local stations' newscasts. The expanded service might include an anchor in the early morning hours when NBC isn't broadcasting. The proposed new service ``has to be viewed as a positive turn of events,'' Bremner says. ``If it's done as well as NBC intends to do it, it will be a major resource for the affiliates.'' During Tuesday's Capitol Hill trip, Sefert says, the affiliate executives will meet with their congressmen to seek: _ Hearings on the issue of cable companies that transmit local broadcast signals without paying for them. The NBC stations don't seek laws requiring payment, he says, but want ``a solution that is acceptable to everybody.'' _ Capitol Hill support for whatever the Federal Communications Commission decides on proposals to let the networks have a financial interest in programs they air that were brought in by outside producers. The major networks currently are barred from a financial interest in such programs by the FCC's financial-syndication rules. But the FCC currently is re-examining the rules in light of the growth of cable.

Elsewhere in television ... HAIL TO THE PAIR: Robert MacNeil and Jim Lehrer have worked together for 15 years in what has evolved into public television's ``MacNeil-Lehrer NewsHour.'' So their production company, which says their partnership is the longest of its kind in TV history, says the two will be the subject a 90-minute PBS special this fall. Which it will produce.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Mon PMs, June 4

For Release PMs Monday, June 4
DOC.HEAD: How A Crunch Spreads
DOC.TEXT: It might be wise to listen to all those complaints of a credit crunch, even if many of them are coming ``merely'' from builders and developers. A credit crunch anywhere in the economy can spread economic woe far and wide. Many business economists have tended to discredit credit crunch claims, arguing that the national statistics fail to show one; much of the evidence is anecdotal; and any problem is restricted to builders. Other analysts contend, however, that even a slight infection in just one limb can spread quickly to the entire body. Builders clearly are involved in a credit crunch, which they say is bound to hurt other businesses. This becomes clear when you consider the ingredients, the trades and skills, the manufacturers, retailers and wholesalers involved in building just one, 1,700-square-foot single-family home. Lumber, of course, some 9,726 board feet of it. And 55 cubic yards of concrete, 1,992 square feet of asphalt shingles for roofing, 2,500 square feet of insulation, 6,484 square feet of wall board and 90 feet of ducting. If you find it difficult to visualize those items, then consider these: 55 gallons of paint, 302 pounds of nails, 12 windows, three bathtubs, three sinks, 15 kitchen cabinets, and, of course, the range, refrigerator, dishwasher ... All of those items must be assembled in a housing unit, and that involves people such as architects, draftsmen, surveyors, masons, plumbers, roofers, painters, paperhangers, electricians and a dozen other vital trades. Most of these are local business people, but the locals order from regional suppliers who get their materials from factories, which are situated throughout the country and which order from raw material suppliers. In all, according to the National Association of Home Builders, which bases its estimate on U.S. government figures, the construction of just one house means 1.8 man-years of employment. Translated, that could mean almost 22 months of work for one person or, for example, about three month's work for seven. Thus, while the credit crunch in building may not to date have made an impression in national statistics, smart economists, including Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan, are concerned. Martin Perlman, NAHB president, says the crunch already is destructive. ``Builders are being indiscriminately cut off from the credit markets. Production is dropping. People are losing their jobs and businesses,'' he says. He cites an association survey in which 60 percent of 1,142 responding builders said changes in lending practices at thrifts and commercial banks have affected their plans for 1990. These are the key findings in regard to thrifts, perhaps better known as savings and loans associations: _About 49 percent of the respondents said savings institutions are reducing the amount they can borrow in the future for land acquisition, land development or construction. _Fifty-two percent said thrifts no longer will make land acquisition loans. _Forty-six percent said thrifts no longer will make land development loans. _Thirty percent said thrifts no longer will make construction loans. To some extent, the attitude of savings and loan associations is more understandable than that of commercial banks, because S&Ls are under greater pressure from regulators to maintain sound lending practices. Some restraints shown by commercial banks are self-imposed, following big losses in speculative ventures. But the builders survey indicates that even sound builders are facing a variety of credit denials. Thirty percent of respondents, for example, said they've been asked for additional collateral on existing loans and 35 percent said banks now seek excessive documentation. Some, they said, are calling loans before maturity. All this might not to date have shown up in national statistics so revered by some economists. But as other economists point out, statistics are historical records, not measures of current events.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv PMs Monday, June 4

DOC.HEAD: Dalai Lama Finding It Difficult to Retire
With AM-Tibetan Troubles
DOC.TEXT: While other world leaders fight to stay in power, and some try to fend off reform, the head of the world's 6 million Tibetans has the opposite problem. The Dalai Lama's people are uncomfortable with democracy and do not want him to retire as their political leader. But then, most other political figures aren't considered living gods. ``I am insisting on stepping down,'' the Dalai Lama said in an interview. ``It is of greatest urgency that democracy comes to us. It is the most creative way for the human spirit.'' In his ornate parlor overlooking the snow-capped Himalayas, the Dalai Lama predicted communism soon would fall in China and his followers would return to their homeland within 10 years. Tibetans believe their mountainous region, with its unique culture, should be an independent nation. China claims Tibet has been part of its territory since the 13th century. To prepare for their return, the Dalai Lama said, Tibetans must embrace democracy and shed the idea that he is a god. It is proving difficult. There is strong conservative opposition to the Dalai Lama's plans to democratize his government-in-exile and few, if any, Tibetans seem willing to abandon the belief that ``His Holiness'' is divine. That belief has made Tibetans ``lazy,'' said the 54-year-old Buddhist leader, who won the 1989 Nobel Peace Prize. ``They think I will do everything for them.'' Tibetans circle his residence, pausing to clasp their hands in prayer. Elderly women, limping with age, climb steep grades to gaze at his compound, whispering ``10,000 years to His Holiness.'' Tibetan Buddhist tradition holds that the first Dalai Lama, born in 1391, was a reincarnation of Chenresi, the Buddhist god of mercy. Subsequent Dalai Lamas are revered as reincarnations of their predecessors. The current Dalai Lama, the 14th, was chosen in 1936 after a series of visions indicated the leader would be found in a house with turquoise tiles in eastern Tibet. When he first told Tibetans of his wish to give up his political position, the Dalai Lama said, ``many people were shocked and they told me I should not say this kind of thing. ``But I continuously spoke out,'' he said, with a playful grin. He remains a reluctant politician, a man of the spirit, not of law or intrigue. Clothed in maroon and saffron robes and wearing his ever-present tinted glasses, the Dalai Lama chuckled, cracked jokes and reached out to squeeze the hand of a reporter as he made a point. ``I am just a Tibetan monk,'' he said, running his fingers over wooden prayer beads. ``I would rather go to an isolated monastery and pray. Now I have no time for prayer. I am always busy, busy with the affairs of this world.''
