DOC.HEAD: Exhibit Recalls Horrors, Absurdities of Stalinist Period
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: A new exhibit in Budapest recalls the shadow of Stalinism that covered half of Europe for more than 40 years. It is called ``Sta-lin! Ra-ko-si!'' and is the first in Eastern Europe to depict the day-to-day life of the 1950s. Hungary's Stalin was Matyas Rakosi, who was installed by the Soviet dictator and ruled unchallenged. Stalin died in 1953, byt Rakosi's reign lasted until the 1956 uprising against Stalinism, which was crushed by Soviet tanks. The exhibit, constructed like a labyrinth, is in a castle on a hill above the Danube River. It includes newspaper headlines, photographs, uniforms of feared men, soiled clothing of the beaten and belongings of the executed. Emil Horn, who conceived it, said he wanted to juxtapose the truth and the Rakosi regime's representation of itself. ``Those days were very sad,'' He said in an interview. ``Now, there is a great irony.'' A giant reprint of a cartoon from the period depicts mice marching behind a placard of a grinning cat. Next to it are equally large photos of Hungarians marching behind portraits of Rakosi and Stalin. The exhibit focuses on the Rakosi era, but repeatedly draws comparisons with the Soviet Union, showing nearly identical uniforms, medals and even constitutions. A cast-bronze head of Rakosi adorns a three-tier podium, recalling the cakes each village, factory and school sent him on his 60th birthday. The podium is piled high with presents: hand-stitched banners, painted vases and flasks depicting the glories of communism. There is sheet music of hymns to the leader. Up a few steps, in a mausoleum-like chamber, are even more elaborate gifts to Stalin. The exhibit also notes differences between Stalinism in the Soviet Union and Hungary. ``Here, it lasted only seven to eight years,'' Horn said. ``Due to the liberal trends in Hungary, Czechoslovakia and the whole region, it would have taken much longer to completely suppress the people than in Russia.'' Horn is a former Communist who believed firmly in Marxism when the Soviets liberated Hungary. About what came later, he said: ``We are ashamed of ourselves.'' His exhibit ``contains my personal self-criticism as well,'' Horn said. ``For me, it is a kind of absolution. I didn't hurt anyone, but still, it is absurd that I and so many people were so stupid. ... Why was I so ignorant?'' Millions of people in Eastern Europe are asking themselves that question. In his New Year's address, President Vaclav Havel of Czechoslovakia said all Czechoslovaks shared responsibility for Communist rule and cautioned against simply blaming leaders for the excesses. An exhibit about Czechoslovakia's history since 1918 opened in Prague last month. It is part of a general effort in what once was the Soviet bloc to express the truth of history and strip away Stalinist falsehoods. Budapest's Rakosi exhibit shows how the Communists rigged the 1947 elections, then chronicles the dissolution of other parties, collectivization of land and experiments in economic self-sufficiency that even included a short-lived attempt to grow cotton. The second part of the exhibit has the atmosphere of an interrogation chamber, courtroom and prison camp. Documents listing charges against prominent victims of the Rakosi regime are displayed along with photographs and personal belongings. They include Cardinal Jozsef Mindszenty and former Interior Minister Laszlo Rajk, who was hanged as a ``Titoist.'' In a depiction of the notorious labor camp at Recsk, where many people died, are huge prints of photos taken secretly by an inmate who now lives in the West. A small cabinet displays such banned materials as Carlo Collodi's ``Pinocchio,'' Disney cartoons and ``The Jungle Book,'' by Rudyard Kipling Looming over the exit is a border guard tower bearing two figures: 18,000, the number of people allowed to travel outside the country in 1951, and 10 million, the number in 1989. Across from the tower are statues of Rakosi and Stalin, toppled, as they were after protesters pulled them down at beginning of the uprising Oct. 23, 1956. Stalin's fist is in the dirt. One visitor wrote in the guest book: ``Thank God we haven't seen this in our lives.'' Another wrote below: ``Unfortunately we have.'' Still another echoed Horn: ``I'm ashamed that the Hungarian people were willing to accept all this for decades.''

DOC.HEAD: Insiders Saw Stock Rally Coming
DOC.TEXT: As unexpected as the stock market's latest upsurge to record highs may have been, it certainly didn't seem to catch corporate insiders by surprise. Before the market began to take off five weeks ago, top managers, directors and major shareholders of corporations had been stepping up buying of their stocks for months, to levels seldom seen over the past two decades. By so doing they put some fresh luster on their reputation as a force to be reckoned with in the search for the right stock to buy at the right time. Since the waning months of 1989, according to tallies by various investment advisory services, insiders have been consistently buying more shares of their companies' stocks than they have sold in open-market transactions. To regular followers of the insiders' activities, that represented an even stronger endorsement of the market outlook than it might appear at first glance. Insiders often obtain stock through private means such as employee purchase plans and the exercise of options they receive as part of their pay. Thus, in their open-market activity, analysts say they typically can be expected to be sellers about two-thirds of the time and buyers in the remaining one-third or so of transactions. ``Because they're often compensated with company stock, about twice as many insiders normally sell than buy,'' said Stephen Leeb in the newsletter Personal Finance. ``But for the last few months, buyers have actually outnumbered sellers. Every time this has happened in the past, stocks across the board have rallied.'' In calculating his ``Insider Indicator,'' Norman Fosback, editor of the advisory publication The Insiders, puts the ``normal buying line'' at 35 percent of the total transactions. For a five-week period through mid-May, the indicator stood at a ``very bullish'' 60 percent. ``The insiders are again telling the market that higher stock price levels are ahead,'' Fosback said. ``The only way to describe their current activity is a `buying panic.''' The rationale for tracking the activities of insiders is straightforward enough. Fosback calls them ``America's most knowledgeable investors.'' Or as Leeb observes, ``What really drives stocks in the long run is what's happening on America's factory floors. ``Who are the best witnesses? Corporate insiders _ officers and directors who have firsthand knowledge of their firms' strengths AND weaknesses.'' The close-up view does not always lead to unerring insight. Insiders had it right in 1980 and 1983, when they grew cautious just ahead of periods of flat or declining stock prices. They gave no such warning, however, in 1987 leading up to the crash on Black Monday, Oct. 19 of that year. As if to make up for that omission, they stampeded in with buy orders after the crash, betting correctly that the market would rebound. Through the 2{ years since then, they have remained consistently if a little less spectacularly bullish. When stocks tumbled early this year, it appeared as though a bear market might have set in, catching corporate insiders unaware. But now, says Fosback, ``the latest upside price burst has once again vindicated the insiders.''

DOC.HEAD: Many Survivors Only Now Dealing With Holocaust Trauma
DOC.TEXT: Only now, 45 years after World War II ended in Europe, are many Jewish survivors coming to grips with the trauma they suffered at the hands of Nazi Germany. A recent survey found that 302,404 of the nearly 1 million Holocaust survivors who fled to Israel from Europe were still alive. Most are 65 to 80, an age at which experts say they will be taking stock of their lives. ``The natural process of aging takes people back to deal with their pasts, to make an account with their souls,'' said Ilana Nahmias, director of Amcha, which provides psychological counseling for survivors. Many seek a sympathetic ear for their nightmares, paranoia, loneliness. Scores have turned to Amcha, which has about 35 volunteer workers at its offices in Jerusalem and Ramat Gan, a suburb of Tel Aviv. Many of the volunteers are children of survivors. Amcha, a non-profit organization, was the first recipient of reparations from East Germany, in the form of a $3.6 million grant in April. Its name means ``people'' or ``your people'' in Hebrew, and was a password Holocaust survivors in Europe used to identify each other. Its cases include: _ A 60-year-old man who spent the war years hiding from the Nazis with the help of farmers, and never shared his experiences with his family. The home atmosphere became tense and his children had trouble ``fitting into the outside world.'' _ A 72-year-old survivor, not given to dwelling on the past, who began thinking constantly of his life in a concentration camp. He was overwhelmed by a need to talk, but did not want to burden his wife with his private terrors because she, too, had lived through the Holocaust. _ A man in his 70s who could not sleep because of a secret he could not tell his daughter: that he had had a first wife and son who were killed by the Nazis while he stood helpless. Counseling helped the first two and their families, but the third man left the program after one session and refused the center's proposal to arrange for his daughter to join him in a meeting with counselors. Nahmias said there were several cases of survivors who had not told relatives and close friends about first families, either because it was too painful or because they felt shame for not preventing the deaths. ``We don't say we can cure pain,'' she said. ``We have no recipe. But many feel they are going to explode, that they have to tell about their experience now or it will be lost. If they feel a little better, it's a lot.'' Some prefer talking to a tape recorder, she said, and the center has 200 hours of recorded testimonies. ``The survivor can come and talk about what he wants,'' said Nahmias, a former colonel in the army women's corps. ``We don't try to find out if it's true or matches historical events. It's enough if that's how he remembers something or how he wants to be remembered.'' Several cases involve survivors who were children during the Holocaust. About 50,000 child victims live in Israel. To protect their privacy, Nahmias did not reveal the names of any of the survivors. The Amcha director related the case of a 55-year-old woman who, when her daughter left home to get married, was suddenly faced again with the fear of separation she felt as a child. While on the run from the Nazis, she had been passed from family to family 17 times. Nahmias said many child survivors were reluctant to speak of their experiences because they felt the suffering of those in the death camps was so much greater. ``I didn't want to talk as a child; I was ashamed of it,'' said Yossi Peled, who survived by hiding with a Christian family in Belgium and now is a major general in Israel's army. Eli and Shoshana Heyman, a German-born couple who survived work camps and Auschwitz and now work as Amcha volunteers, said Holocaust victims have difficulty speaking of it because non-survivors cannot relate to their experience. ``Sometimes you see it in their eyes; they want to understand, but they can't,'' said Shoshana Heyman, who is in charge of Amcha's archives. ``It's impossible. When you want to explain, it sounds so horrid that you can't explain.'' She said they did not tell the ``terrible things'' even to their children, but were able to talk with other survivors. Eli Heyman, a retired communal farmer who counsels lonely and troubled Holocaust victims, said he was haunted by the fact that survivors had such difficulty finding happiness. ``What bothers me is that people who went through the Holocaust, in the end do not get by so well,'' he said. ``One has money, but he does not get by. He is not at one with himself. He is divided. You are not happy and that is the problem. ``It is a not a remedy for a doctor, to ask someone what hurts.'' Although he provides counseling, Heyman said, ``I know it is not possible to find a solution.''

DOC.HEAD: Controversy Over Pumice Mine Centers on Fashion, Old Law
DOC.TEXT: When Bob Crostic bought his first pair of stonewashed jeans recently, he discovered a small chunk of pumice in one of the pockets. There was more than a bit of irony in the find. Crostic, a staffer with the U.S. Forest Service, oversees an open-pit pumice mine in the Santa Fe National Forest that is at the center of a noisy dispute about the use of public lands. Because some of the pumice is used to stonewash or acid-wash fabric, critics contend the forest is being sacrificed for fashion, and ``Fashion vs. Forest'' has become their rallying cry. The Las Conchas Pumice Mine looks like a moonscape, the dazzling white of the pumice piles offset only by a couple of heaps of burned, blackened tree stumps. ``Great stuff to mine,'' Crostic told recent visitors as he grabbed a handful of the lightweight, volcanic rock and sifted it through his fingers. Last spring, as work began to prepare the mine site in northern New Mexico's scenic Jemez Mountains, about 20 members of the environmental group Earth First! converged to protest the operation. Three were arrested when they locked themselves to earthmoving equipment. At issue is a 19th-century federal law that allows private citizens to mine and appropriate public lands at negligible cost. The law, enacted to encourage mineral development, says that anyone who finds a valuable mineral deposit on public lands may stake a claim and mine it or patent the claim and purchase the land. While coal, oil, gas, sand, stone and other minerals have been removed from its provisions, the General Mining Law of 1872 still covers metals such as gold, lead, copper and zinc, as well as pumice. Copar Pumice Co., which had staked claims in the area, received approval last summer from the Forest Service to strip-mine 33 acres in the national forest about 15 miles west of Los Alamos. Copar then must restore the site once mining is finished by recontouring it and planting grass and trees. Environmentalists went to court, contending the mine's impact had not been adequately assessed, but mining continues while the case is pending. In September, Copar owner Richard Cook applied for a patent, or outright ownership, of 1,700 acres surrounding the mine. Under the 1872 law, if the tract is determined to contain valuable pumice, Cook can buy the land for $2.50 an acre. Once he owns the property, no state or federal reclamation laws would require him to restore the site after mining. ``It's essentially a major ripoff of public land under an archaic law,'' said Henry Oat of Santa Fe, who heads the East Fork Preservation Coalition. The operating mine is barely a fourth of a mile from the East Fork of the Jemez River, a pristine trout stream that has been approved by Congress for inclusion in the National Wild and Scenic Rivers system. Nearly 180 acres of the land Cook seeks fall within the quarter-mile corridor on either side of the river that would be protected by the federal designation, which awaits President Bush's approval. The legislation prohibits Cook from patenting the 180 acres along the river, but he cannot be prevented from mining it because he has valid claims. He has said, though, that he would not mine it because that would spoil the view from the river. ``We don't intend to destroy the landscape or the area in any way,'' he said from his office in Espanola. Cook also said he has no plans for the 1,700 acres other than to mine it, but his opponents fear he would develop condominiums or other commercial ventures in the forest. Environmentalists also are worried that the beautiful Jemez area, a popular tourist destination, will turn into a pumice-mining center. The Copar pumice is the remnant of a volcanic explosion 150,000 years ago and is considered valuable because of its large-sized chunks, its purity and its proximity to the highway. Pumice goes into products ranging from building materials to toothpaste. Its use as an industrial abrasive, including stonewashing garments to give them an aged appearance, is a small but growing segment of the market, said Donna Smith, a mineral economist who lives near the mine. Copar, however, is not a major pumice supplier to the garment industry. Cook said about 10 percent of the mine's pumice goes for stonewashing, far less than was anticipated when the mine opened. ``The garment industry just isn't taking all the large chunks now,'' Cook said. Most of Copar's pumice is used for construction, he said. Industry spokesmen say much of the pumice used by major garment manufacturers is imported. Levi Strauss & Co., for example, buys its pumice from Turkey for its products that are stone- or acid-washed, and has cut back about 60 percent on the amount of pumice it uses, supplementing the stone with chemicals, said company spokesman David Samson in San Francisco. Although only a fraction of Copar's product ends up in the industrial machines in which denim is stonewashed, opponents of the mine have urged a boycott of stonewashed clothes. The East Fork Preservation Coalition and other environmental groups also are pushing a proposal to have 115,000 acres, including the mine site, designated as a National Recreation Area, which they say would stop the patent process and offer greater protection for the forest. There are efforts, too, to reform the 118-year-old mining law, including two bills that have been introduced in Congress to revamp it. The Copar mine is one of a series of disputes arising from the law and an example of why it should be changed, said Philip Hocker, president of the Mineral Policy Center in Washington, D.C. ``The law says that anybody who finds a valuable mineral deposit in the public domain has a right to mine it, no matter what the environmental consequences and with no payment to the public,'' he said. ``That's what's wrong with it.''

DOC.HEAD: Job Interview Crucial for Success
DOC.TEXT: Hordes of high school and college graduates are making the rounds of job interviews, and those face-to-face meetings can be crucial to landing employment. A good-looking resume and thorough job application are a good start, but those efforts lead to the interview, the make-or-break moment in getting the job. Think of the man standing on a subway platform in New York holding a violin case. He asks a conductor ``How do you get to Carnegie Hall?'' The conductor answers: ``Practice, practice, practice.'' That's the case in job interviews, too. Consider beforehand what may be asked, practice questions and answers with a friend, and don't get discouraged if it takes several tries to land a job. Each interview is good practice for the next one. Time is important in business, so the first thing to remember is to be on time for the interview. Start out early and arrive a little early if possible. And don't bring anyone along for moral support. Appearance is also important, say experts at the Labor Department. The job interview is not a good time to express individuality or eccentricity in dress or grooming. The clothing worn to an interview depends to some extent on the job being applied for, but in all cases should be clean, neat and conservative. Men, Labor Department officials say, should wear suits or shirts and slacks. Dresses are best for women. Think in advance about how to answer some of the most likely questions, such as why you want to work for that particular company, what your interests and goals are and how you can help the company. This requires learning something about the company beforehand, either from library reading or by talking to people who work there. In answering questions, pause to compose an answer that is concise and to the point. This requires careful listening to make sure you understand the questions. And be sure to let the interviewer finish the question. Don't interrupt. If you don't understand a question, ask the interviewer what he or she means. Then answer honestly. Sometimes people will ask why you left a former job. Tell the truth, but do not say negative things about former employers. Such remarks may be interpreted as unwillingness on your part to cooperate. Two of the hardest questions to deal with are the open-ended ones, such as ``tell me about yourself'' and ``what can I do for you?'' The idea is to get you talking, and the best answer is to narrow down the focus to the reasons why you are a good candidate for the job in question. Don't just ramble on about yourself, describing long-term goals or saying such things as ``I'd like to utilize my education'' or ``I like to work with people.'' Better is something more specific, such as ``I've always had an interest in wholesale sales in the electronic industry and I have studied marketing, which should help me in this job.'' There are some questions employers are not supposed to ask unless they pertain to the job, such as marital status, family planning and child-care arrangements. Some will ask anyway, and it's probably best to go ahead and answer. The focus in a first interview should be on the company and what you can do for it, not on pay and fringe benefits. Information on those things should be available from the personnel department. At any rate, reserve the discussion of pay until a job offer is made. At the end of the interview, ask what the next step will be _ whether you should contact the company again or provide more information, if the company will call you, and when a final decision is likely to be made. Try to end on a positive note, repeating your interest in the job. After the interview, send a note to the interviewer, thanking him or her for the time and providing any added information that may have been requested.

DOC.HEAD: With BC-AP Arts: Tonys
Seattle Repertory Theater Seeks New Heights After Winning a Tony
DOC.TEXT: After the Tony, what? That is the happy question facing the Seattle Repertory Theater, which is being presented the top award for a regional stage company on Sunday night in New York. From the 27-year-old theater that first produced ``I'm Not Rappaport,'' ``The Heidi Chronicles,'' ``Eastern Standard'' and ``Largely New York,'' the answer seems to be to try to do more of the same and keep getting better. Major breakthroughs _ construction of a new playhouse in 1983, production of award-winning new plays and formation of a resident acting company _ came well before the theater awards were announced on May 7. ``I think we could have won at any time in the last five years and it would have been appropriate,'' said artistic director Daniel Sullivan. ``A lot of people said that it was only a matter of time. Other people said it was late in coming,'' said managing director Benjamin Moore. ``It came as a surprise to me.'' The Rep reached Tony caliber 10 years ago, said Peter Donnelly, Moore's predecessor as top administrator of the Rep and now director of Corporate Council for the Arts, a fund-raising group. ``The Tony, I think, is kind of an achievement award as opposed to a `best of' kind of thing,'' Donnelly said. ``I think that it's certainly a nice imprimatur to have,'' Sullivan agreed. ``Our goals have been pretty high for the last few years, and I don't think that's going to change because of the Tony.'' In the past 11 years, the Rep has developed more than 35 new plays, several of which moved on to productions in New York and London. Sullivan also has returned to acting after a 25-year hiatus in addition to originating Herb Gardner's ``Rappaport'' and Wendy Wasserstein's ``Heidi,'' which won Tonys in 1987 and 1989, respectively. ``Heidi'' also won a Pulitzer Prize, and the Drama Desk and New York Drama Critics awards. Sullivan was nominated for a Tony for best director. The premiere of Lyle Kessler's ``Robbers'' last fall at the Rep provided his latest role, Mr. Feathers, a seemingly mysterious American Indian who hires an aimless, innocent young man into private eye work to stop employee theft at a cannery. In a tragic, surreal and hilarious emotional roller coaster of a plot, Feathers turns out to be white and cynical, and the young man realizes he has betrayed his new lover and closest friend. ``I read plays as an actor,'' Sullivan said. ``I try to find truth that I think an actor would find.'' A top goal for the Rep now is to boost the number of actors in the company from the current dozen to about 20, Moore said. ``We also want to begin commissioning new work, not just soliciting new scripts.'' As a third goal, he said that within the next three to five years he would like to see construction of a 275-seat house to complement the 856-seat main stage in the Bagley Wright Theater at the Seattle Center. With attendance at 90 percent of capacity or better for the past decade, all three goals require more money than ticket sales can provide _ and that's where the Tony is most valuable, Sullivan and Moore said. For starters, the award carries a $25,000 grant from American Express. ``I've been telling everyone, we like the recognition, but most of all we like the money _ especially in these days of creeping censorship from the (federal) government through restrictions on the National Endowment for the Arts,'' Sullivan said. ``We like to get money without strings attached.'' The recognition also makes them more appealing to funding sources, said Moore, managing director at the much larger American Conservatory Theater in San Francisco for 15 years before moving to the Rep in 1985. ``This is recognition that these theaters cannot achieve within their own communities,'' he said. ``It's only when people hear from professionals outside their own communities that suddenly their stock goes up.'' The awards, named for early 20th-century actress, producer and director Antoinette Perry, have been awarded since 1947. The regional award dates from 1976. Rather than starting as the vision of an artist, as is true with most performing arts groups, the Rep was organized by local theater fans after Century 21, the 1962 World's Fair. An initial attempt to form an actors company quickly collapsed, but by 1979 the Rep had a yearly budget exceeding $2.3 million, 141,948 ticket buyers who filled the Seattle Center Playhouse to 95 percent of capacity and 21,880 subscribers. Years of artistic doldrums also were ending with the arrival of Sullivan as resident director under the late John Hirsch, acting artistic director. By the time Hirsch left to take the artistic reins of the Shakespeare festival in Stratford, Ontario, Sullivan was well into his new-play program. ``I just came here and decided to do it,'' Sullivan said. ``The new work ... that's something I can't do without.'' The Bagley Wright was completed in 1983, and Moore arrived two years later to help Sullivan provide the final ingredient, successful formation of a resident company of actors. ``The artists were mere guests in this building,'' Sullivan said. ``It was not a very good home for the actor,'' Moore said. ``This theater was still jobbing in actors almost on a show-by-show basis.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, June 3

DOC.HEAD: From AP Newsfeatures
With BC-APN--TV Women

DOC.TEXT: Most producers make television shows to win rating points. Marian Rees aims to win hearts and minds. Rees' productions include 1985's ``Love is Never Silent,'' the Emmy-winning story of deaf parents and their hearing daughter, and this year's ``A Son's Promise,'' the well-received account of a young man's pledge to raise his orphaned brothers. Throughout her career, Rees has fought to deliver programs that have often run contrary to television's lowest-common-denominator formulas. For her efforts, she is now considered one of the most successful and acclaimed women in television. ``I really quarrel with the assumption that good programming is bad business,'' Rees said in an interview. ``People are turning away (from the networks) not because it's bad business. They're turning away because it's bad programming.'' At Marian Rees Associates Inc., an independent production company, Rees has formed an alliance with ``Hallmark Hall of Fame.'' Collaborations with the greeting card company have yielded ``The Marva Collins Story,'' ``The Room Upstairs,'' ``Resting Place,'' ``Love is Never Silent,'' ``Foxfire,'' ``Home Fires Burning'' and ``The Shell Seekers.'' The company also has production deals with all three networks, as well as PBS and cable's Home Box Office and TNT. Since the company was established in 1981, Marian Rees Associates has made 13 movies for television and has nine movies in various stages of development. A volunteer for the Center for Population Options and Alternative Living for the Aging, Rees said her work reflects several concerns. ``My own personal goals _ and the reason I started the company _ was to be able to do the things I had a strong, strong commitment to,'' she said. ``Most of our works try to have a spin to them on an issue. And I've also begun to realize that they all turn around family.'' She studied sociology, psychology and religion at the University of Iowa. Her first job in television was as an NBC receptionist. Rees served as the associate producer on the pilots of two of television's longest-running series, ``All in the Family'' and ``Sanford and Son.'' At Norman Lear's Tandem Productions, she worked on ``The Thief Who Came to Dinner,'' ``The Night They Raided Minsky's'' and ``Duke Ellington...We Love You Madly.'' Subsequent credits included ``Can You Hear the Laughter?'' about Freddie Prinze and ``Angel Dusted'' with Jean Stapleton. Rees knows television still has a lot of room for improvement. ``Children's programming is one of the shames of our industry,'' she said. ``The whole issue of selling through children's programming is abhorrent.'' Rees said a recent television movie about the Laker Girls was ``outright exploitation,'' and she was glad the show fared poorly in the ratings. Rees is the president of Women in Film, an organization whose future, she hopes, is not long. ``Until there is the evidence of equal opportunity and equal pay, then our hope is that there will be no need for Women in Film at all,'' she said. ``The day we celebrate its dissolution is a day we look forward to.''

DOC.HEAD: Jaguar Vanden Plas: Refinements in '90 Include Engine
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto, LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: Status and a refined ride come standard with the 1990 Jaguar Vanden Plas sedan. So does a sense of accomplishment. The Vanden Plas is, after all, the top of Jaguar's standard production line for the United States. And if the car's $48,000 price tag doesn't show that you've arrived, the Jaguar's sleek body lines and soothing, quiet interior will. This is, indeed, a car that's meant as a reward. That's why so many buyers are well-heeled chief executives and business owners. Jaguar spokesman Mike Cook said buyers are typically in their mid to upper 40s and are highly educated. Nearly half are women, and average annual income of Vanden Plas purchasers is more than $200,000. The car comes with a host of standard features, including sunroof, a leather interior that uses no less than seven animal hides, and polished burl walnut on the dashboard, doors and the front seat-backs. The Vanden Plas comes with fuzzy synthetic mats over the regular floor mats for added softness and comfort, a premium sound system, automatic leveling suspension and a 271-page owner's manual. Jaguar has increased its fuel-injected, six-cylinder engine from 3.6 liters to 4, boosting output by 12 percent to 223 horsepower. The result is 0-60 mph acceleration in less than 9 seconds. The gearshift features a sport setting that allows the driver to change the transmission's shift points for added pickup. But even that won't do terrible damage to fuel economy. During the test drive, I averaged close to 20 miles per gallon in mixed city-highway driving using the sport and regular settings intermittently. Front seats were comfortable for me, with electronic adjustments and lumbar support for individual setting. But a friend who has thicker hips and legs found the driver seat a bit confining. His right leg bumped against the parking brake lever situated to the left of the center console, next to the driver seat. Rear legroom was admirable, even with the front seats pushed all the way back. But the middle passenger must sit on a rather stiff seat area _ it has a storage bin underneath the seat leather _ and headroom isn't the greatest, either. The back seat is much better suited for only two passengers. The trunk was low, with 12.7 cubic feet of usable space once the big spare tire was in there. Fit and finish, as expected, was excellent inside and out. Jaguar has seen its U.S. car sales fall off since 1986, when sales hit 24,464. They fell to 22,919 in 1987 as the company lost production during its changeover to a new-model XJ-6, Cook said. He attributed the continued sales slide _ to 20,727 in 1988 and 18,967 in 1989 _ to a soft luxury market in the United States. The company hopes to push unit sales beyond 20,000 again this year. Competitors in the luxury sedan class include the Lexus LS400, which starts at $35,000; the Infiniti Q45, at $38,000; BMW 735i, nearly $50,000; and the Mercedes-Benz 300 series, which starts at just under $40,000. Consumer Reports magazine ranks 1984-88 Jaguar XJ-6 models as much worse than average in owner complaints of trouble. Cook acknowledged that early 1988 models had some problems but said corrections have been made.
