DOC.TEXT: Orders to U.S. factories slumped 2.3 percent in April, helping to push orders down 2 percent for the year, the government said in a report providing more evidence of a slow manufacturing economy. The Commerce Department said Thursday orders to factories totaled a seasonally adjusted $235.6 billion. That followed gains of 4 percent in March and 1.8 percent in February. Despite the gains, the April decline and a 5.5 percent drop in January means factory orders have fallen 2 percent in the year's first four months.

Lower prices and higher consumer incomes made it easier for the typical American family to buy an existing single-family home in April, a real estate trade group said. The National Association of Realtors said Thursday its housing affordability index reached 104.6 in April, up from 103.9 in March. That means a family earning the median income of $34,032 had 104.6 percent of the income needed to qualify for conventional financing covering 80 percent of a median-priced home costing $95,300.

Employees seeking to buy UAL Corp. for $4.54 billion did well in landing Chrysler Corp.'s Gerald Greenwald to head the effort, but still need a top executive with airline industry experience, analysts say. Wall Street quickly signaled its approval Thursday of the deal with Greenwald, who was instrumental in arranging the federal government's bailout of Chrysler a decade ago. UAL stock surged up $4.75 to $155.62{ a share on the New York Stock Exchange.

Chrysler Corp. scrambled to realign its top management and fill gaps created at a critical time by the resignation of Vice Chairman Gerald Greenwald and other executives. Responding to Wednesday's surprise resignation of Greenwald, heir apparent to Chairman Lee A. Iacocca, Chrysler on Thursday named Robert S. Miller, its executive vice president and chief financial officer, as vice chairman.

Striking bus drivers have proposed an employee buyout of Greyhound Lines Inc. to rescue the company from possible bankruptcy brought on by their walkout. The buyout was proposed in a letter dated May 29 from financial advisor Brian M. Freeman to Greyhound management and creditors. The letter didn't specify a price but said a buyout would best resolve the strike.

A former partner of John A. Mulheren Jr. directly linked him to an illegal trading scheme with admitted insider trader Ivan Boesky. Edward McCarthy, a former partner in Jamie Securities Co., testified Thursday the firm temporarily held four large securities positions for Boesky in 1985 because Boesky needed money to comply with federal net capital laws. The comments appeared to corrobate government charges against Mulheren, accused of manipulating a stock price and ``parking'' securities to help Boesky avoid taxes and federal securities regulations.

The Coca-Cola Co. is scrapping its much ballyhooed ``MagiCan'' promotion after bad publicity over mechanical problems with some of the prize-filled soft drink cans. The company had intended to distribute 750,000 of the special cans throughout the summer, but spokesman Randy Donaldson said Thursday that shipments had been halted. The move came a week after Coke took out full-page ads acknowledging the defective cans and explaining how they work.

A Pennsylvania state court ruling barring a phone company from installing devices that alert customers to the numbers of incoming calls could provide ammunition to those trying to block the service elsewhere. Pennsylvania's Commonwealth Court ruled Wednesday that Bell of Pennsylvania may not offer the service, on grounds it is an invasion of privacy and violates state laws on wiretapping and phone-number tracing. Legal experts said Thursday that the ruling implies caller ID services are illegal in other states.

The Civil Aviation Administration of China has ordered 36 Boeing jetliners and taken options on 36 more in a deal worth as much as $4 billion, Boeing Commercial Airplane Group said. The order announced Thursday represent one of the largest purchases of American aircraft by China. It cmae one week after the Bush administration said it would renew most-favored-nation status for China, a designation that gives the country the lowest available tariffs on exports to the United States.

Stock prices finished mixed Thursday following gains from record highs. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials slipped 1.90 to 2,876.66. Bond prices closed mostly higher and the dollar advanced. Energy futures prices fell because of a supply buildup. Grains and soybeans were mostly higher; precious metals futures were mixed, and livestock and pork futures were mostly lower.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Partner Links Mulheren To Boesky Scheme
DOC.TEXT: John A. Mulheren Jr. kept his firm's stock holdings in Unocal Corp. off of profit and loss statements because the shares really belonged to Ivan Boesky, a former partner of Mulheren said in federal court. The testimony Thursday by Edward McCarthy, once a partner in Jamie Securities Co., appeared to directly link Mulheren to what the governmnent charges was an illegal trading scheme to help Boesky cheat on taxes and skirt federal laws. Also, Boesky's former chief trader told a federal judge he regularly takes a drug used to control anxiety or tension. The trader, a government witness, made the admission at the request of defense lawyers who claimed the drug could affect memory. Testifying under immunity from prosecution, McCarthy said Mulheren in 1985 asked him to separate trading in Unocal from the firm's profit and loss statements because the holdings belonged to Boesky. He also said the firm temporarily held four large securities positions for Boesky in 1985 because Boesky needed money to comply with federal net capital laws. The government's charges against Mulheren include manipulating a stock price and ``parking'' securities to help Boesky. The government claims Mulheren bought $10 million in Unocal shares from Boesky in mid-1985 with an agreement to sell back the stock at a later date. The ``parking'' arrangement allegedly was designed to help Boesky create the appearance of losses for tax purposes. In addition, Mulheren is accused of holding large options positions in four companies to help Boesky temporarily raise money to meet federal laws governing the amount of capital a securities firm must hold. The trial has attracted widespread attention because it marked the first time Boesky has testified publicly since he settled insider trading charges 3{ years ago. Boesky was once Wall Street's best-known speculator and his cooperation with investigators has led to numerous prosecutions. He took the stand last week to implicate Mulheren, a former friend and associate. McCarthy, 39, of Freehold, N.J., said Mulheren in the late summer or early fall of 1985 asked him whether Jamie had the buying power to purchase the options because Boesky had ``problems'' with his capital. McCarthy said Mulheren later told him and another partner that ``Boesky wanted his money back'' from trading profits Jamie made in the deal. Previous testimony by Michael Davidoff, Boesky's former chief trader, placed the amount at around $2 million. McCarthy said that when he suggested writing Boesky a check, Mulheren laughed and then devised a scheme under which Boesky's Seemala Corp. would inflate brokerage fee bills to pay back the money. Mulheren, 40, is charged with 41 counts of conspiracy, securities and mail fraud, and record-keeping violations. Also Thursday, Davidoff said in a closed-door hearing before U.S. District Judge Miriam Goldman Cederbaum that he has taken a drug for four or five years to control high blood pressure and nervousness. Defense lawyers said they wanted to find out whether Davidoff was on medication because it may have affected his recollection of events. Mulheren attorney Thomas Puccio said a doctor told him the drug, Ativan, could affect memory, and that the issue would be raised Monday before Cederbaum. The government sought to prevent disclosure, apparently out of fear it could tarnish Davidoff's testimony. According to the Physicians' Desk Reference, Ativan is a brand name for the drug lorazepam. It is taken for ``the management of anxiety disorders or for the short-term relief of the symptoms of anxiety or anxiousness associated with depressive symptoms,'' the text says. Davidoff previously testified about the alleged Unocal and options parking transactions. He has pleaded guilty to one felony count, agreed to cooperate with the government and is awaiting sentencing.

DOC.HEAD: U.S., Trading Partners Want Cuts in Farm Payments, But Differ on Approach
DOC.TEXT: An impasse between the United States and its European trading partners over cutting farm subsidies threatens to block a four-year effort to liberalize the global trading system, government officials said. The warnings came at the end of a two-day meeting of trade and finance officials from two dozen industrialized nations. Officials had hoped the meeting would generate fresh momentum in the trade talks. But instead they ended on a discordant note as the European Community refused to accept U.S. demands to sharply curtail its farm supports and export subsidies. The trading bloc's argument is ``simply not a tenable long-term position,'' said Gareth Evans, Australia's foreign affairs minister. ``They will be putting at risk not just agriculture but the whole round (of trade negotiations) if they stick to a position as tight as that,'' he said. Ministers of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development ended their talks Thursday by saying they agreed ``to take urgent steps to reform agricultural policy, as regards support and protection, so as to permit greater liberalization of trade.'' But in an unusual move, their closing statement acknowledged differences ``on how an approach to these objectives should be expressed at this stage.'' ``It was better to express these differences of views publicly than to try to paper them over,'' said OECD Secretary-General Jean-Claude Paye. Some 100 nations have been attempting to forge a new agreement to reduce trade barriers in 15 areas, including agriculture, textiles and services. The talks began in Uruguay in 1986 and are scheduled to end in December. U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills had wanted this week's OECD meeting to give a push to the trade talks. But the talks appeared to do little more than show how far apart the two sides are. At the heart of the fight is an American demand that the 12-nation EC do much more to rein in government spending on farm subsidies, in particular by moving to eliminate costly export subsidies. But Ray MacSharry, the trading bloc's top farm official, said, ``That is politically impossible and will not happen.'' He contended that getting rid of the program would translate into higher farm prices in Europe and cost the jobs of millions of farmers. The subsidies allows expensive European farm products to compete with lower prices on the world market. The United States complains the subsidies have enabled the community to increase its share of the world market and has responded by setting up its own export subsidy program. American officials also pressed the community to open its markets wider to foreign farm products and reduce farm payments that encourage overproduction of crops. The community rebuffed the pressure. It called instead for an attempt to lower farm payments by first measuring a country's trade performance in agriculture. The ministers did promise to ``to make every effort to overcome the differences'' by a July 23 bargaining session in Geneva. By then, the United States wants preliminary agreements or negotiating texts in all 15 areas under discussion. The Uruguay Round of trade talks is being held under the auspices of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, a forum and agreement for promoting freer trade. OECD members are: Australia, Austria, Belgium, Britain, Canada, Denmark, Finland, France, Greece, Iceland, Ireland, Italy, Japan, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, New Zealand, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey, the United States and West Germany.

DOC.HEAD: Drivers' Union Floats Idea Of Employee Buyout To Save Greyhound
DOC.TEXT: If an employee buyout can solve an airline's woes, striking Greyhound drivers think the same strategy could rescue the only nationwide bus company from the brink of bankruptcy. A financial advisor hired by the drivers has asked to meet with Greyhound Lines Inc. to discuss a possible employee buyout. The advisor, Brian Freeman, isn't new to the idea. He is advising UAL Corp. employees on their effort to complete a proposed $4.54 billion buyout of the parent of United Airlines. In a letter dated May 29 to Greyhound management and creditors, Freeman said he believed ``100 percent employee ownership of all transportation operating and related assets, together with a significant creditor restructuring'' is the best solution to the company's troubles. Freeman said Thursday a price for a Greyhound buyout had not been determined and no financing had been arranged, although he said money ``should be available.'' He said the union also is willing to discuss other alternatives. ``Within the short-term, I intend to make a specific proposal, and begin to press aggressively toward a resolution,'' Freeman wrote on behalf of the Amalgamated Council of Greyhound Local Unions. ``Please advise me immediately whether you wish to explore mutual problem solving. Otherwise I will proceed on my own,'' Freeman wrote. ``I intend to place my client in a position so that, either cooperatively or independently, it can make a specific proposal and press forward within the next several weeks.'' Greyhound's initial response wasn't positive. ``We are surprised the group that has brought about the company's current financial crisis through an unprecedented wave of violence now proposes to profit from its own criminal activity by buying the company,'' said executive vice president P. Anthony Lannie. Greyhound has reported more than two dozen incidents of violence since its drivers went on strike on March 2. The company has been operating reduced schedules since the strike began, using newly hired drivers and about 500 union members who crossed picket lines. Although the company claims the strike is ``irrelevant'' because it has enough drivers to operate, the strike has drained its cash and left it in danger of having to file for bankruptcy protection. Greyhound already has missed more than $14 million in interest and lease payments since the end of April and faces an additional $2.5 million payment on Friday. Unless those payments are met soon, creditors could force the company into involuntary bankruptcy, although Greyhound likely would file for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of federal bankruptcy laws before that happened. The company's debt is the legacy of a leveraged buyout three years ago led by Chairman Fred G. Currey that took the company private. Currey and other investors paid $270 million for the bus operations of Greyhound Corp., since renamed Greyhound Dial Corp. A few months they paid an additional $80 million for Dallas-based Trailways Lines Inc., then the nation's largest operator of Trailways buses. Greyhound has proposed to repurchase most of its $225 million in junk bond debt at a steep discount to enable the company to avoid bankruptcy. The repurchase is tied to Greyhound obtaining as much as $150 million in new financing, however, a task some analysts doubt can be accomplished in light of Greyhound's labor troubles and the state of the financial markets. Further clouding Greyhound's future is a finding by the National Labor Relations Board that the company engaged in unfair labor practices by implementing its contract proposal immediately after the strike began. An administrative law judge will hear arguments in the case in Milwaukee on Sept. 17, beginning a process that could take years to end, and result in the bus company being forced to pay about $10 million a month in back wages. Greyhound says it is confident it will win once the case gets in court.

DOC.HEAD: Greenwald Gets Cautious Thumbs Up On Wall Street
DOC.TEXT: UAL Corp. stock soared after former Chrysler Vice Chairman Gerald Greenwald was chosen to head an employee buyout of United Airlines' parent, but analysts suggested that his appointment alone won't seal the deal. ``While he has a good record on financial matters, the airline industry is unique,'' Robert Joedicke, an airline specialist for Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. in New York, said Thursday. Joedicke said bankers who must finance the deal will want to see a chief operating officer with a strong knowledge of the airline business. ``The key requirement it that there is someone there that understands how to run an airline,'' he said. Greenwald acknowledged as much at a news conference in Highland Park, Mich. He said one of his first tasks would be to seek someone from the airline industry as second in command. Bankers are familar with Greenwald himself. He played major roles in securing federal government loans that saved Chrysler from bankruptcy in 1979, and in negotiating the purchase of American Motors Corp. in 1987. On Thursday, the price of UAL stock surged $4.75 on the New York Stock Exchange to $155.62{. Still, that was well below the $201 offer made by the United Employees Acquisition Corp., which indicates that some investors remain skeptical that the deal will come off, Joedicke said. Other analysts said caution prevails given the employees' failure to raise financing for a $300-a-share buyout offer last October. That triggered a massive 190-point freefall in the Dow Jones industrial average. Greenwald, vice chairman of Chrysler since November 1988, will become chief executive officer of the buyout corporation, an entity formed by the airline's three major unions. If the acquisition attempt is successful, Greenwald, 54, will become chairman and chief executive officer of Chicago-based UAL Corp. and United Airlines. He would replace UAL Chairman Stephen Wolf, who has been targeted for ouster by the unions. UAL spokesman Tony Molinaro said Wolf would have no comment on his fate. In a statement, Wolf said, ``I congratulate our union leaders for recruiting someone of Jerry Greenwald's stature. As he proceeds to finance the transaction, I will be as helpful to him as possible.'' Greenwald said he began seriously considering joining the UAL buyout effort 10 days ago, about five weeks after he was first contacted by the group. ``The offer kept getting more tempting,'' he said. ``At one point, I wasn't at all clear who was going to be running the company. My mind changed from it being a problem to being an opportunity about 10 days ago.'' The offer by the buyout group _ the Air Line Pilots Assocation, the Machinists union and the Association of Flight Attendants _ is made up of $155 in cash, $35 in high-yield notes and $11 a share from UAL's 51 percent stake in Covia, the company's computer reservation system. The UAL board has given the buyout group until Aug. 9 to come up with the financing.

DOC.HEAD: CFO Miller Succeeds Greenwald as Chrysler Vice Chairman
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp. wasted little time in tapping a successor to former Vice Chairman Gerald Greenwald by moving Chief Financial Officer Robert S. Miller one step closer to the chairman's office. Miller, 48, was named vice chairman of the nation's No. 3 automaker Thursday afternoon, less than 24 hours after Greenwald's resignation was announced. The latest moves in the executive suite of Chrysler's Highland Park headquarters come as the company is fighting to hold its declining market share in the face of tough domestic and overseas competition. Greenwald, who was heir apparent to Chrysler Chairman Lee Iacocca, quit Wednesday to head up a three-union bid to buy United Airlines parent company for $4.54 billion. In the management shuffle, Chrysler obliterated the Office of the Chairman, an indication that Iacocca may be reasserting himself in corporate operations. Iacocca's contract expires at the end of 1991. A year ago, he said he was reducing his day-to-day input into Chrysler's car and truck making operations. But at the company's annual meeting in Los Angeles last month, the colorful, 65-year-old Iacocca hedged on whether he would retire next year. ``I've got to think that Iacocca has got to come out and stay beyond '91,'' auto analyst John Kirnan of Kidder, Peabody & Co. said Thursday. Before the announcement of Miller's rise, he and Chrysler Motors President Robert Lutz were seen as likely successors to Greenwald. Miller has focused on the company's financial operations while Lutz has concentrated on product development. After the announcement, Miller consolidated his hold on Chrysler's financial operations by assuming Greenwald's duties of overseeing Chrysler Financial Corp., Chrysler Technologies and the company's international operations. Meantime, Lutz took over Greenwald's chores of supervising Acustar, Chrysler's parts subsidiary, and the Office of Quality and Productivity, both product-oriented. Miller, Lutz and Chrysler Motors Chairman Bennett Bidwell each will report to Iacocca. Bidwell, 62, reportedly has been working a light schedule lately and may take early retirement. Greenwald and Miller shared much of the responsibility of helping put together a series of federally guaranteed loans to rescue Chrysler from a brush with bankruptcy in the late 1970s and early 1980s. Miller now faces more tough financial work as Chrysler wrestles with sagging profits in a weak car and truck market. Chrysler's first-quarter earnings dropped 80 percent to $71 million from year-ago levels. The company's car and truck market share as of the end of April stood at 12.4 percent, down nearly 2 percentage points from a year earlier. Analysts said the drop in profits was less than they expected. But they predicted that an interruption of production of Chrysler's highly profitable minivans this summer could put the company in the red for the third quarter. Also later this year, Chrysler is due to wind up a cost-cutting program designed to trim $1.5 billion from annual expenses and negotiate a new contract with the United Auto Workers. All are formidable chores for an automaker executive. Greenwald said his first task will be to put together financing to pay for the unions' United buyout bid by Aug. 9. Although Greenwald said the main reason he decided to quit was to take on the United challenge, analysts and others have wondered if he was getting tired of waiting for Iacocca to retire. ``I think he recognizes that Lee is probably going to be around for an extended period of time,'' said auto analyst Joseph Phillippi of Shearson Lehman Hutton of New York. ``Even if Lee were to become chairman only and Jerry were to become CEO, he's still going to have the old boss looking over his shoulder. ``That may have bothered him a lot.''

DOC.HEAD: Amarillo Businessman Comes To Defense Of City After Pickens Criticism
DOC.TEXT: T. Boone Pickens doesn't think much of his old home town and has predicted a dire future for Amarillo, but a local businessman has challenged the oilman to back up his words with a $100,000. In a letter that became public in Amarillo this week, Pickens said the Panhandle city is headed for a ``steady, rapid, downhill slide,'' and said the population would dip below 100,000 by 2000, a drop of nearly 40 percent. ``I sure do like this town, and I don't like anybody taking shots at it,'' said Jerry Hodge, who described himself as friends with Pickens. The city has been struggling since the mid-1980s because of the collapse of the energy industry. Pickens left Amarillo last year as both he and some top executives of his Mesa Limited Partnership moved to Dallas. The departure came after years of feuding with the city's newspaper and officials. Shortly before he left, voters defeated all candidates for the Amarillo City Commission perceived as being backed by Pickens. Although Pickens never gave a clear reason for leaving Amarillo, in a letter last month to a friend who was moving back to the town, he said: ``I know that there were better places to live than Amarillo. ... Probably the biggest problem the town has is no leadership.'' ``The city has now moved basically to a blue-collar district,'' Pickens said in the letter, which became public this week in Amarillo and was a hot topic on local television news. Pickens said he agreed with a former associate's description of the town as a ``truck stop. ... I think within 10 years, the town will have less than 100,000 people.'' The Panhandle city's current population is estimated at 160,422. Hodge, a former city commissioner and mayor, challenged Pickens to mach his purchase of a $100,000 certificate of deposit, with the winner receiving both CDs, plus 10 years of interest, in the year 2000. ``The loser will present his money at a dinner prepared by the blue collar workers of Amarillo or by Dallas white collar executives, whichever the case may be,'' Hodge said. Pickens' associates were angry that the letter between friends had become public, and spokesman Ralph Whitworth dismissed Hodge's offer as a publicity ploy. ``If he's got a $100,000, let him give it to economic development instead of PR stunts,'' Whitworth said, noting that Mesa retains a 400-person work force in Amarillo with a $20 million payroll. Although there have been several major layoffs in the last couple of years, other companies have expanded and the unemployment rate has dropped from 6.7 percent in 1986 to about 5 percent currently, said Steve Ahlenius, director of business development and public affairs for the Amarillo Chamber of Commerce.

DOC.HEAD: Nine Settle SEC Civil Charges in Alleged Tipping Case
DOC.TEXT: The former chairman of modular structures company and the wife of the company's ex-president have settled federal securities charges that they tipping off seven friends and relatives to a pending acquisition. The pair, as well as the people they allegedly tipped to confidential corporate information, settled the civil charges Thursday _ the same day they were brought by the Securities and Exchange Commission in San Francisco. In all, the defendants will pay a total of $330,000 in penalties and restitution to settle securities fraud charges, without admitting or denying wrongdoing, the SEC announced in Washington. According to the SEC, Modulaire Industries agreed to be acquired by Waste Management Inc. of Oak Brook, Ill., in May 1987 for $16 a share. At the time, the company's stock was trading for about $7 a share. Three days before Modulaire's acceptance of the offer was made public, according to the SEC complaint, then-chairman Joseph Behar tipped off a friend, who bought 5,400 shares with the alleged illegal inside information. The SEC also charged that Adrienne Wailes, wife of Modulaire's then-president, David Wailes, tipped off several friends and relatives, including the couple's adult son, Deven. David Wailes was not accused of any wrongdoing. Aside from noting that his client had not admitted any wrongdoing, Behar's attorney in San Francisco, Curt Mueller, declined comment. Mrs. Wailes' attorney was not in his office when called for comment. The people tipped by Behar and Mrs. Wailes bought between 750 and 4,300 shares apiece of Modulaire stock before the public announcement of the acquisition drove the stock price up to $15 a share, the SEC said. Two of the buyers _ including Deven Wailes _ canceled their stock purchases before they were completed and did not have to pay any financial penalties.

DOC.HEAD: Pioneer to Acquire 10 Percent of Carolco for $60 Million
DOC.TEXT: A subsidiary of Japan's Pioneer Electronic Corp. will buy about 10 percent of independent film producer Carolco Pictures Inc. for $60 million in exchange for worldwide laser disc rights to Carolco's movies. Pioneer LDCA Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of hardware giant Pioneer Electronic, will buy a new series C convertible preferred stock, Carolco announced Thursday. The stock will pay an annual dividend of 5 percent and will be convertible into common stock at a price of $18.50 a share. Pioneer LDCA also will purchase a warrant entitling the company to purchase 300,000 Carolco shares at a price of $18.50 per share. In exchange, Pioneer receives first refusal to worldwide rights to Carolco titles on laser disc, including the upcoming films ``Terminator II,'' ``The Doors,'' ``Dead Reckoning,'' ``Gale Force'' and ``Two-Fisted Tales.'' Carolco also made the new release ``Total Recall,'' starring Arnold Schwarzenegger. As part of the deal, Pioneer will appoint two members to Carolco's board of directors.

DOC.HEAD: Study Finds Freddie Mac, Fannie Mae Vulnerable to Economic Slowdown
DOC.TEXT: The government-sponsored enterprises that help finance a fourth of the nation's single-family homes are vulnerable to an economic downturn, according to a Bush administration study. Three trends during the 1980s have so far insulated Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac from a slowdown in the economy, said the 480-page study released Thursday. These are rapid inflation of housing prices, an ample supply of first-time home buyers from the Baby Boom generation and fast growth in the packaging of mortgages into securities. However, all three trends are ending, the study said, noting that for Fannie Mae the ``biggest credit risk is a regional or national economic slowdown.'' Fannie Mae (the Federal National Mortgage Association) and Freddie Mac (the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp.) are congressionally chartered but privately owned enterprises. Together, they help finance one of every four single-family home sales by purchasing mortgages, holding some and repackaging most into securities for resale to investors. Because they were created by Congress and dominate so much of the housing market, the agencies are perceived as having the government's implicit guarantee against default. Last year's savings and loan bailout bill passed by Congress ordered the Treasury Department to evaluate the risks posed to taxpayers from a default by Fannie Mae, Freddie Mac and seven other similar government-sponsored enterprises that back loans to home-buyers, students and farmers. The Treasury forwarded its recommendations for improving federal oversight of the enterprises to Congress two weeks ago, but Thursday's report provided the first look at the Bush administration's evaluation of individual organizations. ``None of the (government-sponsored enterprises) are in imminent danger, but obviously some are stronger and some are weaker,'' Treasury Undersecretary Robert Glauber said. Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac account for about three-quarters of the enterprises' $863 billion in debt outstanding at the end of last year. In general, Freddie Mac received the more favorable evaluation. The report said Fannie Mae needed a bigger cushion of capital from its shareholders to insulate taxpayers from risk. Nevertheless, the report said it had concerns in the long run with Freddie Mac because its capital standard does not discourage risk-taking. It said Fannie Mae was more vulnerable to swings in interest rates and that a change of 4 or 5 percentage points could wipe out Fannie Mae's net worth if it were forced to mark its holdings to market value. Fannie Mae holds more mortgages in its investment portfolio than Freddie Mac. It finances its holdings with borrowed money, so its costs rise if interest rates go up. Higher rates also tend to deter homebuyers and dampen house prices. Both enterprises maintain they are well-positioned to withstand an economic downturn, but the Treasury criticized the ``stress tests'' the two devised. It said the tests, intended to show how the enterprises would fare during a recession, depend too heavily on statistical assumptions that may not prove true. The Treasury also noted that Fannie Mae has concentrated slightly more than half of its activity in just five states _ California, New York, Florida, New Jersey and Texas. David Jeffers, Fannie Mae vice president, said his organization has already launched a program to bolster its capital, but he rejected the notion that it needed to change its operations radically. He said Fannie Mae was well-diversified geographically. ``We have demonstrated our ability to manage (our) business in a prudent and profitable way. We don't see any need to change the course we're on,'' he said. Freddie Mac President Leland Brendsel said in a statement: ``Our capital base will remain strong in the long run.'' The other enterprises included in the study are the Federal Home Loan Bank System, Farm Credit Banks, Banks for Cooperatives, Farm Credit System Financial Assistance Corp., Federal Agricultural Mortgage Association (Farmer Mac), Student Loan Marketing Association (Sallie Mae) and College Construction Loan Insurance Association (Connie Lee). In its previous suggestions for reform, the Treasury Department called for raising more private capital to back the enterprises, requiring the enterprises to obtain a triple-A rating from private credit-rating agencies and designating a separate federal office to monitor the safety and soundness of the enterprises.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Closes Higher, Stock Prices Fall
DOC.NOTE: Eds: version also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. dollar finished higher in Tokyo today, while stock prices fell in moderate trading on the Tokyo Stock Exchange. The dollar closed at 152.17 yen in quiet trading, up 0.42 yen from Thursday's close. The U.S. currency opened higher following overnight strength in New York, where it was bought on the expectation the U.S. unemployment rate for May would decline, dealers said. But most market players in Tokyo chose to wait for the figures. On the stock market, the Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues fell 239.68 points, or 0.72 percent, ending the week at 32,891.12 points. The index had gained 204.54 points the previous day. A total of 700 million shares changed hands on the market's first section, down from Thursday's 800 million. Kozo Hasunuma, a trader with Yamaichi Securities Co., said the Nikkei's decline resulted from arbitrage selling of spot issues to profit from the price gap between the spot and futures markets.

DOC.HEAD: Farm Prices Up, USDA Reports
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Agriculture Department economists say prices farmers get for raw products increased 2 percent from April to May, raising the overall commodity index 3.4 percent above a year ago. The department's Agricultural Statistics Board said Thursday in its preliminary report the increase resulted primarily from higher prices for hogs, corn, hay, broilers and lettuce. Hog prices averaged $60.50 per hundred pounds of live weight, a level topped only by the record of $62.10 in August 1986. USDA reported lower prices for eggs, onions, milk and cattle. Although prices for beef cattle posted a slight decline, calves averaged higher. Also up from April levels were sorghum and soybean prices. There were slight drops in prices for barley, wheat and rice. The May price index for livestock and poultry rose 1.2 percent from April and averaged 10 percent above the level of a year ago. Overall crop prices went up 3.1 percent from April but averaged 4.9 percent below the year-earlier level. Fruit prices fueled by oranges and grapefruits were up 3.6 percent from last month, about the same as a year ago. Commercial vegetables were up 3.4 percent from the April level but were down 21 percent below a year earlier. Lettuce and tomatoes were up while carrots and onions were down. The report said: _Cattle averaged $74.30 per hundred pounds of live weight nationally, down from $74.60 in April but up from $68.80 in May 1989. Those are averages for all types of cattle sold as beef. _Hogs averaged $60.50 per hundred pounds, compared with $53.80 in April and $41.60 in May 1989. _Corn, at $2.66 a bushel, was up from $2.51 in April and $2.58 from the level of a year ago. _Wheat prices at the farm, according to preliminary figures, averaged $3.44 a bushel, compared with $3.49 in April and $4.01 a year ago. _Rice averaged $7.21 per hundred pounds, compared with $7.31 in April and $6.78 in May 1989. _Soybeans were $5.92 per bushel, compared with $5.82 last month and $7.20 in May 1989. _Upland cotton was reported at 66.3 cents per pound, up from 65 cents in April and 58.3 cents a year ago. _Eggs were 60.2 cents a dozen, compared with 71.4 cents a dozen in April and 62.6 cents a year ago. _Milk was $13.20 per 100 pounds compared with $13.40 in April and $12.30 at the year-earlier level. _Broilers were 35.2 cents per pound compared with 33.2 cents in April and 44.6 cents a year ago.

USDA officials say recent tests show consumers run little health risk from drug, chemical and pesticide residues in meat and poultry. ``The residue rates are the lowest they've been in years,'' Richard L. Carnevale, assistant deputy administrator of USDA's Food Safety and Inspection Service, told a news briefing Thursday. At the session, he released latest results of tests performed on cattle, calves, swine, goats, sheep, chickens, turkeys, ducks and other animals. USDA officials acknowledged an increase in concern among consumers over residues of pesticides, other farm chemicals such as fertilizers and drugs in the food they purchase for their tables. Such residues are found when drugs such as antibiotics and sulfa have been administered improperly and when the animals have eaten feed that was sprayed with chemicals. Carnevale said, however, that pesticide and chemical residues were not shown to exist in illegal levels in the most recent tests and that only a few problems were found with drug residues. Illegal levels of residues were found in only 0.3 percent of the 41,505 samples tested in the agency's routine monitoring last year, he said. The Food Safety and Inspection Service conducts three types of residue testing programs. Carnevale said the routine monitoring system ``provides us with the most meaningful residue statistics.'' Young veal calves were one area of concern, he said. He said producers and other custodians of the ``bob veal'' calves are being required to sign statements concerning the administration of drugs before slaughter. Tests also showed high levels of sulfa residues in cull dairy cows _ ones that are no longer producing milk and are on their way to slaughter, Carnevale said. He said dairy producers were being notified to step up controls.

The Agriculture Department announced it has quarantined 81 square miles of Dade County, Fla., following the discovery of 19 Mediterranean fruit flies in the Miami area. ``Our quarantine is designed to prevent the spread of Medfly,'' said James W. Glosser, administrator of the department's Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service. The action Thursday followed a request last week by Florida Agriculture Commissioner Doyle Conner to the department to quarantine the entire state of California for combat a Medfly outbreak. The department confirmed that it has no plans to expand its current quarantine of parts of southern California. The fly attacks more than 200 varieties of fruits and vegetables. Citrus is especially vulnerable, with losses of 25 percent to 50 percent of production likely in cases of severe infestation. ``We feel our quarantine procedure and the area that is quarantined are adequate at this point to prevent the spread of Medflies,'' said spokesman Larry Mark. He said the decision not to expand the quarantine was made Wednesday after the National Plant Board Advisory Council, meeting here, recommended no change for at least 30 days.

DOC.HEAD: IMF Official Outlines Stiff Conditions for Reforms in Eastern Europe
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: An official of the International Monetary Fund is laying out stiff conditions for an effective shift from communism to a market economy in eastern Europe. Thomas A. Wolf, senior economist in the fund's European Department, spoke Thursday at a forum unrelated to the U.S.-Soviet summit meeting. By coincidence he outlined his ideas just after President Mikhail Gorbachev, at the Soviet embassy a few blocks away, made a plea to Americans to let the Soviets find their own way toward a system run on market principles. The Bush administration has opposed the Soviet Union joining the 152 members of the IMF and its sister organization, the World Bank. Present members include Poland, Hungary and Romania. Officials elsewhere in Eastern Europe, including the Soviet Union, have said they want to join, too. Wolf listed five areas in which he said comprehensive reforms are needed in Eastern Europe. He did not specify any country. ``Without action in each of these five areas, a market-oriented reform will not be comprehensive and therefore is bound not to meet objectives of the reformers,'' he said. Wolf said Eastern European countries should: _Eliminate much of the economic bureaucracy and let enterprises make their own decisions on matters such as prices, wages, employment, investment, output and foreign trade. One way to do that is to make profit the main motivation for managers, he said, and another is to clearly define property rights. _Initiate price reforms, either by changing the government-fixed prices to bring them close to the balance between supply and demand, or by freeing prices entirely from government control, or anything in between. _Make wages depend on how much workers produce. _Change the system of foreign trade, including the buying and selling of foreign currencies. _Create a new system of government influence on the economy: since the state will no longer control enterprises directly, it must influence them indirectly through taxes, official spending and monetary policy, as Western governments now do. ``It's not enough to give enterprises greater autonomy or greater authority,'' Wolf said. ``They need to be given incentives to use the authority that they are suddenly given. ``But giving enterprises greater authority and greater incentive is still not enough,'' he said. ``They have to be given the responsibility to act through the market in order to raise or maximize profits and to raise wages _ in other words, not to have the possibility of achieving those goals of higher profits and wages by negotiating special deals with the economic bureaucracy.''

DOC.HEAD: China Orders Boeing Jets in Deal Worth Up to $4 Billion
DOC.TEXT: China's Civil Aviation Administration has ordered 36 Boeing jetliners and taken options on 36 more in a deal that could be worth up to $4 billion, Boeing Commercial Airplane Group said. The order, announced Thursday, includes five 747-400 jumbo jets; one 747-200F, a jumbo freighter; four widebody 767s; 13 midsized 757s; and 13 737-300s, a smaller twinjet. Three of the 757s were announced late last year. The firm orders are worth about $2 billion, Boeing spokesman John Wheeler said, but the options, which include nearly the same types of airplanes, could bring the total package to $4 billion. Deliveries will start in 1992 and extend into the late 1990s, Wheeler said. The Civil Aviation Administration oversees the purchase of aircraft for China's airlines. The new jetliners will be used by Air China, Guangzhou CAAC, China Southwest Airlines and others, Boeing said. Attending a signing ceremony in Renton, Wash., were Hu Yizhou, director general of CAAC; Zhu Qizhen, China's ambassador to the United States, and Liu Yuanfan, president of China Aviation Supplies Corp. The order comes a week after the Bush administration said it would renew most-favored-nation status for China, a designation that gives the country the lowest available tariffs on exports to the United States. Nicholas Lardy, a professor of Chinese studies at the University of Washington, Seattle, said he doubted there was any connection between Bush's decision and the deal. ``Negotiations have been proceeding for a long time,'' he noted. The Chinese government has been working to integrate itself into the world economy, Lardy said, adding that this deal suggests their talk is more than just rhetoric. But Wheeler and others said they doubt China would have placed such an order without the favorable trade pact. ``It stands to reason that if the status were changed, it would obviously alter their whole approach to capital goods,'' Wheeler said. Dean Thornton, president of Boeing Commercial Airplane Group, noted that Boeing was the first U.S. company to sell to China when the two countries established relations in 1972. Since then, China has purchased 101 Boeing planes, the company said. A plant in Xian, China, already manufactures tail fins for Boeing 737s. The Chinese order brings total Boeing orders this year to 187 aircraft valued at about $16.2 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Unemployment in 11 Major States
With PM-Unemployment
DOC.TEXT: Here are the May unemployment rates for 11 large states as reported Friday by the Labor Department. California, 5.4 percent, unchanged from April. Florida, 5.6 percent, down from 5.7 percent. Illinois, 5.3 percent, down from 6.1 percent. Massachusetts, 5.5 percent, unchanged from April. Michigan, 7.7 percent, up from 7.3 percent. New Jersey, 4.8 percent, down from 4.9 percent. New York, 5.1 percent, up from 4.9 percent. North Carolina, 4.0 percent, up from 3.8 percent. Ohio, 5.9 percent, unchanged from April. Pennsylvania, 4.9 percent, down from 5.7 percent. Texas, 6.5 percent, up from 6.4 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Current Account Surplus Posts Sharpest Drop in 10 Years
DOC.TEXT: Lower auto and steel exports combined with higher imports of oil, autos, art and airplanes drove Japan's current account surplus down by the steepest amount in 10 years. The surplus in the current account, which measures trade in goods, services and transfer payments, fell 70 percent in April from a year earlier to $2 billion. The surplus totaled $6.58 billion in April 1989. It was the sharpest drop since the surplus contracted 95 percent in June 1979. ``The current account is falling over the long term, and eventually the surplus is going to shrink away,'' said Jan VanDenBerg, an economist with Merrill Lynch in Tokyo. ``The vast majority of it is due to ... consumption demand in Japan growing quite rapidly.'' She said demand in Japan is growing by about 4 percent a year, compared to less than 2 percent a year in the United States. April's trade surplus, which measures only trade in goods, shrank 50 percent to $4.02 billion, the ministry said. Imports, measured on the basis of settled contracts, rose 17 percent from year-ago levels to $17.2 billion while exports fell 7 percent to $21.2 billion, the ministry said. It was the seventh consecutive month exports have declined. Part of the decline was due to the weaker yen, which reduced the value of Japanese exports in dollar terms because of the time lag before lower prices result in higher export volume. The dollar was trading at an average of 157.20 yen in April, compared to 132.12 yen a year earlier, a 16 percent devaluation, Finance Ministry officials noted. Automobile exports in April fell 19 percent from a year earlier, the sharpest drop in 20 years. Ministry officials said this was unusual because Japanese automakers usually boost exports at the beginning of the new fiscal year in April after failing to fill export quotas for the previous year. Auto imports rose for the fifth month in a row, up 72 percent in April last year. Steel exports dropped 23 percent in April, the sixth month in a row that they have fallen about 20 percent from year-earlier levels, the ministry said. Much of the decline was attributed to strong domestic demand for steel. Electric machinery exports fell 6 percent and semiconductor exports fell 8.5 percent. Meanwhile, oil imports rose 22 percent along with heavy production by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries and speculation that prices will rise in the future, the ministry said. Aircraft imports rose 240 percent, timber and wood imports rose 42 percent and painting and art imports tripled. Invisible trade, which includes transactions in insurance, shipping, tourism and other services, posted a $1.84 billion deficit in April, compared with a deficit of $1.29 billion a year earlier. The ministry said the deficit was largely due to huge royalty payments by foreign affiliate firms in Japan to their parent companies overseas. Large purchases of foreign securities by Japanese investors produced a deficit of $5.3 billion in the long-term capital account, down from a $16.4 billion deficit a year earlier. An advisory council of the Finance Ministry said Thursday that Japan's trade and current account surplus isn't a problem for the world economy and could help finance Third World debtor nations and the U.S. budget deficit. Finance Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto also said Friday that the surplus could help finance the development of Eastern Europe. But he also said Japan should consider ways to reduce the surplus, particularly with respect to the United States. The current account report does not include breakdowns of trade by country or region. Last month, the Finance Ministry said Japan's monthly trade surplus with the United States fell from $4.54 billion a year earlier to $2.45 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Westinghouse Exempts Itself From Anti-takeover Law
DOC.TEXT: Westinghouse Electric Corp.'s board has voted to exempt the company from coverage under Pennsylvania's tough new anti-takeover law. The company also said Thursday it will start buying back up to 20 million shares of its common stock. The law, signed April 27, is designed to protect Pennsylvania-based corporations from hostile raiders. It has been sharply attacked by the investment community for sheltering management while denying stockholders the benefits of potential price speculation in their shares. ``Westinghouse is strongly committed to increasing shareholder value,'' Chairman John C. Marous said in a statement, adding that customers, employees, suppliers and communities will benefit if the company continues to operate successfully. Companies have the right to exempt themselves from the law in the first 90 days of its existence. The company said in a separate statement it will purchase the stock in public markets or through private sales during the next year and a half. The company said it will use cash, internally generated funds and short-term debt. ``The stock purchase is in keeping with our strategic direction of enhancing shareholder value,'' Marous said. Marous said the stock purchase is an ``attractive investment.'' The stock closed Thursday at $36.37{, up $1.37{ on the New York Stock Exchange.

DOC.HEAD: ABC Will Use Own Audience-Measuring Formula in Some Cases
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: ABC has come up with it own way to count television viewers next season for purposes of compensating advertisers for smaller-than-promised audiences. In the latest network reaction to an unexplained drop in A.C. Nielsen Co. ratings this year, ABC announced Thursday it will factor previous years' ratings into its formula for so-called ``make-goods.'' The networks sell commercial time on the basis of expected audiences, and give advertisers free air time to ``make good'' for lower ratings. The ABC change will not affect the ratings reported to the public, which generally have fallen since Nielsen switched to a ``people meter'' system that requires each participating viewer to punch in when watching TV. ``What we're trying to address is the unexplainted volatility that happened with the introduction of the people meters in the fall of 1987,'' ABC spokesman Dick Connelly said. He said Thursday that the network had not heard reaction from advertisers, but several ad agency executives were quoted in The New York Times today as expressing anger. Betsy Frank, vice president of the agency Saatchi & Saatchi, called the plan ``confusing and insulting.'' Advertisers are about to begin their yearly advance purchases of air time, which could account for $4 billion of the $9 billion to $10 billion in total network sales predicted for next fall. CBS, which has been running third in the ratings, had no comment on ABC's action, said CBS spokesman Michael Silver. NBC spokesman Curt Block said that top-rated network ``is trying to work out an arrangement'' of its own with advertisers ``that is fair to everbody.'' Last month, a group representing the networks and the National Association of Broadcasters asked Nielsen to study new ways of counting viewers. Nielsen, which says it has found no flaws in its people-meter system, said it would consider the request. The ratings company earns a total of $20 million annually from the three networks, according to a network executive who spoke on condition of anonymity.

The stock market ran up a broad gain today as traders responded to new evidence of a weaker-than-expected economy. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 11.69 to 2,888.35 in the first half hour of the session. Gainers outnumbered losers by almost 3 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 777 up, 279 down and 463 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 32.47 million shares as of 10 a.m. on Wall Street. The Labor Department this morning reported a rise of 164,000 in nonfarm payroll employment during May, attributing the increase almost entirely to temporary hiring for the Census. Job figures for April were revised to show a decrease rather than the small gain reported earlier. Janet Norwood, commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, said no job growth at all has been registered in the private sector of the economy over the last three months. While that news did not bode well for corporate profits in the near future, analysts said it was welcomed on Wall Street as a possible portent of further declines in interest rates and an easing in the Federal Reserve's credit policy. The bond market made its view of the news clear immediately. Prices of long-term Treasury bonds jumped more than $10 for each $1,000 in face value, lowering their yields to the 8.45 percent-8.50 percent range. Westinghouse Electric rose ~ to 37\ on top of a 1]-point gain Thursday, when the company said it plans to buy back as many as 20 million shares of its stock. Among other actively traded blue chips, Boeing climbed 1[ to 83{; General Electric ~ to 69}; Philip Morris \ to 42], and Texas Instruments ] to 42]. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks added .54 to 197.48. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was up .49 at 363.55. On Thursday the Dow Jones industrial average slipped 1.90 to 2,876.66. Advancing issues outnumbered declines by about 8 to 7 on the NYSE, with 783 up, 675 down and 547 unchanged. Big Board volume totaled 165.69 million shares, against 199.54 million in the previous session.

DOC.NOTE: $adv04
For release Monday June 4
DOC.TEXT: The recent plan to slowly shift the Soviet Union toward a market economy has cheered a group of U.S. financiers, who believe the reforms will bolster their efforts to bring a novel type of public finance to Moscow. The group signed an agreement with several Soviet entities in April to finance three public projects with bonds designed to encourage the shift away from central planning and toward the market mechanism. ``This project can help us find financial instruments that can help us solve several problems at the same time,'' said Sergei Plekhanov, deputy director of the Institute of the USA and Canada, one of the Soviet bodies involved in the agreement. Plekhanov said his country has massive social needs that go unmet because of its huge budget deficit. At the same time, households and state enterprises are sitting on tens of billions of rubles for want of goods to buy. Those problems were among the chief reasons behind the government's reform plan announced two weeks ago. It laid out a five-year schedule of food price hikes, banking reforms and partial privatizations designed to produce a so-called regulated market economy. Many radical Soviet reformers found the plan too timid. They criticized the government for backing away from the model created by Poland, which has attempted to move rapidly to a market economy by sharply devaluing the currency, cutting state subsidies and freeing prices. But Jeffrey A. Sachs, who initiated the financing project, says the Soviet's gradual strategy is more humane than Polish-style ``shock therapy,'' and more fitting for a country that hasn't known a market for 70 years. (Sachs is unrelated to the Harvard University professor of the same name who helped devise Poland's program.) Rather than shrink the supply of money to match the amount of goods in the economy, as Poland is doing, Sachs wants to tap into the Soviets' big pool of savings to finance new projects. Using a non-profit corporation called EcoLink, Sachs' group is working on plans to issue bonds in the Soviet Union to finance three projects: an AIDS hospital, an industrial project _ most likely a grain-storage facility, and a prototype network of regional financial exchanges. Soviet citizens have a bad taste for bonds because the government forced purchases of bonds under Stalin and later repudiated them. Also, the ruble has little value because it can't be converted into Western currencies and can't buy much at home. EcoLink argues that bonds can be made palateable, however, by having them pay interest in hard currency or in rubles that will guarantee the ability to buy scarce Soviet resources. The instruments could help contain inflation by absorbing excess cash and foster a move to allocating goods through the market rather than central planning agencies. Hard currency bonds would be appropriate for a grain-storage facility, Sachs suggests. Already the government spends large amounts of hard currency to import grain while perhaps 25 percent of Soviet harvests rot for lack of storage bins and railroad grain cars, he says. Therefore, any investments that reduce grain losses should save hard currency. ``That's an immediate economic benefit that can pay for itself,'' says Muriel Siebert, a financial market consultant and former New York State banking commissioner who is involved in EcoLink. In April the group asked U.S. financial and legal experts to come forward with suggestions to turn the project ideas into reality. Sachs said dozens of investment banks and law firms have expressed interest. The project backers are due to meet in Moscow in July to draw up solid plans for the AIDS hospital and decide on the industrial project. Work on financial exchanges is just beginning. Siebert said EcoLink is likely to propose that exchanges be set up to handle commodities that the Soviets already have some experience in trading _ grain, oil and gold. Talk of bond issues and Soviet financial exchanges might have seemed far-fetched just months ago, Plekhanov said. ``Now all these things are very much in line with the official policy. I think that will speed things up.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for June 4

DOC.HEAD: Bank of America's Parent Acquires Western Savings
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 10th graf to CORRECT to billion, sted million; 12th graf NEW to ADD other major S&L collapses.
DOC.TEXT: The 62 branches of Western Savings & Loan Association reopen today as branches of Bank of America Arizona following the acquisition of the seized thrift's deposits and branch system. Western, placed under federal conservatorship in June 1989, was put up for sale in January. Western had lost hundreds of millions of dollars during the past two years in real-estate loans that soured. Western ranks just under such notorious S&L collapses as Lincoln Savings and Loan Association of Irvine, Calif., and CenTrust Bank of Miami, both expected to cost taxpayers around a record $2 billion each. The acquisition of Western by Bank of America Arizona, a subsidiary of San Francisco-based BankAmerica Corp., was approved by the board of the federal Resolution Trust Corp. ``We plan to be a significant part of the Arizona economy and want to build on our local identity,'' said David Weymouth, president of Bank of America Arizona. ``Bank of America Arizona is a community bank with the backing of a major financial institution.'' Before acquiring Western's branch system, BankAmerica's presence in Arizona consisted of two small, non-banking operations in Phoenix: BankAmerica Sutter Mortgage Corp., an interim construction lender with 25 employees, and Bank of America Payroll Services, a payroll processing firm with a staff of 50. Bank of America, whose parent is the nation's third largest holding company, estimated its share of the Phoenix area's market at about 12 percent. A spokesman for the RTC, the federal agency in charge of insolvent thrifts, said Bank of America paid a premium of $81.2 million for Western's $3.4 billion in deposits. The bank is purchasing $1.7 billion worth of the thrift's performing assets, including investment-grade securities, single-family home loans and consumer loans. The RTC said it is retaining assets with a book value of approximately $2.9 billion, including troubled or non-paying loans, commercial and construction loans, loans on land and multifamily residences, and repossessed real estate. According to the RTC, it will pay Bank of America $1.7 billion in cash, beyond $1.1 billion in prior cash advances. With recovery of its cash advances expected through the sale of assets not purchased by Bank of America, the RTC's ultimate cost will total an estimated $1.7 billion, the agency said. Western ranks just under such notorious S&L collapses as Lincoln Savings and Loan Association of Irvine, Calif., and CenTrust Bank of Miami, each of which is expected to cost taxpayers a record $2 billion. The acquisition was hailed by state Banking Superintendent Hank Rivoir. ``I am looking forward to another major player in the financial community,'' Rivoir said. ``It will be a benefit to the Arizona consumer. It is good that Western has been resolved.'' Western, founded 61 years ago, had 61 branches in Maricopa County, which includes Phoenix, and one in Salt Lake City. The branches include 24 in Smitty's supermarkets. After reopening under the Bank of America name, the branches will operate under their normal schedules, and deposits will be insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp., the RTC said. Losers in the bidding for Western included Security Pacific Corp. and Wells Fargo & Co. The state charter was revised under last-minute legislation that closed a loophole in Arizona' interstate banking law. A bill was rushed through the Legislature and signed by Gov. Rose Mofford late Thursday. Rivoir told lawmakers that some attorneys have interpreted the state's 1985 interstate banking act as allowing out-of-state banks to buy Arizona institutions and operate them as branches without being subject to Arizona regulations. The legislation was aimed primarily at Bank of America, although it would apply to the sale of any Arizona bank. Peter Magnani, BankAmerica vice president for corporate public relations, said his bank has had an interest in Arizona for many years but was not in the financial position to participate when interstate banking was permitted as a result of the 1985 law. Besides Bank of America, BankAmerica's holdings include SeaFirst Corp., Seattle First National Bank and Bank of America Nevada, formerly Nevada First Bank. ``This acquisition provides us with an excellent vehicle for entering Arizona and advancing toward our strategic goal of being the premier provider of retail and wholesale financial services in the western United States,'' said Richard M. Roseberg, BankAmerica chairman and chief executive.

DOC.HEAD: Florida Supreme Court Removes Newspapers' Sales Tax Exemption
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Press lawyers expressed disappointment that the state Supreme Court abolished a sales tax exemption after ruling the tax was unconstitutionally levied on magazines and not on newspapers. ``It's winning the battle but losing the war,'' said James Ervin Jr., a Tallahassee lawyer representing several magazines that had challenged the state's imposition of its 6-cent sales tax on magazines. Ervin said he was pleased the justices ruled that in the interest of freedom of the press, there should be no differentiation between the two types of publications. But he said he was ``very disappointed'' in the panel's 6-0 opinion Thursday extending the tax rather than the exemption. William Hyde, an attorney representing the Florida Press Association, said an appeal to the U.S. Supreme Court is likely. ``It's making the acquisition of knowledge more difficult,'' Hyde said. ``We think that a tax on the press impermissibly burdens the First Amendment,'' said Laura Besvinick, an attorney representing The Miami Herald. Sales of all magazines in Florida have been taxed since 1987, when the state dropped an exemption for subscriptions as part of the extension of the sales tax to a variety of services and the sale of newspapers. The services tax was repealed a few months later, at which time newspapers regained their exemption but subscription magazines did not. Magazines sold in stores had been taxed even before 1987. The Magazine Publishers of America Inc., The Hearst Corp., Time Inc., Golf Digest-Tennis Inc. and others went to court. The state Department of Revenue, the press organization, and the Herald argued that the distinction between the two kinds of publications should be upheld. But while the revenue agency argued the tax should be extended to both types of publications, the newspapers argued the exemption should be extended. A circuit court in Tallahassee ruled for the magazines, barring the state from collecting taxes. The 1st District Court of Appeal passed the issue up to the state's high court as a question of ``great public importance.'' Hyde said he was optimistic the U.S. Supreme Court would agree to review the case because the issue is being considered in courts all over the country.

DOC.HEAD: Manufacturing Expanded In May, Purchasing Managers Report
DOC.TEXT: Manufacturing expanded in May for the second straight month with production and new orders leading the way, the nation's purchasing managers said in a survey released today. Economists said the increase showed the manufacuring sector might be struggling back but added that that today's unemployment report gave a slightly conflicting message. The government said the unemployment rate fell 0.1 percentage point to 5.3 percent in May. However, an increase of 164,000 new jobs included 145,000 temporary census workers. Private economists had expected non-government industries to create at least 125,000 new jobs in May, far greater than the 19,000 that were added. ``Today's unemployment report just doesn't square with the purchasing managers,'' said Allen Sinai, an economist with Boston Co. in New York. ``Probably the (purchasing managers) survey is reflecting strength in aerospace and still reflecting some rebound in autos,'' he said, adding that recoveries in automobile production apparently are not being matched by sales. The National Association of Purchasing Management's economic index rose to 50.7 percent in May, up from 50.2 percent the month before. A reading above 50 indicates the manufacturing economy is generally expanding; below 50, that it is generally declining. The production index increased significantly, from 53 percent in April to 56.3 percent in May. New orders increased, but at a much slower rate than in April. April's increase followed 11 straight months of declines, the group said in a press release from its Tempe, Ariz. headquarters. The purchasing managers' report is based on a monthly survey of purchasing executives at more than 300 industrial companies. Most of the figures are adjusted for seasonal factors.

DOC.HEAD: West Germany Joins France In Banning British Beef
DOC.TEXT: West Germany joined France Friday in banning British beef imports because of the ``mad cow'' disease that has killed thousands of cattle and prompted many Britons to shun the meat. However, the European Community offered a helping hand to Britain's cattle industry by offering to buy 20,600 tons of meat. British officials say the beef poses no threat to people who eat it. That country's Meat and Livestock Commission accused the Germans of responding to fears about a flood of cheap British beef, rather than concern for public health. Britain made similar charges Thursday about the French ban. France, which normally purchases more than half Britain's exported beef, imposed its ban Wednesday. French officials said some meat might be tainted by the so-called ``mad cow'' disease, or bovine spongiform encephalopathy. The fatal nervous disorder causes a degeneration of brain tissue in infected cattle, but British officials say there is no evidence the disease can be transmitted to humans. West Germany, which already had barred imports of British beef still on the bone, emulated France today by extending the ban to canned beef. The Agriculture Ministry in Bonn said it feared that British beef normally destined for France might be rerouted to West Germany. A total ban was necessary ``to protect consumers from infection,'' the ministry said. A team of French veterinarians sent to Britain to assess the disease returned today to submit its report. France's Agriculture Ministry said no decision on the duration of the ban would be made until after a meeting of the European Community's veterinary committee. However, British agriculture officials said the committee meeting had been postponed indefinitely. European Community officials denounced France's ban Thursday as illegal and demanded it be revoked. In Brussels, Belgium, EC headquarters announced today that the Community would buy 20,600 tons of British beef to help shore up falling meat prices. The British Meat and Livestock Commission said bans and fears arising from the disease are costing their industry about $850,000 a day. Beef sales reportedly have fallen by about 30 percent in Britain. Sir Simon Gourlay, president of the National Farmers Union in Britain, called for retaliatory action f the bans persist. But he did not elaborate. The disease, which was identified in Britain in 1986, is blamed for killing 13,648 cows there. The cause is unknown. Because the symptoms are similar to scrapie, a sheep disease, it is assumed the disease was transmitted through cattle feeds. They use sheep offal as a protein supplement.

DOC.HEAD: Airline Lowers Fare for Soviet Emigres
DOC.TEXT: Pan American World Airways is knocking a few rubles off the cost of emigrating from the Soviet Union to the United States. The airline announced Friday it is offering a one-way ticket to the U.S. for $999, a 32 percent discount from the regular fare of $1,466. Pan Am said the fare is designed to help the flow of immigrants to the U.S. It said their access to air travel has been restricted by a requirement that they fly on the Soviet airline Aeroflot, which has limited seating and expensive fares. Emigres can skirt the requirement by buying the discounted tickets outside the Soviet Union and arranging through Pan Am to pick them up in the country, said Pan Am spokeswoman Elizabeth Hlinko. The discounted flights are available from Moscow and Leningrad.

DOC.HEAD: West German Auto-Maker to Form Yugoslav Subsidiary
DOC.TEXT: West German automaker Volkswagen AG announced plans Friday to invest $60 million in a Yugoslav subsidiary that will manufacture two of its latest models in the 1990s. In a joint statement, Volkswagen and UNIS, a Yugoslav firm that has undertaken small-scale production of Volkswagen models in the past, said the investment would be made over the next two years. A contract was signed to set up a subsidiary company to produce 45,000 vehicles annually, according to the statement reported by radio Belgrade. The plant will produce new versions of Volkswagen's Golf and Jetta models scheduled to appear on the market in 1992, the report said. Volkswagen has maintained close business ties for over 20 years with the Yugoslav firm.

DOC.HEAD: President Elected Chairman
DOC.TEXT: Tom Stephens, president and chief executive officer of Manville Corp., on Friday was named chairman of the international manufacturing and natural resources company. He succeeds George C. Dillon, who will remain as a director and chairman of the company's executive committee, Manville said in a statement. Manville also approved an agreement for its forest products subsidiary, Manville Forest Products, to acquire the stock of Fiskeby Board AB, a European supplier of recycled boxboard products. Manville said it accepted offers from Morgan Crucible PLC of England for its European ceramic fiber assets and insulating brick businesses, and its 49 percent interest in a Dutch joint venture for production of a type of foam. Terms of the deals were not disclosed. Stephens was named president and chief executive officer of Manville in 1986. He held a number of positions, including president of the forest products company and chief financial officer. Dillon is the retired former chairman, president and CEO of Butler Manufacturing Co. of Kansas City, Mo. He has served on Manville's board for 21 years. In addition to paper and wood products, Manville's primary businesses include building and engineered products, Fiberglas and industrial insulation products, roofing systems, and filtration and minerals. Manville has more than 18,000 employees at more than 50 plants and four mines around the world.

DOC.HEAD: Nintendo Sues Game Company Over Copyright
DOC.TEXT: Nintendo of America Inc. has sued a San Francisco company to prevent distribution of a product that allows video-game players to change the way Nintendo games are played. The suit, filed in U.S. District Court in San Francisco, claims a new product called Game Genie, which is designed for play with a Nintendo home video game system, causes Nintendo game characters to move at slower speeds or bypass obstacles originally programmed into the games. It allows players to skip entire game levels, and to add extra ``lives'' to a player's life. Nintendo claims the product, created by Lewis Galoob Toys of South San Francisco, creates ``derivative'' works of copyrighted Nintendo games. ``U.S. copyright law prevents third parties from creating and marketing `derivatives' of copyrighted video games without the express consent of the game's owner,'' Howard Lincoln, Nintendo's senior vice president, said in a press release announcing the suit Thursday. Galoob introduced Game Genie on May 8 and sued Nintendo on May 17 after Nintendo notified Galoob of its claim of copyright infringement. Galoob's suit seeks a court declaration that Game Genie does not infringe Nintendo copyrights. Nintendo filed its lawsuit after deciding to reject a proposal that Nintendo give Galoob a license to market Game Genie, Nintendo said. Lincoln compared Game Genie to ``speed-up kits'' which were introduced for the popular arcade game Pacman several years ago. Courts found such kits to be unauthorized derivative works of the original Pacman game and enjoined their sale. But Steven M. Klein, executive vice president and general counsel at Galoob, rejected any links to the Pacman situation. Game Genie is for use in private homes, while the Pacman speed-up kits were designed for use in public video arcades, he said in a telephone interview Friday. ``Home owners can modify games. Selling them a product that allows them to do that is not illegal,'' he said. ``Nintendo has conveniently ignored provisions of the copyright act that allows a product like this to be sold,'' he said. Lincoln said Game Genie allows Nintendo games to be mastered without any skill. ``We cannot stand by while the essence of our business _ the creation of ever more challenging video games _ is put at risk by the Game Genie product,'' he said. Klein did not dispute that Game Genie allows success with Nintendo games without requiring skill, but denied it would be detrimental to Nintendo. ``Nintendo believes anything that interferes with their monopoly is a threat to their business,'' he said.
