DOC.HEAD: Shareholder Rights Big Winner In This Season's Contests
DOC.TEXT: The 1990 annual meetings and their scuffles and skirmishes are largely over, and all the combatants are claiming victory _ even if the vote tallies don't show it. The clearest winners this season were shareholders, particularly the big institutional investors no longer content with passive ownership in the stocks of corporate America. ``It was a banner year for institutional shareholders,'' said Gray Davis, the comptroller of California and a trustee of the state's employee pension funds, the largest in the nation. Davis was a prominent voice in pressing for a greater shareholder role in how companies are run during this annual meeting season, the primary forum for dialogue between management and the owners they must answer to. Todd Lang, a New York attorney who specializes in corporate shareholder law, said ``this has been the season when the institutions, which own more than a majority of the equities in the United States, have gone active with their positions.'' Shareholders placed more issues on annual meeting agendas this season and institutions became more vocal. The shareholders' biggest triumph came early in the season, before and during the March 29 annual meeting of Lockheed Corp., as dissident investor Harold Simmons waged a proxy fight with management to gain control of the defense contractor's board of directors. Simmons lost, but management was frightened he might win. So the company granted big concessions, including a promise to put at least one institutional investor representative on the board. Shareholders also won votes on several proposals, among them a call for confidential proxy voting, which would enable them to vote free from coercive pressure like in a political election. In many companies, shareholders sought a bigger voice in corporate policy and governance. At the K mart Corp. and Avon Products Inc. meetings, for example, shareholders approved non-binding resolutions asking management to submit the companies' ``poison pill'' takeover defenses to shareholder votes. These measures, which make hostile takeovers more expensive, generally fall under the jurisdiction of directors. Many shareholders don't like pills because they can block attractive prices stock in a takeover fight. There was other evidence of shareholder activism. Although management proposals generally were approved, in some cases they won by slimmer margins than in past votes. At the Time Warner Inc. meeting, management's stock incentive plan was approved, but one-quarter of the shares _ a relatively large bloc _ were cast against it. Management wasn't the only group coming up short this year. Stockholders also refused to rally around corporate takeover strategists. At Lockheed, where Simmons sought to install allies on the board, and at American General Corp., where suitor Torchmark Inc. had similar plans, shareholders voted against the insurgents. The outcome was expected to be the same at USX Corp., where shareholders voted on investor Carl Icahn's non-binding proposal to break up the steel-energy conglomerate. The tally had not been completed by the end of last week, but Icahn had already said he expected to lose. Lang, a partner with the firm Weil Gotshal & Manges in New York, said the shareholders are listening to the dissidents' ideas, but ``they're probably going to vote with their pocketbooks.'' Harry DeAngelo, a finance professor at the University of Michigan, agreed. ``There's a tendency for (shareholders) to go with the incumbent group unless the dissidents have a tangible proposal for distributing value'' or raising a company's stock price, he said. That was the case at Lockheed and USX, where Simmons and Icahn had ideas about ways to increase the price of the companies' stock but did not offer shareholders any guarantees. Torchmark also had little concrete value to offer. The suitor had encountered obstacles in its attempt to buy American General and resorted to a proxy fight. Dissidents had some victories, however. The Belzberg family of Canada managed to win one seat on the board of Armstrong World Industries Inc., though it subsequently scrapped a takeover offer for the company. Dissident shareholders upset the entire board of XTRA Corp., a trailer leasing company. Icahn and Simmons said they expected to eventually come out ahead financially even if they fell short of votes. Both said they expect management ultimately to respond to their complaints and take steps to boost the value of their stock. Shareholders did suffer disappointment this season _ perhaps the biggest came in their struggle with Exxon Corp. over the oil company's environmental record. The funds of which Davis is a trustee and the pension funds of New York City and Massachusetts had sought assurances from Exxon that it would improve safety procedures following the Exxon Valdez oil spill off Alaska last year. Management refused to adopt any environmental proposal made by shareholders. Nevertheless, Davis said, ``We're not going away and Exxon will have to come to terms with its environmental indifference.'' Davis said he expects shareholder power _ particularly that of the big institutions _ to increase over the next 10 years as the pension funds increase their stakes in U.S. companies. He predicted management will be forced to consult regularly with shareholders. Right now, he acknowledged, shareholders have more leverage in situations where management faces a threat, such as a takeover or proxy fight. But he looks for that to change. Lang agreed that institutional shareholders ``have enormous potential power,'' but said their new activism poses a number of legal questions. For example, under Securities and Exchange Commission regulations, institutional investors are subject to different disclosure requirements according to their level of activism. But if an institution that was previously considered passive becomes more activist, it could find itself in violation of SEC rules, Lang said. Shareholders face other dilemmas as they seek a bigger role _ especially as they clamor for places on boards of directors. ``A member of a board is supposed to represent all the shareholders,'' said John Lubin, a management professor at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania. ``If they go on the board, legally and in every sense, they're not supposed to represent their own interests.''

The company estimated significantly lower earnings for the fiscal quarter that ended Thursday. Among other actively traded blue chips, Ford Motor rose | to 46}; Philip Morris ~ to 43; General Electric \ to 69[, and McDonald's 1[ to 35}. DOC.HEAD: Debt Holders OK Plan to Defer Interest Payments
DOC.TEXT: A group of Campeau Corp. bondholders approved a proposal by the financially distressed company to defer certain interest payments until the end of 1991 while it tries to restructure. More than the necessary two-thirds majority of the bondholders supported the extraordinary resolution, a Campeau spokesman said after a meeting in Toronto, where the Canadian company is based. Spokesman Richard W. Wertheim said the actual vote count wouldn't be known for several days, until a final tally is completed. Campeau, parent of two extensive U.S. retailing companies now in bankruptcy court proceedings, had said that a ``significant negative cash flow'' due to debt service obligations forced it to seek the deferral until Dec. 31, 1991. The company is negotiating similar deferrals with other creditors. Management of Campeau has developed a business plan designed to restructure the company's financial affairs. It involves substantial real estate and other asset sales. Campeau's restructuring has no direct bearing on the reorganization of Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp., the two Campeau-owned American retailing companies based in Cincinnati. They filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code in January. At the Toronto meeting, Paul Campbell, president of Campeau's Canadian operations, said the company ``will face many more challenges in the months ahead.'' He said there was ``no immediate prospect of an infusion of equity'' into Campeau. The group that approved the deferral Friday were owners of Campeau's 7{ percent convertible subordinated debentures, a type of bond. The debentures are Campeau's only publicly held debt. The rest of its outstanding debt was placed privately. Robert Campeau, company founder and its chairman and chief executive, did not attend the meeting, Wertheim said. Campeau and his family hold about 42 percent of the debentures and Olympia & York Developments Ltd., a Canada-based property development company and a major Campeau creditor, holds 25.3 percent. The rest of are widely held.

DOC.HEAD: Purchasing Managers Report Manufacturing Rebound, Economists Skeptical
DOC.TEXT: A survey of purchasing managers indicated on Friday an improvement in manufacturing in May, but economists said the report was overshadowed and contradicted by government unemployment numbers. Gains in production and new orders led the increase, the second in as many months for the purchasing managers' index. The rise in the index is more a sign that the manufacturing slump has hit bottom, than a precursor of a strong recovery, , said James Solloway, director of economic research at Argus Research Inc. in New York. ``It does show some stability in manufacturing coming in. But things are still soft,'' Solloway said. Economists also said the report by the National Association of Purchasing Management was probably influenced by increased automobile production that is not being matched by sales. The purchasing managers' index rose to 50.7 percent in May, up from 50.2 percent the month before. A reading above 50 indicates the manufacturing economy is generally expanding; below 50, that it is generally declining. It was the highest level for the purchasing managers' index since it reached 52.7 percent in April 1989. ``The index is giving us a rosier picture of manufacturing than is justified,'' Allen Sinai, an economist at Boston Co. in New York, said, noting weak unemployment figures. The government said Friday the unemployment rate fell 0.1 percentage point to 5.3 percent in May. However, an increase of 164,000 new jobs was almost entirely due to the addition of temporary census workers. Private economists had expected non-government industries to create at least 125,000 new jobs in May, far greater than the 19,000 that were added. According to the purchasing managers' report, the production index increased significantly, to 56.3 percent from 53 percent in April. The new orders index came in at 54.8 percent, but that was a slower growth rate than the 55.5 percent figure for April. New export orders also grew in May, although the increase was not as much as reported the two previous months. The new export orders index was 54 percent, down from 60.5 percent in April and 59.5 percent in March. The production managers reported declining prices in May, resuming a trend that began nearly a year ago. The price index increased in April, for the first time since last May, to 50.8. It dropped to 48.5 last month. Christopher Low, an economist at CM&M Group, a New York investment group, said: ``The increase in orders shows the manufacturing sector is struggling back. The inflation shows declines in commodities prices, but what that misses is increases in labor costs and service industry prices.'' April's increase in the overall index followed 11 straight months of declines, the group said in a press release from its Tempe, Ariz. headquarters. The purchasing managers' report is based on a monthly survey of purchasing executives at more than 300 industrial companies. Most of the figures are adjusted for seasonal factors.

DOC.HEAD: With BC-Housing Market
DOC.TEXT: Here's a regional breakdown of real estate market conditions throughout the United States, based on reports from realtors, lenders and economists:
DOC.HEAD: NORTHEAST
DOC.TEXT: Conditions are sluggish partly because of an oversupply of homes. Big layoffs on Wall Street and weakeness in Massachusetts' high-tech-dominated economy have softened demand for housing and brought recession-like conditions to the area _ a reversal from a few years ago when some homes were appreciating in double-digit rates. Many homes are falling in value _ as much as 1 percent per month in some pockets of metropolitan New York, while the length of time needed to sell a home is rising. Home prices were off on average 3 percent to 5 percent during the first quarter of 1990 from a year ago in cities like Hartford, Conn.; Boston and New York, the National Association of Realtors says. New Haven, Conn., was especially weak, with prices down 11 percent. Pockets of strength include Buffalo, Rochester and Albany, N.Y., where prices were up between 2 percent and 12 percent. Another exception is Pittsburgh, where home values were reported to be stable and prices are considered comparably affordable.
DOC.HEAD: MIDWEST
DOC.TEXT: Unlike the Northeast, where prices exploded in the '80s, homes in this region appreciated more modestly. Lower prices and ``quality of life'' benefits have attracted many businesses and are supporting demand for housing. Examples of prices increases as of the first quarter, according to the Realtors association, include: Akron, Ohio, up 17.5 percent; Grand Rapids, Mich., 14 percent; Chicago, 12 percent; Milwaukee, 7.5 percent; Cincinnati, 7 percent; Detroit, 6.5 percent; and Louisville, Ky., 3 percent.
DOC.HEAD: SOUTH
DOC.TEXT: The region is mixed. Many cities in the Southeast are strong economically. A few ``oil-patch'' areas around Texas remain weak, although cities like Houston and Dallas are reported to be rebounding. Cities where home prices have risen or remain stable, according to the Realtors, include: Baltimore, up 13 percent; Houston, up 12 percent; Miami, 8 percent; Dallas, 5 percent; San Antonio, Texas, 2 percent; Washington, D.C., unchanged; and Birmingham, Ala., unchanged. Among the weak spots: Oklahoma City and New Orleans, down around 2 percent.
DOC.HEAD: WEST
DOC.TEXT: Also mixed. California real estate remains strong but the pace of increases in home sales and prices has slowed from the dizzying rate of just a year and a half ago. Some Californians, particularly from bigger cities like Los Angeles, decided to cash out and move to less expensive areas, increasing the supply of available homes. Cities like Denver and Phoenix continue to have serious economic problems due partly to volatility in the oil industry and the collapse of many savings and loans, although some real estate markets are showing signs of stabilizing. Examples of increases in home prices, according to the Realtors: Sacramento, Calif., up 27 percent; Las Vegas, 10 percent; Los Angeles, 5 percent; Orange County, Calif., 3 percent.
DOC.HEAD: NORTHWEST
DOC.TEXT: Conditions are healthy, making this region the brightest spot for real estate in the United States. Demand for housing is outstripping supply partly because of an influx of outsiders. Californians constitute at least half of all out-of-state buyers. Home prices in Seattle soared 36.5 percent over a year ago, according to the Realtors _ the highest appreciation rate in the nation. Portland, Ore., was up 12 percent.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv Sunday, June 3

DOC.TEXT: Stock prices climbed to new highs today, inspired by revived hopes for lower interest rates. Shortly before the close, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was up 20.67 at 2,897.33.

DOC.HEAD: IBM Sells 13,000 Personal Computers To Soviet Union
DOC.TEXT: International Business Machines Corp. said Friday it has signed its biggest contract yet with the Soviet Union, under which it will supply over 13,000 personal computers for use in schools. ``It is a significant step up from the level of (Soviet) business we've been doing before,'' said IBM spokesman Mac Jeffery. The value of the contract was not disclosed, but Jeffrey said the Soviets will pay in a convertible currency and that they received a discount comparable to the one IBM offers other customers for computers bought for educational use. Barry Bosak, an industry analyst at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co., said the contract could be worth $20 million to $30 million, depending on the discount and the types of printers and other equipment included. He said it probably ranks among the largest sales of computer equipment to the Soviet Union by a Western company. Jeffery said IBM has been selling computers in the Soviet Union since 1975, but he declined to quantify the earlier sales.``We hope this will lead to other things,'' he said. IBM and the U.S.S.R. State Committees for Education and Informatics said in a statement that the contract ``could form the basis for the build-up of assembly operations for personal computers in the U.S.S.R.,'' and that feasibility studies on such assembly operations have been launched. ``It is something that both sides are seriously looking at,'' Jeffery said, declining to elaborate. Bosak said the possibility of building Soviet assembly plants is more important than the size of the contract. Setting up an assembly operation ``would give them (IBM) a working base,'' he said. As part of the deal with the state education committee, IBM will provide 150 educational software packages that have been translated into Russian. In addition, IBM will work with outside software companies to provide additional applications programs and will train Soviet software engineers to write educational software, Jeffery said. IBM also will train teachers to use the computers, he said. The contract is for IBM's Personal System-2 machines featuring Intel Corp.'s 80286 microprocessor _ the most sophisticated microprocessor allowed to be exported to the Soviet Union by U.S. companies under current export rules, Jeffery said. Shipments will begin in September in time for some schools to begin using the machines in the 1990-91 school year, IBM said.

DOC.HEAD: Argentina Reportedly Ready to Resume Interest Payments
DOC.TEXT: Argentina is to resume negotiations next week with creditor banks over the possible resumption of interest payments for the first time in two years on its $60 billion foreign debt, local newspapers reported Friday. However, talks are likely to be contentious, with creditor banks apparently seeking more than the Argentine government is offering to pay, the reports stated. Citing sources in the Economy Ministry, the daily Clarin reported the government is prepared to pay $70 million a month for three months, but creditor banks want a minimum $100 million monthly for the rest of 1990. The daily La Nacion reported foreign bankers don't want monthly payments at all, but rather a lump sum before negotiations resume. The 11-month-old government of President Carlos Menem is seeking debt forgiveness, approval for debt capitalization and new loans. Its mission to New York will be led by the president-designate of the Central Bank, Javier Gonzalez Fraga. Fraga told the financial daily El Cronista Comercial that foreign banks basically want ``interest payments. They have received virtually nothing in more than two years.'' Negotiations with a steering committee that represents banks owed about $40 billion _ mostly U.S. banks _ are likely to be difficult. The U.S. government in January ordered banks to more than double their reserves set aside to cover potentially bad loan to Argentina, cutting into bank earnings. Overdue interest may total $8.5 billion this year, the Argentine government conceded in a letter to the International Monetary Fund last Friday. Nevertheless, the IMF indicated it approved of Menem's policy of budget austerity and privatizations, and unblocked payment of a $1.7 billion loan. The loan was granted last October but suspended five months later when the IMF said Menem's government had failed to meet targets for controlling inflation and reducing the government budget deficit. In the IMF letter, Argentina pledged to pay $500 million in overdue interest, but acknowledged full payments would not be made for at least three years. Argentina's economy, emerging from two bouts of hyperinflation, is mired in recession. Menem's government has implemented an economic austerity program that includes budget cuts, the lifting of price controls and plans for privatization of government-owned companies.

Stock prices churned ahead to a new high today as traders responded to fresh evidence of a weaker-than-expected economy. The Labor Department this morning reported a rise of 164,000 in nonfarm payroll employment during May, attributing the increase almost entirely to temporary hiring for the Census. Job figures for April were revised to show a decrease rather than the small gain reported earlier. Janet Norwood, commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, said no job growth at all has been registered in the private sector of the economy over the last three months. While that news did not bode well for corporate profits in the near future, analysts said it was welcomed on Wall Street as a possible portent of further declines in interest rates and an easing in the Federal Reserve's credit policy. The bond market gave the news an enthusiastic welcome. Prices of long-term Treasury bonds jumped about $15 for each $1,000 in face value, lowering their yields to the 8.44 percent-8.47 percent range.

DOC.HEAD: Dutch Electronics Firm Develops Machine For Better-Sounding Audio Cassettes
DOC.TEXT: The Dutch electronics company NV Philips has developed a conventional audio tape process that music industry officials say is good enough that it could put a dent in the new digital audio tape market. Philips quietly unveiled its new tape machine for several major record companies in Los Angeles last week. But the company has declined to discuss the so-called digital compact cassette machine, which is scheduled to hit the market next year. ``It sounds very good; it's not as good as a CD (compact disc), but it's so much better than standard analog cassettes,'' said Al McPherson, chief engineer for Warner Bros. Records. Philips held the demonstrations to drum up music industry support for its new product. McPherson said Warner had not agreed to offer such support, but is very, very interested in the technology. Consumers could use the Philips machine to record or play music utilizing either digital audio tapes or conventional audio tapes. The conventional tapes are more widely available and much cheaper than the digital ones, but the digital tapes' sound quality is far superior. Industry officials have also said the machine could rejuvenate flagging audio cassette sales. Although the audio cassette developed by Philips in 1963 represents more than half of all pre-recorded music sales, sales fell in 1989 in the wake of CD competition.

DOC.HEAD: Energy Prices Mixed as Market Stabilizes
DOC.TEXT: Energy futures prices were mixed Friday as the market sought to stabilize after steep price declines the day before. The July contract for wholesale unleaded gasoline was down 0.48 cent to 60.78 cents a gallon on the New York Mercantile Exchange after falling 2.00 cents on Thursday. The August contract was down 0.03 cent to 58.12 cents, while later months increased. The July contract for West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude oil, was up 10 cents to $17.50 a 42-gallon barrel, after falling 68 cents on Thursday. The August and September contracts were also up slightly. ``We had a nice little bounce back from yesterday's blows,'' said John Hill, vice president at Merrill Lynch Energy Futures. ``The traders bought back to cover short positions, evening things up for the weekend and balancing off from yesterday.'' Prices tumbled Thursday because of an industry report that indicated an oversupply of petroleum. The American Petroleum Institute reported late Wednesday that U.S. inventories of gasoline and and crude oil rose last week by 1.1 million barrels and 2.1 million barrels respectively. Among other futures traded Friday on the New York Merc, the July contract for home heating oil fell 0.62 cent to 48.73 cents a gallon. Later heating oil contract months also dropped. Natural gas prices were also down. The July contract slipped to $1.585 per 1,000 cubic feet from $1.590 late Thursday.

The Russell 3000 index of companies with the largest market value closed at 201.02 Friday, up 4.20, or 2.13 percent, from a week ago and up 3.74, or 1.90 percent, this year to date. The Russell 1000 index of the largest companies, closed at 188.78 Friday, up 4.04, or 2.19 percent, from a week ago and up 3.67, or 1.98 percent, this year to date. DOC.HEAD: Settlement Announced In General Mills-Cholesterol Cereal Case
DOC.TEXT: General Mills Inc. has settled a complaint from attorneys general in three states about advertising for the defunct Benefit brand cereal, the company said Thursday. Minnesota Attorney General Hubert Humphrey III and the attorneys general in Iowa and Wisconsin alleged that an advertisement claiming that ``Benefit removes cholesterol from your body'' were false and misleading. Golden Valley-based General Mills said Thursday it agreed to pay each of the three states $7,000. The settlement is not an admission of wrongdoing, the company said. ``The settlement was the fastest and least costly way to resolve differences over a single newspaper ad for a product that hasn't been sold for over five months,'' the company said in a statement. General Mills said it took exception with Humphrey's description of the settlement. He said that under the agreement General Mills will not make any similar claims that its products ``remove cholesterol'' from the body. Although the Golden Valley based company removed Benefit cereal from store shelves last winter, Humphrey said, nothing prevented the company from resurrecting a similar product with the same ``highly questionable claims.'' ``These cholesterol claims have gotten out of control,'' said Humphrey. ``To imply that a single product will magically remove cholesterol is misleading and deceptive to consumers. It takes an overall low-fat, low-cholesterol diet to help reduce cholesterol.'' ``We strongly disagree with his characterization of the settlement,'' General Mills said. Company spokeswoman Kathy Newton said the settlement applies only to a single newspaper ad printed in August of last year. She said the ``interim ad'' featured a PacMan cartoon character gobbling up the word ``Cholesterol'' in the phrase ``Benefit removes cholesterol from your body.'' Humphrey has urged the federal Food and Drug Administration to ban health claims unless there is scientific consensus that the claims are true. He also urged the federal agency to spell out the exact wording that food manufacturers must use in making any health claims about their products. Since Benefit was removed from store shelves, it has been sold as a food for livestock, Newton said. The company had an inventory of about 50 tons of the flakes when the product was yanked from the consumer market. It is being used to fatten cows and pigs on several South Dakota farms, she said. ``That is not an uncommon thing whatsoever,'' Newton said. ``If it's an edible type product we try not to waste it.''

DOC.HEAD: Next Chairman? Lutz and Miller Wait in Chrysler's Wings
DOC.TEXT: A leadership shuffle at Chrysler Corp. leaves a financial whiz and a lover of fast cars waiting in the wings for Chairman Lee Iacocca's retirement. But analysts speculated Friday the differing backgrounds of ``bean counter'' Robert S. Miller and ``car guy'' Robert Lutz may prompt Iacocca, 65, to stick around past the late-1991 expiration of his contract. The shuffle announced Thursday divided the duties of former Vice Chairman Gerald Greenwald between Miller, 48, and Lutz, 58. Miller got Greenwald's title and most of his duties, but that doesn't mean he's a shoo-in to succeed Iacocca, analysts said. Since Miller has had little exposure to product development and Lutz has had few dealings with financial matters, they said a coordinator is needed. Analysts said that would be Iacocca now that Greenwald has departed to lead a union coalition seeking a $4.54 billion leveraged buyout of United Airlines. A year ago, it appeared Iacocca would step down as chief executive officer when his contract expired at the end of 1991 and hand over Chrysler's reigns to Greenwald. Greenwald has said Iacocca told him last year that the chairmanship ``is yours to lose.'' Auto analyst Doug Laughlin of Bear Stearns & Co. in New York said the ``bad news'' resulting from Greenwald's resignation was ``who is the long-term chairman for Chrysler.'' ``The good news is that Iacocca stays around longer either to groom or find a successor,'' he said. Chrysler moved swiftly in the hours after Greenwald's resignation was announced. In addition to dividing Greenwald's duties between Miller and Lutz, it eliminated the Office of the Chairman, which Iacocca and Greenwald shared. Chrysler Motors Chairman Bennett Bidwell, 62, who's reportedly suffering health problems, was passed over in the shuffle, presumably leaving him out of the running for chairman. The Detroit Free Press quoted unidentified sources Friday as saying Bidwell plans to retire in December. Company spokesmen declined to discuss Bidwell's intentions or his health. That leaves Lutz and Miller on deck. Auto analyst David Healy of Barclays Bank in New York called both highly able in their chosen fields. Healy and other analysts said it's difficult to tell who's in line for Iacocca's job, partly because Chrysler has done some innovative things with its corporate offices. Among the scenarios analysts suggested: _An outsider could be brought in, much like Iacocca was in 1979. _Lutz or Miller could become the new chairman after some grooming. _Miller and Lutz could share the office. ``It's possible to split it up where they both would wind up with big titles and each guy would handle his traditional area,'' Healy said. ``Chrysler has had so many variations on its structure that nothing would surprise me.'' Miller joined Chrysler in 1979 as assistant controller. With Greenwald, he helped secure loans and federal guarantees which helped the automaker avoid bankruptcy in the early 1980s. Like Iacocca, Lutz and Bidwell, Miller worked for Ford Motor Co. before going to Chrysler, mostly in overseas financial operations. At Chrysler, Miller became vice president and treasurer in 1980, and rose to become the corporation's chief financial officer in 1988. He also is credited with raising money and developing a financial plan that rescued the Detroit Symphony last year. Lutz, born in Zurich, Switzerland, started his automotive career with General Motors Corp. in 1963 and worked in a number of administrative jobs in Europe. He then spent three years with the West German automaker BMW before joining Ford of Europe in 1974. He worked for Ford for a dozen years, before joining Chrysler in 1986 as an executive vice president. Lutz is known for his love of cars, especially driving them fast. Stories about Lutz's love of speed are popular in Detroit. One goes that he likes a strip of highway close to his Ann Arbor home because a wall between traffic lanes hides his Lamborghini Countach from the State Police as he roars to work at Chrysler's Highland Park headquarters.

DOC.HEAD: U.S-Japan Auto Parts Talks to Be Held June 14 in Louisville
DOC.TEXT: High-level talks on increasing access of U.S. automobile parts suppliers to Japanese markets will be held June 14 in Louisville, Ky., the Commerce Department said Thursday. The negotiations will be headed by Commerce Undersecretary J. Michael Farren and Naomichi Suzuki, Japanese vice minister of international trade and industry. Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher and Japanese International Trade and Industry Minister Kabun Muto agreed in April to raise the level of the talks. Known as the Market Oriented Sector Selective, they are designed to accelerate progress on increasing U.S. suppliers' access to the Japanese auto market and to ensure greater involvement of U.S. suppliers in the design phase of Japanese car manufacturers. U.S. auto parts exports to Japan now total about $600 million a year, less than 1 percent of the Japanese auto parts market.

DOC.HEAD: Fixed-Rate Mortgage Rates Fall
DOC.TEXT: Fixed-rate home mortgages are averaging 10.29 percent, down from 10.33 percent last week, according to a national survey released Friday by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. On one-year adjustable rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 8.55 percent this week, up from 8.53 percent the week before. The rates, compiled from a national survey, do not include add-on fees known as points.

DOC.HEAD: Nation's Unemployment Rate Falls to 5.3 Percent in May
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 5th graf, Stock prices ... to UPDATE with closing; INSERTS new 9th graf, Revised figures ... to include revised April figures; picks up 8th graf pvs, ``The job ... Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The hiring of thousands of temporary census workers helped push the nation's unemployment rate down slightly to 5.3 percent in May, the government said Friday. Despite the 0.1 percentage point decline in the jobless rate, analysts viewed the report as a sign of a sluggish economy because private sector job growth slowed to a near standstill in May. ``These numbers are a real danger signal ... and bring into question whether we can muddle through without tilting toward recession,'' economist David Jones of Aubrey G. Lanston & Co. said. The report, the first comprehensive look at May's economic activity, shows the economy is ``worse than sluggish _ it is moribund,'' said Richard W. Rahn, chief economist at the U.S. Chamber of Commerce. Stock prices on Wall Street rose to a new high as traders took weak job growth as a sign that the Federal Reserve might lower interest rates. At the close, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was 2,900.97, up 24.31 from Thursday. In other economic news Friday, the Commerce Department reported construction spending continued to slide in April, dropping 0.7 percent for the second straight month as interest rates remained high. The civilian jobless rate as measured by a household survey fell slightly in May from April's 5.4 percent unemployment rate, the Labor Department said. The nation's jobless rate has been fluctuating around 5.3 percent for more than a year. There were 164,000 new jobs created last month, according to a separate survey of business establishments, but the number was artificially inflated by the federal government's hiring of 145,000 temporary census workers. Revised figures for April showed jobs actually declined by 23,000 that month rather than posting a small increase as the Labor Department had earlier reported. ``The job market has been bolstered only by census hiring. The private sector has been stagnant for the past three months,'' said Janet Norwood, commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Since February, the economy has added just 264,000 new jobs and if government jobs are excluded, private payrolls actually fell by 105,000, the government said. ``Job creation has ground to a halt increasingly in one industry after another,'' said economist Allen Sinai of the Boston Co. Analysts said the unemployment dip was also helped by the relatively slow expansion of the labor force in recent months. After growing by 430,000 workers in February and March, the number of Americans working or actively seeking jobs grew by just 165,000 during April and May. The nation's manufacturing sector, which has been in a slump for months, continued to falter as factory jobs fell by 35,000 jobs, bringing the total manufacturing losses to 310,000 jobs since March 1989. The electrical equipment, auto and apparel industries together have lost 190,000 jobs during that period. Construction jobs fell by 20,000 in May, reflecting continued weakness in the housing market, the government said. Employment in the construction industry is only 30,000 above its level of a year earlier, compared with a 180,000 gain in the prior May-to-May period. The service sector, which has been carrying the economy, added 216,000 jobs, but that included the once-every-decade census jobs. Health services added 47,000 jobs, wholesale trade contributed 16,000 and business services added another 15,000 jobs. In contrast, other industries within the service sector are slumping. Retail trade has posted a 19,000-job loss since January while finance, insurance and real estate has added just 28,000 jobs over the past five months. Average hourly earnings posted a 0.4 percent rise in May to $9.99, up from the $9.95 the average worker earned an hour in April. If earnings rose at that pace every month, that would mean a 5 percent annual increase. Jones called the higher wage costs, coupled with slow job growth, ``the worst of both possible worlds.'' ``It's certainly going to put a squeeze on corporate profits,'' he said. The average manufacturing work week rose to 41.1 hours in May, up from 40.7 hours in April. Manufacturing overtime increased to 4 hours, up from the average of 3.5 hours in April. In a separate calculation of unemployment that counts members of the armed serviced stationed in the United States, the May jobless rate was 5.3 percent, the same as April and also May's civilian rate.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mixed; Gold Off
DOC.TEXT: The dollar wound up the week on a mixed note Friday, gaining against the West German mark and Swiss franc and losing ground to the Japanese yen and British pound in domestic trading. The dollar's strength versus several key currencies tended to depress precious metals. Gold bullion prices declined in the United States and abroad. A widely awaited report on the U.S. labor market in May initially had a negative impact on the dollar. The report, the first comprehensive look at last month's economic activity, signaled continuing sluggish growth. It also implied that inflationary pressures aren't as powerful as previously thought, which drove down interest rates in the bond market Friday. Falling U.S. interest rates reduce returns on dollar-denominated holdings and can curb demand for dollars. The unemployment rate dipped to 5.3 percent in May from April's 5.4 percent and non-farm payrolls expanded by an unexpectedly small number. There were 164,000 new jobs created last month at business establishments, but the figure was inflated by the federal government's hiring of 145,000 temporary census workers. Sales of other currencies to collect profits amassed during recent advances helped the dollar recover from its lows of the day. Lingering concerns about various international matters also benefited the dollar. Confidence in the West German currency has been eroded by speculation that German unification could undermine the mark's value. Scott Hinton, currency analyst at Elders Futures Inc. in New York, said trading was heavy after release of the unemployment report in early U.S. trading. But it slowed considerably by midday, which is typical for a Friday. Currency dealers usually refrain from establishing significant new positions on Fridays because events over the weekend might have an impact on exchange rates. The dollar's performance against the Japanese yen was mixed. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 152.17 yen, up 0.42 yen from Thursday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 151.45 yen. It was quoted at 151.85 yen near the end of New York trading, down from 152.10 late Thursday. The British pound rose to $1.6840 in London from $1.6760 late Thursday. Sterling rose to $1.6810 from $1.6780 late Thursday. Selected late dollar rates in New York, compared with Thursday's late quotes, included: 1.6985 West German marks, up from 1.6965; 1.4375 Swiss francs, up from 1.4290; 5.7295 French francs, up from 5.724; 1,250.375 Italian lire, up from 1,248.25; and 1.17465 Canadian dollars, up from 1.17285. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Thursday's levels, included: 1.6940 West German marks, down from 1.6990; 1.4358 Swiss francs, up from 1.4325; 5.7180 French francs, down from 5.7300; 1.9073 Dutch guilders, up from 1.9060; 1,247.25 Italian lire, up from 1,247.00; and 1.1728 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1740. Gold and silver prices weakened. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, a troy ounce of gold for June delivery tumbled $5.10 to close at $359.20. Republic National Bank quoted a late bid of $358.75 a troy ounce for gold bullion, $4.95 lower than Thursday. In London, gold fell to a late bid of $361.25 a troy ounce from $363.75 late Thursday. In Zurich, gold fell to a closing bid of $363.00 from $364.00 late Thursday. Gold in Hong Kong dropped 21 cents to close at $365.04. Silver for June delivery dropped to $5.046 a troy ounce on New York's Comex from $5.074 Thursday. In London, silver fell to a late bid of $5.05 a troy ounce from $5.08 bid late Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Precious Metals Futures Plunge
DOC.TEXT: Precious metals futures plunged Friday on the New York Commodity Exchange in the wake of weak May employment figures and amid uncertainty about whether a trade agreement will result from U.S.-Soviet summit talks. On other markets, grain and soybean futures fell; livestock and pork futures were higher, and energy futures were mixed. Peter Caudillo, an analyst with Josephthal & Co. in New York, said that the precious metals market was monitoring the progress of talks between President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev in Washington, D.C. ``If nothing positive comes of out of the summit, there are fears the Soviets will be forced again to sell gold in the open market'' to pay for overseas purchases, Caudillo said. He noted that gold has not been able to rally since mid-May, when heavy cash market selling of the metal sent prices tumbling. The U.S. Labor Department announced Friday that the nation's unemployment rate went fell 0.1 percenttage point to 5.3 percent in May while job growth amounted to a smaller-than-expected 164,000. ``The figures are indicating economic weakness, translating into a downward trend in inflation,'' he said. Gold is seen as a haven during inflationary periods. Silver futures were battered by gold's plunge, with the day's gains erased when investors liquidated near-month contracts. Gold settled $5.10 to $5.80 lower with the contract for delivery in June at $359.20 a troy ounce; silver was 2.8 cents to 4.4 cents lower with June at $5.046 a troy ounce. Grain and soybean futures were mostly lower on the Chicago Board of Trade as improving weather depressed prices. Soybeans dropped sharply when the July support level of $6.05 a bushel was breached and followthrough selling set in. National Weather Service forecasts called for dry conditions much of next week, which will facilitate planting of soybeans, said William Biedermann, an analyst with Allendale Inc. in Chicago. Soybean plantings had been delayed by soggy fields. Corn futures were pushed lower by progress made this week in planting the corn crop. Biedermann noted that sparce export business and a lack of progress in trade talks during the Bush-Gorbachev summit talks influenced corn futures. Fairly good weather, allowing for progress in the harvesting of the winter crop, pushed wheat futures lower. Wheat was 1 cent to 4{ cents lower with July at $3.29\ a bushel; corn was 1} cents to 2\ cents lower with July at $2.75} a bushel; oats were a { cent lower to 1 cent higher with July at $1.44 a bushel; soybeans were 5\ cents to 7{ cents lower with July at $6.02 a bushel. Energy futures were mixed on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The near-month contract for crude oil bounced back from Thursday's sharp selloff on belief that the drop was overdone, analysts said. Gasoline, while slightly higher, continued to be pressured from American Petroleum Institute inventory figures showing refinery runs increased sharply last month, while gasoline stocks also rose. West Texas Intermediate crude oil was 10 cents lower to 10 cents higher with July at $17.50 a barrel; heating oil was .15 cent to .78 cent lower with July at 48.73 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .48 cent lower to .15 cent higher with July at 60.78 cents a gallon. Livestock and pork futures were higher in trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle were .17 cent to .52 cent higher with June at 74.47 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .20 cent to .72 cent higher with August at 84.37 cents a pound; live hogs were .35 cent lower to .25 cent higher with June at 65.75 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .85 cent to 1.42 cents higher with July at 65.05 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Blizzard of Improved Products Unveiled At Electronics Show
DOC.TEXT: Last year it was hand-held video games, watchable Walkmans and interactive compact discs. This year, it's digital audio tape, scaled-down camcorders and movie-theater sound for the home. Every year, millions of dollars in new electronics technology goes on display at the Consumer Electronics Show, but what does it mean for someone who bought last year's innovation and now faces bewildering new choices? ``Products will continue to be put out with new features and new bells and whistles,'' acknowledged Marvin Lurie, spokesman for the suburban Lombard-based National Association of Retail Dealers of America. ``The only way to get it sorted out is to go to a qualified dealer who can explain the benefits,'' Lurie said Friday. He said his group represents about 20 percent of U.S. consumer electronics retailers. Many of them will be among the estimated 55,000 visitors to the annual show, beginning Saturday at McCormick Place, where 1,400 manufacturers will be showing tens of thousands of products for four days in an area equivalent to the size of 17 football fields. ``We are THE industry show,'' said Tom Lauterback, spokesman for the Consumer Electronics Group of the Washington-based Electronics Industries Association, sponsor of the June show in Chicago and a similar January show in Las Vegas. The shows are closed to the public. Consumer electronics, a $44 billion-a-year industry that includes audio, video, home office and home-automation products, has slowed to ``single-digit'' growth, but ``I suppose every industry would love to be able to say that,'' Lauterback said Friday. Unlike in past years, ``we don't have on hand a product that everyone is going to want but no one has,'' said Lurie. ``Digital audio tape might be that, except that if it comes on the market later this year, it's not going to come at a mass-market price,'' he said, adding that DAT systems are expected to retail at $1,000 to $1,200. Though DAT technology has existed for years, it wasn't until Wednesday that a Japanese government agency announced new technology standards that will open that country's market for DAT players. The players can make nearly perfect copies of prerecorded music, but manufacturers have held off marketing them out of a fear of lawsuits from copyright disputes. Japan's new standards are designed to limit consumers' abilities to make new copies, and Congress is scheduled to hold hearings this month on a proposal to adopt similar standards in the United States. Political problems similarly plague high-resolution television, said Don Krueger, senior vice president and director of research for Sanyo Securities of America, the U.S. arm of one of Japan's biggest brokerage firms. ``The Japanese have the standard of technology, but Europe and the U.S. don't want to adopt the standard,'' he said in a telephone interview Friday. ``Nobody wants the Japanese to dominate the high-definition TV'' as they have other areas of the consumer electronics market, he said. Meanwhile, ``there's nothing terribly exciting out there ..., '' he said. ``We've kind of hit a black hole right now.'' Hence, improvements to existing products are holding sway at this year's show, including ultra-compact camcorders _ the size of half a cigarette carton _ marketed by Panasonic and Sony and a movie-theater sound system for the home marketed by Lucasfilm Ltd. In the video game arena, disabled youngsters will get a shot at Nintendo action through a voice-command headset unveiled by Konami Inc. of suburban Buffalo Grove. The proliferation of consumer electronics products overall may sometimes seem bewildering, but it is an inevitable byproduct of the American way of doing business, said sociologist Peter Whalley, an associate professor at Loyola University who teachs a course on technology and society. ``The standard marketing strategy is to maximize the number of products out there to fill the niches out there,'' he said Friday. ``I don't think the electronics industry does it more than anyone else.''

DOC.HEAD: Highest Closes in Dow Jones Industrials Average
With AM-Wall Street
Bond Prices Soar On News Of Weaker Economy
DOC.TEXT: Bond prices soared Friday as the market reacted to sharply weaker-than-expected job growth in May that pointed to an economic slowdown. The Treasury's benchmark 30-year bond jumped 1{ points, or $15 per $1,000 face amount. Its yield, which rises when prices fall, tumbled to 8.44 percent from 8.57 percent late Thursday. It was the lowest yield on the 30-year bond since late March. The government reported that the nation's unemployment rate fell 0.1 percentage point to 5.3 percent in May, but that only 19,000 jobs, excluding temporary census workers, were created. Steven A. Wood, an economist with BankAmerica Capital Markets in San Francisco, said the report ``suggests the economy is performing much more weakly than expected, and that will lead to lower inflation and an easing of monetary policy.'' Inflation erodes the value of fixed-income securities such as bonds. An easing of monetary policy by the Federal Reserve Board would lower interest rates, which would benefit bond prices. ``The Fed has been concerned, as have the markets, that the economy has been growing too rapidly to allow inflationary pressures to recede,'' Wood said. ``Now it appears the economy is not growing nearly as strongly.'' The Labor Department said the number of new jobs in May increased by 164,000 over April, but that number was artificially bolstered by the federal government's hiring of 145,000 temporary census workers. Private economists had expected non-government industries to add at least 125,00 jobs in May, far above the 19,000 reported. Wood said the market took off slowly after the report was issued, rising on light volume before heavy trading began in all maturities. In another economic report Friday, a survey of the nation's purchasing managers indicated that U.S. manufacturing expanded in May for the second straight month. The National Association of Purchasing Management's economic index rose to 50.7 percent in May, from 50.2 percent in April. A reading above 50 indicates the manufacturing economy is generally expanding; below 50, that it is generally declining. Tom Lanier, a Treasury bill trader with Manufacturers Hanover Trust Co., said the bond market had little reaction to the report since it was little changed from April. In the secondary market for Treasury bonds, prices of short-term governments were up from 5-16 point to | point, intermediate maturities jumped from 23-32 point to 1 5-16 points, and long-term issues climbed as much as 1{ points, according to Telerate Inc., the financial information service. The movement of a point is equivalent to a change of $10 in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face value. The Shearson Lehman Hutton Daily Treasury Bond Index, which measures price movements on all outstanding Treasury issues with maturities of a year or longer, gained 7.89 to 1,160.22. In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds rose to 91 11-16 from 91 12-32 late Thursday. The average yield to maturity dropped to 7.50 percent from 7.53 percent. Yields on three-month Treasury bills fell to 7.94 percent as the discount dropped 6 basis points to 7.69 percent. Yields on six-month bills were down to 8.01 percent as the discount was off 12 basis points to 7.61 percent. Yields on one-year bills issued at auction Thursday were down to 8.04 percent as the discount was down 16 basis points to 7.49 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The yield is the annualized return on an investment in a Treasury bill. The discount is the percentage that bills are selling below the face value, which is paid at maturity. The federal funds rate, the interest rate banks charge each other on overnight loans, was quoted at 8\ percent, unchanged from late Thursday.

The hiring of thousands of temporary census workers helped push the nation's unemployment rate down slightly to 5.3 percent in May, the government said. The civilian jobless rate fell slightly in May from April's 5.4 percent rate, the Labor Department said Friday. But analysts viewed the report as a sign of a sluggish economy because private sector job growth slowed to a near standstill. There were 164,000 new jobs created last month, according to a separate survey of business establishments, but the number was artificially inflated by the federal government's hiring of 145,000 temporary census workers.

Two judges supervising hundreds of asbestos injury lawsuits ordered the Manville Corp. bankruptcy case reopened to overhaul a financially ailing trust fund designed to compensate victims of asbestos-related diseases. In a joint order, a federal judge and a New York state judge on Friday said the Manville Personal Injury Settlement Trust was out of money and suggested the company advance it $200 million to $300 million so it can resume payments to victims. The trust was formed in Manville's 1988 reorganization, six years after it was driven into bankruptcy court by lawsuits over production of asbestos, the insulation and building material found to cause severe and sometimes fatal illnesses.

Construction spending fell 0.7 percent in April for the second consecutive month, the government said. Analysts said the report signalled a weakening building industry. The Commerce Department said Friday that residential, non-residential and government construction spending totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $432.4 billion in April. The revised 0.7 percent March decline was improved from the 1.4 percent drop first reported last month.

A survey of purchasing managers indicated an improvement in manufacturing in May, but economists said the report was overshadowed and contradicted by government unemployment numbers. Gains in production and new orders led the increase reported Friday in the National Association of Purchasing Managment survey, the second in as many months. Economists also said the report probably was influenced by increased automobile production not being matched by sales.

The Soviets cannot go back to a controlled economy and cannot go forward to a successful free-market economy without help from the West, Soviet academicians said. The comments came at a meeting Friday between 10 Soviet academicians and a group of U.S. industry, education and government leaders. The session at the National Academy of Sciences centered on a candid report by the Soviet experts on their nation's efforts to radically change its economy.

International Business Machines Corp. said it has signed its biggest contract yet with the Soviet Union, under which it will supply over 13,000 personal computers for use in schools. The value of the contract was not disclosed Friday. IBM said the Soviets will pay in a convertible currency and that they received a discount comparable to one IBM offers other customers for computers bought for educational use.

The bankruptcy trustee for Eastern Airlines met with the federal prosecutor in Brooklyn in an effort to head off possible criminal charges against the carrier for allegedly falsifying maintenance records, a source said. The trustee, Martin R. Shugrue, met for ``an hour or two'' Friday with Andrew J. Maloney, the U.S. attorney for the Eastern District, said the source, speaking on the condition of anonymity.

Possible rear-seat defects in some Chrysler minivans are being investigated as the result of the death a 2-year-old boy in a crash, a government spokesman said. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration probe, announced Friday, was prompted in part by a coroner's complaint that the seats are unsafe. Chrysler spokesman Tom Jakobowski said the company was cooperating with the investigation.

Argentina is to resume negotiations next week with creditor banks over the possible resumption of interest payments for the first time in two years on its $60 billion foreign debt, local newspapers reported. But creditor banks apparently are seeking more than the Argentine government is offering to pay, the reports Friday said. The daily Clarin said the government is prepared to pay $70 million a month for three months, but creditor banks want a minimum $100 million monthly for the rest of 1990.

Stock prices hit a new high Friday, reaching the 2,900 level in the Dow Jones industrial average for the first time. The Dow average of 30 blue chips rose 24.31 to 2,900.97, stretching its gain for the week to 80.05 points. Bond prices soared on the government's weak job growth report. The dollar gained against the West German mark and Swiss franc and lost ground to the Japanese yen and British pound. Precious metals futures plunged; grain and soybean futures fell; livestock and pork futures were higher, and energy futures were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: LA Gear Stock Plunges
DOC.TEXT: The price of L.A. Gear Inc. stock fell nearly 22 percent Friday after the company said it expected its earnings for the current quarter would be down sharply from a year ago. L.A. Gear stock fell $8.50 per share to close at $30.50 on the New York Stock Exchange _ down nearly 40 percent from its high of $50.37{ on May 24. Most of Friday's decline came after the sneakers and apparel maker said at midafternoon that it expected to report quarterly earnings of 50 to 60 cents per share in the March-May quarter compared with 90 cents per share a year earlier. The forecast surprised many Wall Street analysts. ``The earnings the company indicated were considerably lower than we had indicated,'' said Jay J. Meltzer, a Goldman Sachs analyst in New York. But Meltzer said the earnings report alone could not account for the precipitous stock fall. He had no other explanation for it, however. Dick Broderick, an outside publicist for the company, was in a meeting and could not immediately be reached for comment, his office reported. L.A. Gear's profit more than doubled last year, reaching $55 million. The company's stock had surged last week, in part because the Salomon Brothers brokerage had repeated a buy recommendation. Salomon Brothers analyst Heidi R. Steinberg said she could not account for Friday's fall. L.A. Gear, known for trendy shoes and signing celebrity endorsers like Michael Jackson, Joe Montana and Paula Abdul to multimillion-dollar contracts, was a go-go company for the past two years, with booming sales moving it up into the No. 3 spot behind Nike Inc. and Reebok International Ltd. Many investors made big profits, while others found it ``a stock they loved to hate'' and the share price has whipsawed, said Donald L. Wampach, who follows emerging growth stocks for Hamilton Investments Inc. in Chicago. Wampach noted that ``short sellers'' who bet the stock price will fall had frequently gotten burned on L.A. Gear shares. He said he believes the company is undergoing a difficult change into an established, medium-size outfit, but remains fundamentally strong. The earnings decline is probably attributable to the transition from older shoe models to new Michael Jackson, hiking and back-to-school lines, he said. ``The Street sure didn't anticipate the word on the earnings, though,'' Wampach said.

DOC.HEAD: NBC Criticizes Nielsen Ratings
DOC.TEXT: NBC, joining in the ABC and CBS challenge of the Nielsen ``people-meter'' ratings system, said Friday it is ``seriously concerned'' about the system's value to the industry. The A.C. Nielsen Co. promptly fired back, saying in a statement it had investigated the system's reports of decreasing levels of network viewing and ``we feel it's a real decline.'' The people-meters, the industry ratings standard since the fall of 1987, are viewer-activated devices that record what shows are being watched and which members of a participating family are watching. The networks contend that the people-meter figures under-count the real audience, and that the system, which is in 4,000 homes, is flawed. ABC on Thursday fired the first round against the system, saying it would use its own formula of ratings analysis to determine if it should give ``make-goods'' to advertisers of ABC shows that get ratings lower than ABC had promised. Make-goods are commercial slots given free to businesses when their ads air on shows with less-than-expected ratings. Ads are sold on the basis of the network's prediction of the size and makeup of the audience. NBC, in a statement Friday, said it was troubled by what it called ``the unexplained aberrations in the Nielsen people meter ratings,'' and said it was taking a close look at ABC's plan and other possibilities. However, it also said such steps are ``only interim solutions to the problem'' and called for networks and advertisers alike to work for ``a viable system that would eliminate concerns about accuracy and reliability.'' CBS research vice president David Poltrack, who has been a strong critic of the people-meter methodology, said in an interview that the network ``has not yet reviewed all the options'' it may have in the dispute. It probably will start the review Monday, he said, ``and start looking at the (advertising) industry reactions'' to ABC's plan. He also said he felt that the people-meter system's ``deficiences and instability make it an unreliable tool for television audience measurement.'' ``We feel the people-meter system is not responsible for the (viewing) decline, and it's the buyers of advertising time who ultimately will decide the validity of each network's proposal,'' said Nielsen spokeswoman Jo LaVerde. Several advertising agency executives panned the ABC plan, and came to the defense of the Nielsen rarings system. Steve Sternberg, manager of broadcast research at the ad agency Bozell Inc., said his agency feels the decline in TV audiences evident in the Nielsen ratings are genuine rather than due to faults in the measurement system. The ABC plan to base audience guarantees on a three-year average rather than the upcoming season's actual results ``is a blatant attempt to lock advertisers into historical viewing levels, favorable to ABC _ in the face of deteriorating network viewing,'' Kevin Burns and John Hunt of the ad agency Ogilvy & Mather wrote in a commentary on the ABC plan. They said the audience guarantees were enacted to protect advertisers in return for making a sizeable long-term commitment. ``In effect, the ABC proposal would provide a gurantee for the network rather than the advertiser. Despite the current turmoil in the medium, we don't believe it is the advertisers' responsibility to guarantee the networks a profit,'' they wrote. Richard Kostyra, media services director at the J. Walter Thompson ad agency, said the ABC plan could ``move a lot of money into Fox'' which has said it would give the normal guarantees on sales on its network. He said it would also encourage advertisers to spend more to advertise on cable television, syndicated shows and alternative media outlets such as those aimed at reaching women in doctor's offices or beauty parlors and shoppers in the supermarket checkout lines. Paul Schulman, who heads an ad buying service that carries his name, said the guarantees are only one of the items to be negotiated on buying ad time. ``This isn't the key to the whole negotiations. We have to see what kind of price increasaes they are seeking,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Affiliated Publications Acquires 80 Percent of ASM Communications
DOC.TEXT: Affiliated Publications Inc., the parent company of The Boston Globe's publishing company, has agreed to acquire 80 percent of the outstanding common stock of ASM Communications Inc., which publishes periodicals on the advertising and marketing industry. Terms of the agreement were not disclosed by either party. ASM Communications Inc., founded in 1978, publishes Adweek, Adweek's Marketing Week, and Photo District News. Other properties include Marketing Computers, Adbank, Marketer's Guide to Media. Adweek is a national network of seven weekly magazines covering marketing and communications industries, with a total circulation of 83,000. All the ASM properties will become part of Affiliated's specialty publishing and information subsidiary, BPI Communications Inc. Under the terms of the agreement, Kenneth L. Fadner will continue to serve as president of ASM and will retain a substantial equity interest in the company. Also continuing in management roles will be John C. Thomas Jr., ASM chairman, and W. Pendleton Tudor, executive committee chairman. BPI now published 15 specialty magazines, 29 annual directories, publishes and distributes specialty books under five imprints and operates two book clubs. Affiliated Publications Inc. is also the parent company of Globe Newspaper Co. publisher of The Boston Globe.
